setting"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/school-based-intimate-partner-violence-prevention-programs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County youth with teen dating violence education that addresses healthy relationships, gender norms, relationship coercion, and violence in a school setting"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Crime \u0026 delinquency"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/school-based-intimate-partner-violence-prevention-programs","pid":1572,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-01-30","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that school-based programs to prevent youth intimate partner violence (IPV) increase knowledge about, and improve attitudes toward, teen dating violence ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}) and avert dating violence ({De Koker 2014}, {Whitaker 2006}). However, effects vary by program; additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and identify the most successful interventions to reduce dating violence ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}, {O\u2019Leary 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, participants in school-based IPV prevention interventions for middle and high school students demonstrate increases in knowledge about healthy behaviors in couple relationships and greater awareness of appropriate approaches to conflict solution than non-participants ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}, {Campbell-Fellmeth 2013}). Participating students also report less acceptance of dating violence than non-participating peers ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Fourth R program ({CBPP-Fourth R}), Safe Dates ({YG-Program search}, {Whitaker 2006}), and Shifting Boundaries are three school-based youth IPV programs that have been shown to decrease dating violence perpetration and victimization among adolescents ({De Koker 2014}). Fourth R substantially reduces violent delinquency among youth with a history of child maltreatment and also increases participating adolescents\u2019 condom use ({CBPP-Fourth R}). The Start Strong program, designed for middle school students, decreases gender stereotypes and acceptance of teen dating violence among participants two years after the intervention ({Miller 2015}). Overall, programs with longer durations and comprehensive approaches are more effective than shorter programs and programs without comprehensive approaches ({De Koker 2014}, {Whitaker 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYouth IPV prevention programs may increase teen mothers\u2019 awareness of gender stereotypes and community resources for teen dating violence ({Herrman 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that school-based programs to prevent youth intimate partner violence (IPV) increase knowledge about, and improve attitudes toward, teen dating violence ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}) and avert dating violence ({De Koker 2014}, {Whitaker 2006}). However, effects vary by program; additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and identify the most successful interventions to reduce dating violence ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}, {O\u2019Leary 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, participants in school-based IPV prevention interventions for middle and high school students demonstrate increases in knowledge about healthy behaviors in couple relationships and greater awareness of appropriate approaches to conflict solution than non-participants ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}, {Campbell-Fellmeth 2013}). Participating students also report less acceptance of dating violence than non-participating peers ({Campbell-De La Rue 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Fourth R program ({CBPP-Fourth R}), Safe Dates ({YG-Program search}, {Whitaker 2006}), and Shifting Boundaries are three school-based youth IPV programs that have been shown to decrease dating violence perpetration and victimization among adolescents ({De Koker 2014}). Fourth R substantially reduces violent delinquency among youth with a history of child maltreatment and also increases participating adolescents\u2019 condom use ({CBPP-Fourth R}). The Start Strong program, designed for middle school students, decreases gender stereotypes and acceptance of teen dating violence among participants two years after the intervention ({Miller 2015}). Overall, programs with longer durations and comprehensive approaches are more effective than shorter programs and programs without comprehensive approaches ({De Koker 2014}, {Whitaker 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYouth IPV prevention programs may increase teen mothers\u2019 awareness of gender stereotypes and community resources for teen dating violence ({Herrman 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ESafe Dates and the Fourth R are two examples of school-based intimate partner prevention programs with curriculum available online ({Safe Dates}, {CPS-Fourth R}). Safe Dates training is offered in several states ({Safe Dates}) and the Start Strong program is implemented in 11 U.S. cities ({Start Strong}). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\u2019s (CDC)\u2019s Dating Matters, a middle school and community-based prevention initiative, has been implemented in four pilot sites (Baltimore, Chicago, Ft. Lauderdale, and Oakland, CA) ({CDC-Dating Matters}). Coaching Boys into Men ({CBIM}) is another example of a youth IPV\u0026nbsp;prevention initiative.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ESafe Dates and the Fourth R are two examples of school-based intimate partner prevention programs with curriculum available online ({Safe Dates}, {CPS-Fourth R}). Safe Dates training is offered in several states ({Safe Dates}) and the Start Strong program is implemented in 11 U.S. cities ({Start Strong}). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\u2019s (CDC)\u2019s Dating Matters, a middle school and community-based prevention initiative, has been implemented in four pilot sites (Baltimore, Chicago, Ft. Lauderdale, and Oakland, CA) ({CDC-Dating Matters}). Coaching Boys into Men ({CBIM}) is another example of a youth IPV\u0026nbsp;prevention initiative.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":1,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced delinquent behavior","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced delinquent behavior\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased condom use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased condom use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased knowledge of intimate partner violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased knowledge of intimate partner violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced intimate partner violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced intimate partner violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CPS-Fourth R","Safe Dates","CDC-Teen dating violence"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Crime \u0026 delinquency","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CPS-Fourth R\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221968\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CPS-Fourth R\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Center for Addiction and Mental Health Centre for Prevention Science (CAMH-CPS). setting\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"ce15b851-48a1-4c70-ab86-7cde0c7de259","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3621}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_curated_lis ub.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"e98aa2b5-06a0-448e-9aed-f8647b276599","meta":{"target_revision_id":11294,"drupal_internal__target_id":6286}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"db29cd12-ba50-4afe-9c7a-a8815b72cd46","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":34}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ca8c87e8-ad24-461f-9429-a93bf91f6fe4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":45}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"e076998a-491c-45ee-bc55-43ea4b0b8d03","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":55}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"01c2a90f-f836-44ed-a16a-613ab4674834","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3559}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e0b73411-3f66-4269-8be2-6c91c34fe8e1","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1549}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4df0f95d-4679-4ad4-8792-39eb8315a4cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1548}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c4c459a6-32a5-4a23-9862-bf529774c929","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1546}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"c152e1db-4436-4531-b330-b5f4cb021b3f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3994}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"a40c9179-92f6-4531-9d6a-db5e60b8dfa0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3954}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/cc154000-d755-45fc-bfe9-76d7668653ad\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1337"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"aab6f7f6-a045-4b4e-a2c3-327c66cf77c4","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/aab6f7f6-a045-4b4e-a2c3-327c66cf77c4?resourceVersion=id%3A1339"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1339,"drupal_internal__vid":1339,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Mentoring programs to prevent youth delinquency","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:19+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Mentoring programs to prevent youth delinquency | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Pair youth at risk for delinquent behavior with mentors to develop relationships and spend time at regular meetings for an extended period; mentors have greater knowledge, skills, etc. than mentees"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-programs-to-prevent-youth-delinquency"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Pair youth at risk for delinquent behavior with mentors to develop relationships and spend time at regular meetings for an extended period; mentors have greater knowledge, skills, etc. than mentees"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Crime \u0026 delinquency,Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-programs-to-prevent-youth-delinquency","pid":1574,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-12-13","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is at risk for delinquency in your community? Which youth populations are most affected? How many youth express mentoring needs but do not have services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can you enhance coordination between mentoring programs, schools, and juvenile justice settings to address unmet needs for mentoring among youth at risk?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can state and local mentoring-related policies be expanded to advance high-quality, long-term mentoring programs serving more youth from disadvantaged backgrounds?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is at risk for delinquency in your community? Which youth populations are most affected? How many youth express mentoring needs but do not have services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can you enhance coordination between mentoring programs, schools, and juvenile justice settings to address unmet needs for mentoring among youth at risk?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can state and local mentoring-related policies be expanded to advance high-quality, long-term mentoring programs serving more youth from disadvantaged backgrounds?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that mentoring programs for youth at risk have the potential to reduce disparities in delinquent behavior among youth. Youth facing environmental risk factors such as low family income benefit more from mentoring than youth with no risk factors or only individual risk factors such as academic challenges ({DuBois 2002}, {DuBois 2011}). Youth identifying as racial or ethnic minorities are at a higher risk for delinquency because they are more likely to experience adversity related to concentrated poverty, neighborhood violence, unemployment, social marginalization, and discrimination ({Case 2017}). Mentoring programs appear to have greater impacts for male youth, youth of color, and younger youth; male youth are more likely to engage in delinquent behavior and crime than female youth ({NMRC-Erdem 2020}). Participation in the Arches Transformative Mentoring program, group mentoring as part of efforts to reduce racial inequities in the justice system for young men of color (ages 16-24) in New York City, has been shown to reduce reconvictions ({Urban-Lynch 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParental incarceration is an adverse childhood experience that leads to a higher risk of poor child development through negative consequences related to family instability, stress, and stigmatization; children of parents involved in the justice system are more likely to display external behavior problems than their peers whose parents are not in the justice system ({Stelter 2023}, {Stump 2018}). Youth in foster care experience less secure and often negative, abusive relationships with adults as well as frequent placement moves that affect youth mental and behavioral health ({Stelter 2018}). Mentoring relationships may support youth experiencing parental incarceration and youth in foster care ({Stelter 2023}, {Stelter 2018}); however, mentees in foster care are more likely to close mentoring relationships prematurely than mentees not in foster care ({Stelter 2018}). A 2014 national survey estimates nine million youth at risk (ages 8-18) never had a mentor though their mentoring needs are high. To close this mentoring gap, researchers recommend expanding federal and state policies that advance quality mentoring and supporting private sector engagement in mentoring ({Bruce 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that mentoring programs for youth at risk have the potential to reduce disparities in delinquent behavior among youth. Youth facing environmental risk factors such as low family income benefit more from mentoring than youth with no risk factors or only individual risk factors such as academic challenges ({DuBois 2002}, {DuBois 2011}). Youth identifying as racial or ethnic minorities are at a higher risk for delinquency because they are more likely to experience adversity related to concentrated poverty, neighborhood violence, unemployment, social marginalization, and discrimination ({Case 2017}). Mentoring programs appear to have greater impacts for male youth, youth of color, and younger youth; male youth are more likely to engage in delinquent behavior and crime than female youth ({NMRC-Erdem 2020}). Participation in the Arches Transformative Mentoring program, group mentoring as part of efforts to reduce racial inequities in the justice system for young men of color (ages 16-24) in New York City, has been shown to reduce reconvictions ({Urban-Lynch 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParental incarceration is an adverse childhood experience that leads to a higher risk of poor child development through negative consequences related to family instability, stress, and stigmatization; children of parents involved in the justice system are more likely to display external behavior problems than their peers whose parents are not in the justice system ({Stelter 2023}, {Stump 2018}). Youth in foster care experience less secure and often negative, abusive relationships with adults as well as frequent placement moves that affect youth mental and behavioral health ({Stelter 2018}). Mentoring relationships may support youth experiencing parental incarceration and youth in foster care ({Stelter 2023}, {Stelter 2018}); however, mentees in foster care are more likely to close mentoring relationships prematurely than mentees not in foster care ({Stelter 2018}). A 2014 national survey estimates nine million youth at risk (ages 8-18) never had a mentor though their mentoring needs are high. To close this mentoring gap, researchers recommend expanding federal and state policies that advance quality mentoring and supporting private sector engagement in mentoring ({Bruce 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe modern development of mentoring for youth at risk stemmed from the establishment of Big Brothers Big Sisters (BBBS, formerly Big Brothers) and a few other organizations in the early 1900s when more states adopted juvenile courts ({EY MENTOR 2019}). In response to the increased number of youth in the New York City court, the BBBS movement started in 1904 with the idea that caring adults could help prevent youth delinquent behavior ({BBBS History}). The first U.S. juvenile court in Cook County, Chicago also assigned probation officers to provide guidance and support to youth detained in the court ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Mentoring is an attractive way to prevent youth delinquent behavior given its low cost and ability to use local resources and adult volunteers ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAdolescents exposed to adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) in early childhood (ages 5-7) are more likely to display delinquent behavior because ACEs increase trauma and stress, and influence an early start of childhood misconduct ({Jackson 2023a}). Individuals with lower incomes, less education, and those who are LGBTQ+, multiracial, Black, or Hispanic are more likely to be exposed to ACEs than individuals with higher incomes, more education, and those who are cisgender, heterosexual, or white ({Giano 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe modern development of mentoring for youth at risk stemmed from the establishment of Big Brothers Big Sisters (BBBS, formerly Big Brothers) and a few other organizations in the early 1900s when more states adopted juvenile courts ({EY MENTOR 2019}). In response to the increased number of youth in the New York City court, the BBBS movement started in 1904 with the idea that caring adults could help prevent youth delinquent behavior ({BBBS History}). The first U.S. juvenile court in Cook County, Chicago also assigned probation officers to provide guidance and support to youth detained in the court ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Mentoring is an attractive way to prevent youth delinquent behavior given its low cost and ability to use local resources and adult volunteers ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAdolescents exposed to adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) in early childhood (ages 5-7) are more likely to display delinquent behavior because ACEs increase trauma and stress, and influence an early start of childhood misconduct ({Jackson 2023a}). Individuals with lower incomes, less education, and those who are LGBTQ+, multiracial, Black, or Hispanic are more likely to be exposed to ACEs than individuals with higher incomes, more education, and those who are cisgender, heterosexual, or white ({Giano 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mentoring programs reduce delinquent behavior ({Raposa 2019}, {Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {NMRC-Hawkins 2020}) and aggression ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}) among youth at risk in the short-term. Such programs may prevent youth from being involved in the juvenile justice system ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Effects can vary significantly depending on program characteristics and implementation quality; programs that make emotional support or mentee advocacy a key component appear to have greater effects than programs that emphasize modeling or teaching ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {DuBois 2021}). Programs that focus on behavior problems, provide pre-match training for mentors, are long-term and school-based also have greater effects ({Raposa 2019}). More research is needed to confirm long-term effects, especially during adulthood ({DuBois 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may reduce alcohol use and drug use, including marijuana, among youth at risk in some cases ({NMRC-Erdem 2020}, {Raposa 2019}, {Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {Matz 2014}, {Thomas 2013}). Youth mentees in community-based Big Brothers and Big Sisters mentoring programs reported reductions in substance use and arrest 18 months after participation ({DuBois 2022}). Elementary school students at risk participating in a four-year long community-based mentoring program that began in kindergarten or first grade show reduced problem behavior and improved positive behavior in school ({Eddy 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may reduce recidivism for youth who display initial delinquent behaviors or are already involved with the juvenile justice system in some circumstances ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Advocacy-based mentoring programs and group mentoring for youth involved in the juvenile justice system have been shown to reduce re-arrests, re-convictions, and misconduct ({Karcher 2016}, {Urban-Cramer 2018}, {Urban-Lynch 2018}). One Ohio-based study indicates that mentoring programs had no impact on recidivism for youth on probation or parole; however, a majority of those participants did not complete their mentoring programs ({Duriez 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEnhanced community-based mentoring that provides additional structured activities based on special curriculum for youth from disadvantaged backgrounds may be more effective in reducing delinquent behavior among male mentees compared to standard community-based mentoring. For female mentees, the impact is not different ({Brezina 2016}). Enhanced mentoring (i.e., providing pre- and post-match mentor training, mentoring activities, monitoring and coaching, and setting specific goals) is more effective than standard mentoring to reduce substance use and behavior problems, build longer and stronger mentor-mentee relationships, and address the needs of mentees, especially for children of parents in the criminal justice system ({Stelter 2023}, {Stump 2018}). Youth entering school-based mentoring programs with adequate relationships with their parents may benefit more than those with very strong or very poor parental relationships ({Schwartz 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDC researchers recommend that programs set program-wide goals while mentors and mentees set individual session goals. In choosing mentors, programs should clearly define qualifications, and consider mentors\u2019 commitment, abilities, and life circumstances ({CDC-Thornton 2002}). Mentors\u2019 race or socio-economic status may not affect outcomes ({Gaddis 2012}); frequent interaction ({Miller 2012}), long durations in a mentor-mentee relationship, and high levels of trust and emotional bond with a mentor have been associated with stronger academic and behavioral outcomes ({Gaddis 2012}, {DuBois 2021}). Researchers recommend mentor training and support, and implementation with high fidelity for program effectiveness ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Mentor training that teaches positive coping strategies (e.g., emotional regulation, conflict resolution, future orientation, and active listening) can help mentors build supportive relationships with youth at risk ({Wesely 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mentoring programs reduce delinquent behavior ({Raposa 2019}, {Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {NMRC-Hawkins 2020}) and aggression ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}) among youth at risk in the short-term. Such programs may prevent youth from being involved in the juvenile justice system ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Effects can vary significantly depending on program characteristics and implementation quality; programs that make emotional support or mentee advocacy a key component appear to have greater effects than programs that emphasize modeling or teaching ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {DuBois 2021}). Programs that focus on behavior problems, provide pre-match training for mentors, are long-term and school-based also have greater effects ({Raposa 2019}). More research is needed to confirm long-term effects, especially during adulthood ({DuBois 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may reduce alcohol use and drug use, including marijuana, among youth at risk in some cases ({NMRC-Erdem 2020}, {Raposa 2019}, {Campbell-Tolan 2013}, {Matz 2014}, {Thomas 2013}). Youth mentees in community-based Big Brothers and Big Sisters mentoring programs reported reductions in substance use and arrest 18 months after participation ({DuBois 2022}). Elementary school students at risk participating in a four-year long community-based mentoring program that began in kindergarten or first grade show reduced problem behavior and improved positive behavior in school ({Eddy 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may reduce recidivism for youth who display initial delinquent behaviors or are already involved with the juvenile justice system in some circumstances ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Advocacy-based mentoring programs and group mentoring for youth involved in the juvenile justice system have been shown to reduce re-arrests, re-convictions, and misconduct ({Karcher 2016}, {Urban-Cramer 2018}, {Urban-Lynch 2018}). One Ohio-based study indicates that mentoring programs had no impact on recidivism for youth on probation or parole; however, a majority of those participants did not complete their mentoring programs ({Duriez 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEnhanced community-based mentoring that provides additional structured activities based on special curriculum for youth from disadvantaged backgrounds may be more effective in reducing delinquent behavior among male mentees compared to standard community-based mentoring. For female mentees, the impact is not different ({Brezina 2016}). Enhanced mentoring (i.e., providing pre- and post-match mentor training, mentoring activities, monitoring and coaching, and setting specific goals) is more effective than standard mentoring to reduce substance use and behavior problems, build longer and stronger mentor-mentee relationships, and address the needs of mentees, especially for children of parents in the criminal justice system ({Stelter 2023}, {Stump 2018}). Youth entering school-based mentoring programs with adequate relationships with their parents may benefit more than those with very strong or very poor parental relationships ({Schwartz 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDC researchers recommend that programs set program-wide goals while mentors and mentees set individual session goals. In choosing mentors, programs should clearly define qualifications, and consider mentors\u2019 commitment, abilities, and life circumstances ({CDC-Thornton 2002}). Mentors\u2019 race or socio-economic status may not affect outcomes ({Gaddis 2012}); frequent interaction ({Miller 2012}), long durations in a mentor-mentee relationship, and high levels of trust and emotional bond with a mentor have been associated with stronger academic and behavioral outcomes ({Gaddis 2012}, {DuBois 2021}). Researchers recommend mentor training and support, and implementation with high fidelity for program effectiveness ({NMRC-Hawkins 2020}). Mentor training that teaches positive coping strategies (e.g., emotional regulation, conflict resolution, future orientation, and active listening) can help mentors build supportive relationships with youth at risk ({Wesely 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMentoring is one of the most commonly used interventions to prevent and reduce delinquent behavior ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}). Examples of mentoring programs include Big Brothers Big Sisters of America ({BBBS}), Friends for Youth 1 to 1 Mentoring ({FFY Mentoring}), Achievement Mentoring ({CSS-AM}), and Fostering Healthy Futures for children and adolescents involved in the child welfare system ({FHF}). There are mentoring program guidelines and resources for immigrant and refugee youth ({NMRC-Immigrant}), tribal youth ({TYRC-Tribal mentoring}), and LGBTQ+ youth ({MENTOR-LGBTQ}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMENTOR is another non-profit organization that works with many partners around the country to support over 5,000 mentoring programs ({MENTOR}). MENTOR and its network of affiliates also support National Mentoring Month, to increase awareness about the impacts mentors can have on youth and encourage civic leaders and stakeholders to prioritize and invest in mentoring programs and opportunities ({MENTOR-Mentoring month}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMentoring is one of the most commonly used interventions to prevent and reduce delinquent behavior ({Campbell-Tolan 2013}). Examples of mentoring programs include Big Brothers Big Sisters of America ({BBBS}), Friends for Youth 1 to 1 Mentoring ({FFY Mentoring}), Achievement Mentoring ({CSS-AM}), and Fostering Healthy Futures for children and adolescents involved in the child welfare system ({FHF}). There are mentoring program guidelines and resources for immigrant and refugee youth ({NMRC-Immigrant}), tribal youth ({TYRC-Tribal mentoring}), and LGBTQ+ youth ({MENTOR-LGBTQ}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMENTOR is another non-profit organization that works with many partners around the country to support over 5,000 mentoring programs ({MENTOR}). MENTOR and its network of affiliates also support National Mentoring Month, to increase awareness about the impacts mentors can have on youth and encourage civic leaders and stakeholders to prioritize and invest in mentoring programs and opportunities ({MENTOR-Mentoring month}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":5,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced drug use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced drug use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced recidivism","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced recidivism\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced delinquent behavior","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced delinquent behavior\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced aggression","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced aggression\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["MENTOR","MENTOR 2016","MENTOR-LGBTQ","TYRC-Tribal mentoring","NMRC-Immigrant","OJJDP-Mentoring","CDC-Thornton 2002"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Crime \u0026 delinquency,Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022MENTOR\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221714\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022MENTOR\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022MENTOR. your community, which youth involved in the justice system have access to Multisystemic Therapy (MST) services? Who cannot access MST services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can correctional officers, MST providers, educators, family members, peer mentors, and others work together to support youth involved in the justice system that are receiving MST?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat other societal and community-level factors impact youth involved in the justice system within your community? For example, do they experience poverty, racial profiling, discrimination, or barriers to accessing support services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIn your community, which youth involved in the justice system have access to Multisystemic Therapy (MST) services? Who cannot access MST services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can correctional officers, MST providers, educators, family members, peer mentors, and others work together to support youth involved in the justice system that are receiving MST?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat other societal and community-level factors impact youth involved in the justice system within your community? For example, do they experience poverty, racial profiling, discrimination, or barriers to accessing support services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact Multisystemic Therapy (MST) may have on disparities among youth involved in the justice system. Disparities exist within the justice system and in both access to mental health services and the quality of mental health care available ({Satodiya 2024}). Adolescents from racially minoritized groups experience higher rates of mental health conditions, yet they are less likely to use mental health services ({Hoffman 2022}). Additionally, while total youth incarceration rates have declined over the past ten years, youth of color are significantly more likely to be incarcerated than white youth ({Sentencing Project 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts recommend adapting MST to reflect the client\u2019s cultural background ({Sayegh 2019}, {Brown 2024}) and suggest that effective therapists may have relevant cultural knowledge in order to adapt MST for clients ({Bunting 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact Multisystemic Therapy (MST) may have on disparities among youth involved in the justice system. Disparities exist within the justice system and in both access to mental health services and the quality of mental health care available ({Satodiya 2024}). Adolescents from racially minoritized groups experience higher rates of mental health conditions, yet they are less likely to use mental health services ({Hoffman 2022}). Additionally, while total youth incarceration rates have declined over the past ten years, youth of color are significantly more likely to be incarcerated than white youth ({Sentencing Project 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts recommend adapting MST to reflect the client\u2019s cultural background ({Sayegh 2019}, {Brown 2024}) and suggest that effective therapists may have relevant cultural knowledge in order to adapt MST for clients ({Bunting 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EYouth of color have been disproportionately overrepresented throughout the history of the juvenile justice system in the U.S. and racially disparate practices and treatment for youth in the system persist to this day. These disparities can be attributed to the nation\u2019s history of racial segregation and discrimination, the false belief that youth of color are culturally inclined to delinquency, and the systemic and racialized policies and practices within the juvenile justice system. Examples of these policies and practices include discriminatory policing in communities of color along with differential treatment of youth of color throughout the juvenile court process, where decision makers lack appropriate assessment tools, training, program options for youth, and cultural competence ({NCTSN-Lacey 2013}). Black, Native, and Hispanic youth have and continue to be arrested and involved in the juvenile justice system at disproportionate rates, compared to white youth ({OJJDP-R\/ED 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, which was reauthorized in 2018, provides federal standards for the care and custody of youth and families involved in the juvenile justice system ({CJJ-JJDPA}). One of its four requirements helps states assess and eliminate racial and ethnic disparities within the juvenile justice system ({CJJ-JJDPA}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EYouth of color have been disproportionately overrepresented throughout the history of the juvenile justice system in the U.S. and racially disparate practices and treatment for youth in the system persist to this day. These disparities can be attributed to the nation\u2019s history of racial segregation and discrimination, the false belief that youth of color are culturally inclined to delinquency, and the systemic and racialized policies and practices within the juvenile justice system. Examples of these policies and practices include discriminatory policing in communities of color along with differential treatment of youth of color throughout the juvenile court process, where decision makers lack appropriate assessment tools, training, program options for youth, and cultural competence ({NCTSN-Lacey 2013}). Black, Native, and Hispanic youth have and continue to be arrested and involved in the juvenile justice system at disproportionate rates, compared to white youth ({OJJDP-R\/ED 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, which was reauthorized in 2018, provides federal standards for the care and custody of youth and families involved in the juvenile justice system ({CJJ-JJDPA}). One of its four requirements helps states assess and eliminate racial and ethnic disparities within the juvenile justice system ({CJJ-JJDPA}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that Multisystemic Therapy (MST) reduces the likelihood of recidivism and incarceration for adolescents who have committed serious offenses more than treatment as usual ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {Tan 2017}, {Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {RAND-Fain 2014}, {Blueprints}). MST can also reduce delinquent or antisocial behavior and alcohol and drug use among youth who have offended ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Blueprints}, {Baldwin 2012}). MST also reduces out-of-home placements in foster care ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Vidal 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMST can improve participating youths\u2019 functioning at school, work, and home ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}), and increase positive peer relationships ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}). MST may also improve family functioning and reduce self-reported delinquency ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Blueprints}). MST can decrease delinquent behavior, sexual behavior problems, incarceration, and residential treatment for youth charged with sexual offenses ({Satodiya 2024}, {CEBC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMST may reduce arrest and incarceration, and increase probation completion among Hispanic youth that have offenses ({RAND-Fain 2014}). MST appears to be effective for youth involved with gangs ({Boxer 2017}). A small study suggests that MST may be effective for youth with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who display disruptive behaviors ({Wagner 2019}). A 25-year follow-up evaluation of MST for those with problematic sexual behaviors found fewer offenses, days of incarceration, and family-related civil suits among MST participants, compared to youth that received usual community services ({Borduin 2021}). Arrest rates and days of incarceration are also lower for siblings and caregivers of MST participants 20 years after treatment ({Wagner 2014}, {Johnides 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EReductions in delinquency are greater for youth that committed serious offenses than for non-justice-involved youth with conduct disorder ({Satodiya 2024}, {Tan 2017}, {Markham 2018}, {McCart 2016}). Effects are also stronger when the program is implemented with high treatment fidelity ({Goense 2016}). A Hawaii-based study indicates that MST that focuses on a limited number of concerns may be associated with better therapeutic outcomes, compared to MST that addresses multiple co-occurring concerns, such as multiple diagnoses, life stressors, disruptive life events, and barriers to the therapeutic process, at the same time ({Holmes 2022}, {Holmes 2023a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA version of MST for families of abused and neglected children has been shown to improve children\u2019s and caregivers\u2019 mental health and reduce the likelihood that caregivers will neglect or assault their children ({Swenson 2010}, {Pane 2013}). A Netherlands-based adaptation of MST for youth with intellectual disabilities can improve parenting skills, family relationships, and lead to sustained positive behavior changes ({Blankestein 2019}). MST for youth with mental illnesses may reduce poor behavior, suicide attempts, and out-of-home placements, and improve family functioning ({Pane 2013}). Adaptations of MST have also been linked to better metabolic control and reduced hospital admissions for youth with poorly controlled diabetes, weight loss for youth that are overweight ({Pane 2013}), and reduced viral load for youth taking HIV retroviral medications ({Letourneau 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers suggest that MST for youth who have offended is cost-effective compared to treatment as usual ({Goorden 2016}, {Dopp 2018}). A Washington-based analysis estimates that MST cost $9,486 per adolescent in 2022, with an average benefit of $3.01 for every dollar invested ({WSIPP-MST 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that Multisystemic Therapy (MST) reduces the likelihood of recidivism and incarceration for adolescents who have committed serious offenses more than treatment as usual ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {Tan 2017}, {Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {RAND-Fain 2014}, {Blueprints}). MST can also reduce delinquent or antisocial behavior and alcohol and drug use among youth who have offended ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Blueprints}, {Baldwin 2012}). MST also reduces out-of-home placements in foster care ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Vidal 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMST can improve participating youths\u2019 functioning at school, work, and home ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}), and increase positive peer relationships ({Markham 2018}, {van der Stouwe 2014}). MST may also improve family functioning and reduce self-reported delinquency ({Campbell-Littell 2021}, {van der Stouwe 2014}, {Zajac 2015}, {Blueprints}). MST can decrease delinquent behavior, sexual behavior problems, incarceration, and residential treatment for youth charged with sexual offenses ({Satodiya 2024}, {CEBC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMST may reduce arrest and incarceration, and increase probation completion among Hispanic youth that have offenses ({RAND-Fain 2014}). MST appears to be effective for youth involved with gangs ({Boxer 2017}). A small study suggests that MST may be effective for youth with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who display disruptive behaviors ({Wagner 2019}). A 25-year follow-up evaluation of MST for those with problematic sexual behaviors found fewer offenses, days of incarceration, and family-related civil suits among MST participants, compared to youth that received usual community services ({Borduin 2021}). Arrest rates and days of incarceration are also lower for siblings and caregivers of MST participants 20 years after treatment ({Wagner 2014}, {Johnides 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EReductions in delinquency are greater for youth that committed serious offenses than for non-justice-involved youth with conduct disorder ({Satodiya 2024}, {Tan 2017}, {Markham 2018}, {McCart 2016}). Effects are also stronger when the program is implemented with high treatment fidelity ({Goense 2016}). A Hawaii-based study indicates that MST that focuses on a limited number of concerns may be associated with better therapeutic outcomes, compared to MST that addresses multiple co-occurring concerns, such as multiple diagnoses, life stressors, disruptive life events, and barriers to the therapeutic process, at the same time ({Holmes 2022}, {Holmes 2023a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA version of MST for families of abused and neglected children has been shown to improve children\u2019s and caregivers\u2019 mental health and reduce the likelihood that caregivers will neglect or assault their children ({Swenson 2010}, {Pane 2013}). A Netherlands-based adaptation of MST for youth with intellectual disabilities can improve parenting skills, family relationships, and lead to sustained positive behavior changes ({Blankestein 2019}). MST for youth with mental illnesses may reduce poor behavior, suicide attempts, and out-of-home placements, and improve family functioning ({Pane 2013}). Adaptations of MST have also been linked to better metabolic control and reduced hospital admissions for youth with poorly controlled diabetes, weight loss for youth that are overweight ({Pane 2013}), and reduced viral load for youth taking HIV retroviral medications ({Letourneau 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers suggest that MST for youth who have offended is cost-effective compared to treatment as usual ({Goorden 2016}, {Dopp 2018}). A Washington-based analysis estimates that MST cost $9,486 per adolescent in 2022, with an average benefit of $3.01 for every dollar invested ({WSIPP-MST 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThirty-four states have licensed Multisystemic Therapy (MST) providers. Some states, for example Maine, Nebraska, and New Mexico, fund MST programs through Medicaid state plans ({MST}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThirty-four states have licensed Multisystemic Therapy (MST) providers. Some states, for example Maine, Nebraska, and New Mexico, fund MST programs through Medicaid state plans ({MST}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":6,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced delinquent behavior","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced delinquent behavior\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced substance abuse","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced substance abuse\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved family functioning","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved family functioning\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced suicide","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced suicide\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced sexual violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced sexual violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced recidivism","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced recidivism\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced incarceration","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced incarceration\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced foster care use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced foster care use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["MST"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Crime \u0026 delinquency","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Home","field_program_sources":"{\u0022MST\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221873\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022MST\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Multisystemic Therapy (MST). (2024). A systematic review of multisystemic therapy in adolescent sex offenders. \u003Cem\u003EThe Journal of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law\u003C\\\/em\u003E, \u003Cem\u003E52\u003C\\\/em\u003E(1), 51\u0026ndash;60.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/jaapl.org\\\/content\\\/52\\\/1\\\/51.long\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-11-26\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022CEBC\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221072\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CEBC\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022California Evidence-Based Clearinghouse for Child Welfare (CEBC). Information and resources for child welfare professionals: List of programs.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.cebc4cw.org\\\/search\\\/by-program-name\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-10-22\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Boxer 2017\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228245\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Boxer 2017\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Boxer P, Docherty M, Ostermann M, Kubik J, Veysey B. Effectiveness of multisystemic therapy for gang-involved youth offenders: One year follow-up analysis of recidivism outcomes. Children and Youth Services Review. 2017;73:107-112.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.sciencedirect.com\\\/science\\\/article\\\/pii\\\/S0190740916305345\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-08-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Wagner 2019\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215258\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Wagner 2019\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Wagner, D. Multisystemic therapy for disruptive behavior problems in youths with autism spectrum disorder: Results from a small randomized clinical trial. \u003Cem\u003EEvidence-Based Practice in Child and Adolescent Mental Health\u003C\\\/em\u003E, \u003Cem\u003E4\u003C\\\/em\u003E(1), 42\u0026ndash;54.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1080\\\/23794925.2018.1560237\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-11-26\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Borduin 2021\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215257\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Borduin 2021\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Borduin, C. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2014;82(3):492-499.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pubmed\\\/24417600\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-08-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Johnides 2017\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228249\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Johnides 2017\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Johnides BD, Borduin CM, Wagner DV, Dopp AR. Effects of multisystemic therapy on caregivers of serious juvenile offenders: A 20-year follow-up to a randomized clinical trial. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2017;85(4):323-334.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/m\\\/pubmed\\\/28333534\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-08-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022McCart 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228241\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022McCart 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022McCart MR, Sheidow AJ. Evidence-based psychosocial treatments for adolescents with disruptive behavior. c4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3993}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/ac92d738-1149-4f92-82f1-7cbe183c37c7\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1340"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/ac92d738-1149-4f92-82f1-7cbe183c37c7\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1340"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"a40c9179-92f6-4531-9d6a-db5e60b8dfa0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3954}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/ac92d738-1149-4f92-82f1-7cbe183c37c7\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1340"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/ac92d738-1149-4f92-82f1-7cbe183c37c7\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1340"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1341,"drupal_internal__vid":1341,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Treatment Foster Care Oregon","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:19+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Treatment Foster Care Oregon | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Place severely and chronically delinquent youth in foster families that are trained in structured behavior management and connected to TFCO program staff; formerly called Multidimensional Treatment Foster Care"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/treatment-foster-care-oregon"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Place severely and chronically delinquent youth in foster families that are trained in structured behavior management and connected to TFCO program staff; formerly called Multidimensional Treatment Foster Care"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Home"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Crime \u0026 delinquency"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/treatment-foster-care-oregon","pid":1576,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2016-09-06","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that Treatment Foster Care Oregon (TFCO) reduces participating youths\u2019 recidivism ({SPTW}, {Osei 2016}) and delinquency ({OJJDP Model Programs}, {Blueprints}, {Turner 2011}) compared to peers in group homes. TFCO has also been shown to reduce violent crime ({Blueprints}, {CG-Violence}, {OJJDP Model Programs}), days of incarceration ({SPTW}, {Osei 2016}), and drug use ({Blueprints}, {Leve 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFor girls, TFCO has been shown to reduce teen pregnancy and increase school attendance and homework completion ({SPTW}, {Rhoades 2013}). Juvenile female offenders in TFCO experience greater decreases in psychological problems, depression, and suicidal ideation than girls in group care homes ({Poulton 2014}, {Harold 2013}, {Kerr 2014}). TFCO for preschoolers (TFCO-P) can increase the likelihood of successful, permanent placement for participants and decrease their problem behaviors ({CEBC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA Washington-based analysis estimates that TFCO cost about $8,300 per juvenile offender in 2016, with a benefit to cost ratio of $1.70 ({WSIPP-Benefit cost}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that Treatment Foster Care Oregon (TFCO) reduces participating youths\u2019 recidivism ({SPTW}, {Osei 2016}) and delinquency ({OJJDP Model Programs}, {Blueprints}, {Turner 2011}) compared to peers in group homes. TFCO has also been shown to reduce violent crime ({Blueprints}, {CG-Violence}, {OJJDP Model Programs}), days of incarceration ({SPTW}, {Osei 2016}), and drug use ({Blueprints}, {Leve 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFor girls, TFCO has been shown to reduce teen pregnancy and increase school attendance and homework completion ({SPTW}, {Rhoades 2013}). Juvenile female offenders in TFCO experience greater decreases in psychological problems, depression, and suicidal ideation than girls in group care homes ({Poulton 2014}, {Harold 2013}, {Kerr 2014}). TFCO for preschoolers (TFCO-P) can increase the likelihood of successful, permanent placement for participants and decrease their problem behaviors ({CEBC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA Washington-based analysis estimates that TFCO cost about $8,300 per juvenile offender in 2016, with a benefit to cost ratio of $1.70 ({WSIPP-Benefit cost}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ETFCO is used in more than 50 U.S. locations and internationally ({Henggeler 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ETFCO is used in more than 50 U.S. locations and internationally ({Henggeler 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":7,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced teen pregnancy","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced teen chronically delinquent youth in foster families that are trained in structured behavior management and connected to TFCO program staff; formerly called Multidimensional Treatment Foster Care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EPlace severely and chronically delinquent youth in foster families that are trained in structured behavior management and connected to TFCO program staff; formerly called Multidimensional Treatment Foster Care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"ce15b851-48a1-4c70-ab86-7cde0c7de259","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3621}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/field_curated_list?r a132-4d49-9711-ef6a7a0cf56d","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1547}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"958c5efe-bbdc-4335-a7db-90e0e4741dc0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1544}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"ac92d738-1149-4f92-82f1-7cbe183c37c7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1340}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a13e380b-94cc-4a06-80b5-bef40beb32ad","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":2152}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"89d8b5e3-eed8-4637-bf4c-cb6bb10afac4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3993}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9e571e83-5e60-4c50-9f54-9ea157cb8805\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1341"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"a40c9179-92f6-4531-9d6a-db5e60b8dfa0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3954}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\ programs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:35+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"School-based behavior by teaching self-awareness, emotional self-control, self-esteem, social problem solving, conflict resolution, team work, social skills,
