Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/school-based-violence-bullying-prevention-programs","pid":1577,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2025-01-22","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your school-based bullying and violence prevention program engage parents, teachers, and students?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your program support those most at risk like female students, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or questioning (LGBTQ) youth, students with disabilities, and\/or socially isolated youth?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes the program offer information about violence, change thought patterns associated with violence, and build social skills?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your school-based bullying and violence prevention program engage parents, teachers, and students?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your program support those most at risk like female students, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or questioning (LGBTQ) youth, students with disabilities, and\/or socially isolated youth?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes the program offer information about violence, change thought patterns associated with violence, and build social skills?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact school-based violence and bullying programs have on school aged youth across populations. Evidence shows programs are effective for students of various ages, socio-economic status, and ethnicity ({CG-Violence}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact school-based violence and bullying programs have on school aged youth across populations. Evidence shows programs are effective for students of various ages, socio-economic status, and ethnicity ({CG-Violence}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EBased on 2021-2022 data, approximately 19 percent of middle and high school students have reported being bullied in school, while 22 percent reported bullying taking place in an online space or via text message ({NCES-Bullying}, {Stopbullying.gov}). Higher rates of bullying have been reported by female students compared to male students and is higher for students of two or more races ({NCES-Bullying}). Reports of bullying varied based on student and school characteristics ({NCES-Bullying}) and may take place in schools, on the playground or the bus, in neighborhoods, travelling to or from school, and in cyber spaces ({Stopbullying.gov}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EBased on 2021-2022 data, approximately 19 percent of middle and high school students have reported being bullied in school, while 22 percent reported bullying taking place in an online space or via text message ({NCES-Bullying}, {Stopbullying.gov}). Higher rates of bullying have been reported by female students compared to male students and is higher for students of two or more races ({NCES-Bullying}). Reports of bullying varied based on student and school characteristics ({NCES-Bullying}) and may take place in schools, on the playground or the bus, in neighborhoods, travelling to or from school, and in cyber spaces ({Stopbullying.gov}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school-based violence and bullying prevention programs reduce violence and victimization ({CG-Violence}, {Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {RAND-Wong 2009}, {Jimenez Barbero 2012}, {Matjasko 2012}). Such programs have also been shown to modestly reduce bullying in some circumstances ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {Matjasko 2012}, {Gaffney 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, whole-school violence prevention programs reduce violence. Programs that offer information about violence, change thought patterns associated with violence, and build social skills have been shown to reduce violence. Such programs are effective for students of various ages, socio-economic status, and ethnicity ({CG-Violence}); in a few cases, program effects appear greatest among boys and older students ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost school-based anti-bullying programs also reduce victimization (being bullied), bullying, and aggressive behavior ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {Jimenez Barbero 2012}). Programs implemented at the classroom level appear more effective than formal school policies against bullying or approaches that focus on specific bullies ({RAND-Wong 2009}), and longer, more intense programs reduce bullying more than less intense programs ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}). Multi-component interventions ({Bradshaw 2015}), including a focus on classroom management and rules, better playground supervision, and firm discipline ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}), as well as incentives for bullies to change their behavior, and focused attention for at-risk youth ({Ferguson 2007}) can also increase program effectiveness. Examples of effective anti-bullying programs include Olweus ({Blueprints}) and KiVa ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based violence and bullying prevention programs are more likely to succeed with family education components, appropriate adaptations for the social and cultural characteristics of the school population, long program durations, and high levels of parent engagement ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}, {Bradshaw 2015}) including interventions that improve parent engagement ({van Niejenhuis 2020}). Interventions that teach social and interpersonal skills as well as aim to modify attitudes and beliefs are more effective than those that focus on mitigating responses to provocation ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}) and have been found to reduce behavioral issues in elementary schools ({Freeman 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based violence and bullying prevention programs may be implemented to address school safety concerns. Programs that emphasize engagement and train youth to recognize signs of harmful behaviors may promote the perception of school safety ({Hsieh 2022}). Comprehensive approaches have been developed to address school safety concerns;this approach may hold promise but requires engagement and commitment of key staff members and adequate time allocation for changes to occur ({Dymnicki 2021}). Adopting the principles and practices of trauma-informed schools may enhance bullying prevention efforts and address the social emotional and mental health needs of vulnerable students ({Blitz 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school-based violence and bullying prevention programs reduce violence and victimization ({CG-Violence}, {Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {RAND-Wong 2009}, {Jimenez Barbero 2012}, {Matjasko 2012}). Such programs have also been shown to modestly reduce bullying in some circumstances ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {Matjasko 2012}, {Gaffney 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, whole-school violence prevention programs reduce violence. Programs that offer information about violence, change thought patterns associated with violence, and build social skills have been shown to reduce violence. Such programs are effective for students of various ages, socio-economic status, and ethnicity ({CG-Violence}); in a few cases, program effects appear greatest among boys and older students ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost school-based anti-bullying programs also reduce victimization (being bullied), bullying, and aggressive behavior ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}, {Jimenez Barbero 2012}). Programs implemented at the classroom level appear more effective than formal school policies against bullying or approaches that focus on specific bullies ({RAND-Wong 2009}), and longer, more intense programs reduce bullying more than less intense programs ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}). Multi-component interventions ({Bradshaw 2015}), including a focus on classroom management and rules, better playground supervision, and firm discipline ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}), as well as incentives for bullies to change their behavior, and focused attention for at-risk youth ({Ferguson 2007}) can also increase program effectiveness. Examples of effective anti-bullying programs include Olweus ({Blueprints}) and KiVa ({Campbell-Farrington 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based violence and bullying prevention programs are more likely to succeed with family education components, appropriate adaptations for the social and cultural characteristics of the school population, long program durations, and high levels of parent engagement ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}, {Bradshaw 2015}) including interventions that improve parent engagement ({van Niejenhuis 2020}). Interventions that teach social and interpersonal skills as well as aim to modify attitudes and beliefs are more effective than those that focus on mitigating responses to provocation ({Jimenez Barbero 2012}) and have been found to reduce behavioral issues in elementary schools ({Freeman 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based violence and bullying prevention programs may be implemented to address school safety concerns. Programs that emphasize engagement and train youth to recognize signs of harmful behaviors may promote the perception of school safety ({Hsieh 2022}). Comprehensive approaches have been developed to address school safety concerns;this approach may hold promise but requires engagement and commitment of key staff members and adequate time allocation for changes to occur ({Dymnicki 2021}). Adopting the principles and practices of trauma-informed schools may enhance bullying prevention efforts and address the social emotional and mental health needs of vulnerable students ({Blitz 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many resources and tools available federally to help states, schools, parents, and victims of bullying ({Stopbullying.gov}). As of January 2018, all states and Washington, D.C. have anti-bullying legislation ({LawAtlas-Anti bullying}). Most states have model policies schools can use to reduce bullying. The federal government also offers bullying and violence prevention resources ({US DHHS-Stop bullying}, {CDC-School violence}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many resources and tools available federally to help states, schools, parents, and victims of bullying ({Stopbullying.gov}). As of January 2018, all states and Washington, D.C. have anti-bullying legislation ({LawAtlas-Anti bullying}). Most states have model policies schools can use to reduce bullying. The federal government also offers bullying and violence prevention resources ({US DHHS-Stop bullying}, {CDC-School violence}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":8,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced bullying","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced bullying\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced victimization","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced victimization\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Bringing in the Bystander program (BITB)","CDC-School violence","US DHHS-Stop bullying","YG-SVP","AIR-SSL SCI Resources","AIR-Bullying","AIR-School climate","Olweus","KiVa"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Bringing in the Bystander program (BITB)\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215423\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Bringing in the Bystander program (BITB)\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Soteria Solutions. 198-43f8-8ad3-6194b7ea53ea","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1706}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a88ce862-2f36-433c-b932-406f6efc128c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1701}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"d60bd461-98d0-4abf-bc19-9155638eb29b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1694}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"358d2ea5-5e70-46f4-b0e3-671f28f41de9","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1679}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"b62533d5-dde1-4e55-af3f-31351600e742","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1652}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4272765e-cb64-4fb9-82dd-2df7c7cd874e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1651}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"29b2132e-a8b3-4cd6-a77b-a63c93a5d3e5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1648}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"34101f82-4e0e-46ca-81be-871f4658430e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1594}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"f3960390-7f4e-45ca-98f7-cb0eab65c6b6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1570}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"ecf7c28e-e777-4309-ab4c-e684d14dd570","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3995}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"405f084e-8f43-4cb8-8e13-59fd96af074f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3952}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5ebc47a8-7c48-43ff-9bcd-f81a3a97e040\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1342"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1343,"drupal_internal__vid":1343,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Firearm licensing laws","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:23+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Firearm licensing laws | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Require a potential purchaser to obtain a permit or license before purchasing a firearm"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/firearm-licensing-laws"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Require a potential purchaser to obtain a permit or license before purchasing a firearm"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Crime \u0026 delinquency"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/firearm-licensing-laws","pid":1578,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2022-12-15","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho experiences a greater risk of death by firearms in your community? How can firearm licensing laws help increase their safety?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are objective, nondiscriminatory ways to enforce firearm licensing laws? What resources and trainings are needed?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow do preemption laws impact your ability to implement licensing laws?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho experiences a greater risk of death by firearms in your community? How can firearm licensing laws help increase their safety?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are objective, nondiscriminatory ways to enforce firearm licensing laws? What resources and trainings are needed?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow do preemption laws impact your ability to implement licensing laws?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact firearm licensing laws may have on disparities in firearm-related homicides and suicides. Compared to purchaser licensing, licensing of firearm possession is more likely to be at a risk of discriminatory licensing policies and enforcement ({Abelow 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFirearm deaths disproportionally affect populations by race and ethnicity, age, gender, poverty level, and urbanization level. In 2020, the firearm homicide rate was highest among Black people (27 per 100,000 individuals), about 13 times higher than white people. Both American Indian and Alaska Native people and white people had higher suicide rates, more than twice that of Black and Hispanic people. Individuals ages 25-44 and males had the highest firearm homicide rates compared to other age groups and females. Counties with higher poverty rates had higher firearm homicide and suicide rates than counties with lower poverty rates ({Kegler 2022}). In 2020, firearm suicide rates for rural counties were 2.1 times higher than large metropolitan counties ({JHCGVS 2022}). Regarding firearm ownership, males, white people, and residents of rural areas are more likely to own firearms than females, other racial and ethnic groups, and residents of urban or suburban areas ({Pew-Schaeffer 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact firearm licensing laws may have on disparities in firearm-related homicides and suicides. Compared to purchaser licensing, licensing of firearm possession is more likely to be at a risk of discriminatory licensing policies and enforcement ({Abelow 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFirearm deaths disproportionally affect populations by race and ethnicity, age, gender, poverty level, and urbanization level. In 2020, the firearm homicide rate was highest among Black people (27 per 100,000 individuals), about 13 times higher than white people. Both American Indian and Alaska Native people and white people had higher suicide rates, more than twice that of Black and Hispanic people. Individuals ages 25-44 and males had the highest firearm homicide rates compared to other age groups and females. Counties with higher poverty rates had higher firearm homicide and suicide rates than counties with lower poverty rates ({Kegler 2022}). In 2020, firearm suicide rates for rural counties were 2.1 times higher than large metropolitan counties ({JHCGVS 2022}). Regarding firearm ownership, males, white people, and residents of rural areas are more likely to own firearms than females, other racial and ethnic groups, and residents of urban or suburban areas ({Pew-Schaeffer 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe first gun control policy was passed by a European colony in 1619, which banned the sale or gift of firearms to Native Americans. This was a controversial policy because firearm trading was profitable and Native Americans were sometimes allies against colonial adversaries ({Spitzer 2017}). The addition of the Bill of Rights to the U.S. Constitution in 1791 included the Second Amendment, which states that, \u0026ldquo;A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed\u0026rdquo; ({CONAN-Second Amendment}). The varied interpretations of the Second Amendment have shaped firearm regulations ever since it was ratified.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThrough the early 1930s, there was wide variation in state gun laws: major forms of state gun policies addressed hunting, militia, and gun carrying restrictions, with less attention given to firearm sale bans ({Spitzer 2017}). The National Firearms Act was passed in 1934 to control firearm transactions and possession of unregistered firearms, in recognition of increased crime rates and public safety concerns ({ATF-NFA}). Since then, federal firearm legislation has moved forward in regulating firearm owners and dealers, but there have still been gaps in gun laws. For example, the Gun Control Act of 1968 (GCA) created a federal firearm licensing system for dealers and prohibited firearm sales and possession for felons and other unlawful individuals; yet some restrictions were removed by the Firearm Owners\u2019 Protection Act of 1986 ({ATF-NFA}, {US DOJ-Gun violence 2001}). The Brady Bill in 1993 established a background check system for gun purchases ({GLC-Gun lobby}); however, loopholes remained that allowed prohibited purchasers to access firearms, such as through private sales without background checks ({Everytown-Loopholes}, {CAP-Parsons 2020}). Gun rights advocacy groups, such as the National Rifle Association (NRA) and the National Shooting Sports Foundation (NSSF), have been successful at lobbying against firearm regulations and encouraging states to pass preemption laws that prevent local governments from implementing local gun control policies ({GLC-Gun lobby}, {Montez 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlthough the health impacts of firearms are well documented, Congress prohibited federal research dollars from being used for gun violence and injury prevention research from 1996-2020 ({APA-Weir 2021}). In 2021, approximately 48,900 people died from firearm-related injuries in the U.S., including firearm homicides (43%) and suicides (54%). Firearm homicide and suicide rates have increased over time; 80% of total homicides and 55% of total suicides in 2021 involved a firearm ({Pew-Gramlich 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe first gun control policy was passed by a European colony in 1619, which banned the sale or gift of firearms to Native Americans. This was a controversial policy because firearm trading was profitable and Native Americans were sometimes allies against colonial adversaries ({Spitzer 2017}). The addition of the Bill of Rights to the U.S. Constitution in 1791 included the Second Amendment, which states that, \u201cA well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed\u201d ({CONAN-Second Amendment}). The varied interpretations of the Second Amendment have shaped firearm regulations ever since it was ratified.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThrough the early 1930s, there was wide variation in state gun laws: major forms of state gun policies addressed hunting, militia, and gun carrying restrictions, with less attention given to firearm sale bans ({Spitzer 2017}). The National Firearms Act was passed in 1934 to control firearm transactions and possession of unregistered firearms, in recognition of increased crime rates and public safety concerns ({ATF-NFA}). Since then, federal firearm legislation has moved forward in regulating firearm owners and dealers, but there have still been gaps in gun laws. For example, the Gun Control Act of 1968 (GCA) created a federal firearm licensing system for dealers and prohibited firearm sales and possession for felons and other unlawful individuals; yet some restrictions were removed by the Firearm Owners\u2019 Protection Act of 1986 ({ATF-NFA}, {US DOJ-Gun violence 2001}). The Brady Bill in 1993 established a background check system for gun purchases ({GLC-Gun lobby}); however, loopholes remained that allowed prohibited purchasers to access firearms, such as through private sales without background checks ({Everytown-Loopholes}, {CAP-Parsons 2020}). Gun rights advocacy groups, such as the National Rifle Association (NRA) and the National Shooting Sports Foundation (NSSF), have been successful at lobbying against firearm regulations and encouraging states to pass preemption laws that prevent local governments from implementing local gun control policies ({GLC-Gun lobby}, {Montez 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlthough the health impacts of firearms are well documented, Congress prohibited federal research dollars from being used for gun violence and injury prevention research from 1996-2020 ({APA-Weir 2021}). In 2021, approximately 48,900 people died from firearm-related injuries in the U.S., including firearm homicides (43%) and suicides (54%). Firearm homicide and suicide rates have increased over time; 80% of total homicides and 55% of total suicides in 2021 involved a firearm ({Pew-Gramlich 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that firearm licensing laws decrease firearm-related homicides ({Rudolph 2015}, {Hasegawa 2019}, {Webster 2014}, {Crifasi 2018}, {McCourt 2020}) and suicides ({Crifasi 2015}, {Andres 2011}, {McCourt 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStates with permit-to-purchase laws have lower firearm-related homicide and suicide rates than states without such laws, and can reduce both rates following implementation of these laws ({Crifasi 2015}, {Rudolph 2015}, {McCourt 2020}, {Kalesan 2016}, {Anestis 2015}). Permit-to-purchase laws may decrease firearm-related suicide rates among males ({Andres 2011}) and firearm-related homicides in large urban counties with a high prevalence of firearm-related homicides ({Crifasi 2018}). Repealing such laws may increase firearm suicide and homicide rates ({Crifasi 2015}, {Webster 2014}, {Hasegawa 2019}, {McCourt 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPermit-to-purchase handgun laws that require either fingerprinting or in-person applications may decrease fatal mass shootings ({Webster 2020}). License to own and permit to purchase laws are associated with reductions in gun trafficking ({GLC-Licensing}, {JHCGPR}). A Massachusetts-based study shows that expanding the eligibility disqualification criteria in the existing licensing laws has no short-term impact on violent crimes ({Iwama 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that firearm licensing laws decrease firearm-related homicides ({Rudolph 2015}, {Hasegawa 2019}, {Webster 2014}, {Crifasi 2018}, {McCourt 2020}) and suicides ({Crifasi 2015}, {Andres 2011}, {McCourt 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStates with permit-to-purchase laws have lower firearm-related homicide and suicide rates than states without such laws, and can reduce both rates following implementation of these laws ({Crifasi 2015}, {Rudolph 2015}, {McCourt 2020}, {Kalesan 2016}, {Anestis 2015}). Permit-to-purchase laws may decrease firearm-related suicide rates among males ({Andres 2011}) and firearm-related homicides in large urban counties with a high prevalence of firearm-related homicides ({Crifasi 2018}). Repealing such laws may increase firearm suicide and homicide rates ({Crifasi 2015}, {Webster 2014}, {Hasegawa 2019}, {McCourt 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPermit-to-purchase handgun laws that require either fingerprinting or in-person applications may decrease fatal mass shootings ({Webster 2020}). License to own and permit to purchase laws are associated with reductions in gun trafficking ({GLC-Licensing}, {JHCGPR}). A Massachusetts-based study shows that expanding the eligibility disqualification criteria in the existing licensing laws has no short-term impact on violent crimes ({Iwama 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2021, ten states (Connecticut, Hawaii, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Nebraska, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, Rhode Island) require a permit to purchase handguns or other firearms, and three states (Illinois, Massachusetts, and New York) require a license to own a firearm. California and Washington require prospective purchasers to obtain a firearm safety training certificate first, and Washington, D.C. has a registration law that works as a license requirement. Among these states, eight states have stronger licensing laws that require a permit to purchase, a license to own, or a firearm safety certificate for all classes of firearms ({GLC-Licensing}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost states prevent local governments from enacting gun laws via state preemption legislation ({LawAtlas-State preemption}); as of January 2022, only eight states (California, Colorado, Connecticut, Hawaii, Nebraska, Massachusetts, New Jersey, and New York) allow local governments to enact gun laws, with exceptions for local laws relevant to minors in some states, for example, Maryland and Texas ({GLC-Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2021, ten states (Connecticut, Hawaii, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Nebraska, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, Rhode Island) require a permit to purchase handguns or other firearms, and three states (Illinois, Massachusetts, and New York) require a license to own a firearm. California and Washington require prospective purchasers to obtain a firearm safety training certificate first, and Washington, D.C. has a registration law that works as a license requirement. Among these states, eight states have stronger licensing laws that require a permit to purchase, a license to own, or a firearm safety certificate for all classes of firearms ({GLC-Licensing}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost states prevent local governments from enacting gun laws via state preemption legislation ({LawAtlas-State preemption}); as of January 2022, only eight states (California, Colorado, Connecticut, Hawaii, Nebraska, Massachusetts, New Jersey, and New York) allow local governments to enact gun laws, with exceptions for local laws relevant to minors in some states, for example, Maryland and Texas ({GLC-Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":10,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced gun trafficking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced gun trafficking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced crime","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced crime\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced homicide","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced homicide\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced suicide","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced suicide\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Everytown-State gun law strength","RAND-Firearm law database","GLC-Licensing","EFSGV-REIA","JHCGPR","US DOJ-ATF"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Crime \u0026 delinquency","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Everytown-State gun law strength\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228590\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Everytown-State gun law strength\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Everytown for Gun Safety Support Fund (Everytown). 2022 Everytown gun law rankings.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/everytownresearch.org\\\/rankings\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-03-03\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022RAND-Firearm law database\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228591\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022RAND-Firearm law database\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Cherney S, Morral AR, Schell TL, Smucker S, Hoch E. RAND state firearm law database. Santa Monica: RAND Corporation; 2022.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.rand.org\\\/pubs\\\/tools\\\/TLA243-2-v2.html\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-03-03\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022GLC-Licensing\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002211900\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022GLC-Licensing\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Giffords Law Center (GLC). al__target_id":1496}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7aba029f-def5-4c05-8fc0-058977dcaffe","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1444}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"3ecf4d7e-3c52-488e-a027-92c2082a85ce","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1366}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"aab6f7f6-a045-4b4e-a2c3-327c66cf77c4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1339}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"d69d60f4-2ab6-4971-afb0-2932106a4837","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3992}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"a40c9179-92f6-4531-9d6a-db5e60b8dfa0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3954}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/28a35c4c-b4e7-4482-a3d5-31e72c3049b3\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1343"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1344,"drupal_internal__vid":1344,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Consumer-directed health plans","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:23+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Consumer-directed health plans | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Establish high deductible health plans paired with pre-tax medical expense accounts such as Health Reimbursement Arrangements (HRAs) or Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) and information tools"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/consumer-directed-health-plans"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Establish high deductible health plans paired with pre-tax medical expense accounts such as Health Reimbursement Arrangements (HRAs) or Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) and information tools"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/consumer-directed-health-plans","pid":1579,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-05-17","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is mixed evidence about the effects of consumer-directed health plans (CDHPs). CDHPs reduce short-term health care costs by inducing participants to seek less health care ({Agarwal 2017}, {Brot-Goldberg 2017}, {Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2010}, {Haviland 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEnrollment in CDHPs appears to reduce both appropriate and inappropriate care ({Agarwal 2017}, {Brot-Goldberg 2017}). Overall, CDHP participation has been shown to reduce office visits ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Reddy 2014}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Haviland 2011}), preventive care and recommended screenings ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Haviland 2011}), specialist visits ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}), and procedures ({Haviland 2011}), particularly among individuals with lower incomes and chronic conditions ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Reddy 2014}). CDHP participants are more likely to reduce prescription drug use and, in some cases, can be less likely to adhere to medication regimens than peers with traditional health insurance ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {NBER-Huckfeldt 2015}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Fronstin 2013a}, {Haviland 2011}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2010}). \u0026nbsp;A three year study suggests little to no effect on cancer screening rates following CDHP enrollment, despite increases in screening before enrollment ({Eisenberg 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDHPs cover preventive services; however, participants often do not realize this ({EBRI-Fronstin 2010}) and forgo preventive care ({Haviland 2011}). In some cases CDHPs may increase hospitalizations, likely due to participants deferring needed care ({Agarwal 2017}). Recent studies have found little evidence that CDHP participation reduces the use of low value services ({Reid 2017}, {Bundorf 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe effect of CDHPs on emergency room use is unclear. Some studies suggest CDHPs reduce non-emergency ER visits. Other studies suggest CDHPs increase visits to the ER ({Agarwal 2017}). A six year study indicates ER visits and hospital admissions among low income individuals increase in their first year of CDHP enrollment, though not the second year ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, switching to a CDHP can decrease outpatient spending compared to traditional plans ({Reid 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2012}), though decreases in spending may erode over time ({Haviland 2016}). In one study, for example, only spending on laboratory services and prescription drugs remained lower over four years ({Fronstin 2013a}). CDHPs with HSAs appear to reduce spending more than CDHPs with HRAs, especially on outpatient services and prescription drugs ({Haviland 2011}). However, one recent study suggests that enrollment in CDHPs may increase out-of-pocket spending and the likelihood of financial burden, particularly among enrollees with lower incomes or chronic conditions ({Zhang 2018}). Another study suggests increased spending on procedures ({Ellis 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA majority of cost savings and spending reductions associated with CDHPs are the result of forgone care ({Brot-Goldberg 2017}, {RAND-Haviland 2012}), including reduced use of outpatient services ({Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2016}) and prescriptions ({Fronstin 2013a}, {Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2016}). Cost savings can also result from choosing generic drugs, avoiding hospital stays, and visiting fewer specialists ({RAND-Haviland 2012}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealthier individuals are more likely to enroll in CDHPs than less healthy individuals ({McDevitt 2014}), and the spending reductions from CDHPs appear concentrated among the healthiest enrollees ({Bundorf 2016}). There is little evidence available on provision, use, or effectiveness of tools to assist decision making in CDHPs ({Bundorf 2016}). A study of a large self-insured firm found no evidence of price shopping, despite the availability of a comprehensive price shopping tool, among enrollees who have had a CDHP for two years ({Brot-Goldberg 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDHPs are a type of high deductible health plan (HDHP). Individuals enrolled in HDHPs are more likely to face problems paying medical bills or to delay or forgo medical care than peers with traditional plans ({NCHS-Cohen 2017}). The higher the deductible on HDHPs, the higher the burden on enrollees with lower incomes ({Abdus 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is mixed evidence about the effects of consumer-directed health plans (CDHPs). CDHPs reduce short-term health care costs by inducing participants to seek less health care ({Agarwal 2017}, {Brot-Goldberg 2017}, {Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2010}, {Haviland 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEnrollment in CDHPs appears to reduce both appropriate and inappropriate care ({Agarwal 2017}, {Brot-Goldberg 2017}). Overall, CDHP participation has been shown to reduce office visits ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Reddy 2014}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Haviland 2011}), preventive care and recommended screenings ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Haviland 2011}), specialist visits ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}), and procedures ({Haviland 2011}), particularly among individuals with lower incomes and chronic conditions ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Reddy 2014}). CDHP participants are more likely to reduce prescription drug use and, in some cases, can be less likely to adhere to medication regimens than peers with traditional health insurance ({Agarwal 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {NBER-Huckfeldt 2015}, {Fronstin 2013}, {Fronstin 2013a}, {Haviland 2011}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2010}). \u0026nbsp;A three year study suggests little to no effect on cancer screening rates following CDHP enrollment, despite increases in screening before enrollment ({Eisenberg 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDHPs cover preventive services; however, participants often do not realize this ({EBRI-Fronstin 2010}) and forgo preventive care ({Haviland 2011}). In some cases CDHPs may increase hospitalizations, likely due to participants deferring needed care ({Agarwal 2017}). Recent studies have found little evidence that CDHP participation reduces the use of low value services ({Reid 2017}, {Bundorf 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe effect of CDHPs on emergency room use is unclear. Some studies suggest CDHPs reduce non-emergency ER visits. Other studies suggest CDHPs increase visits to the ER ({Agarwal 2017}). A six year study indicates ER visits and hospital admissions among low income individuals increase in their first year of CDHP enrollment, though not the second year ({EBRI-Fronstin 2016}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, switching to a CDHP can decrease outpatient spending compared to traditional plans ({Reid 2017}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2012}), though decreases in spending may erode over time ({Haviland 2016}). In one study, for example, only spending on laboratory services and prescription drugs remained lower over four years ({Fronstin 2013a}). CDHPs with HSAs appear to reduce spending more than CDHPs with HRAs, especially on outpatient services and prescription drugs ({Haviland 2011}). However, one recent study suggests that enrollment in CDHPs may increase out-of-pocket spending and the likelihood of financial burden, particularly among enrollees with lower incomes or chronic conditions ({Zhang 2018}). Another study suggests increased spending on procedures ({Ellis 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA majority of cost savings and spending reductions associated with CDHPs are the result of forgone care ({Brot-Goldberg 2017}, {RAND-Haviland 2012}), including reduced use of outpatient services ({Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2016}) and prescriptions ({Fronstin 2013a}, {Bundorf 2016}, {EBRI-Fronstin 2016}, {Haviland 2016}). Cost savings can also result from choosing generic drugs, avoiding hospital stays, and visiting fewer specialists ({RAND-Haviland 2012}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealthier individuals are more likely to enroll in CDHPs than less healthy individuals ({McDevitt 2014}), and the spending reductions from CDHPs appear concentrated among the healthiest enrollees ({Bundorf 2016}). There is little evidence available on provision, use, or effectiveness of tools to assist decision making in CDHPs ({Bundorf 2016}). A study of a large self-insured firm found no evidence of price shopping, despite the availability of a comprehensive price shopping tool, among enrollees who have had a CDHP for two years ({Brot-Goldberg 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDHPs are a type of high deductible health plan (HDHP). Individuals enrolled in HDHPs are more likely to face problems paying medical bills or to delay or forgo medical care than peers with traditional plans ({NCHS-Cohen 2017}). The higher the deductible on HDHPs, the higher the burden on enrollees with lower incomes ({Abdus 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2017, 24% of U.S. firms that offer health benefits offer high deductible health plans (HDHP) with savings options. Large firms are more likely to offer the option than small firms; 53% of firms with 200 or more employees offer high deductible plans with a savings option. Deductibles vary but, as of 2017, 24% of HDHP-covered workers were in a plan with a deductible of $3,000 or more ({KFF-Employer health benefits 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2016, 35% of privately insured adults were enrolled in an employment-based HDHP and 6% in a directly purchased HDHP ({NCHS-Cohen 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Affordable Care Act (ACA) allows HDHPs; all plans must offer preventive care at no cost to the patient ({PBS-Kane 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2017, 24% of U.S. firms that offer health benefits offer high deductible health plans (HDHP) with savings options. Large firms are more likely to offer the option than small firms; 53% of firms with 200 or more employees offer high deductible plans with a savings option. Deductibles vary but, as of 2017, 24% of HDHP-covered workers were in a plan with a deductible of $3,000 or more ({KFF-Employer health benefits 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2016, 35% of privately insured adults were enrolled in an employment-based HDHP and 6% in a directly purchased HDHP ({NCHS-Cohen 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Affordable Care Act (ACA) allows HDHPs; all plans must offer preventive care at no cost to the patient ({PBS-Kane 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":20,"field_program_impact":3,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced health care costs","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced health care costs\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NCSL-HSAs and CDHPs","ABIM-Choosing Wisely"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NCSL-HSAs and CDHPs\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00224004\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NCSL-HSAs and CDHPs\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL).
