A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"94e001b7-bce0-46d7-89e9-c70359cf66cd","meta":{"target_revision_id":11301,"drupal_internal__target_id":6293}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"96922922-ed4f-40f0-aa7f-c46d52ae9333","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":66}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"00aae93d-38c4-48b6-b299-87a5caf34677","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1670}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4beae2f3-a41b-4100-bce4-cc38e70835c6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1669}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9965185f-f51b-4cd1-b923-271966f6ce16","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1579}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1383}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1362}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"c3c7f5ca-c671-4d4e-8360-07bd4a042113","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3853}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"fb93818a-de8b-4ff0-b8d2-a393381b0524","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3958}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1344"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1345,"drupal_internal__vid":1345,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Mental health benefits legislation","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:35+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Mental health benefits legislation | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Regulate mental health insurance to increase access to mental health services, including treatment for substance use disorders"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mental-health-benefits-legislation"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Regulate mental health insurance to increase access to mental health services, including treatment for substance use disorders"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center,Workplace"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mental-health-benefits-legislation","pid":1580,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-09-12","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho has access to mental health services in your community and who does not? Are there local efforts or programs that emphasize the importance of mental health care and reducing stigma associated with mental health conditions and substance use disorders?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs there guidance available to teach patients about mental health coverage through their insurance? What partnerships (e.g., primary care clinics, employers, community organizations) could be established to increase knowledge?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are health care providers, community members, and policymakers engaged in oversight efforts to ensure parity is properly applied by health insurers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho has access to mental health services in your community and who does not? Are there local efforts or programs that emphasize the importance of mental health care and reducing stigma associated with mental health conditions and substance use disorders?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs there guidance available to teach patients about mental health coverage through their insurance? What partnerships (e.g., primary care clinics, employers, community organizations) could be established to increase knowledge?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are health care providers, community members, and policymakers engaged in oversight efforts to ensure parity is properly applied by health insurers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact mental health benefits legislation may have on disparities in access to mental health care and mental health outcomes among diverse groups. Available evidence suggests implementing mental health benefits parity through public insurance (i.e., Medicaid and Medicare) can increase access to mental health care for individuals with low incomes ({Fung 2023}, {Burns 2020}), but individuals from racially and ethnically minoritized groups may not experience the same benefits ({Fung 2023}). A national study suggests that when parity laws require private health plans to cover alcohol treatments, treatment rates may increase more for Hispanic patients than white or Black patients ({Mulia 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in mental health outcomes exist in the U.S. within racially, ethnically ({Sharifian 2024}), gender ({Mongelli 2024}), and geographically ({McCarthy 2024}) diverse civilian populations, as well as among service members and veterans, compared with those at less risk because of their identity, military service status ({Sharifian 2024}), or community type ({McCarthy 2024}). Mental health conditions are far more common in groups who have been historically marginalized and minoritized by society; for example, individuals with multi-racial backgrounds or those that are LGBTQ+ are more likely to experience mental illness ({APA-MH Disparities fact sheet}, {APA-MH LGBTQ fact sheet}). Even with parity legislation to mandate mental health coverage equal to that of physical health coverage, challenges in meeting the mental health needs of populations who have been under-resourced and disenfranchised remain ({Fung 2023}, {Heboyan 2021}, {Maxwell 2020}, {Lawrence 2020}). Limited cultural competency among health care and mental health care providers can lead to misdiagnosis or underdiagnosis of mental health conditions in diverse populations due to language barriers, different cultural presentations of symptoms, mental illness stigma, and distrust of the health care system ({APA-MH Disparities fact sheet}). Additionally, there are not enough mental health providers, and those who are practicing are less likely to be in rural and under-resourced urban areas, and they may choose not to accept patients with Medicare or Medicaid benefits ({Carlo 2020}, {Peterson 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws alone cannot overcome systemic issues that prevent adequate access to mental health care for people from racially and ethnically minoritized groups, individuals with low incomes, and other socio-economically disadvantaged populations ({Fung 2023}, {Heboyan 2021}, {Maxwell 2020}, {Lawrence 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAdditionally, insurers may impose limits not addressed by parity, such as setting separate copayments and deductibles, disproportionately burdening families and individuals with lower incomes ({Maxwell 2020}). The legal complexity of how parity applies may also prevent those with less education, lower incomes, or less trust in the legal system from identifying wrongful denial of claims and pursuing legal complaints ({Lawrence 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact mental health benefits legislation may have on disparities in access to mental health care and mental health outcomes among diverse groups. Available evidence suggests implementing mental health benefits parity through public insurance (i.e., Medicaid and Medicare) can increase access to mental health care for individuals with low incomes ({Fung 2023}, {Burns 2020}), but individuals from racially and ethnically minoritized groups may not experience the same benefits ({Fung 2023}). A national study suggests that when parity laws require private health plans to cover alcohol treatments, treatment rates may increase more for Hispanic patients than white or Black patients ({Mulia 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in mental health outcomes exist in the U.S. within racially, ethnically ({Sharifian 2024}), gender ({Mongelli 2024}), and geographically ({McCarthy 2024}) diverse civilian populations, as well as among service members and veterans, compared with those at less risk because of their identity, military service status ({Sharifian 2024}), or community type ({McCarthy 2024}). Mental health conditions are far more common in groups who have been historically marginalized and minoritized by society; for example, individuals with multi-racial backgrounds or those that are LGBTQ+ are more likely to experience mental illness ({APA-MH Disparities fact sheet}, {APA-MH LGBTQ fact sheet}). Even with parity legislation to mandate mental health coverage equal to that of physical health coverage, challenges in meeting the mental health needs of populations who have been under-resourced and disenfranchised remain ({Fung 2023}, {Heboyan 2021}, {Maxwell 2020}, {Lawrence 2020}). Limited cultural competency among health care and mental health care providers can lead to misdiagnosis or underdiagnosis of mental health conditions in diverse populations due to language barriers, different cultural presentations of symptoms, mental illness stigma, and distrust of the health care system ({APA-MH Disparities fact sheet}). Additionally, there are not enough mental health providers, and those who are practicing are less likely to be in rural and under-resourced urban areas, and they may choose not to accept patients with Medicare or Medicaid benefits ({Carlo 2020}, {Peterson 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws alone cannot overcome systemic issues that prevent adequate access to mental health care for people from racially and ethnically minoritized groups, individuals with low incomes, and other socio-economically disadvantaged populations ({Fung 2023}, {Heboyan 2021}, {Maxwell 2020}, {Lawrence 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAdditionally, insurers may impose limits not addressed by parity, such as setting separate copayments and deductibles, disproportionately burdening families and individuals with lower incomes ({Maxwell 2020}). The legal complexity of how parity applies may also prevent those with less education, lower incomes, or less trust in the legal system from identifying wrongful denial of claims and pursuing legal complaints ({Lawrence 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMental health conditions and neurodiversity have long been stigmatized by society, seen as a source of shame for both the individuals who suffer from it and their families ({Ahad 2023}). Mental illness was typically viewed as a moral or spiritual failing ({NLM-Psychiatric timeline}); people with mental health conditions were viewed as a burden and ignored or minimized at best. However, individuals with more severe issues would be locked in asylums and kept from greater society, where treatments were often brutal, and almost always ineffective ({PBS American Experience-Mental illness}). The system could also be exploited, and those who stepped outside the bounds of society could be subjected to cruelty and incarceration in asylums, and later institutions ({CSP-Mental illness}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile society\u2019s understanding of and treatments for mental health have evolved over time, stigma around mental health conditions remains common in many communities ({Ahad 2023}). Stigma against mental health and substance use disorders, as well as distrust of the mental health care system, may prevent those who need help from seeking care, even if it is covered by their insurance ({Heboyan 2021}, {Carlo 2020}). In western cultures, including the U.S., there are often assumptions about individuals with mental health conditions, such as the mistaken belief that they are unpredictable or dangerous, contributing to discrimination and social exclusion ({Ahad 2023}), and reducing options for work, education, housing, and social connections ({APA-Stigma}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe National Institute of Mental Health was established in 1949 to research the mind, brain, and behavior as a way to reduce mental illness ({PBS American Experience-Mental illness}). Mental health care coverage was still not a standard part of insurance coverage, although following World War II some insurers began covering a limited amount of hospital-based psychiatric care ({Barry 2010}). In the 1970s and 1980s, some state legislatures passed mandated benefits laws for private insurance, establishing minimum benefits for mental health and\/or substance abuse disorders ({Barry 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELegislation to establish insurance coverage parity for physical health and mental health conditions began appearing with the 1996 Mental Health Parity Act, though it excluded addiction related treatments ({Druss 2018}), and many state governments passed additional, stricter mental health parity laws for private insurance in the late 1990s and early 2000s ({Douglas 2024}, {Solomon 2022}). The 2008 Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA) expanded federal parity requirements and the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extended them further, along with the declaration that care for mental health and substance use disorders is an essential health benefit ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}, {Douglas 2024}, {Peterson 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn September 2024, new final rules were released by the U.S. Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and the Treasury to further the fundamental purpose of the MHPAEA and ensure full equity in health insurance coverage for mental health conditions and substance abuse disorders ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMental health conditions and neurodiversity have long been stigmatized by society, seen as a source of shame for both the individuals who suffer from it and their families ({Ahad 2023}). Mental illness was typically viewed as a moral or spiritual failing ({NLM-Psychiatric timeline}); people with mental health conditions were viewed as a burden and ignored or minimized at best. However, individuals with more severe issues would be locked in asylums and kept from greater society, where treatments were often brutal, and almost always ineffective ({PBS American Experience-Mental illness}). The system could also be exploited, and those who stepped outside the bounds of society could be subjected to cruelty and incarceration in asylums, and later institutions ({CSP-Mental illness}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhile society\u2019s understanding of and treatments for mental health have evolved over time, stigma around mental health conditions remains common in many communities ({Ahad 2023}). Stigma against mental health and substance use disorders, as well as distrust of the mental health care system, may prevent those who need help from seeking care, even if it is covered by their insurance ({Heboyan 2021}, {Carlo 2020}). In western cultures, including the U.S., there are often assumptions about individuals with mental health conditions, such as the mistaken belief that they are unpredictable or dangerous, contributing to discrimination and social exclusion ({Ahad 2023}), and reducing options for work, education, housing, and social connections ({APA-Stigma}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe National Institute of Mental Health was established in 1949 to research the mind, brain, and behavior as a way to reduce mental illness ({PBS American Experience-Mental illness}). Mental health care coverage was still not a standard part of insurance coverage, although following World War II some insurers began covering a limited amount of hospital-based psychiatric care ({Barry 2010}). In the 1970s and 1980s, some state legislatures passed mandated benefits laws for private insurance, establishing minimum benefits for mental health and\/or substance abuse disorders ({Barry 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELegislation to establish insurance coverage parity for physical health and mental health conditions began appearing with the 1996 Mental Health Parity Act, though it excluded addiction related treatments ({Druss 2018}), and many state governments passed additional, stricter mental health parity laws for private insurance in the late 1990s and early 2000s ({Douglas 2024}, {Solomon 2022}). The 2008 Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA) expanded federal parity requirements and the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extended them further, along with the declaration that care for mental health and substance use disorders is an essential health benefit ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}, {Douglas 2024}, {Peterson 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn September 2024, new final rules were released by the U.S. Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and the Treasury to further the fundamental purpose of the MHPAEA and ensure full equity in health insurance coverage for mental health conditions and substance abuse disorders ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mental health benefits legislation that includes parity requirements increases access to care for mental health conditions ({CG-Mental health}, {Hall 2023b}, {Burns 2020}, {Mulvaney-Day 2019}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Li 2020d}, {Block 2020}, {Friedman 2017}, {Harwood 2017}) and reduces costs to patients ({CG-Mental health}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Kennedy-Hendricks 2018}, {Ettner 2016}, {Busch 2013}, {Barry 2013}, {McConnell 2013}). More comprehensive parity laws yield stronger effects ({Haffajee 2019}, {CG-Sipe 2015}, {Wen 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMental health benefits legislation that includes parity requirements has been shown to modestly increase diagnostic and therapy visits for behavioral health care ({Harwood 2017}), and applying parity requirements to Medicaid can increase use of outpatient and inpatient mental health care and prescription medications for mental health conditions ({Burns 2020}). Such laws can also increase access to outpatient ({Mulvaney-Day 2019}, {Friedman 2017}) and inpatient care for patients diagnosed with substance use disorder ({Friedman 2017}). A study of the dual impact of the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA) and the Affordable Care Act (ACA) suggests they may reduce rates of severe morbidity among birthing people, particularly those with perinatal mood and anxiety disorders ({Hall 2023b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws can reduce suicide rates and prevalence of poor mental health for patients receiving treatment for mental health conditions ({CG-Mental health}, {Solomon 2022}), including among college-aged students; reductions in poor mental health days appear to be greater among female students ({Solomon 2022}). Parity laws have also been shown to increase the use of specialty behavioral health care services for children ({Block 2020}), including children with autism spectrum disorder ({Stuart 2017}). A study based on national data suggests greater exposure to comprehensive parity laws in childhood and adolescence reduces the need for mental health visits in adulthood, perhaps by ensuring greater access to needed care at an earlier age ({Heboyan 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws improve financial protection for patients ({CG-Mental health}, {CG-Sipe 2015}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Ettner 2016}), including families of children receiving care ({Kennedy-Hendricks 2018}). Such laws reduce out-of-pocket spending for patients, including high utilizers of mental health services ({Haffajee 2019}), patients with bipolar disorder, major depression, and adjustment disorders ({Busch 2013}), families whose children have the highest cost for mental health care ({Barry 2013}), and mental health and substance abuse treatment for adults with severe mental illness ({McConnell 2013}). In some cases, however, individuals diagnosed with substance use disorder may experience a modest increase in out-of-pocket spending ({Friedman 2017}). Children with autism spectrum disorder ({Stuart 2017}) and adults with health insurance through large employers appear to experience no change in total out-of-pocket costs following parity implementation, even with increases in service use ({Harwood 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, mental health parity requirements do not appear to significantly increase insurers\u2019 annual cost per health plan member ({CG-Jacob 2015}, {CG-Mental health}). An Oregon-based study, however, saw insurer spending for patients with severe mental illness increase post-parity ({McConnell 2013}), and a study of children\u2019s access to behavioral health services found increased total per-member-per-month costs ({Block 2020}). Studies of one of the largest managed behavioral health organizations in the U.S. indicate cost shifting from patients to plans ({Ettner 2016}) of approximately $1.05 per enrollee ({Harwood 2017}). Parity requirements for substance use disorder services appear to cause a modest increase in health plan spending ({Friedman 2017}, {Busch 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest an ongoing need to monitor insurer compliance with the parity requirements of the federal MHPAEA and other parity laws ({Knopf 2022}, {Berry 2017}) and recommend using clear definitions of mental health conditions based on current diagnosis standards in legislation ({Heboyan 2021}). Additional reform is needed to expand access to substance use disorder treatment and ensure coverage amounts are based on evidence-based practices ({Dickson-Gomez 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mental health benefits legislation that includes parity requirements increases access to care for mental health conditions ({CG-Mental health}, {Hall 2023b}, {Burns 2020}, {Mulvaney-Day 2019}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Li 2020d}, {Block 2020}, {Friedman 2017}, {Harwood 2017}) and reduces costs to patients ({CG-Mental health}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Kennedy-Hendricks 2018}, {Ettner 2016}, {Busch 2013}, {Barry 2013}, {McConnell 2013}). More comprehensive parity laws yield stronger effects ({Haffajee 2019}, {CG-Sipe 2015}, {Wen 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMental health benefits legislation that includes parity requirements has been shown to modestly increase diagnostic and therapy visits for behavioral health care ({Harwood 2017}), and applying parity requirements to Medicaid can increase use of outpatient and inpatient mental health care and prescription medications for mental health conditions ({Burns 2020}). Such laws can also increase access to outpatient ({Mulvaney-Day 2019}, {Friedman 2017}) and inpatient care for patients diagnosed with substance use disorder ({Friedman 2017}). A study of the dual impact of the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA) and the Affordable Care Act (ACA) suggests they may reduce rates of severe morbidity among birthing people, particularly those with perinatal mood and anxiety disorders ({Hall 2023b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws can reduce suicide rates and prevalence of poor mental health for patients receiving treatment for mental health conditions ({CG-Mental health}, {Solomon 2022}), including among college-aged students; reductions in poor mental health days appear to be greater among female students ({Solomon 2022}). Parity laws have also been shown to increase the use of specialty behavioral health care services for children ({Block 2020}), including children with autism spectrum disorder ({Stuart 2017}). A study based on national data suggests greater exposure to comprehensive parity laws in childhood and adolescence reduces the need for mental health visits in adulthood, perhaps by ensuring greater access to needed care at an earlier age ({Heboyan 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParity laws improve financial protection for patients ({CG-Mental health}, {CG-Sipe 2015}, {Haffajee 2019}, {Ettner 2016}), including families of children receiving care ({Kennedy-Hendricks 2018}). Such laws reduce out-of-pocket spending for patients, including high utilizers of mental health services ({Haffajee 2019}), patients with bipolar disorder, major depression, and adjustment disorders ({Busch 2013}), families whose children have the highest cost for mental health care ({Barry 2013}), and mental health and substance abuse treatment for adults with severe mental illness ({McConnell 2013}). In some cases, however, individuals diagnosed with substance use disorder may experience a modest increase in out-of-pocket spending ({Friedman 2017}). Children with autism spectrum disorder ({Stuart 2017}) and adults with health insurance through large employers appear to experience no change in total out-of-pocket costs following parity implementation, even with increases in service use ({Harwood 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, mental health parity requirements do not appear to significantly increase insurers\u2019 annual cost per health plan member ({CG-Jacob 2015}, {CG-Mental health}). An Oregon-based study, however, saw insurer spending for patients with severe mental illness increase post-parity ({McConnell 2013}), and a study of children\u2019s access to behavioral health services found increased total per-member-per-month costs ({Block 2020}). Studies of one of the largest managed behavioral health organizations in the U.S. indicate cost shifting from patients to plans ({Ettner 2016}) of approximately $1.05 per enrollee ({Harwood 2017}). Parity requirements for substance use disorder services appear to cause a modest increase in health plan spending ({Friedman 2017}, {Busch 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest an ongoing need to monitor insurer compliance with the parity requirements of the federal MHPAEA and other parity laws ({Knopf 2022}, {Berry 2017}) and recommend using clear definitions of mental health conditions based on current diagnosis standards in legislation ({Heboyan 2021}). Additional reform is needed to expand access to substance use disorder treatment and ensure coverage amounts are based on evidence-based practices ({Dickson-Gomez 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2019, 49 states have mental health insurance parity laws, some more comprehensive than federal parity laws ({Douglas 2024}). The 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA) named coverage of mental health and substance use treatment as one of the ten essential health benefits; all plans in the individual and small employer market must include this treatment coverage ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}), extending the benefits of the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008 (MHPAEA) which required this coverage for large group employers, the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Medicaid managed care organizations (MCOs) ({Medicaid-MHPAEA}). Large, self-funded non-federal governmental employers that self-insure are exempt from state insurance mandates ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe U.S. Department of Labor (U.S. DOL), Employee Benefits Security Administration offers tools and resources about using mental health and substance use disorder benefits, why claims may be denied and how to file an appeal, where to access treatment services, and guidance for families and caregivers ({US DOL-Parity}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2019, 49 states have mental health insurance parity laws, some more comprehensive than federal parity laws ({Douglas 2024}). The 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA) named coverage of mental health and substance use treatment as one of the ten essential health benefits; all plans in the individual and small employer market must include this treatment coverage ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}), extending the benefits of the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008 (MHPAEA) which required this coverage for large group employers, the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Medicaid managed care organizations (MCOs) ({Medicaid-MHPAEA}). Large, self-funded non-federal governmental employers that self-insure are exempt from state insurance mandates ({CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe U.S. Department of Labor (U.S. DOL), Employee Benefits Security Administration offers tools and resources about using mental health and substance use disorder benefits, why claims may be denied and how to file an appeal, where to access treatment services, and guidance for families and caregivers ({US DOL-Parity}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":23,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced suicide","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced suicide\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased substance use disorder treatment","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased substance use disorder treatment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased access to mental health services","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to mental health services\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced patient costs","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced patient costs\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["US DOL-Parity","Medicaid-MHPAEA","CMS-CCIIO-MHPAEA"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center,Workplace","field_program_sources":"{\u0022US DOL-Parity\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214998\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022US DOL-Parity\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Employee Benefits Security Administration. State parity laws and access to treatment for substance use disorder in the United States: Implications for federal parity legislation. JAMA Psychiatry. 2013;70(12):1355-1362.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/archpsyc.jamanetwork.com\\\/article.aspx?articleid=1761269\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-06-11\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Solomon 2022\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214997\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Solomon 2022\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Solomon, K. Journal of Health Economics, 86, 102675.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1016\\\/j.jhealeco.2022.102675\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Stuart 2017\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228277\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Stuart 2017\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Stuart EA, McGinty EE, Kalb L, et al. Medical Care, 59(10), 939\u0026ndash;946.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/journals.lww.com\\\/lww-medicalcare\\\/fulltext\\\/2021\\\/10000\\\/Impact_of_Mental_Health_Insurance_Legislation_on.12.aspx\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022CG-Jacob 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228273\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CG-Jacob 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Jacob V, Qu S, Chattopadhyay S, et al. The Journal of Mental Health Policy and Economics. 2015;18(1):39-48.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/stacks.cdc.gov\\\/view\\\/cdc\\\/36899\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-06-11\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Busch 2014\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00224043\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Busch 2014\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Busch SH, Epstein AJ, Harhay MO, et al. The effects of federal parity on substance use disorder treatment. ams":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"01593356-ed9b-4b16-889b-c2189e79d1da","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1672}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"74d0efca-07cd-4815-8004-e41b930ce852","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1625}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1379}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"30133e69-3e72-4e56-8509-f31c761ded8f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4000}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1345"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"40c88a84-ed70-4a9d-b047-3e3e1c896256","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/40c88a84-ed70-4a9d-b047-3e3e1c896256?resourceVersion=id%3A1346"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1346,"drupal_internal__vid":1346,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Financial incentives for health professionals serving underserved areas","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:23+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Financial incentives for health professionals serving underserved areas | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Expand incentives such as scholarships and loans with service requirements and loan repayment or forgiveness programs for health care providers who practice in rural or other underserved areas"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-incentives-for-health-professionals-serving-underserved-areas"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Expand incentives such as scholarships and loans with service requirements and loan repayment or forgiveness programs for health care providers who practice in rural or other underserved areas"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-incentives-for-health-professionals-serving-underserved-areas","pid":1581,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-12-14","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can financial incentive programs address the health care needs of both rural and urban underserved areas? Can underserved practices partner directly with programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can providers receiving financial incentives connect with formal or informal networks of support during their placement in a rural or underserved area to feel more integrated with the community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional strategies can rural areas implement to retain providers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can financial incentive programs address the health care needs of both rural and urban underserved areas? Can underserved practices partner directly with programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can providers receiving financial incentives connect with formal or informal networks of support during their placement in a rural or underserved area to feel more integrated with the community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional strategies can rural areas implement to retain providers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that financial incentive programs have the potential to decrease disparities in access to care for patients in underserved areas by increasing the number of health care providers in rural and urban underserved areas ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Wilson 2009}, {Sempowski 2004}, {Opoku 2015}, {Daniels 2007}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELoan forgiveness or repayment programs, often funded by state governments or the National Health Service Corps (NHSC), may support increased access to care for patients in underserved areas by requiring providers to serve in safety net health care practices, including primary care, behavioral health, and dental health care ({Pathman 2022}). Participating providers typically remain in underserved areas longer than non-participants ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). A Maryland-based study suggests that physicians participating in a loan repayment program care for more patients receiving Medicare than non-participating providers, which may increase access to care for older adults with low incomes ({Quigley 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, rural populations in the U.S. have higher rates of chronic health conditions, experience more poverty, and have significantly higher mortality rates than urban areas. Lack of access to primary care physicians is one component contributing to higher mortality rates ({Zabel 2023}). Today, approximately 20% of the U.S. population resides in rural areas, but only 10% of physicians provide care there ({Arredondo 2023}). Additionally, half of rural physicians are over 55, and a third are scheduled to retire by 2033 ({STAT-Empinado 2023}), creating a substantial and ongoing need to train and retain rural providers.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that financial incentive programs have the potential to decrease disparities in access to care for patients in underserved areas by increasing the number of health care providers in rural and urban underserved areas ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Wilson 2009}, {Sempowski 2004}, {Opoku 2015}, {Daniels 2007}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELoan forgiveness or repayment programs, often funded by state governments or the National Health Service Corps (NHSC), may support increased access to care for patients in underserved areas by requiring providers to serve in safety net health care practices, including primary care, behavioral health, and dental health care ({Pathman 2022}). Participating providers typically remain in underserved areas longer than non-participants ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). A Maryland-based study suggests that physicians participating in a loan repayment program care for more patients receiving Medicare than non-participating providers, which may increase access to care for older adults with low incomes ({Quigley 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, rural populations in the U.S. have higher rates of chronic health conditions, experience more poverty, and have significantly higher mortality rates than urban areas. Lack of access to primary care physicians is one component contributing to higher mortality rates ({Zabel 2023}). Today, approximately 20% of the U.S. population resides in rural areas, but only 10% of physicians provide care there ({Arredondo 2023}). Additionally, half of rural physicians are over 55, and a third are scheduled to retire by 2033 ({STAT-Empinado 2023}), creating a substantial and ongoing need to train and retain rural providers.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 1907, the American Medical Association (AMA) began publishing medical school ratings ({Moehling 2020}). Shortly after, medical system reformer Abraham Flexner\u2019s 1910 report asserted that there were too many medical schools in the U.S. and that they produced poorly trained physicians ({Duffy 2011}). The Flexner Report contributed to decisions to virtually end women\u2019s admission to medical schools and severely restrict Black students\u2019 admittance ({Barkin 2010}, {Laws 2021}). Medical school programs standardized ({Barkin 2010}) and began charging higher tuition and fees, which further limited who could attend. At the same time, graduates may have been drawn to urban areas post-graduation due to higher salaries, larger patient bases and networks of health professionals, and more modern technology and facilities, such as laboratories ({Moehling 2020}). By the 1920s, public health officials warned that fewer providers were practicing in rural areas ({Moehling 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 1960s and 1970s, there were efforts to increase access to college and health professional schools for students identifying as minorities, from low income backgrounds, and for women. Recruitment efforts, pipeline programs, and affirmative action policies were designed to address the long history of structural barriers that prevented underrepresented minority students from enrolling in higher education, including medical schools ({Toretsky 2018}, {Figueroa 2014}, {Thelin 2022}, {US ED-Harvill 2012}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}), yet racial disparities in medical school enrollment persisted ({Toretsky 2018}, {Figueroa 2014}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 1970s, Congress established the National Health Service Corps (NHSC), awarding scholarships to primary care providers in exchange for a minimum of two years\u2019 service in Health Professional Shortage Areas (HPSAs) ({US DHHS-NHSC Timeline}). In 1987, NHSC expanded to increase the number of spots for providers in HPSAs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA) granted the NHSC permanent authorization along with a mandatory funding stream ({US DHHS-NHSC Timeline}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe number of medical students with rural backgrounds has been declining since the early 2000s and underrepresented minority students with rural backgrounds remain a small percentage of medical students; for example, less than 0.5 percent of new students in 2017 ({Shipman 2019}). As of 2023, only 7% of physicians identify as Hispanic or Black ({Davis 2023b}). The cost of medical education likely plays a significant role in the small numbers of underrepresented minority and rural students pursuing medicine ({Davis 2023b}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 1907, the American Medical Association (AMA) began publishing medical school ratings ({Moehling 2020}). Shortly after, medical system reformer Abraham Flexner\u2019s 1910 report asserted that there were too many medical schools in the U.S. and that they produced poorly trained physicians ({Duffy 2011}). The Flexner Report contributed to decisions to virtually end women\u2019s admission to medical schools and severely restrict Black students\u2019 admittance ({Barkin 2010}, {Laws 2021}). Medical school programs standardized ({Barkin 2010}) and began charging higher tuition and fees, which further limited who could attend. At the same time, graduates may have been drawn to urban areas post-graduation due to higher salaries, larger patient bases and networks of health professionals, and more modern technology and facilities, such as laboratories ({Moehling 2020}). By the 1920s, public health officials warned that fewer providers were practicing in rural areas ({Moehling 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 1960s and 1970s, there were efforts to increase access to college and health professional schools for students identifying as minorities, from low income backgrounds, and for women. Recruitment efforts, pipeline programs, and affirmative action policies were designed to address the long history of structural barriers that prevented underrepresented minority students from enrolling in higher education, including medical schools ({Toretsky 2018}, {Figueroa 2014}, {Thelin 2022}, {US ED-Harvill 2012}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}), yet racial disparities in medical school enrollment persisted ({Toretsky 2018}, {Figueroa 2014}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 1970s, Congress established the National Health Service Corps (NHSC), awarding scholarships to primary care providers in exchange for a minimum of two years\u2019 service in Health Professional Shortage Areas (HPSAs) ({US DHHS-NHSC Timeline}). In 1987, NHSC expanded to increase the number of spots for providers in HPSAs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA) granted the NHSC permanent authorization along with a mandatory funding stream ({US DHHS-NHSC Timeline}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe number of medical students with rural backgrounds has been declining since the early 2000s and underrepresented minority students with rural backgrounds remain a small percentage of medical students; for example, less than 0.5 percent of new students in 2017 ({Shipman 2019}). As of 2023, only 7% of physicians identify as Hispanic or Black ({Davis 2023b}). The cost of medical education likely plays a significant role in the small numbers of underrepresented minority and rural students pursuing medicine ({Davis 2023b}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that financial incentive programs increase the number of health care providers caring for patients in underserved areas ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Wilson 2009}, {Sempowski 2004}, {Opoku 2015}, {Daniels 2007}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which incentives are most effective ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Misfeldt 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParticipants in financial incentive programs are more likely to care for patients in underserved areas than non-participating peers ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Quigley 2022}, {Barnighausen 2009b}, {Daniels 2007}). On average, participants remain in underserved areas longer than non-participants ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). However, providers may not always stay in rural or remote communities following their commitment ({Misfeldt 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EScholarships ({Misfeldt 2014}), loan repayments ({Quigley 2022}, {Misfeldt 2014}), and loan forgiveness programs appear to support recruitment of health care providers to underserved areas ({Daniels 2007}). Loan repayment programs also appear to increase the duration providers practice in these locations ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Renner 2010}, {Opoku 2015}). A Maryland-based study suggests that physicians in rural areas who receive loan repayments remain in their positions beyond their service commitment ({Quigley 2022}). Surveys of administrators at safety net health care practices indicate that loan repayment and forgiveness programs may make it easier and faster to recruit providers for primary care, behavioral health, and dental health care ({Pathman 2022}). Financial incentives are more effective as part of multi-dimensional programs than incentives alone ({Sempowski 2004}, {Misfeldt 2014}), and incentive programs offered at the end of training may be more successful than those offered earlier ({Barnighausen 2009b}). Surveys suggest that competitive salaries, professional development, knowledgeable support staff, and professional support may increase the likelihood of provider retention in rural or underserved areas following the completion of service commitments ({Scarbrough 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMid-level providers such as nurse practitioners (NPs), nurse midwives, and physician assistants (PAs) may be more likely to practice in rural areas than other health care professionals ({Daniels 2007}). Primary care NPs ({Spetz 2016}, {DesRoches 2013}) and family medicine NPs ({Odell 2013}) are also more likely to practice in rural or underserved areas than NPs with other specialties. Additional research is needed about financial incentive interventions to bring nurses, allied health professionals, and indigenous health care practitioners to rural or underserved areas ({Russell 2021}, {Kueakomoldej 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that providers who participate in financial incentive programs may have elected to practice in underserved areas even without incentives ({Renner 2010}, {Quigley 2022}, {Kueakomoldej 2022}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). A study of the National Health Service Corps (NHSC) found that motivations of participating providers was often two-fold: physicians wanted loan repayment assistance as well as to care for underserved populations ({Pathman 2019}). Rural background or origin is also associated with the decision to practice and remain in rural communities ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Crump 2015}, {Petrany 2013}, {Renner 2010}, {Wilson 2009}, {Daniels 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that expanding financial incentives with service requirements to include general surgeons ({Tierney 2017}, {Collins 2016}), OB\/GYN physicians, nurse midwives ({Smulian 2016}), and telehealth providers offering mental health care ({Collins 2016}) may increase access in rural and underserved communities.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that financial incentive programs increase the number of health care providers caring for patients in underserved areas ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Wilson 2009}, {Sempowski 2004}, {Opoku 2015}, {Daniels 2007}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which incentives are most effective ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Misfeldt 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EParticipants in financial incentive programs are more likely to care for patients in underserved areas than non-participating peers ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Quigley 2022}, {Barnighausen 2009b}, {Daniels 2007}). On average, participants remain in underserved areas longer than non-participants ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). However, providers may not always stay in rural or remote communities following their commitment ({Misfeldt 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EScholarships ({Misfeldt 2014}), loan repayments ({Quigley 2022}, {Misfeldt 2014}), and loan forgiveness programs appear to support recruitment of health care providers to underserved areas ({Daniels 2007}). Loan repayment programs also appear to increase the duration providers practice in these locations ({Goodfellow 2016}, {Renner 2010}, {Opoku 2015}). A Maryland-based study suggests that physicians in rural areas who receive loan repayments remain in their positions beyond their service commitment ({Quigley 2022}). Surveys of administrators at safety net health care practices indicate that loan repayment and forgiveness programs may make it easier and faster to recruit providers for primary care, behavioral health, and dental health care ({Pathman 2022}). Financial incentives are more effective as part of multi-dimensional programs than incentives alone ({Sempowski 2004}, {Misfeldt 2014}), and incentive programs offered at the end of training may be more successful than those offered earlier ({Barnighausen 2009b}). Surveys suggest that competitive salaries, professional development, knowledgeable support staff, and professional support may increase the likelihood of provider retention in rural or underserved areas following the completion of service commitments ({Scarbrough 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMid-level providers such as nurse practitioners (NPs), nurse midwives, and physician assistants (PAs) may be more likely to practice in rural areas than other health care professionals ({Daniels 2007}). Primary care NPs ({Spetz 2016}, {DesRoches 2013}) and family medicine NPs ({Odell 2013}) are also more likely to practice in rural or underserved areas than NPs with other specialties. Additional research is needed about financial incentive interventions to bring nurses, allied health professionals, and indigenous health care practitioners to rural or underserved areas ({Russell 2021}, {Kueakomoldej 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that providers who participate in financial incentive programs may have elected to practice in underserved areas even without incentives ({Renner 2010}, {Quigley 2022}, {Kueakomoldej 2022}, {Barnighausen 2009b}). A study of the National Health Service Corps (NHSC) found that motivations of participating providers was often two-fold: physicians wanted loan repayment assistance as well as to care for underserved populations ({Pathman 2019}). Rural background or origin is also associated with the decision to practice and remain in rural communities ({Cochrane-Grobler 2015}, {Crump 2015}, {Petrany 2013}, {Renner 2010}, {Wilson 2009}, {Daniels 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that expanding financial incentives with service requirements to include general surgeons ({Tierney 2017}, {Collins 2016}), OB\/GYN physicians, nurse midwives ({Smulian 2016}), and telehealth providers offering mental health care ({Collins 2016}) may increase access in rural and underserved communities.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe National Health Service Corps (NHSC) provides up to $50,000 in loan repayment and scholarships for physicians, dentists, advance practice nurses (nurse practitioners, certified nurse midwives), physician assistants, dental hygienists, and mental health professionals who work for two years in a Tier 1 Health Professional Shortage Area (HPSA) ({US DHHS-NHSC}). NHSC\u2019s Students to Service Loan Repayment Program (NHSC S2S LRP) also provides up to $120,000 to fourth year medical students who commit to practice primary care in a HPSA for three years full-time or six years half-time; the 2024 program features a new Maternity Care Target Area (MCTA) Supplemental Award of up to $40,000 in additional loan repayment funding for maternity care health professionals who then practice in MCTAs ({US DHHS-NHSC S2S LRP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA number of other entities provide loan repayment programs. The Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), for example, offers a Nurse Corps Loan Repayment Program that repays 60% of qualified loan balances for two years of work at a critical shortage facility; for an optional third year, it will pay 25% of the original balance ({HRSA-NURSE Corps LRP}). The Indian Health Service\u2019s Loan Repayment Program provides up to $25,000 per year for two years for a variety of providers and allied health professionals; the contract may be extended annually until eligible loans (up to $50,000) have been paid ({US DHHS-IHS}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EState funded loan repayment programs may complement the NHSC federal program ({US DHHS-NHSC}, {Pathman 2012a}), such as North Dakota\u2019s ND Healthcare Professional Loan Repayment Program, the Oklahoma\u2019s Health Care Workforce Training Commission\u2019s Physician Loan Repayment Program, and New Hampshire\u2019s State Loan Repayment Program ({ND DHHS-Loan repayment}, {OK HWTC-Loan repayment}, {NH DHHS-SLRP}). States can also include other specialties in their loan repayment programs, for example, in North Carolina general surgeons practicing in HPSAs are eligible ({Collins 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe National Health Service Corps (NHSC) provides up to $50,000 in loan repayment and scholarships for physicians, dentists, advance practice nurses (nurse practitioners, certified nurse midwives), physician assistants, dental hygienists, and mental health professionals who work for two years in a Tier 1 Health Professional Shortage Area (HPSA) ({US DHHS-NHSC}). NHSC\u2019s Students to Service Loan Repayment Program (NHSC S2S LRP) also provides up to $120,000 to fourth year medical students who commit to practice primary care in a HPSA for three years full-time or six years half-time; the 2024 program features a new Maternity Care Target Area (MCTA) Supplemental Award of up to $40,000 in additional loan repayment funding for maternity care health professionals who then practice in MCTAs ({US DHHS-NHSC S2S LRP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA number of other entities provide loan repayment programs. The Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), for example, offers a Nurse Corps Loan Repayment Program that repays 60% of qualified loan balances for two years of work at a critical shortage facility; for an optional third year, it will pay 25% of the original balance ({HRSA-NURSE Corps LRP}). The Indian Health Service\u2019s Loan Repayment Program provides up to $25,000 per year for two years for a variety of providers and allied health professionals; the contract may be extended annually until eligible loans (up to $50,000) have been paid ({US DHHS-IHS}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EState funded loan repayment programs may complement the NHSC federal program ({US DHHS-NHSC}, {Pathman 2012a}), such as North Dakota\u2019s ND Healthcare Professional Loan Repayment Program, the Oklahoma\u2019s Health Care Workforce Training Commission\u2019s Physician Loan Repayment Program, and New Hampshire\u2019s State Loan Repayment Program ({ND DHHS-Loan repayment}, {OK HWTC-Loan repayment}, {NH DHHS-SLRP}). States can also include other specialties in their loan repayment programs, for example, in North Carolina general surgeons practicing in HPSAs are eligible ({Collins 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":28,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased access to care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased availability of health professionals in underserved areas","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased availability of health professionals in underserved areas\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["RHIhub-Loan repayment","US DHHS-NHSC","HRSA-NURSE Corps LRP","US DHHS-IHS","RTT Collaborative"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022RHIhub-Loan repayment\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213718\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022RHIhub-Loan repayment\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Rural Health Information Hub (RHIhub). compensation","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:35+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Long-term care employee compensation | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Increase wages and benefits for personal or home care workers, nurse aides, and others who provide direct care to patients in long-term care (LTC) settings"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/long-term-care-employee-compensation"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Increase wages and benefits for personal or home care workers, nurse aides, and others who provide direct care to patients in long-term care (LTC) settings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Residential facility,Workplace"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Employment \u0026 job training,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/long-term-care-employee-compensation","pid":1582,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-11-20","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EOffering higher wages and more comprehensive benefits is a suggested strategy to improve recruitment and retention of individuals that provide long-term care (LTC) ({Frogner 2016}, {CWF-Raphael 2008}, {US DHHS-Fishman 2004}). Available evidence suggests that increasing wages and other benefits for LTC staff may reduce turnover ({Frogner 2016}, {Butler 2014}, {Hewko 2015}, {Morgan 2013}, {Powers 2010}, {Morris 2009}, {Wiener 2009}), particularly among newly hired or young caregivers ({Butler 2014}, {Howes 2005}). Providing health insurance may also help employers retain existing staff ({Stone 2017}, {Howes 2008}) and attract new part-time employees ({Howes 2008}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELow wages and benefits are consistently cited by LTC workers as a source of stress ({Lapane 2007}), and by researchers as a reason for high turnover ({Frogner 2016}, {Stone 2012}). Studies suggest that higher wages ({Morgan 2013}, {Head 2013b}, {Butler 2014}) and offering more hours to part-time staff ({Stone 2017}) may positively affect retention of LTC workers.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that individuals leave LTC roles for similar positions that provide better wages, full time status ({Banijamali 2014}, {Morris 2009}), and reimbursement for travel ({Morris 2009}). Offering health insurance ({Stone 2017}, {Frogner 2016}), consistent patient assignments ({Stone 2017}), workplace safety improvements, proper patient care training ({Butler 2017}), and opportunities for professional development, mentorship, and educational support for career advancement ({Frogner 2016}) may all contribute to higher retention of LTC workers.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EOffering higher wages and more comprehensive benefits is a suggested strategy to improve recruitment and retention of individuals that provide long-term care (LTC) ({Frogner 2016}, {CWF-Raphael 2008}, {US DHHS-Fishman 2004}). Available evidence suggests that increasing wages and other benefits for LTC staff may reduce turnover ({Frogner 2016}, {Butler 2014}, {Hewko 2015}, {Morgan 2013}, {Powers 2010}, {Morris 2009}, {Wiener 2009}), particularly among newly hired or young caregivers ({Butler 2014}, {Howes 2005}). Providing health insurance may also help employers retain existing staff ({Stone 2017}, {Howes 2008}) and attract new part-time employees ({Howes 2008}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELow wages and benefits are consistently cited by LTC workers as a source of stress ({Lapane 2007}), and by researchers as a reason for high turnover ({Frogner 2016}, {Stone 2012}). Studies suggest that higher wages ({Morgan 2013}, {Head 2013b}, {Butler 2014}) and offering more hours to part-time staff ({Stone 2017}) may positively affect retention of LTC workers.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that individuals leave LTC roles for similar positions that provide better wages, full time status ({Banijamali 2014}, {Morris 2009}), and reimbursement for travel ({Morris 2009}). Offering health insurance ({Stone 2017}, {Frogner 2016}), consistent patient assignments ({Stone 2017}), workplace safety improvements, proper patient care training ({Butler 2017}), and opportunities for professional development, mentorship, and educational support for career advancement ({Frogner 2016}) may all contribute to higher retention of LTC workers.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2015, direct care workers such as home health aides, personal care aides, and certified nursing assistants employed by home care agencies and other third party employers are covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act\u2019s minimum wage and overtime protections ({US DOL-Direct care wage}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2015, direct care workers such as home health aides, personal care aides, and certified nursing assistants employed by home care agencies and other third party employers are covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act\u2019s minimum wage and overtime protections ({US DOL-Direct care wage}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":30,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased retention of long-term care workers","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased retention of long-term care workers\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["US DOL-Direct care"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Employment \u0026 job training,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Residential facility,Workplace","field_program_sources":"{\u0022US DOL-Direct care\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226365\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022US DOL-Direct care\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022U.S. Department of Labor (U.S. DOL).
