for new nurses","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:27+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Mentoring for new nurses | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Pair new nurses with more experienced nurses who act as a resource and provide support as the new nurse establishes her or himself professionally"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-for-new-nurses"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Pair new nurses with more experienced nurses who act as a resource and provide support as the new nurse establishes her or himself professionally"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center,School,Workplace"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-for-new-nurses","pid":1583,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-09-28","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that mentoring programs increase retention ({Zhang 2016}, {Jones 2017}, {Schroyer 2016}) and job satisfaction among new nurses ({Zhang 2016}, {Jones 2017}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Zhang 2016}, {Nowell 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may increase nursing skills, reduce stress and anxiety levels ({Zhang 2016}, {Edwards 2015}), and improve confidence, decision-making, self-efficacy, and the professional practice environment ({Zhang 2016}, {Verret 2016}). Researchers suggest that mentorship by preceptors for newly licensed nurses last a minimum of six months ({Anderson 2012}) and that mentors and preceptors receive appropriate mentor training ({Zhang 2016}, {Spiva 2017}, {Rebholz 2015}, {Rush 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentorship may increase retention among experienced nurses who transition to new work environments, including new types of units ({Mann-Salinas 2014}) and faculty roles ({Hulton 2016}, {Nowell 2017}, {Specht 2013}). Experienced nurses with mentors report greater levels of job satisfaction ({Mann-Salinas 2014}) and new nursing faculty with mentors report lower levels of role conflict and role ambiguity ({Specht 2013}) than peers who transition without mentors. Serving as a mentor may also increase retention rates ({Baggot 2005}) and job satisfaction ({Jones 2017}, {Baggot 2005}) among experienced nurses.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBy reducing turnover rates, mentoring programs can reduce costs for health care organizations ({Zhang 2016}, {Trepanier 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that mentoring programs increase retention ({Zhang 2016}, {Jones 2017}, {Schroyer 2016}) and job satisfaction among new nurses ({Zhang 2016}, {Jones 2017}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Zhang 2016}, {Nowell 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs may increase nursing skills, reduce stress and anxiety levels ({Zhang 2016}, {Edwards 2015}), and improve confidence, decision-making, self-efficacy, and the professional practice environment ({Zhang 2016}, {Verret 2016}). Researchers suggest that mentorship by preceptors for newly licensed nurses last a minimum of six months ({Anderson 2012}) and that mentors and preceptors receive appropriate mentor training ({Zhang 2016}, {Spiva 2017}, {Rebholz 2015}, {Rush 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMentorship may increase retention among experienced nurses who transition to new work environments, including new types of units ({Mann-Salinas 2014}) and faculty roles ({Hulton 2016}, {Nowell 2017}, {Specht 2013}). Experienced nurses with mentors report greater levels of job satisfaction ({Mann-Salinas 2014}) and new nursing faculty with mentors report lower levels of role conflict and role ambiguity ({Specht 2013}) than peers who transition without mentors. Serving as a mentor may also increase retention rates ({Baggot 2005}) and job satisfaction ({Jones 2017}, {Baggot 2005}) among experienced nurses.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBy reducing turnover rates, mentoring programs can reduce costs for health care organizations ({Zhang 2016}, {Trepanier 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EA variety of health care organizations and partners support and implement nurse mentoring programs. The Organization of Nurse Executives of New Jersey\u2019s (ONE NJ\u2019s) program, for example, matched more than 75 mentor\/mentee pairs from 2011-2014 ({Rich 2015}, {ONE NJ}). Vermont Nurses in Partnership\u2019s (VNIP\u2019s) Clinical Transition Framework (CFT) supports new graduates and experienced nurses transitioning to new practice environments ({VNIP}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EA variety of health care organizations and partners support and implement nurse mentoring programs. The Organization of Nurse Executives of New Jersey\u2019s (ONE NJ\u2019s) program, for example, matched more than 75 mentor\/mentee pairs from 2011-2014 ({Rich 2015}, {ONE NJ}). Vermont Nurses in Partnership\u2019s (VNIP\u2019s) Clinical Transition Framework (CFT) supports new graduates and experienced nurses transitioning to new practice environments ({VNIP}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":32,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased job skills","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased job skills\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased nurse retention","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased nurse retention\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased job satisfaction","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased job satisfaction\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":[],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center,School,Workplace","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Zhang 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226286\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Zhang 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Zhang Y, Qian Y, Wu J, Wen F, Zhang Y. incentives for new nursing faculty","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:27+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Financial incentives for new nursing faculty | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Offer loan repayment, tuition assistance, competitive academic salaries, etc. to students who teach in nursing programs after completing an advanced degree"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-incentives-for-new-nursing-faculty"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Offer loan repayment, tuition assistance, competitive academic salaries, etc. to students who teach in nursing programs after completing an advanced degree"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-incentives-for-new-nursing-faculty","pid":1584,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-11-14","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EOffering financial incentives to nursing graduate students who agree to teach in nursing undergraduate or graduate programs is a suggested strategy to increase the number and availability of nursing faculty ({Gerolamo 2017}, {McDermid 2012}, {Morgan 2014}, {Fox 2009a}, {Rich 2010}, {Allan 2008}, {Siela 2008}, {AACN-Nursing faculty}). By encouraging highly educated nurses to teach, such programs may improve the teaching quality in nursing schools ({Young 2016}). Available evidence suggests that the cost of higher education and the salary gap between nurses working in academia and clinical settings are barriers to nurses pursuing careers as nursing faculty ({Westphal 2016}, {Oermann 2016}, {Nardi 2013}); the salary gap between nurses in academia and other faculty may also be a disincentive ({Dreifuerst 2016}, {Morgan 2014}). However, financial incentives alone may not be enough to mitigate the nursing faculty shortage ({McDermid 2012}, {Duvall 2010}, {Hessler 2006}). Additional evidence is necessary to confirm effects, especially in the long-term ({Dreifuerst 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESurveys of nursing faculty members suggest that financial incentives and mentoring may support recruitment, hiring, and retention of minority nursing faculty ({Salvucci 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EOffering financial incentives to nursing graduate students who agree to teach in nursing undergraduate or graduate programs is a suggested strategy to increase the number and availability of nursing faculty ({Gerolamo 2017}, {McDermid 2012}, {Morgan 2014}, {Fox 2009a}, {Rich 2010}, {Allan 2008}, {Siela 2008}, {AACN-Nursing faculty}). By encouraging highly educated nurses to teach, such programs may improve the teaching quality in nursing schools ({Young 2016}). Available evidence suggests that the cost of higher education and the salary gap between nurses working in academia and clinical settings are barriers to nurses pursuing careers as nursing faculty ({Westphal 2016}, {Oermann 2016}, {Nardi 2013}); the salary gap between nurses in academia and other faculty may also be a disincentive ({Dreifuerst 2016}, {Morgan 2014}). However, financial incentives alone may not be enough to mitigate the nursing faculty shortage ({McDermid 2012}, {Duvall 2010}, {Hessler 2006}). Additional evidence is necessary to confirm effects, especially in the long-term ({Dreifuerst 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESurveys of nursing faculty members suggest that financial incentives and mentoring may support recruitment, hiring, and retention of minority nursing faculty ({Salvucci 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EFederal funding for financial initiatives to address the nursing faculty shortage include: Title VIII of the Public Health Services Act, which funds Nursing Workforce Development Programs; Nurse Faculty Loan Programs, funded through the Nurse Corps Loan Repayment Program; and Graduate Assistance in Area of National Need, which awards grants to nursing programs ({ANA-Title VIII}, {HRSA-Nurse Corps}, {US ED-Graduate assistance}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPhilanthropic and health care groups also often contribute to scholarships and endowments ({Feldman 2015}); the New Jersey Nursing Initiative (NJNI), funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF), is one example ({NJNI}). Individual nursing schools may also establish programs such as Pace University\u2019s Lienhard School of Nursing\u2019s Grow Our Own program ({Grow Our Own}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EFederal funding for financial initiatives to address the nursing faculty shortage include: Title VIII of the Public Health Services Act, which funds Nursing Workforce Development Programs; Nurse Faculty Loan Programs, funded through the Nurse Corps Loan Repayment Program; and Graduate Assistance in Area of National Need, which awards grants to nursing programs ({ANA-Title VIII}, {HRSA-Nurse Corps}, {US ED-Graduate assistance}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPhilanthropic and health care groups also often contribute to scholarships and endowments ({Feldman 2015}); the New Jersey Nursing Initiative (NJNI), funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF), is one example ({NJNI}). Individual nursing schools may also establish programs such as Pace University\u2019s Lienhard School of Nursing\u2019s Grow Our Own program ({Grow Our Own}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":33,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased availability of nursing faculty","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased availability of nursing faculty\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Benefits.gov","WI DHS-Primary care","AACN-State policies","HRSA-Faculty LRP","HRSA-NURSE Corps LRP","BND-Nurse educators"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Benefits.gov\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222306\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Benefits.gov\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Benefits.gov. Nursing education loan repayment program.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.benefits.gov\\\/benefits\\\/benefit-details\\\/449\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222017-11-14\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022WI DHS-Primary care\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222317\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022WI DHS-Primary care\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS). Wisconsin primary care office.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.dhs.wisconsin.gov\\\/health\\\/primarycare\\\/ProviderRecruitmentandRetention.htm\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222017-11-14\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022AACN-State policies\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222304\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022AACN-State policies\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN). program","id":"1e1f4843-cd04-47f2-8b8f-55c17196a32e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1348}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"cd1a86cf-f669-478b-853a-f58aa4766fab","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1347}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"40c88a84-ed70-4a9d-b047-3e3e1c896256","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1346}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"d0c2cf80-4bf4-41b2-9de7-028a20f55b93","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3855}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"89aa19c6-d487-4fac-9dd9-63b568ebc107","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3955}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f58a168e-0fcb-4471-84ea-db0be88c703f\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1349"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1350,"drupal_internal__vid":1350,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Nurse practitioner scope of practice","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:27+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Nurse practitioner scope of practice | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Use regulation to extend nurse practitioners\u2019 (NPs\u2019) scope of practice to provide care to the full scope of their training and skills without physician oversight, especially for primary care"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/nurse-practitioner-scope-of-practice"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Use regulation to extend nurse practitioners\u2019 (NPs\u2019) scope of practice to provide care to the full scope of their training and skills without physician oversight, especially for primary care"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/nurse-practitioner-scope-of-practice","pid":1585,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-03-16","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that nurse practitioners (NPs) provide high quality routine care that is equivalent to ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Cochrane-Kuethe 2013}, {Newhouse 2011}, {Buerhaus 2015}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}), and sometimes better than, comparable care provided by physicians ({Martinez-Gonzalez 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Newhouse 2011}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}). On average, nurse practitioners\u2019 patient satisfaction scores are similar to ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}) or higher than physicians\u2019 scores ({Martinez-Gonzalez 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Newhouse 2011}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, health status and outcomes for patients that receive routine care from NPs are equal to that of patients treated by physicians ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Oliver 2014}, {Cochrane-Kuethe 2013}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}). NPs generally provide longer consults ({Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}), more health advice ({Cochrane-Laurant 2004}), and are more likely to take patient histories and discover history-related causes of health issues than physicians ({AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStandardizing NP scope of practice laws to support full NP autonomy, within the scope of NP training, may increase the availability of primary care providers ({Xue 2016}, {Buerhaus 2015}, {Barnes 2016}, {Spetz 2016}, {Naylor 2010}, {IOM-Nursing 2011}, {Graves 2016b}). NPs with expanded scope of practice have been shown to improve provider availability for injured workers using worker\u2019s compensation benefits, particularly in rural areas ({Sears 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStates that do not require physician oversight appear to have more NPs than states that require greater oversight ({Reagan 2013}, {Perry 2012}). One study indicates higher numbers of primary care NPs in states with less oversight, particularly if NPs are paid the physician Medicaid reimbursement rate ({Barnes 2016}). Primary care NPs ({Spetz 2016}, {DesRoches 2013}) and family medicine NPs ({Odell 2013}) are more likely to practice in rural or health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) than NPs with other specialties or physicians. Primary care NPs also care for a greater portion of Medicare ({DesRoches 2013}) and Medicaid patients ({Buerhaus 2015}, {Barnes 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EModels suggest that removing restrictions on NP scope of practice could reduce health care costs ({Xue 2016}).\u0026nbsp;A study that compares states with full scope of practice regulations to states with more restrictions indicates that expanded NP scope of practice laws do not affect physician earnings ({Pittman 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEqualizing NP and physician reimbursement rates is a suggested strategy to encourage full NP autonomy, as allowed within state laws ({Barnes 2016}, {IOM-Nursing 2011}); as of 2012, Medicare reimbursed independent NPs at 85% of the physician rate ({Cassidy 2013}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that nurse practitioners (NPs) provide high quality routine care that is equivalent to ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Cochrane-Kuethe 2013}, {Newhouse 2011}, {Buerhaus 2015}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}), and sometimes better than, comparable care provided by physicians ({Martinez-Gonzalez 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Newhouse 2011}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}). On average, nurse practitioners\u2019 patient satisfaction scores are similar to ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}) or higher than physicians\u2019 scores ({Martinez-Gonzalez 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Newhouse 2011}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, health status and outcomes for patients that receive routine care from NPs are equal to that of patients treated by physicians ({Stanik-Hutt 2013}, {Oliver 2014}, {Cochrane-Kuethe 2013}, {AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}, {Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}). NPs generally provide longer consults ({Cochrane-Laurant 2004}, {Horrocks 2002}), more health advice ({Cochrane-Laurant 2004}), and are more likely to take patient histories and discover history-related causes of health issues than physicians ({AHRQ-O\u2019Grady 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStandardizing NP scope of practice laws to support full NP autonomy, within the scope of NP training, may increase the availability of primary care providers ({Xue 2016}, {Buerhaus 2015}, {Barnes 2016}, {Spetz 2016}, {Naylor 2010}, {IOM-Nursing 2011}, {Graves 2016b}). NPs with expanded scope of practice have been shown to improve provider availability for injured workers using worker\u2019s compensation benefits, particularly in rural areas ({Sears 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStates that do not require physician oversight appear to have more NPs than states that require greater oversight ({Reagan 2013}, {Perry 2012}). One study indicates higher numbers of primary care NPs in states with less oversight, particularly if NPs are paid the physician Medicaid reimbursement rate ({Barnes 2016}). Primary care NPs ({Spetz 2016}, {DesRoches 2013}) and family medicine NPs ({Odell 2013}) are more likely to practice in rural or health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) than NPs with other specialties or physicians. Primary care NPs also care for a greater portion of Medicare ({DesRoches 2013}) and Medicaid patients ({Buerhaus 2015}, {Barnes 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EModels suggest that removing restrictions on NP scope of practice could reduce health care costs ({Xue 2016}).\u0026nbsp;A study that compares states with full scope of practice regulations to states with more restrictions indicates that expanded NP scope of practice laws do not affect physician earnings ({Pittman 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEqualizing NP and physician reimbursement rates is a suggested strategy to encourage full NP autonomy, as allowed within state laws ({Barnes 2016}, {IOM-Nursing 2011}); as of 2012, Medicare reimbursed independent NPs at 85% of the physician rate ({Cassidy 2013}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of March 2017, 22 states and Washington, D.C. allow nurse practitioners to diagnose, treat, and prescribe medications without physician involvement ({Campaign for Action}). New Hampshire expanded the scope of practice of psychiatric mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs) in 2015, following extensive collaboration among PMHNPs, physician leaders, and policy makers focused on improving care within the state mental health system ({de Nesnera 2016}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENational organizations such as Campaign for Action, the National Governors Association, and the Federal Trade Commission have efforts underway in support of expanded scope of practice for nurse practitioners ({Campaign for Action}, {NGA-NP 2012}, {FTC-Gilman 2014}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of March 2017, 22 states and Washington, D.C. allow nurse practitioners to diagnose, treat, and prescribe medications without physician involvement ({Campaign for Action}). New Hampshire expanded the scope of practice of psychiatric mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs) in 2015, following extensive collaboration among PMHNPs, physician leaders, and policy makers focused on improving care within the state mental health system ({de Nesnera 2016}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENational organizations such as Campaign for Action, the National Governors Association, and the Federal Trade Commission have efforts underway in support of expanded scope of practice for nurse practitioners ({Campaign for Action}, {NGA-NP 2012}, {FTC-Gilman 2014}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":36,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased access to care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased patient satisfaction","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient satisfaction\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["APRN Consensus toolkit","Barton-NP","Clavelle 2012","KFF-NP","AANP"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022APRN Consensus toolkit\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222378\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APRN Consensus toolkit\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Council of State Boards of Nursing (NCSBN). Chapter 43. Advanced practice registered nurses: The Impact on patient safety and quality. -wwfh_program","id":"c8a3fcb9-c3dd-47e0-8429-f0d904d3fb4a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1590}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1381}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1351}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"43c2f44f-e680-4360-9b07-746bd89f50af","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3857}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"f19a7d55-bf01-4879-9013-2d8c8607c29a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4002}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1350"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1351,"drupal_internal__vid":1351,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Allied dental professional scope of practice","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:27+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Allied dental professional scope of practice | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Expand the role of allied dental professionals (e.g., hygienists, therapists, etc.) via changes to statute, dentist supervision requirements, etc."}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/allied-dental-professional-scope-of-practice"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Expand the role of allied dental professionals (e.g., hygienists, therapists, etc.) via changes to statute, dentist supervision requirements, etc."}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/allied-dental-professional-scope-of-practice","pid":1586,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-10-23","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho experiences poor oral health outcomes (e.g., cavities) in your community? Is your community considered a dental health professional shortage area (HPSA)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDo training programs for allied dental professionals exist locally? If not, can partnerships between dental providers and local universities and community colleges establish programs, generate funding, and support pathways to licensure?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community raise public awareness of allied dental professionals as a workforce that can increase access to oral health care, particularly for those in dental HPSAs? How can community voices champion legally expanded scopes of practice at the state and local levels?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho experiences poor oral health outcomes (e.g., cavities) in your community? Is your community considered a dental health professional shortage area (HPSA)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDo training programs for allied dental professionals exist locally? If not, can partnerships between dental providers and local universities and community colleges establish programs, generate funding, and support pathways to licensure?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community raise public awareness of allied dental professionals as a workforce that can increase access to oral health care, particularly for those in dental HPSAs? How can community voices champion legally expanded scopes of practice at the state and local levels?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that expanding scope of practice laws for allied dental professionals has the potential to decrease disparities in access to oral health care between individuals in dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) and those in areas with large numbers of dental care providers ({Chen 2024}, {Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}). Allied dental professionals are often required by state laws to practice in under-resourced dental HPSAs as a way to make dental care accessible and more affordable for those who are uninsured, have limited incomes ({Khan 2024}), or live in rural ({Akinlotan 2023}) or remote areas ({Hill 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExpanded practice autonomy for dental hygienists has been shown to increase the use of preventive care in dental HPSAs ({Chen 2024}). In contrast, states which grant dental hygienists less autonomy have significantly higher rates of preventable dental-related emergency department visits for rural residents compared to states that allow greater autonomy to dental hygienists ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists have a broader scope of practice than dental hygienists; dental care clinics in states that allow both types of providers can have greater operational efficiency along with the capacity to treat additional patients, especially those without insurance or with public insurance ({Khan 2024}). While the number of states authorizing dental therapists to practice remains limited (only 14 states as of 2024), employing dental therapists in these states reduces disparities in access to dental care for patients living in under-resourced areas ({Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}, {Mertz 2021}). A Tribal health organization in Southwest Alaska established the first dental therapist training program in the U.S., which increased access to oral health care and reduced cavities among local Native children and adults ({Hill 2022a}). Furthermore, most dental therapists trained in this program are members of the community they later serve, improving trust between patients and providers as well as increasing access to care and improving oral health outcomes ({Bianchi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA Minnesota-based study indicates that authorizing dental therapists to treat patients increases access to dental care for adults with low incomes; however, racial and ethnic disparities in oral health care continue, as improvements were among white patients only ({Elani 2022}). However, another study suggests that non-white patients in Minnesota may have a greater intention to return for care by a dental therapist than white patients ({Zhao 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExpanded scope of practice laws for allied dental professionals can support a more diverse dental workforce. Training programs for dental auxiliaries are shorter and more affordable than those to become a dentist, and often meant for local students intending to practice in the area following graduation ({Mertz 2021}). When dental hygienists can provide more complex services (i.e., local anesthesia) at a lesser cost than dentists through expanded scope of practice laws, practices may be more likely to accept patients whose insurance reimburses providers at lower rates, making it easier for patients with Medicaid to locate a provider ({Nasseh 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that expanding scope of practice laws for allied dental professionals has the potential to decrease disparities in access to oral health care between individuals in dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) and those in areas with large numbers of dental care providers ({Chen 2024}, {Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}). Allied dental professionals are often required by state laws to practice in under-resourced dental HPSAs as a way to make dental care accessible and more affordable for those who are uninsured, have limited incomes ({Khan 2024}), or live in rural ({Akinlotan 2023}) or remote areas ({Hill 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExpanded practice autonomy for dental hygienists has been shown to increase the use of preventive care in dental HPSAs ({Chen 2024}). In contrast, states which grant dental hygienists less autonomy have significantly higher rates of preventable dental-related emergency department visits for rural residents compared to states that allow greater autonomy to dental hygienists ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists have a broader scope of practice than dental hygienists; dental care clinics in states that allow both types of providers can have greater operational efficiency along with the capacity to treat additional patients, especially those without insurance or with public insurance ({Khan 2024}). While the number of states authorizing dental therapists to practice remains limited (only 14 states as of 2024), employing dental therapists in these states reduces disparities in access to dental care for patients living in under-resourced areas ({Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}, {Mertz 2021}). A Tribal health organization in Southwest Alaska established the first dental therapist training program in the U.S., which increased access to oral health care and reduced cavities among local Native children and adults ({Hill 2022a}). Furthermore, most dental therapists trained in this program are members of the community they later serve, improving trust between patients and providers as well as increasing access to care and improving oral health outcomes ({Bianchi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA Minnesota-based study indicates that authorizing dental therapists to treat patients increases access to dental care for adults with low incomes; however, racial and ethnic disparities in oral health care continue, as improvements were among white patients only ({Elani 2022}). However, another study suggests that non-white patients in Minnesota may have a greater intention to return for care by a dental therapist than white patients ({Zhao 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExpanded scope of practice laws for allied dental professionals can support a more diverse dental workforce. Training programs for dental auxiliaries are shorter and more affordable than those to become a dentist, and often meant for local students intending to practice in the area following graduation ({Mertz 2021}). When dental hygienists can provide more complex services (i.e., local anesthesia) at a lesser cost than dentists through expanded scope of practice laws, practices may be more likely to accept patients whose insurance reimburses providers at lower rates, making it easier for patients with Medicaid to locate a provider ({Nasseh 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, more than 74 million people in the U.S. reside in one of approximately 7,400 federally designated dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Khan 2024}); most areas are rural or remote ({Akinlotan 2023}). Newly graduated dentists are less likely to practice in rural areas than urban ones and those who do care for rural communities are approaching retirement age; expanding the scope of practice of allied dental professionals who may be more likely to find rural practice appealing could be one piece of the solution ({Akinlotan 2023}). The Surgeon General\u2019s report on oral health in 2000 called for an improved dental workforce with greater capacity and diversity in provider types to address oral health inequalities across the country ({Mertz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDentists have been supported in their work by dental auxiliaries of various scopes of practice since the 19\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century ({Haden 2001}). However, a formal training program for dental hygienists was not established until 1914 ({Mertz 2021}), followed in 1916 by a law in Connecticut that first described dental hygiene as a practice ({Haden 2001}). Allied dental education programs soon followed in dental schools, technical colleges, and community colleges ({Haden 2001}). By 1951, every state and Washington, D.C. legally recognized dental hygiene practice ({Haden 2001}). To this day, dental hygienists must maintain state-specific licenses which may mean pursuing additional training, as the scope of practice and educational requirements can vary greatly by state ({Chen 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists first began to practice in the U.S. through the federally authorized Alaska Community Health Aide Program in 2003, established by the Alaska Native Tribal Health System ({Simon 2021}). In 2009, Minnesota became the first state to authorize dental therapy practice through legislation as a way to reduce disparities in access to oral care by requiring dental therapists to practice in dental HPSAs ({Khan 2024}, {Mertz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, more than 74 million people in the U.S. reside in one of approximately 7,400 federally designated dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Khan 2024}); most areas are rural or remote ({Akinlotan 2023}). Newly graduated dentists are less likely to practice in rural areas than urban ones and those who do care for rural communities are approaching retirement age; expanding the scope of practice of allied dental professionals who may be more likely to find rural practice appealing could be one piece of the solution ({Akinlotan 2023}). The Surgeon General\u2019s report on oral health in 2000 called for an improved dental workforce with greater capacity and diversity in provider types to address oral health inequalities across the country ({Mertz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDentists have been supported in their work by dental auxiliaries of various scopes of practice since the 19\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century ({Haden 2001}). However, a formal training program for dental hygienists was not established until 1914 ({Mertz 2021}), followed in 1916 by a law in Connecticut that first described dental hygiene as a practice ({Haden 2001}). Allied dental education programs soon followed in dental schools, technical colleges, and community colleges ({Haden 2001}). By 1951, every state and Washington, D.C. legally recognized dental hygiene practice ({Haden 2001}). To this day, dental hygienists must maintain state-specific licenses which may mean pursuing additional training, as the scope of practice and educational requirements can vary greatly by state ({Chen 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists first began to practice in the U.S. through the federally authorized Alaska Community Health Aide Program in 2003, established by the Alaska Native Tribal Health System ({Simon 2021}). In 2009, Minnesota became the first state to authorize dental therapy practice through legislation as a way to reduce disparities in access to oral care by requiring dental therapists to practice in dental HPSAs ({Khan 2024}, {Mertz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that expanding the roles of allied dental professionals increases access to oral health care ({Chen 2024}, {Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}, {Brickle 2023}, {Elani 2022}, {Bailit 2012}, {Galloway 2002}). A number of studies indicate that allied dental professionals trained to perform restorations and other treatments can perform these treatments as well as dentists ({Dyer 2016}, {Phillips 2013}, {Rodriguez 2013b}, {Naughton 2014}, {Bailit 2012}, {Galloway 2002}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which role expansions best increase access to care ({Naughton 2014}, {Dyer 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists provide care with indirect dentist supervision and have been shown to increase access to dental care and reduce cavities, especially via programs for children from families with low incomes ({Bailit 2012}, {Simmer-Beck 2015}) and to increase the use of dental care by white adults with low incomes ({Elani 2022}). Dental therapists are more likely to offer preventive care at the population level (often treating a large number of patients at a school or community-based event) than dentists ({Hill 2022a}). In Minnesota, dental therapists are required to care for under-resourced populations, supporting greater access to oral health care in rural and metropolitan areas ({Blue 2016}) and expanded access to primary dental care for all ages ({Brickle 2023}). Authorizing and employing dental therapists in Minnesota increased access to preventive, diagnostic, restorative, and oral surgery services ({Khan 2024}, {Hill 2022a}) and allowed dentists to take on more complex, generally adult cases ({Khan 2024}), while maintaining a high quality of dental health care and patient satisfaction ({Zhao 2024}). In Alaska Native communities, oral health care by dental therapists contributed to reduced rates of emergency department visits for dental care by children and adults; however, overall rates are still high ({Chi 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFollowing expanded autonomy at the state level for dental hygienists, the use of preventive dental care such as cleanings, exams, and fluoride applications has been shown to increase in dental health provider shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Chen 2024}). Dental hygienists who serve in community settings under policies that support a broad scope of practice (i.e., direct access policies) also appear to increase access to care for older adults, individuals with special needs, children, individuals who are minoritized by society, and rural populations ({Naughton 2014}). An Oregon-based evaluation of a state-approved dental pilot project for children from families with low incomes suggests that Expanded Practice Dental Hygienists (EPDHs) located at school dental clinics or in community settings may improve children\u2019s oral health status, including reduced cavities, and may increase parents\u2019 satisfaction with their children\u2019s dental care ({Kohli 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudies have shown that dentists generally have positive attitudes towards extended scope of practice regulations for dental auxiliaries ({Reinder 2017}). By delegating preventive care and less complicated procedures to allied dental providers within their practice, dentists have additional time to perform complex procedures ({Reinder 2017}). Patients report satisfaction with care provided by dental auxiliaries ({Dyer 2016}), including dental therapists ({Zhao 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEvidence regarding the effect of expanded function allied dental professionals on private practice income is mixed ({Bailit 2012}, {Beazoglou 2012a}, {Beazoglou 2012b}, {Galloway 2002}); financial effect appears to depend on the functions performed, office composition, and caseload ({Rodriguez 2013b}, {Beazoglou 2012b}). Analysis of dental therapists in Minnesota with expanded scopes of practice reveal significant returns on investments, beyond that of dentists; return on investment by dentists can initially increase after adding dental therapists to a practice ({Khan 2024}). Studies in New Zealand, Australia, and Canada suggest that dental therapists can be cost effective, particularly when treating children ({Friedman 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInsurance reimbursement policies may not support expansion of auxiliary roles; for example, as of 2021, dental hygienists may be directly reimbursed as Medicaid providers in only 19 states ({ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement}). Yet, when dental hygienists can provide more complex services (i.e., local anesthesia) at a lesser cost than dentists through expanded scope of practice laws, practices may be more likely to accept patients enrolled in Medicaid whose insurance reimburses providers at lower rates ({Nasseh 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts recommend that additional evaluation of dental therapy education and implementation of dental therapy practice is needed to inform policy decisions regarding expanded scope of practice at both the state and federal levels ({Hill 2022a}, {Luo 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that expanding the roles of allied dental professionals increases access to oral health care ({Chen 2024}, {Hill 2022a}, {Khan 2024}, {Brickle 2023}, {Elani 2022}, {Bailit 2012}, {Galloway 2002}). A number of studies indicate that allied dental professionals trained to perform restorations and other treatments can perform these treatments as well as dentists ({Dyer 2016}, {Phillips 2013}, {Rodriguez 2013b}, {Naughton 2014}, {Bailit 2012}, {Galloway 2002}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which role expansions best increase access to care ({Naughton 2014}, {Dyer 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDental therapists provide care with indirect dentist supervision and have been shown to increase access to dental care and reduce cavities, especially via programs for children from families with low incomes ({Bailit 2012}, {Simmer-Beck 2015}) and to increase the use of dental care by white adults with low incomes ({Elani 2022}). Dental therapists are more likely to offer preventive care at the population level (often treating a large number of patients at a school or community-based event) than dentists ({Hill 2022a}). In Minnesota, dental therapists are required to care for under-resourced populations, supporting greater access to oral health care in rural and metropolitan areas ({Blue 2016}) and expanded access to primary dental care for all ages ({Brickle 2023}). Authorizing and employing dental therapists in Minnesota increased access to preventive, diagnostic, restorative, and oral surgery services ({Khan 2024}, {Hill 2022a}) and allowed dentists to take on more complex, generally adult cases ({Khan 2024}), while maintaining a high quality of dental health care and patient satisfaction ({Zhao 2024}). In Alaska Native communities, oral health care by dental therapists contributed to reduced rates of emergency department visits for dental care by children and adults; however, overall rates are still high ({Chi 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFollowing expanded autonomy at the state level for dental hygienists, the use of preventive dental care such as cleanings, exams, and fluoride applications has been shown to increase in dental health provider shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Chen 2024}). Dental hygienists who serve in community settings under policies that support a broad scope of practice (i.e., direct access policies) also appear to increase access to care for older adults, individuals with special needs, children, individuals who are minoritized by society, and rural populations ({Naughton 2014}). An Oregon-based evaluation of a state-approved dental pilot project for children from families with low incomes suggests that Expanded Practice Dental Hygienists (EPDHs) located at school dental clinics or in community settings may improve children\u2019s oral health status, including reduced cavities, and may increase parents\u2019 satisfaction with their children\u2019s dental care ({Kohli 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudies have shown that dentists generally have positive attitudes towards extended scope of practice regulations for dental auxiliaries ({Reinder 2017}). By delegating preventive care and less complicated procedures to allied dental providers within their practice, dentists have additional time to perform complex procedures ({Reinder 2017}). Patients report satisfaction with care provided by dental auxiliaries ({Dyer 2016}), including dental therapists ({Zhao 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEvidence regarding the effect of expanded function allied dental professionals on private practice income is mixed ({Bailit 2012}, {Beazoglou 2012a}, {Beazoglou 2012b}, {Galloway 2002}); financial effect appears to depend on the functions performed, office composition, and caseload ({Rodriguez 2013b}, {Beazoglou 2012b}). Analysis of dental therapists in Minnesota with expanded scopes of practice reveal significant returns on investments, beyond that of dentists; return on investment by dentists can initially increase after adding dental therapists to a practice ({Khan 2024}). Studies in New Zealand, Australia, and Canada suggest that dental therapists can be cost effective, particularly when treating children ({Friedman 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInsurance reimbursement policies may not support expansion of auxiliary roles; for example, as of 2021, dental hygienists may be directly reimbursed as Medicaid providers in only 19 states ({ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement}). Yet, when dental hygienists can provide more complex services (i.e., local anesthesia) at a lesser cost than dentists through expanded scope of practice laws, practices may be more likely to accept patients enrolled in Medicaid whose insurance reimburses providers at lower rates ({Nasseh 2024}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts recommend that additional evaluation of dental therapy education and implementation of dental therapy practice is needed to inform policy decisions regarding expanded scope of practice at both the state and federal levels ({Hill 2022a}, {Luo 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMany states have revised or considered revising their allied dental professional scope of practice laws in the last decade; minimum educational requirements, manner of supervision by dentists, and billing options continue to limit where dental auxiliaries may practice ({Simon 2021}). As of 2021, 42 states allow dental hygienists to initiate patient care outside of traditional dental offices, without the presence of a dentist ({ADHA-Direct access}). As of 2024, 19 states allow dental hygienists to receive direct reimbursement for care provided to Medicaid eligible patients ({ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement}) and only eight states explicitly bar independent practice ({NCSL-Direct access}). Kansas, Maine, Minnesota, South Carolina, and Vermont expanded dental hygienists\u2019 scope of practice to include risk assessments, the placement of basic tooth restorations, sealant applications, supervision of dental assistants, and the ability to maintain independent dental hygiene practices in communities with limited access to dental care, along with care in public health settings ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, Alaska Native communities in the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta region of Southwest Alaska ({Hill 2022a}) along with 14 states (Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Idaho, Michigan, Minnesota, Maine, New Mexico, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin) have authorized dental therapists to practice in some or all settings (i.e., traditional dental offices and clinics, schools, mobile clinics, or nursing homes) ({ADTA-Dental therapist}, {NPDT}). As of July 2023, in Minnesota, 141 licensed dental therapists and 99 certified advanced dental therapists offer oral health care services in under-resourced areas across the state ({Brickle 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMany states have revised or considered revising their allied dental professional scope of practice laws in the last decade; minimum educational requirements, manner of supervision by dentists, and billing options continue to limit where dental auxiliaries may practice ({Simon 2021}). As of 2021, 42 states allow dental hygienists to initiate patient care outside of traditional dental offices, without the presence of a dentist ({ADHA-Direct access}). As of 2024, 19 states allow dental hygienists to receive direct reimbursement for care provided to Medicaid eligible patients ({ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement}) and only eight states explicitly bar independent practice ({NCSL-Direct access}). Kansas, Maine, Minnesota, South Carolina, and Vermont expanded dental hygienists\u2019 scope of practice to include risk assessments, the placement of basic tooth restorations, sealant applications, supervision of dental assistants, and the ability to maintain independent dental hygiene practices in communities with limited access to dental care, along with care in public health settings ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, Alaska Native communities in the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta region of Southwest Alaska ({Hill 2022a}) along with 14 states (Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Idaho, Michigan, Minnesota, Maine, New Mexico, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin) have authorized dental therapists to practice in some or all settings (i.e., traditional dental offices and clinics, schools, mobile clinics, or nursing homes) ({ADTA-Dental therapist}, {NPDT}). As of July 2023, in Minnesota, 141 licensed dental therapists and 99 certified advanced dental therapists offer oral health care services in under-resourced areas across the state ({Brickle 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":37,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased availability of health professionals in underserved areas","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased availability of health professionals in underserved areas\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced cavities","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced cavities\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased patient satisfaction","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient satisfaction\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased access to oral health care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to oral health care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["ADTA-Dental therapist","Pew-Expand dental","CHAWI-Dental therapy","ME-Ch 575 2014","MDH-DT and ADT","ADHA-Dental hygiene programs"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022ADTA-Dental therapist\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215192\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022ADTA-Dental therapist\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022American Dental Therapy Association (ADTA). American Journal of Public Health. 2014;104(6):1005-1009.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/ajph.aphapublications.org\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.2105\\\/AJPH.2014.301895\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-08-23\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215197\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022ADHA-Medicaid reimbursement\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022American Dental Hygienists\u0026rsquo; Association (ADHA).\u0026nbsp;(n.d.). \u003Cem\u003EScope of practice:\u003C\\\/em\u003E \u003Cem\u003EMedicaid reimbursement.\u003C\\\/em\u003E Retrieved October 22, 2024.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.adha.org\\\/advocacy\\\/scope-of-practice\\\/direct-access\\\/reimbursement\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-10-23\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Nasseh 2024\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215203\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Nasseh 2024\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Nasseh,\u0026nbsp;K.,\u0026nbsp;Bowblis,\u0026nbsp;J. A survey of dental therapists\u0026rsquo; practice patterns and training in Minnesota. \u003Cem\u003EThe Journal of the American Dental Association\u003C\\\/em\u003E, \u003Cem\u003E152\u003C\\\/em\u003E(10), 813\u0026ndash;821.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1016\\\/j.adaj.2021.05.004\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-10-23\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Simon 2021\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215183\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Simon 2021\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Simon, L., Donoff, R. B., \u0026amp; Friedland, B. (2021). 351"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"3a2437b7-d0c1-4367-8268-c6c2a69751ff","meta":{"target_revision_id":11308,"drupal_internal__target_id":6300}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"7e1ea8d2-3217-4754-97ee-97cd2050cfb4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3552}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"0a6d3d5c-74e8-4789-b84e-3f17219a9a18","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3555}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1351"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"172251c5-2560-4d8e-8da4-d7b1183d07df","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1581}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1355}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1350}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/
