m","id":"a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1352,"drupal_internal__vid":1352,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Community health workers","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:31+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Community health workers | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Engage professional or lay health workers to provide education, referral and follow-up, case management, home visiting, etc. for those who experience barriers in accessing health care; also called promotoras(es) de salud or community health representatives"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/community-health-workers"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Engage professional or lay health workers to provide education, referral and follow-up, case management, home visiting, etc. for those who experience barriers in accessing health care; also called promotoras(es) de salud or community health representatives"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Home,Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Child \u0026 family well-being,Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/community-health-workers","pid":1587,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-02-06","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your community employ CHWs, either working independently or as part of interdisciplinary health care teams?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are CHWs recruited to programs? Are community members involved in selecting CHWs and developing the programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre partnerships in place, such as between academic institutions, non-profits, health care systems, and community-based organizations to sustain and evolve programs based on community needs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs sustainable funding available to train and employ CHWs? What steps can programs take to secure long-term funding?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supervision and supports are available to CHWs working in your community, to help them address challenges and develop professionally?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there groups who might benefit from CHW services in your community who are not currently receiving them? (For example, individuals leaving incarceration, immigrants, or others who commonly experience barriers to accessing health care and social services.)\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EDoes your community employ CHWs, either working independently or as part of interdisciplinary health care teams?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are CHWs recruited to programs? Are community members involved in selecting CHWs and developing the programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre partnerships in place, such as between academic institutions, non-profits, health care systems, and community-based organizations to sustain and evolve programs based on community needs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs sustainable funding available to train and employ CHWs? What steps can programs take to secure long-term funding?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supervision and supports are available to CHWs working in your community, to help them address challenges and develop professionally?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there groups who might benefit from CHW services in your community who are not currently receiving them? (For example, individuals leaving incarceration, immigrants, or others who commonly experience barriers to accessing health care and social services.)\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence community health workers (CHWs) decrease disparities in health outcomes and access to care for individuals from minority groups and in communities with fewer resources, enhancing health equity ({Scott 2018}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {Kim 2016}, {Franklin 2015}, {CG-CVD 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW interventions can improve access to care for patients that may not otherwise receive care including women ({Andrews 2004}) and older adults from ethnic minority populations ({Bellhouse 2018}, {Verhagen 2014}). CHW interventions are usually focused on improving health and well-being among those communities and individuals who are members of minority groups, socially or economically marginalized, or who face geographic, language, or other barriers to accessing care ({Scott 2018}, {Olaniran 2017}). CHW interventions have been shown to be effective among Blacks ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}, {Andrews 2004}), Hispanics ({Verhagen 2014}), Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders ({Islam 2015}), and the effects of CHW interventions are stronger when the CHW and patients have the same racial or ethnic background ({Wells 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHWs hired locally and with training in cultural sensitivity can improve the effectiveness of primary care teams treating individuals with chronic illness ({Franklin 2015}) and act as a bridge between individuals and the medical system ({Trump 2017}). Successfully integrating CHWs onto interdisciplinary primary care teams can improve access to care and outcomes for diseases such as diabetes and asthma and reduce health disparities ({Franklin 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that CHWs who are members of the community they serve can enhance the cultural relevance of public health efforts in addition to providing bilingual support ({Schroeder 2018}). In Native communities, Native community health workers may increase access to care, including cancer screening and maternal and child health services, and promote positive mental health outcomes, increased economic self-determination, and sovereignty ({O\u2019Keefe 2021}). In general, CHW interventions can support individuals\u2019 positive mental health outcomes and reduce disparities in access to high-quality mental health services, though CHWs\u2019 scope of care in the U.S. could be expanded to include evidence-based counseling therapies, as in low- and middle-income countries ({Barnett 2018}). Experts suggest the role and function of CHWs can strengthen health systems and support providing care that is equitable and affordably increases access to more comprehensive care and services ({Scott 2018}, {McCollum 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe median annual wage for CHWs is lower than other occupations and turnover rates are higher, likely due to low wages, lack of professional and organizational recognition, and short-term grant funding typical of CHW programs ({Jones 2022a}). The majority of CHWs in the U.S. are women, and wage disparities associated with sex, race, and ethnicity influence conditions for CHWs ({Jones 2022a}). State models for certification may decrease turnover among CHWs who are male and non-white, but in general, wage increases among CHWs appear to be higher for those who are male, white, and employed as CHWs part-time, compared with CHWs who are female, non-white, and full time ({Jones 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence community health workers (CHWs) decrease disparities in health outcomes and access to care for individuals from minority groups and in communities with fewer resources, enhancing health equity ({Scott 2018}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {Kim 2016}, {Franklin 2015}, {CG-CVD 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW interventions can improve access to care for patients that may not otherwise receive care including women ({Andrews 2004}) and older adults from ethnic minority populations ({Bellhouse 2018}, {Verhagen 2014}). CHW interventions are usually focused on improving health and well-being among those communities and individuals who are members of minority groups, socially or economically marginalized, or who face geographic, language, or other barriers to accessing care ({Scott 2018}, {Olaniran 2017}). CHW interventions have been shown to be effective among Blacks ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}, {Andrews 2004}), Hispanics ({Verhagen 2014}), Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders ({Islam 2015}), and the effects of CHW interventions are stronger when the CHW and patients have the same racial or ethnic background ({Wells 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHWs hired locally and with training in cultural sensitivity can improve the effectiveness of primary care teams treating individuals with chronic illness ({Franklin 2015}) and act as a bridge between individuals and the medical system ({Trump 2017}). Successfully integrating CHWs onto interdisciplinary primary care teams can improve access to care and outcomes for diseases such as diabetes and asthma and reduce health disparities ({Franklin 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that CHWs who are members of the community they serve can enhance the cultural relevance of public health efforts in addition to providing bilingual support ({Schroeder 2018}). In Native communities, Native community health workers may increase access to care, including cancer screening and maternal and child health services, and promote positive mental health outcomes, increased economic self-determination, and sovereignty ({O\u2019Keefe 2021}). In general, CHW interventions can support individuals\u2019 positive mental health outcomes and reduce disparities in access to high-quality mental health services, though CHWs\u2019 scope of care in the U.S. could be expanded to include evidence-based counseling therapies, as in low- and middle-income countries ({Barnett 2018}). Experts suggest the role and function of CHWs can strengthen health systems and support providing care that is equitable and affordably increases access to more comprehensive care and services ({Scott 2018}, {McCollum 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe median annual wage for CHWs is lower than other occupations and turnover rates are higher, likely due to low wages, lack of professional and organizational recognition, and short-term grant funding typical of CHW programs ({Jones 2022a}). The majority of CHWs in the U.S. are women, and wage disparities associated with sex, race, and ethnicity influence conditions for CHWs ({Jones 2022a}). State models for certification may decrease turnover among CHWs who are male and non-white, but in general, wage increases among CHWs appear to be higher for those who are male, white, and employed as CHWs part-time, compared with CHWs who are female, non-white, and full time ({Jones 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ECommunities have long recognized individuals not trained in clinical or Western medicine as providers of essential health services. Roles closer to modern community health workers evolved as physician training and healthcare became more formalized, leaving some communities without access to more modern healthcare services. For example, in China from the 1920s to the 1970s, individuals from varied backgrounds combined traditional practices with short-term formal medical training to provide health education, vaccinations, and basic medical care in rural villages, as well as collecting health data ({Perry 2014b}). Similar programs became popular throughout Asia and Latin America, with the World Health Organization promoting the approach in the 1970s; however, program challenges related to funding, continuing education, and recognition of CHWs in health systems, as well as significant global political and economic crises, meant that many countries were forced to end their CHW programs ({Perry 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW programs in the U.S. were also designed to expand access to care for communities geographically distant from or unfairly excluded from mainstream health care because of race, ethnicity, or poverty ({Perry 2014b}). Such programs became more popular in the 1960s and 1970s as part of social justice movements, with CHWs typically being members of the community where they work, based on the belief that community members are best positioned to understand their community and to evaluate its needs and identify solutions ({NACHW-Mason 2021}). Some programs called workers \u0026ldquo;neighborhood health aides\u0026rdquo; and focused on promoting health and well-being among migrant farmworkers, Native individuals, those experiencing poverty, and other groups ({Urban-Bovbjerg 2013a}). CHWs in the U.S. have always provided a broad range of services, such as disease prevention and management, including to those with illnesses marginalized or stigmatized by mainstream health care such as HIV\/AIDS, maternal and child health services, mental health support, and community advocacy ({NACHW-Mason 2021}). Though programs in the U.S. faced challenges in the 1980s and 1990s, similar to programs globally, more recently CHWs have received increased government recognition and funding ({Shah 2014}). In 2009, the Bureau of Labor Statistics created an occupational classification for CHWs, and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) in 2010 provided significant funding to grow CHW programs ({Shah 2014}, {RHIhub-CHW (Topics Page-FAQ) 2021}). The U.S. Department of Labor recognizes CHWs as health professionals providing cost-effective care within health systems ({RHIhub-CHW (Topics Page-FAQ) 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ECommunities have long recognized individuals not trained in clinical or Western medicine as providers of essential health services. Roles closer to modern community health workers evolved as physician training and healthcare became more formalized, leaving some communities without access to more modern healthcare services. For example, in China from the 1920s to the 1970s, individuals from varied backgrounds combined traditional practices with short-term formal medical training to provide health education, vaccinations, and basic medical care in rural villages, as well as collecting health data ({Perry 2014b}). Similar programs became popular throughout Asia and Latin America, with the World Health Organization promoting the approach in the 1970s; however, program challenges related to funding, continuing education, and recognition of CHWs in health systems, as well as significant global political and economic crises, meant that many countries were forced to end their CHW programs ({Perry 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW programs in the U.S. were also designed to expand access to care for communities geographically distant from or unfairly excluded from mainstream health care because of race, ethnicity, or poverty ({Perry 2014b}). Such programs became more popular in the 1960s and 1970s as part of social justice movements, with CHWs typically being members of the community where they work, based on the belief that community members are best positioned to understand their community and to evaluate its needs and identify solutions ({NACHW-Mason 2021}). Some programs called workers \u201cneighborhood health aides\u201d and focused on promoting health and well-being among migrant farmworkers, Native individuals, those experiencing poverty, and other groups ({Urban-Bovbjerg 2013a}). CHWs in the U.S. have always provided a broad range of services, such as disease prevention and management, including to those with illnesses marginalized or stigmatized by mainstream health care such as HIV\/AIDS, maternal and child health services, mental health support, and community advocacy ({NACHW-Mason 2021}). Though programs in the U.S. faced challenges in the 1980s and 1990s, similar to programs globally, more recently CHWs have received increased government recognition and funding ({Shah 2014}). In 2009, the Bureau of Labor Statistics created an occupational classification for CHWs, and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) in 2010 provided significant funding to grow CHW programs ({Shah 2014}, {RHIhub-CHW (Topics Page-FAQ) 2021}). The U.S. Department of Labor recognizes CHWs as health professionals providing cost-effective care within health systems ({RHIhub-CHW (Topics Page-FAQ) 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that community health workers (CHWs) improve access to health care and increase patient knowledge and healthy behaviors ({Scott 2018}). Health effects appear strongest for preventive care interventions focused on cardiovascular disease ({CG-CVD 2015}), diabetes ({CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {Trump 2017}), and health behaviors such as screening for cancer or other diseases ({Scott 2018}, {Kim 2016}). CHW interventions can improve health among individuals from minority groups and in communities with fewer resources, reducing disparities in health outcomes and enhancing health equity ({Scott 2018}, {Barnett 2018}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {CG-CVD 2015}). However, effects vary by program and context, and additional evidence is needed to confirm which interventions are most effective for specific conditions ({Scott 2018}, {Bellhouse 2018}, {Barnett 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW interventions can help reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) ({CG-CVD 2015}, {Kim 2016}). Interventions that engage CHWs as part of team-based care improve blood pressure and cholesterol in patients at increased risk for CVD. When engaged as health educators and outreach, enrollment, and information agents, CHWs appear to increase healthy behaviors in patients at increased risk for CVD and may also help reduce CVD-related morbidity and mortality ({CG-CVD 2015}). For patients with diabetes, CHW interventions can improve glycemic and lipid control and reduce healthcare use ({CG-Diabetes Management 2017}), and may improve diabetes-related self-management behaviors, knowledge, and self-efficacy ({Trump 2017}), including among Latino patients ({Little 2014}). A Pennsylvania-based study suggests CHW support can improve chronic disease control, including clinical outcomes related to diabetes, obesity, and smoking, among Black individuals living with multiple chronic diseases and experiencing poverty, as well as improve mental health and quality of care and reduce hospital admissions ({Kangovi 2017}). In some instances, CHWs can increase physical activity among those at risk for or diagnosed with chronic disease ({Costa 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBy reaching and mobilizing populations within their communities, CHWs have been shown to improve access to care for patients that may not otherwise receive care ({Andrews 2004}), such as older adults from ethnic minority populations ({Verhagen 2014}) or with complex health conditions ({Kennedy 2021}). CHWs can also increase screenings for cancer, such as for colorectal cancer, mammograms, and pap testing for cervical cancer ({Scott 2018}, {Bellhouse 2018}, {Kim 2016}), including among women from ethnic minority groups, such as Korean American and Vietnamese American women ({Bellhouse 2018}), women who are recent immigrants ({Choi 2016}), and older Latina women who do not have health insurance and are earning lower incomes ({Savas 2021}). CHWs can also improve access to high-quality mental health services, though their scope of care is more limited in the U.S. than in lower-income countries ({Barnett 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHWs can provide a range of maternal and child health services, often as part of home visiting programs ({Scharff 2022}). Community health workers appear to enhance access to pre- and post-natal care ({Scharff 2022}, {AZ DHS-Health Start 2021}, {Andrews 2004}), can increase breastfeeding initiation and exclusivity among women with lower incomes and Black women ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}, {Andrews 2004}), and may decrease the severity of postpartum depression symptoms ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}). CHWs can increase childhood immunization rates ({Wightman 2022}, {Cochrane-Lewin 2010}) and improve TB treatment outcomes ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}). CHW interventions may also reduce symptoms and urgent care use among children with chronic conditions ({Raphael 2013}). CHW interventions addressing childhood obesity, most commonly through health behavior education or counseling, may modestly decrease BMI and may help reduce disparities between communities with less resources and those with more; experts note promising practices include programs delivered in a group setting, to parents and children ({Schroeder 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA U.S.-based model, Transitions Clinic Network, supports individuals that are returning to the community from incarceration by including CHWs on teams providing primary, behavioral, and mental health care, as well as social support. This model may reduce individuals\u2019 hospitalizations, in amount and duration, as well as parole and probation violations ({Wang 2019a}), and has the potential to reduce criminal justice system costs and produce $2.55 in state savings per dollar invested ({Harvey 2022}). Pairing registered nurses and CHWs may increase latent tuberculosis infection treatment completion rates among adults experiencing homelessness, especially those age 50 or older ({Nyamathi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest establishing a comprehensive policy for formalization of CHW roles that incorporates occupational regulation ({CDC-CHW 2015}), a more defined scope of practice ({Allen 2015}, {Pittman 2015}, {CDC-CHW 2015}), and more standardized workforce training ({CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}), job titling ({Islam 2015}) and certification ({CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}). Some experts caution that required or voluntary certification may make it harder for organizations to recruit or retain CHWs, though certification can increase CHWs\u2019 professional legitimacy ({NACHW-Mason 2021}), may increase wages, and is required by some insurers, such as Medicaid, for reimbursement ({Jones 2022a}). In some states, training must be led or co-led by an experienced CHW ({NACHW-Mason 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESuccessful CHW programs have high-quality supervision that is supportive rather than punitive, provide regular logistical support such as with supplies and transportation, and involve communities in decisions about CHW hiring and activities. Community participation can increase their sense of ownership, trust, and acceptance of CHW efforts, which is associated with positive outcomes such as CHW retention, performance, and effectiveness ({Scott 2018}). CHWs have strong affiliations with the communities and individuals they serve and programs should anticipate and help CHWs navigate possible tension if the priorities of the health system or CHW employer compete with local priorities ({Scott 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhen integrating CHWs into primary care, teams often include CHWs along with nurses, physicians, and dieticians, while broader teams may include staff such as social workers or traditional healers ({Franklin 2015}). Experts suggest the most effective teams have a shared understanding of roles, norms, values, and goals; practice egalitarianism, with patients and families\u2019 preferences respected; cooperate, recognizing all members\u2019 contributions; work interdependently; and demonstrate synergy, meaning the patient outcome was better than if they had not been treated using a team approach ({Franklin 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts also stress the importance of identifying sustainable funding mechanisms for CHW services ({Allen 2015}, {CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}), such as Medicaid payment, which is more sustainable than short-term grant funding ({Jones 2022a}, {CDC-CHW 2015}). Cost analyses suggest that integrating CHWs into the health care system can be cost-effective for certain conditions ({Scott 2018}, {Kim 2016}). CHW interventions for cardiovascular disease prevention and diabetes management ({CG-CVD 2015}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}) and to promote cervical and colorectal cancer screening appear to be cost-effective. In urban U.S. settings, CHW interventions which increase colorectal cancer screening may be associated with net savings in healthcare costs ({CG-Attipoe-Dorcoo 2021}), and the IMPaCT intervention, in which CHWs support individuals living with chronic disease, is estimated to return $2.00 for every dollar invested, through reductions in hospitalization ({Kangovi 2017}). A Detroit-based study of CHWs funded through Medicaid finds that CHWs can reduce ER use and increase outpatient care among Medicaid recipients, offsetting cost savings in the short term; however, increased outpatient care among individuals who underuse such care could contribute to cost savings in the long-term ({Heisler 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that community health workers (CHWs) improve access to health care and increase patient knowledge and healthy behaviors ({Scott 2018}). Health effects appear strongest for preventive care interventions focused on cardiovascular disease ({CG-CVD 2015}), diabetes ({CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {Trump 2017}), and health behaviors such as screening for cancer or other diseases ({Scott 2018}, {Kim 2016}). CHW interventions can improve health among individuals from minority groups and in communities with fewer resources, reducing disparities in health outcomes and enhancing health equity ({Scott 2018}, {Barnett 2018}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}, {CG-CVD 2015}). However, effects vary by program and context, and additional evidence is needed to confirm which interventions are most effective for specific conditions ({Scott 2018}, {Bellhouse 2018}, {Barnett 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW interventions can help reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) ({CG-CVD 2015}, {Kim 2016}). Interventions that engage CHWs as part of team-based care improve blood pressure and cholesterol in patients at increased risk for CVD. When engaged as health educators and outreach, enrollment, and information agents, CHWs appear to increase healthy behaviors in patients at increased risk for CVD and may also help reduce CVD-related morbidity and mortality ({CG-CVD 2015}). For patients with diabetes, CHW interventions can improve glycemic and lipid control and reduce healthcare use ({CG-Diabetes Management 2017}), and may improve diabetes-related self-management behaviors, knowledge, and self-efficacy ({Trump 2017}), including among Latino patients ({Little 2014}). A Pennsylvania-based study suggests CHW support can improve chronic disease control, including clinical outcomes related to diabetes, obesity, and smoking, among Black individuals living with multiple chronic diseases and experiencing poverty, as well as improve mental health and quality of care and reduce hospital admissions ({Kangovi 2017}). In some instances, CHWs can increase physical activity among those at risk for or diagnosed with chronic disease ({Costa 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBy reaching and mobilizing populations within their communities, CHWs have been shown to improve access to care for patients that may not otherwise receive care ({Andrews 2004}), such as older adults from ethnic minority populations ({Verhagen 2014}) or with complex health conditions ({Kennedy 2021}). CHWs can also increase screenings for cancer, such as for colorectal cancer, mammograms, and pap testing for cervical cancer ({Scott 2018}, {Bellhouse 2018}, {Kim 2016}), including among women from ethnic minority groups, such as Korean American and Vietnamese American women ({Bellhouse 2018}), women who are recent immigrants ({Choi 2016}), and older Latina women who do not have health insurance and are earning lower incomes ({Savas 2021}). CHWs can also improve access to high-quality mental health services, though their scope of care is more limited in the U.S. than in lower-income countries ({Barnett 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHWs can provide a range of maternal and child health services, often as part of home visiting programs ({Scharff 2022}). Community health workers appear to enhance access to pre- and post-natal care ({Scharff 2022}, {AZ DHS-Health Start 2021}, {Andrews 2004}), can increase breastfeeding initiation and exclusivity among women with lower incomes and Black women ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}, {Andrews 2004}), and may decrease the severity of postpartum depression symptoms ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}). CHWs can increase childhood immunization rates ({Wightman 2022}, {Cochrane-Lewin 2010}) and improve TB treatment outcomes ({Cochrane-Lewin 2010}). CHW interventions may also reduce symptoms and urgent care use among children with chronic conditions ({Raphael 2013}). CHW interventions addressing childhood obesity, most commonly through health behavior education or counseling, may modestly decrease BMI and may help reduce disparities between communities with less resources and those with more; experts note promising practices include programs delivered in a group setting, to parents and children ({Schroeder 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA U.S.-based model, Transitions Clinic Network, supports individuals that are returning to the community from incarceration by including CHWs on teams providing primary, behavioral, and mental health care, as well as social support. This model may reduce individuals\u2019 hospitalizations, in amount and duration, as well as parole and probation violations ({Wang 2019a}), and has the potential to reduce criminal justice system costs and produce $2.55 in state savings per dollar invested ({Harvey 2022}). Pairing registered nurses and CHWs may increase latent tuberculosis infection treatment completion rates among adults experiencing homelessness, especially those age 50 or older ({Nyamathi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest establishing a comprehensive policy for formalization of CHW roles that incorporates occupational regulation ({CDC-CHW 2015}), a more defined scope of practice ({Allen 2015}, {Pittman 2015}, {CDC-CHW 2015}), and more standardized workforce training ({CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}), job titling ({Islam 2015}) and certification ({CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}). Some experts caution that required or voluntary certification may make it harder for organizations to recruit or retain CHWs, though certification can increase CHWs\u2019 professional legitimacy ({NACHW-Mason 2021}), may increase wages, and is required by some insurers, such as Medicaid, for reimbursement ({Jones 2022a}). In some states, training must be led or co-led by an experienced CHW ({NACHW-Mason 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESuccessful CHW programs have high-quality supervision that is supportive rather than punitive, provide regular logistical support such as with supplies and transportation, and involve communities in decisions about CHW hiring and activities. Community participation can increase their sense of ownership, trust, and acceptance of CHW efforts, which is associated with positive outcomes such as CHW retention, performance, and effectiveness ({Scott 2018}). CHWs have strong affiliations with the communities and individuals they serve and programs should anticipate and help CHWs navigate possible tension if the priorities of the health system or CHW employer compete with local priorities ({Scott 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhen integrating CHWs into primary care, teams often include CHWs along with nurses, physicians, and dieticians, while broader teams may include staff such as social workers or traditional healers ({Franklin 2015}). Experts suggest the most effective teams have a shared understanding of roles, norms, values, and goals; practice egalitarianism, with patients and families\u2019 preferences respected; cooperate, recognizing all members\u2019 contributions; work interdependently; and demonstrate synergy, meaning the patient outcome was better than if they had not been treated using a team approach ({Franklin 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts also stress the importance of identifying sustainable funding mechanisms for CHW services ({Allen 2015}, {CDC-CHW 2015}, {Pittman 2015}), such as Medicaid payment, which is more sustainable than short-term grant funding ({Jones 2022a}, {CDC-CHW 2015}). Cost analyses suggest that integrating CHWs into the health care system can be cost-effective for certain conditions ({Scott 2018}, {Kim 2016}). CHW interventions for cardiovascular disease prevention and diabetes management ({CG-CVD 2015}, {CG-Diabetes Management 2017}) and to promote cervical and colorectal cancer screening appear to be cost-effective. In urban U.S. settings, CHW interventions which increase colorectal cancer screening may be associated with net savings in healthcare costs ({CG-Attipoe-Dorcoo 2021}), and the IMPaCT intervention, in which CHWs support individuals living with chronic disease, is estimated to return $2.00 for every dollar invested, through reductions in hospitalization ({Kangovi 2017}). A Detroit-based study of CHWs funded through Medicaid finds that CHWs can reduce ER use and increase outpatient care among Medicaid recipients, offsetting cost savings in the short term; however, increased outpatient care among individuals who underuse such care could contribute to cost savings in the long-term ({Heisler 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ECommunity health workers (CHWs) practice across the country, providing a variety of services in diverse settings. As of 2021, states with the highest concentration of CHWs are Alaska, Kentucky, New Mexico, New York, and Washington ({US BLS-CHWs 2021}). Most states have some statewide definitions, standards, and policies for CHWs and as of 2020, 18 states have statewide certification, either required ({Barbero 2021}) or using a voluntary certification process ({CDC-CHW Certification}). CHW organizations, consisting of mostly CHW members, exist in 31 states and can be strong advocates for the CHW workforce, including in certification decisions ({Barbero 2021}). As of July 2022, Medicaid payment for some CHW services or for specific populations is authorized in at least 29 states ({KFF-Haldar 2023}). The non-profit MHP Salud develops CHW programs across the U.S. which focus on Hispanic and Latino communities and maintains a directory of states\u2019 CHW organizations, multi-stakeholder coalitions, and certification programs ({MHP Salud-CHW National}). Very few states routinely monitor statewide employer readiness or CHW employment, as recommended by experts ({Barbero 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2022, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) awarded $225.5 million in American Rescue Plan funding to support CHW training; grantees include organizations in rural areas and Hawaii, and the Northwest Portland Area Indian Health Board ({US DHHS-Expand CHW}). The CDC initiative Community Health Workers for COVID Response and Resilient Communities (CCR) began in 2021 and provides three years of financial support and technical assistance to states, localities, territories, tribes, and more to increase the number of CHWs in communities experiencing the most severe impacts of COVID-19 and communities with a long history of health disparities ({CDC-CHW CCR}). The Envision Equity multi-state partnership of CHWs and allies provides training and technical support to CCR grantees ({Envision Equity}). National Institutes of Health also has a CHW Health Disparities Initiative focused on reducing racial disparities in heart disease, with resources for CHW training, network-building, and evaluation ({NIH-CHW Health Disparities}). Transitions Clinic Network (TCN) is a national network of primary care facilities supporting individuals returning to the community from incarceration; the network includes 14 states and Puerto Rico ({TCN-Home}). The TCN model includes hiring and training CHWs with lived experience of incarceration to play a key role on care teams ({TCN-CHWs}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA variety of CHW programs provide important care across the rural U.S. ({RHIhub-CHW Innovation}). Examples include Kentucky Homeplace, a CHW program serving counties in eastern Kentucky since 1994 and managed by the University of Kentucky College of Medicine ({UK-KY Homeplace}). Kentucky Homeplace CHWs can provide health education, referrals, and advocacy, and assistance arranging transportation ({UK-KY Homeplace}). To ensure health services reach Native communities in rural Alaska, the state\u2019s Health Aide model blends Western and traditional health practice and provides training and certification for behavioral, community, and dental health aides with a greater scope of care than CHWs, with required oversight by a licensed clinician ({AK CHAP-About}). Arizona\u2019s long-running Health Start program employs CHWs in several counties and focuses on pre- and post-natal referral, education, and advocacy services for families with children up to age two ({NAU-Health Start}, {Strong Families AZ-Health Start}). The Arizona Community Health Workers Association (AzCHOW) aims to include CHWs in the field\u2019s policy decisions and guides development of training programs, including for CHWs to receive voluntary certification ({AzCHOW}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW programs can use emerging technology to enhance training and CHW outreach. The University of New Mexico\u2019s Project ECHO uses the ECHO model to facilitate training CHWs as part of multi-disciplinary care teams, using in-person and virtual formats to present cases and offer peer support ({UNM-CHW ECHO}). Medical professionals from the University of Michigan, and a community advisory board including local health department staff and CHWs, developed an oral health e-learning module that is now part of the state\u2019s standard CHW certification and training materials ({Lapidos 2022}). In Oregon, federally-qualified health care center One Community Health partnered with De Las M\u0026iacute;as, a digital platform and app designed for and by Latinas to support health and well-being, to add a CHW interface. CHWs from One Community Health will combine in-person engagement with the evidence-based technology ({OCH-De Las Mias}). The University of Pennsylvania\u2019s IMPaCT Community program assists health care organizations in developing a CHW workforce, including offering technology such as decision support tools and analytics ({Penn-IMPaCT}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ECommunity health workers (CHWs) practice across the country, providing a variety of services in diverse settings. As of 2021, states with the highest concentration of CHWs are Alaska, Kentucky, New Mexico, New York, and Washington ({US BLS-CHWs 2021}). Most states have some statewide definitions, standards, and policies for CHWs and as of 2020, 18 states have statewide certification, either required ({Barbero 2021}) or using a voluntary certification process ({CDC-CHW Certification}). CHW organizations, consisting of mostly CHW members, exist in 31 states and can be strong advocates for the CHW workforce, including in certification decisions ({Barbero 2021}). As of July 2022, Medicaid payment for some CHW services or for specific populations is authorized in at least 29 states ({KFF-Haldar 2023}). The non-profit MHP Salud develops CHW programs across the U.S. which focus on Hispanic and Latino communities and maintains a directory of states\u2019 CHW organizations, multi-stakeholder coalitions, and certification programs ({MHP Salud-CHW National}). Very few states routinely monitor statewide employer readiness or CHW employment, as recommended by experts ({Barbero 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2022, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) awarded $225.5 million in American Rescue Plan funding to support CHW training; grantees include organizations in rural areas and Hawaii, and the Northwest Portland Area Indian Health Board ({US DHHS-Expand CHW}). The CDC initiative Community Health Workers for COVID Response and Resilient Communities (CCR) began in 2021 and provides three years of financial support and technical assistance to states, localities, territories, tribes, and more to increase the number of CHWs in communities experiencing the most severe impacts of COVID-19 and communities with a long history of health disparities ({CDC-CHW CCR}). The Envision Equity multi-state partnership of CHWs and allies provides training and technical support to CCR grantees ({Envision Equity}). National Institutes of Health also has a CHW Health Disparities Initiative focused on reducing racial disparities in heart disease, with resources for CHW training, network-building, and evaluation ({NIH-CHW Health Disparities}). Transitions Clinic Network (TCN) is a national network of primary care facilities supporting individuals returning to the community from incarceration; the network includes 14 states and Puerto Rico ({TCN-Home}). The TCN model includes hiring and training CHWs with lived experience of incarceration to play a key role on care teams ({TCN-CHWs}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA variety of CHW programs provide important care across the rural U.S. ({RHIhub-CHW Innovation}). Examples include Kentucky Homeplace, a CHW program serving counties in eastern Kentucky since 1994 and managed by the University of Kentucky College of Medicine ({UK-KY Homeplace}). Kentucky Homeplace CHWs can provide health education, referrals, and advocacy, and assistance arranging transportation ({UK-KY Homeplace}). To ensure health services reach Native communities in rural Alaska, the state\u2019s Health Aide model blends Western and traditional health practice and provides training and certification for behavioral, community, and dental health aides with a greater scope of care than CHWs, with required oversight by a licensed clinician ({AK CHAP-About}). Arizona\u2019s long-running Health Start program employs CHWs in several counties and focuses on pre- and post-natal referral, education, and advocacy services for families with children up to age two ({NAU-Health Start}, {Strong Families AZ-Health Start}). The Arizona Community Health Workers Association (AzCHOW) aims to include CHWs in the field\u2019s policy decisions and guides development of training programs, including for CHWs to receive voluntary certification ({AzCHOW}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECHW programs can use emerging technology to enhance training and CHW outreach. The University of New Mexico\u2019s Project ECHO uses the ECHO model to facilitate training CHWs as part of multi-disciplinary care teams, using in-person and virtual formats to present cases and offer peer support ({UNM-CHW ECHO}). Medical professionals from the University of Michigan, and a community advisory board including local health department staff and CHWs, developed an oral health e-learning module that is now part of the state\u2019s standard CHW certification and training materials ({Lapidos 2022}). In Oregon, federally-qualified health care center One Community Health partnered with De Las M\u00edas, a digital platform and app designed for and by Latinas to support health and well-being, to add a CHW interface. CHWs from One Community Health will combine in-person engagement with the evidence-based technology ({OCH-De Las Mias}). The University of Pennsylvania\u2019s IMPaCT Community program assists health care organizations in developing a CHW workforce, including offering technology such as decision support tools and analytics ({Penn-IMPaCT}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":38,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased breastfeeding rates","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased breastfeeding rates\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased patient knowledge","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient knowledge\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased access to care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased healthy behaviors","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased healthy behaviors\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased preventive care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased preventive care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CDC-CHW Toolkit","NASHP-CHW Models","CHW Central","RHIhub-CHW","RHIhub-CHW Innovation","Georgetown-Scott 2008","NACHW-DRC"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Child \u0026 family well-being,Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Home,Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CDC-CHW Toolkit\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002211958\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CDC-CHW Toolkit\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). experience barriers in accessing health care; also called promotoras(es) de salud or community health representatives\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"6421c7b2-7014-440e-9db3-ddcef2347c45","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3635}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"185d395a-df3d-4aa8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"a638af05-06d6-46ce-b490-25e18d55c91f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":21}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"9c091979-5739-4910-9ff2-1518c33bd741","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":24}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--disparity_ratings","id":"37e6c336-4955-4db7-8a11-5f9dfe2f44ba","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3651}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_e 4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1352"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1353,"drupal_internal__vid":1353,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Federally qualified health centers (FQHCs)","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:31+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Increase support for non-profit health care organizations and deliver comprehensive care to uninsured, underinsured, and vulnerable patients regardless of ability to pay; often called community health centers (CHCs)"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/federally-qualified-health-centers-fqhcs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Increase support for non-profit health care organizations and deliver comprehensive care to uninsured, underinsured, and vulnerable patients regardless of ability to pay; often called community health centers (CHCs)"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/federally-qualified-health-centers-fqhcs","pid":1588,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-12-18","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community advocate to increase state-level and health system-level commitments to provide care to underserved populations, including through FQHCs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there areas in your community that are not designated as a Health Provider Shortage Areas (HPSA) or Medically Underserved Areas (MUA) that meet the criteria? What organizations could you partner with to open an FQHC and support their application for the MUA and\/or HPSA designation(s)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat organizations could you collaborate with to improve access to services provided at FQHCs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community advocate to increase state-level and health system-level commitments to provide care to underserved populations, including through FQHCs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there areas in your community that are not designated as a Health Provider Shortage Areas (HPSA) or Medically Underserved Areas (MUA) that meet the criteria? What organizations could you partner with to open an FQHC and support their application for the MUA and\/or HPSA designation(s)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat organizations could you collaborate with to improve access to services provided at FQHCs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) have the potential to decrease disparities in access to primary care health services for people with low incomes, people of color, and people without health insurance ({Urban-Saloner 2014}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}, {Hicks 2006}, {Lee 2023}, {Shi 2013},{Gresenz 2006}, {Shi 2007}, {Shi 2007a}, {Cunningham 2004}, {Bodenheimer 2010}), as well as improve health outcomes ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Wright 2015}, {Hicks 2006}, {Lee 2023}, {Goldman 2012}, {Bodenheimer 2010}). By serving uninsured, underinsured, and other vulnerable patients, FQHCs provide care to those who may previously have had little or no opportunity to receive regular, non-emergency care ({Bodenheimer 2010}, {Starfield 2005}, {Siegel 2004}). Additional research is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatients living near a FQHC or similar safety net provider may be more likely to seek health services ({Lee 2023}), including uninsured children ({Gresenz 2006}). FQHCs may be more likely to provide appointments to Medicaid patients than non-FQHCS ({Urban-Saloner 2014}). FQHCs may reduce low birth weight births among populations with low incomes, populations of color, and in rural areas ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Starfield 2005}, {Siegel 2004}). FQHCs appear to decrease hospitalizations due to ambulatory care-sensitive conditions among patients who are Black and Hispanic ({Wright 2015}), and for Medicaid and Medicare eligible Black patients ({Wright 2017b}). FQHCs decrease disparities in the quality of care for chronic diseases, such as hypertension and asthma, among populations with low incomes and populations of color ({Hicks 2006}, {Goldman 2012}). For mental health care, expanding the intensity of services available, versus increasing the number of patients that can be served, may be more effective at reducing emergency department use for psychiatric care among Black youth ({Bruckner 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENew FQHCs and FQHC sites that opened after the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) were more likely to be in Medically Underserved Areas (MUAs) with higher rates of poverty, uninsurance, and residents of color ({Behr 2022}), but not in rural areas ({Behr 2022}, {Chang 2019}). However, these expanded locations did not improve access for individuals who may experience cultural or language barriers ({Evans 2022}). Experts recommend expanding FQHCs in MUAs and Health Professional Shortage Areas (HPSAs) in small towns, metro areas, and formerly redlined sections of urban cities to increase to access of care ({Lee 2023}, {Xue 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs may increase availability of providers in underserved areas, such as HPSAs ({Xue 2018}). States with higher rates of explicit and implicit racial bias appear to have fewer FQHCs and fewer qualifying areas acknowledged as HPSAs. These findings suggest there are fewer opportunities of care for those served by FQHCs, and more barriers to identifying treatment needs of Black patients and patients with low incomes ({Snowden 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) have the potential to decrease disparities in access to primary care health services for people with low incomes, people of color, and people without health insurance ({Urban-Saloner 2014}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}, {Hicks 2006}, {Lee 2023}, {Shi 2013},{Gresenz 2006}, {Shi 2007}, {Shi 2007a}, {Cunningham 2004}, {Bodenheimer 2010}), as well as improve health outcomes ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Wright 2015}, {Hicks 2006}, {Lee 2023}, {Goldman 2012}, {Bodenheimer 2010}). By serving uninsured, underinsured, and other vulnerable patients, FQHCs provide care to those who may previously have had little or no opportunity to receive regular, non-emergency care ({Bodenheimer 2010}, {Starfield 2005}, {Siegel 2004}). Additional research is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatients living near a FQHC or similar safety net provider may be more likely to seek health services ({Lee 2023}), including uninsured children ({Gresenz 2006}). FQHCs may be more likely to provide appointments to Medicaid patients than non-FQHCS ({Urban-Saloner 2014}). FQHCs may reduce low birth weight births among populations with low incomes, populations of color, and in rural areas ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Starfield 2005}, {Siegel 2004}). FQHCs appear to decrease hospitalizations due to ambulatory care-sensitive conditions among patients who are Black and Hispanic ({Wright 2015}), and for Medicaid and Medicare eligible Black patients ({Wright 2017b}). FQHCs decrease disparities in the quality of care for chronic diseases, such as hypertension and asthma, among populations with low incomes and populations of color ({Hicks 2006}, {Goldman 2012}). For mental health care, expanding the intensity of services available, versus increasing the number of patients that can be served, may be more effective at reducing emergency department use for psychiatric care among Black youth ({Bruckner 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENew FQHCs and FQHC sites that opened after the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) were more likely to be in Medically Underserved Areas (MUAs) with higher rates of poverty, uninsurance, and residents of color ({Behr 2022}), but not in rural areas ({Behr 2022}, {Chang 2019}). However, these expanded locations did not improve access for individuals who may experience cultural or language barriers ({Evans 2022}). Experts recommend expanding FQHCs in MUAs and Health Professional Shortage Areas (HPSAs) in small towns, metro areas, and formerly redlined sections of urban cities to increase to access of care ({Lee 2023}, {Xue 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs may increase availability of providers in underserved areas, such as HPSAs ({Xue 2018}). States with higher rates of explicit and implicit racial bias appear to have fewer FQHCs and fewer qualifying areas acknowledged as HPSAs. These findings suggest there are fewer opportunities of care for those served by FQHCs, and more barriers to identifying treatment needs of Black patients and patients with low incomes ({Snowden 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal Housing Administration\u2019s redlining practices entrenched racial residential segregation in the U.S. and resulted in fewer health care facilities, resources, and funding in urban areas with largely Black populations ({Lee 2023}, {Lee 2022c}). Past residential redlining and present-day disparities in access to health care are associated with delays in disease diagnosis and treatment of health conditions, fewer preventive health visits, shortages of behavioral health clinicians, and larger Medicaid or uninsured populations in neighborhoods that are primarily Black and low income ({Lee 2023}). Formerly redlined neighborhoods are more likely to be near man-made environmental hazards producing pollution or toxins, and have older homes in poor condition containing health hazards such as lead paint and mold ({Braveman 2022}). Residents of redlined neighborhoods continue to experience worse health outcomes, such as increased likelihood of preterm birth and a higher prevalence of asthma, heat-related conditions, and chronic diseases like diabetes ({Lee 2022c}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECommunity Health Centers (CHCs), forerunners of federally qualified health centers (FQHCs), were established in 1965 as part of the War on Poverty to provide primary preventive care to medically underserved communities, including families with low incomes, people without health insurance, migrants, and those experiencing homelessness ({NBER-Kose 2022}). The CHC program was formalized by Congress in 1975; Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act required them to serve medically underserved areas (MUAs) ({NBER-Kose 2022}). In 1989, in response to low Medicaid reimbursement rates in some states, the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act created FQHCs and changed financing and reimbursement options ({NBER-Kose 2022}). Ongoing federal support, including initiatives in the 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, the 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA), and financial incentives for services provided to Medicare and Medicaid patients, has supported expansion ({Chang 2019}). The ACA expanded Medicaid eligibility and increased federal funding of section 330 of the Public Health Service Act, the two largest sources of funding for FQHCs ({Lyu 2023}, {Han 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal Housing Administration\u2019s redlining practices entrenched racial residential segregation in the U.S. and resulted in fewer health care facilities, resources, and funding in urban areas with largely Black populations ({Lee 2023}, {Lee 2022c}). Past residential redlining and present-day disparities in access to health care are associated with delays in disease diagnosis and treatment of health conditions, fewer preventive health visits, shortages of behavioral health clinicians, and larger Medicaid or uninsured populations in neighborhoods that are primarily Black and low income ({Lee 2023}). Formerly redlined neighborhoods are more likely to be near man-made environmental hazards producing pollution or toxins, and have older homes in poor condition containing health hazards such as lead paint and mold ({Braveman 2022}). Residents of redlined neighborhoods continue to experience worse health outcomes, such as increased likelihood of preterm birth and a higher prevalence of asthma, heat-related conditions, and chronic diseases like diabetes ({Lee 2022c}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECommunity Health Centers (CHCs), forerunners of federally qualified health centers (FQHCs), were established in 1965 as part of the War on Poverty to provide primary preventive care to medically underserved communities, including families with low incomes, people without health insurance, migrants, and those experiencing homelessness ({NBER-Kose 2022}). The CHC program was formalized by Congress in 1975; Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act required them to serve medically underserved areas (MUAs) ({NBER-Kose 2022}). In 1989, in response to low Medicaid reimbursement rates in some states, the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act created FQHCs and changed financing and reimbursement options ({NBER-Kose 2022}). Ongoing federal support, including initiatives in the 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, the 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA), and financial incentives for services provided to Medicare and Medicaid patients, has supported expansion ({Chang 2019}). The ACA expanded Medicaid eligibility and increased federal funding of section 330 of the Public Health Service Act, the two largest sources of funding for FQHCs ({Lyu 2023}, {Han 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) increase access to primary care ({Urban-Saloner 2014}, {Shi 2013}, {Lo Sasso 2010}, {Siegel 2004}, {Gresenz 2006}, {Bodenheimer 2010}, {Hicks 2006}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}, {Lee 2023}, {Cunningham 2004}, {Shi 2007}, {Shi 2007a}) and improve health outcomes for their patients ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Meredith 2016}, {Wright 2015}, {Ross 2012}, {Lee 2023}, {Goldman 2012}, {Bodenheimer 2010}, {Hicks 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs have been shown to perform as well as or better than non-safety net providers on measures of quality and access to care, such as continuity of care and delivery of preventive services ({Shi 2013}, {Shi 2012}, {Goldman 2012}, {Hicks 2006}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}), particularly for children ({Gresenz 2006}) and Medicare patients ({Lavelle 2018}, {Ross 2012}). FQHCs may improve access to oral health care ({Jones 2013}) and appear to provide effective care for PTSD ({Meredith 2016}). They may increase prenatal care and smoking cessation in pregnant women, and reduce low birthweight births ({NBER-Kose 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECenters with medical training programs may improve some patient outcomes, including hypertension, cancer screenings and immunizations ({Choi 2023}), and FQHCs with community health worker and patient navigator programs increase cancer screenings in medically underserved populations ({Roland 2017}). FQHCs that become advanced primary care practices (APCPs) or that adopt principles of the patient centered medical home may further improve health and health care ({RAND-Kahn 2015}, {Calman 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs in states that expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) increased patient volumes, increased Medicaid coverage among patients, and reduced numbers of patients without insurance ({Cole 2018}, {Cole 2017}, {Han 2017}). Expanded Medicaid funding was associated with more clinic visits, including preventative and mental health visits ({Han 2017}) and, in rural FQHCs, improved quality of care and increased service provision ({Cole 2018}). States that expanded dental benefits increased the number of dental visits ({Lyu 2023}). Additionally, states that expanded Medicaid were more likely to have new FQHCs open in medically underserved areas with higher rates of poverty, uninsurance, and residents of color ({Behr 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatients who receive most of their ambulatory care at community health centers such as FQHCs have lower overall medical expenditures than those who receive care elsewhere ({Richard 2012}), and many patients continue to use FQHCs even after obtaining insurance ({Ku 2011}). FQHCs may be more likely than other providers to offer appointments outside standard business hours (i.e. early or late appointments, on weekends), behavioral health services including providing medication-assisted treatment for opioid use, and screen patients for social and financial needs ({Lewis 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInvestments in community health centers have been shown to reduce costs for local health care systems and provide economic benefits for surrounding communities ({Rothkopf 2011}, {Dor 2009}, {Shi 2007a}, {NACHC-Primary care 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) increase access to primary care ({Urban-Saloner 2014}, {Shi 2013}, {Lo Sasso 2010}, {Siegel 2004}, {Gresenz 2006}, {Bodenheimer 2010}, {Hicks 2006}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}, {Lee 2023}, {Cunningham 2004}, {Shi 2007}, {Shi 2007a}) and improve health outcomes for their patients ({NBER-Kose 2022}, {Meredith 2016}, {Wright 2015}, {Ross 2012}, {Lee 2023}, {Goldman 2012}, {Bodenheimer 2010}, {Hicks 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs have been shown to perform as well as or better than non-safety net providers on measures of quality and access to care, such as continuity of care and delivery of preventive services ({Shi 2013}, {Shi 2012}, {Goldman 2012}, {Hicks 2006}, {O\u2019Malley 2005}), particularly for children ({Gresenz 2006}) and Medicare patients ({Lavelle 2018}, {Ross 2012}). FQHCs may improve access to oral health care ({Jones 2013}) and appear to provide effective care for PTSD ({Meredith 2016}). They may increase prenatal care and smoking cessation in pregnant women, and reduce low birthweight births ({NBER-Kose 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECenters with medical training programs may improve some patient outcomes, including hypertension, cancer screenings and immunizations ({Choi 2023}), and FQHCs with community health worker and patient navigator programs increase cancer screenings in medically underserved populations ({Roland 2017}). FQHCs that become advanced primary care practices (APCPs) or that adopt principles of the patient centered medical home may further improve health and health care ({RAND-Kahn 2015}, {Calman 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs in states that expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) increased patient volumes, increased Medicaid coverage among patients, and reduced numbers of patients without insurance ({Cole 2018}, {Cole 2017}, {Han 2017}). Expanded Medicaid funding was associated with more clinic visits, including preventative and mental health visits ({Han 2017}) and, in rural FQHCs, improved quality of care and increased service provision ({Cole 2018}). States that expanded dental benefits increased the number of dental visits ({Lyu 2023}). Additionally, states that expanded Medicaid were more likely to have new FQHCs open in medically underserved areas with higher rates of poverty, uninsurance, and residents of color ({Behr 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatients who receive most of their ambulatory care at community health centers such as FQHCs have lower overall medical expenditures than those who receive care elsewhere ({Richard 2012}), and many patients continue to use FQHCs even after obtaining insurance ({Ku 2011}). FQHCs may be more likely than other providers to offer appointments outside standard business hours (i.e. early or late appointments, on weekends), behavioral health services including providing medication-assisted treatment for opioid use, and screen patients for social and financial needs ({Lewis 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInvestments in community health centers have been shown to reduce costs for local health care systems and provide economic benefits for surrounding communities ({Rothkopf 2011}, {Dor 2009}, {Shi 2007a}, {NACHC-Primary care 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 2022, there were 1,373 federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) operating more than 15,000 service sites in the United States and its territories. These FQHCs served 30.5 million patients through over 126 million patient visits ({HRSA-FQHC Trends 2022}). As of 2019, more than 91% of FQHC patients reported incomes below 200% of the federal poverty level. Furthermore, 48% of patients were enrolled in Medicaid, 23% were uninsured, and 63% of patients receiving care at FQHCs were from racial\/ethnic minority groups. Yet, there are still many medically underserved areas (MUAs) that do not have any FQHCs.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs are primarily funded through the federal Community Health Center Fund and Medicaid reimbursements ({CWF-Horstman 2023}). However, federal funding does not appear to have kept up with market forces and inflation ({NACHC-Community Health Center Funding 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 2022, there were 1,373 federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) operating more than 15,000 service sites in the United States and its territories. These FQHCs served 30.5 million patients through over 126 million patient visits ({HRSA-FQHC Trends 2022}). As of 2019, more than 91% of FQHC patients reported incomes below 200% of the federal poverty level. Furthermore, 48% of patients were enrolled in Medicaid, 23% were uninsured, and 63% of patients receiving care at FQHCs were from racial\/ethnic minority groups. Yet, there are still many medically underserved areas (MUAs) that do not have any FQHCs.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFQHCs are primarily funded through the federal Community Health Center Fund and Medicaid reimbursements ({CWF-Horstman 2023}). However, federal funding does not appear to have kept up with market forces and inflation ({NACHC-Community Health Center Funding 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":39,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased continuity of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased continuity of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased access to oral health care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to oral health care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased access to health care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to health care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["HRSA-Health centers","RHIhub-FQHCs","CiMH-Jarvis 2011","NCIOM"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022HRSA-Health centers\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222628\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022HRSA-Health centers\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). Pediatrics. 2006;117(3):e509-17.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/pediatrics.aappublications.org\\\/content\\\/117\\\/3\\\/e509\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Bodenheimer 2010\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222101\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Bodenheimer 2010\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Bodenheimer T, Pham HH. Health Affairs. 2010;29(5):799-805.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.healthaffairs.org\\\/doi\\\/full\\\/10.1377\\\/hlthaff.2010.0026?url_ver=Z39.88-2003\u0026rfr_id=ori:rid:crossref.org\u0026rfr_dat=cr_pub%3dpubmed\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Hicks 2006\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222099\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Hicks 2006\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Hicks LS, O\\u2019Malley AJ, Lieu TA, et al. Health Affairs. 2012;31(8):1739-1748.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.healthaffairs.org\\\/doi\\\/full\\\/10.1377\\\/hlthaff.2011.1028\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-10\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Goldman 2012\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222095\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Goldman 2012\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Goldman LE, Chu PW, Tran H, Romano MJ, Stafford RS. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2012;43(2):142-9.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.ajpmonline.org\\\/article\\\/S0749-3797(12)00287-5\\\/abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-08\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Shi 2012\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222691\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Shi 2012\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Shi L, Lebrun LA, Zhu J, et al.
