Health Services Research. 2012;47(6):2225-2249.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1111\\\/j.1475-6773.2012.01418.x\\\/abstract;jsessionid=D2B387546C24FC6BB94F80E77548A21C.d02t03?deniedAccessCustomisedMessage=\u0026userIsAuthenticated=false\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-10\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Lavelle 2018\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213654\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Lavelle 2018\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Lavelle TA, Rose AJ, Timbie JW, et al. a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"eef4c54c-a13c-4b5e-bf48-05ff2e2d9d2f","meta":{"target_revision_id":11310,"drupal_internal__target_id":6302}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"cbd9a012-996b-4ba5-a3d6-02d78e250003","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3542}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"21038cae-21fd-4ae4-8bfe-79df6e1b8190","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":54}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"0a6d3d5c-74e8-4789-b84e-3f17219a9a18","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3555}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"b2b44f94-2b31-4017-8464-003db8d2bbb1","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1742}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"35673ae4-a78f-4908-8fbb-057d40d86d10","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1733}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"af38f3f7-9ef9-4871-a855-0323e6f545b3","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1710}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"01593356-ed9b-4b16-889b-c2189e79d1da","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1672}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7cefc1a5-58ac-4973-9b96-042955140e54","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1650}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"514d5583-fad1-4002-b180-4ff72ccd63d6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1649}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"14ca1cf1-eb53-4a88-9485-64680be04dbc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1641}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a7d63553-397d-48c8-955b-a178f35adaa6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1595}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"fe5561a0-607d-40f6-81c7-ef2979967a66","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1593}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1356}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1354}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a9df4083-d708-447d-b467-e8cd5e1004cc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1352}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1353"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/kl homes","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:31+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Medical homes | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Provide continuous, comprehensive, whole person primary care that uses a coordinated team of medical providers across the health care system"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/medical-homes"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Provide continuous, comprehensive, whole person primary care that uses a coordinated team of medical providers across the health care system"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/medical-homes","pid":1589,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-05-16","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that medical homes improve quality of health care and access to care ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Olayiwola 2017}, {Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Rosenthal 2008}, {Homer 2008}, {Hoff 2013}), and increase the use of preventive services\u0026nbsp;compared to traditional care ({Sinaiko 2017}, {Olayiwola 2017}, {Hadland 2014}, {Jackson 2013}, {Alexander 2012}). Medical homes reduce preventable emergency room visits ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Hadland 2014}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Chin 2009}, {Diedhiou 2010}, {Hoff 2013}) and hospitalizations ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Hoff 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes increase continuity of care ({van Walraven 2010}), use of evidence-based medicine ({Homer 2008}), and patient and family participation in care ({Rosenthal 2008}, {Homer 2008}). Medical homes improve adherence to treatment ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}), increase general preventive screenings such as cholesterol and blood pressure checks ({Hoff 2013}), increase screening for cervical cancer and breast cancer, and reduce specialist visits ({Sinaiko 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes appear to increase patient satisfaction ({Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}) and can reduce provider burnout ({Hoff 2013}). In some circumstances, medical homes may allow patients to access care more quickly and easily than traditional care models ({Homer 2008}, {Christensen 2013}, {Kern 2013}) and may reduce unmet medical needs ({Strickland 2011}, {O\u2019Malley 2012}, {Bennedict 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEffects appear strongest for children with special health care needs ({Homer 2008}) and individuals with chronic conditions such as diabetes or mental illness ({Amiel 2011}). Medical homes improve chronic disease management ({Hoff 2013}), including diabetes care ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}). Medical homes can also reduce emergency visits for asthmatic individuals ({Chin 2009}, {Diedhiou 2010}), Latinos and Vietnamese with mental illness ({Olayiwola 2017}), and children insured by Medicaid ({Christensen 2015}). Healthy children with medical homes are more likely to receive preventive care and developmental screenings, experience a greater health-related quality of life, and are less likely to seek care at the emergency department than children who receive traditional care ({Hadland 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch on primary care transformation indicates that practices becoming medical homes should first build a relationship-centered workplace with shared leadership and time for group planning. Then, rather than incremental change or following top-down directives, practices should pursue group-directed, whole-system transformation ({Crabtree 2011}, {Nutting 2009}). Practices should also help doctors develop the skills for team-based care and expect a change process up to three years long ({Nutting 2009}). Survey results suggest that joining learning collaboratives ({McMullen 2013}) and hiring care coordinators ({McAllister 2013}) may help ease the transformation process.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes can yield cost savings over traditional care in some circumstances ({Homer 2008}, {Rosenthal 2008}), but not in others ({Hoff 2013}, {Jackson 2013}). Most state medical home initiatives have been associated with increased quality and reduced costs ({Takach 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes have been shown to improve health disparities related to race, income, gender, and age ({Olayiwola 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that medical homes improve quality of health care and access to care ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Olayiwola 2017}, {Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Rosenthal 2008}, {Homer 2008}, {Hoff 2013}), and increase the use of preventive services\u0026nbsp;compared to traditional care ({Sinaiko 2017}, {Olayiwola 2017}, {Hadland 2014}, {Jackson 2013}, {Alexander 2012}). Medical homes reduce preventable emergency room visits ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Hadland 2014}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Chin 2009}, {Diedhiou 2010}, {Hoff 2013}) and hospitalizations ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}, {Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}, {Hoff 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes increase continuity of care ({van Walraven 2010}), use of evidence-based medicine ({Homer 2008}), and patient and family participation in care ({Rosenthal 2008}, {Homer 2008}). Medical homes improve adherence to treatment ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}), increase general preventive screenings such as cholesterol and blood pressure checks ({Hoff 2013}), increase screening for cervical cancer and breast cancer, and reduce specialist visits ({Sinaiko 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes appear to increase patient satisfaction ({Alexander 2012}, {van Walraven 2010}) and can reduce provider burnout ({Hoff 2013}). In some circumstances, medical homes may allow patients to access care more quickly and easily than traditional care models ({Homer 2008}, {Christensen 2013}, {Kern 2013}) and may reduce unmet medical needs ({Strickland 2011}, {O\u2019Malley 2012}, {Bennedict 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEffects appear strongest for children with special health care needs ({Homer 2008}) and individuals with chronic conditions such as diabetes or mental illness ({Amiel 2011}). Medical homes improve chronic disease management ({Hoff 2013}), including diabetes care ({van den Berk-Clark 2017}). Medical homes can also reduce emergency visits for asthmatic individuals ({Chin 2009}, {Diedhiou 2010}), Latinos and Vietnamese with mental illness ({Olayiwola 2017}), and children insured by Medicaid ({Christensen 2015}). Healthy children with medical homes are more likely to receive preventive care and developmental screenings, experience a greater health-related quality of life, and are less likely to seek care at the emergency department than children who receive traditional care ({Hadland 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch on primary care transformation indicates that practices becoming medical homes should first build a relationship-centered workplace with shared leadership and time for group planning. Then, rather than incremental change or following top-down directives, practices should pursue group-directed, whole-system transformation ({Crabtree 2011}, {Nutting 2009}). Practices should also help doctors develop the skills for team-based care and expect a change process up to three years long ({Nutting 2009}). Survey results suggest that joining learning collaboratives ({McMullen 2013}) and hiring care coordinators ({McAllister 2013}) may help ease the transformation process.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes can yield cost savings over traditional care in some circumstances ({Homer 2008}, {Rosenthal 2008}), but not in others ({Hoff 2013}, {Jackson 2013}). Most state medical home initiatives have been associated with increased quality and reduced costs ({Takach 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMedical homes have been shown to improve health disparities related to race, income, gender, and age ({Olayiwola 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2018, 26 states have enacted changes to increase medical home access for Medicaid recipients ({NASHP-Map}). The National Committee for Quality Assurance\u2019s (NCQA\u2019s) Patient-Centered Medical Home Recognition Program is the most widely used medical home evaluation program in the nation; it has recognized over 12,000 practices with 60,000 clinicians for their commitment to a patient-centered approach to care and quality improvement ({NCQA-PCMH}). The New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) collaborated with NCQA to develop the New York State customized PCMH Recognition Program in support of New York\u2019s dedication to the medical home model ({NCQA-NYS PCHM}). The Veterans Health Administration has utilized a patient-centered medical home model known as Patient Aligned Care Teams (PACT) since 2010 ({Hebert 2014}, {US VA-PACT}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2018, 26 states have enacted changes to increase medical home access for Medicaid recipients ({NASHP-Map}). The National Committee for Quality Assurance\u2019s (NCQA\u2019s) Patient-Centered Medical Home Recognition Program is the most widely used medical home evaluation program in the nation; it has recognized over 12,000 practices with 60,000 clinicians for their commitment to a patient-centered approach to care and quality improvement ({NCQA-PCMH}). The New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) collaborated with NCQA to develop the New York State customized PCMH Recognition Program in support of New York\u2019s dedication to the medical home model ({NCQA-NYS PCHM}). The Veterans Health Administration has utilized a patient-centered medical home model known as Patient Aligned Care Teams (PACT) since 2010 ({Hebert 2014}, {US VA-PACT}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":40,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased continuity of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased continuity of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased patient engagement","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient engagement\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased practice of evidence-based medicine","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased practice of evidence-based medicine\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved care for chronic conditions","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved care for chronic conditions\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced hospital utilization","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced hospital utilization\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased patient satisfaction","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient satisfaction\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased access to care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased preventive care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased preventive care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced emergency room visits","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced emergency room visits\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced hospital utilization","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced hospital utilization\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["PCPCC-PCMH map","AHRQ-PCMH Resources","NCMHI","NCQA-PCMH eligibility","CWF-MH","SNMHI"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022PCPCC-PCMH map\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228447\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022PCPCC-PCMH map\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Patient-Centered Primary Care Collaborative (PCPCC). system\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"bdbfb0c8-7f51-4487-bf38-46fe4e35bd2e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":16}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"185d395a-df3d-4aa8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"9db6427d-c54c-4a80-918d-4a5dd6012582","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":25}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a8585888-f0c9-4a01-a363-a3db7802d4ba\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1354"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"arity":0,"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"arity":1,"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href _related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"31b2abb4-7c68-45c5-84b7-faf7c2698e14","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1736}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"35673ae4-a78f-4908-8fbb-057d40d86d10","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1733}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"af38f3f7-9ef9-4871-a855-0323e6f545b3","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1710}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e922742d-f022-4978-8dbf-60f9dea6e555","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1707}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9e3edf1f-39e6-44ed-8663-4fd44f517126","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1663}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"09f6e4d9-d023-4f80-9e3a-45d953e3eb5c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1656}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7cefc1a5-58ac-4973-9b96-042955140e54","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1650}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"514d5583-fad1-4002-b180-4ff72ccd63d6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1649}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"14ca1cf1-eb53-4a88-9485-64680be04dbc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1641}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a7d63553-397d-48c8-955b-a178f35adaa6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1595}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"fe5561a0-607d-40f6-81c7-ef2979967a66","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1593}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"d5c1861e-a418-4c35-91e2-cf99ee0bbbe3","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1583}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7b127fdb-49cb-437c-ac24-4d7d33f91125","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1531}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"be674d22-d2ac-427f-9edf-841cfd0a15e8","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1382}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1378}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1356}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"2dd417ae-664f-42c7-a0cf-3ec2e95699da","meta":{"drupal_intern dental programs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:31+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"School dental programs | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Provide sealants, fluoride treatment, screening, and other preventive dental care on school grounds via partnerships with dental professionals"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/school-dental-programs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Provide sealants, fluoride treatment, screening, and other preventive dental care on school grounds via partnerships with dental professionals"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/school-dental-programs","pid":1590,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-12-17","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can students and families be involved in decisions surrounding the availability of school dental programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can school dental programs and partners foster trusting relationships between providers and underserved students and families? How can partnerships expand to benefit the students and families via outreach efforts in the broader community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ECan school dental programs offer care beyond the school day to promote parent and guardian involvement in their children\u0026rsquo;s dental care?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional funding streams (e.g., local, state, or federal government; non-profits, private organizations) can school dental program administrators pursue to make programs sustainable and expand services to treat additional students in need? How can program partnerships with dental service providers (e.g., dental schools, dental hygiene or therapy education programs) reduce the cost of care and expand the number of available providers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can students and families be involved in decisions surrounding the availability of school dental programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can school dental programs and partners foster trusting relationships between providers and underserved students and families? How can partnerships expand to benefit the students and families via outreach efforts in the broader community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ECan school dental programs offer care beyond the school day to promote parent and guardian involvement in their children\u2019s dental care?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional funding streams (e.g., local, state, or federal government; non-profits, private organizations) can school dental program administrators pursue to make programs sustainable and expand services to treat additional students in need? How can program partnerships with dental service providers (e.g., dental schools, dental hygiene or therapy education programs) reduce the cost of care and expand the number of available providers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school dental programs have the potential to decrease disparities in access to oral health care when implemented in communities with lower incomes and higher rates of cavities among children ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024a}). For participating students, programs have been shown to reduce cavities, increase the number of dental treatments received, and decrease disparities in tooth decay ({CG-Oral health}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA New York City-based study of school dental clinics in schools primarily treating students from families with low incomes or identifying as Black or Hispanic, found that applying silver diamine fluoride reduces cavities to the same degree as dental sealants and atraumatic restorative treatment ({Ruff 2024a}). A study of school dental programs located across 16 states suggests that use of dental sealants increases when programs are implemented in high-needs schools (i.e., more than half of students participate in free or reduced-price meal programs) ({Patel 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPartnerships between school dental programs and varied types of providers can support access to oral health care for previously underserved children. Partnerships between school dental programs and dental schools appear to increase access to oral health care for children from families with low incomes and support the training of future dentists ({Partido 2021}). Services delivered via school partnerships with mobile dental clinics appear to reduce cavities among children living in under-resourced, rural areas ({Enciso 2015}). Children residing in rural areas often experience poorer oral health and more cavities than children in urban or suburban areas due to lack of access; school dental programs in rural areas have the potential to reduce this disparity by increasing access to providers ({Dawkins 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EChildren and adolescents from families with low incomes are more likely to experience cavities than wealthier peers, which can cause pain, difficulty eating, and infections, and contribute to lower school attendance and lower grades ({Patel 2022a}). While rates of untreated tooth decay have improved over the past 20 years (10% compared to 20%), as of 2023, by the age of 19, 65% of children from families with low incomes have had a cavity, with higher rates for children of Mexican American or American Indian and Alaska Native heritage ({Kumar 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school dental programs have the potential to decrease disparities in access to oral health care when implemented in communities with lower incomes and higher rates of cavities among children ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024a}). For participating students, programs have been shown to reduce cavities, increase the number of dental treatments received, and decrease disparities in tooth decay ({CG-Oral health}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA New York City-based study of school dental clinics in schools primarily treating students from families with low incomes or identifying as Black or Hispanic, found that applying silver diamine fluoride reduces cavities to the same degree as dental sealants and atraumatic restorative treatment ({Ruff 2024a}). A study of school dental programs located across 16 states suggests that use of dental sealants increases when programs are implemented in high-needs schools (i.e., more than half of students participate in free or reduced-price meal programs) ({Patel 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPartnerships between school dental programs and varied types of providers can support access to oral health care for previously underserved children. Partnerships between school dental programs and dental schools appear to increase access to oral health care for children from families with low incomes and support the training of future dentists ({Partido 2021}). Services delivered via school partnerships with mobile dental clinics appear to reduce cavities among children living in under-resourced, rural areas ({Enciso 2015}). Children residing in rural areas often experience poorer oral health and more cavities than children in urban or suburban areas due to lack of access; school dental programs in rural areas have the potential to reduce this disparity by increasing access to providers ({Dawkins 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EChildren and adolescents from families with low incomes are more likely to experience cavities than wealthier peers, which can cause pain, difficulty eating, and infections, and contribute to lower school attendance and lower grades ({Patel 2022a}). While rates of untreated tooth decay have improved over the past 20 years (10% compared to 20%), as of 2023, by the age of 19, 65% of children from families with low incomes have had a cavity, with higher rates for children of Mexican American or American Indian and Alaska Native heritage ({Kumar 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EHealth care options within schools began in the early 1900s with the addition of nurses to treat children\u2019s minor injuries or illnesses emerging during the school day ({Ryst 2021}, {North 2020}), and by 1911, there were 102 cities with nurses in their schools ({North 2020}). Prior to World War I, roughly 70 U.S. cities sponsored school dental clinics, staffed by dentists, offering reparative and restorative care; participating dentists viewed this as a public service commitment and as a way to prevent disease ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}). Free services continued throughout the Great Depression and the number of programs grew even as children\u2019s treatment at private dental clinics declined ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHowever, by the late 1950s, roughly half of school-aged children were being treated approximately once a year by dentists in private practices; school dental programs began to be regarded by dental providers as offering lesser care and more suited to oral health education than oral health treatment ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}). Other oral health improvement efforts, including community water fluoridation, the promotion and acceptance of daily toothbrushing, fluoride toothpaste, and advances in dental treatment and preventive care significantly reduced cavities among children during the second half of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century ({Kumar 2023}). Yet, the use of preventive dental care by children from families with low incomes decreased by roughly 10% from 2016 to 2021 ({CDC-Oral health disparities}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn recent years, some states have established school dental screening laws or school-linked programs as a way to direct children to dental care. Yet, referral tracking systems must be in place to ensure children receive the recommended care. California\u2019s school-based electronic referral management system shows promise ({Kumar 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, more than 74 million people in the U.S. reside in one of approximately 7,400 federally designated dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Khan 2024}); most areas are rural or remote ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EHealth care options within schools began in the early 1900s with the addition of nurses to treat children\u2019s minor injuries or illnesses emerging during the school day ({Ryst 2021}, {North 2020}), and by 1911, there were 102 cities with nurses in their schools ({North 2020}). Prior to World War I, roughly 70 U.S. cities sponsored school dental clinics, staffed by dentists, offering reparative and restorative care; participating dentists viewed this as a public service commitment and as a way to prevent disease ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}). Free services continued throughout the Great Depression and the number of programs grew even as children\u2019s treatment at private dental clinics declined ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHowever, by the late 1950s, roughly half of school-aged children were being treated approximately once a year by dentists in private practices; school dental programs began to be regarded by dental providers as offering lesser care and more suited to oral health education than oral health treatment ({RAND-Schlossman 1986}). Other oral health improvement efforts, including community water fluoridation, the promotion and acceptance of daily toothbrushing, fluoride toothpaste, and advances in dental treatment and preventive care significantly reduced cavities among children during the second half of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century ({Kumar 2023}). Yet, the use of preventive dental care by children from families with low incomes decreased by roughly 10% from 2016 to 2021 ({CDC-Oral health disparities}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn recent years, some states have established school dental screening laws or school-linked programs as a way to direct children to dental care. Yet, referral tracking systems must be in place to ensure children receive the recommended care. California\u2019s school-based electronic referral management system shows promise ({Kumar 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2024, more than 74 million people in the U.S. reside in one of approximately 7,400 federally designated dental health professional shortage areas (HPSAs) ({Khan 2024}); most areas are rural or remote ({Akinlotan 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":0,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school dental programs increase access to oral health care ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024a}) and prevent cavities, especially for children from families with low incomes ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024}, {Ruff 2024a}, {Starr 2021}, {CDC-Gooch 2009}, {Simmer-Beck 2015}, {Carpino 2017}, {Niederman 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESealant programs substantially reduce cavity formation in sound, pitted, and fissured teeth ({Tinanoff 2015}, {CG-Oral health}), especially for children from families with low incomes ({CG-Oral health}, {CG-Griffin 2017}). Effects are strongest when programs seal the newly erupted molars of second and sixth graders ({CDC-Gooch 2009}), treat children with the highest risk of cavity development, and perform services directly in schools rather than at local clinics ({CG-Oral health}). Sealants appear to stay on teeth longer when programs use two-person teams to apply them ({CDC-Gooch 2009}), though additional personnel costs may reduce the number of students a program can serve ({Scherrer 2007}). School dental programs that employ registered nurses to apply fluoride varnishes have been shown to reduce cavities in treated children to the same degree as programs with dental hygienists ({Ruff 2024}). An Oregon-based evaluation of a dental pilot program for children from families with low incomes suggests that preventive dental care provided by dental hygienists at school dental clinics may improve children\u2019s oral health, may reduce cavities, and may increase parents\u2019 satisfaction with their children\u2019s dental care ({Kohli 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFluoride supplements ({Cochrane-Tubert 2011}), toothpastes, mouth rinses, gels, or varnishes also prevent cavities, although students may be most likely to use toothpaste ({Cochrane-Marinho 2015}). Fluoride varnishes and dental sealants prevent cavities when applied to permanent molars ({Cochrane-Kashbour 2020}). Fluoride treatments may increase the risk of fluorosis for children under age six ({Pizzo 2007}, {Prystupa 2011}); additional research is needed regarding potential adverse effects of swallowing fluoride gels ({Cochrane-Marinho 2015}, {Ammari 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based dental programs may reduce costs by performing screenings and applying sealants during the same visit ({CG-Oral health}), and programs serving larger schools can reduce costs by employing an extra assistant and chair so that dentists and hygienists can move from one sterilized station to the next. Reducing supervision requirements for dental hygienists can also reduce the cost of sealant programs in many states ({Scherrer 2007}); school dental programs that employ dental hygienists to assess oral health and apply sealants cost less than programs with dentists in these roles ({CG-Oral health}, {Neidell 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) considers preventively sealing the molars of all children from families with low incomes a cost-effective strategy ({CDC-Gooch 2009}); sealant programs are most cost-effective when focused on children at high risk of developing cavities (i.e., children from families with low incomes, past history of cavities, high sugar diet, enamel defects, etc.) ({Tinanoff 2015}). Overall, school-based sealant programs appear to become cost saving within two ({CG-Oral health}) to four years ({CG-Griffin 2017}). In Connecticut, Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) appear to have saved 50% per dental patient by treating children in their schools rather than in clinics ({Bailit 2012a}). Additional research on barriers to establishing and maintaining sealant programs at schools is needed to improve the long-term sustainability of programs ({Patel 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA national study of school dental programs suggests that partnerships between schools and medical and dental providers can increase students\u2019 participation and that mobile dental units can improve access for students whose working parents are unable to take their children to dental offices ({Patel 2022a}). Services delivered via school partnerships with mobile dental clinics appear to reduce cavities among children living in under-resourced, rural areas ({Enciso 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that school dental programs increase access to oral health care ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024a}) and prevent cavities, especially for children from families with low incomes ({CG-Oral health}, {Ruff 2024}, {Ruff 2024a}, {Starr 2021}, {CDC-Gooch 2009}, {Simmer-Beck 2015}, {Carpino 2017}, {Niederman 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESealant programs substantially reduce cavity formation in sound, pitted, and fissured teeth ({Tinanoff 2015}, {CG-Oral health}), especially for children from families with low incomes ({CG-Oral health}, {CG-Griffin 2017}). Effects are strongest when programs seal the newly erupted molars of second and sixth graders ({CDC-Gooch 2009}), treat children with the highest risk of cavity development, and perform services directly in schools rather than at local clinics ({CG-Oral health}). Sealants appear to stay on teeth longer when programs use two-person teams to apply them ({CDC-Gooch 2009}), though additional personnel costs may reduce the number of students a program can serve ({Scherrer 2007}). School dental programs that employ registered nurses to apply fluoride varnishes have been shown to reduce cavities in treated children to the same degree as programs with dental hygienists ({Ruff 2024}). An Oregon-based evaluation of a dental pilot program for children from families with low incomes suggests that preventive dental care provided by dental hygienists at school dental clinics may improve children\u2019s oral health, may reduce cavities, and may increase parents\u2019 satisfaction with their children\u2019s dental care ({Kohli 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFluoride supplements ({Cochrane-Tubert 2011}), toothpastes, mouth rinses, gels, or varnishes also prevent cavities, although students may be most likely to use toothpaste ({Cochrane-Marinho 2015}). Fluoride varnishes and dental sealants prevent cavities when applied to permanent molars ({Cochrane-Kashbour 2020}). Fluoride treatments may increase the risk of fluorosis for children under age six ({Pizzo 2007}, {Prystupa 2011}); additional research is needed regarding potential adverse effects of swallowing fluoride gels ({Cochrane-Marinho 2015}, {Ammari 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based dental programs may reduce costs by performing screenings and applying sealants during the same visit ({CG-Oral health}), and programs serving larger schools can reduce costs by employing an extra assistant and chair so that dentists and hygienists can move from one sterilized station to the next. Reducing supervision requirements for dental hygienists can also reduce the cost of sealant programs in many states ({Scherrer 2007}); school dental programs that employ dental hygienists to assess oral health and apply sealants cost less than programs with dentists in these roles ({CG-Oral health}, {Neidell 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) considers preventively sealing the molars of all children from families with low incomes a cost-effective strategy ({CDC-Gooch 2009}); sealant programs are most cost-effective when focused on children at high risk of developing cavities (i.e., children from families with low incomes, past history of cavities, high sugar diet, enamel defects, etc.) ({Tinanoff 2015}). Overall, school-based sealant programs appear to become cost saving within two ({CG-Oral health}) to four years ({CG-Griffin 2017}). In Connecticut, Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) appear to have saved 50% per dental patient by treating children in their schools rather than in clinics ({Bailit 2012a}). Additional research on barriers to establishing and maintaining sealant programs at schools is needed to improve the long-term sustainability of programs ({Patel 2022a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA national study of school dental programs suggests that partnerships between schools and medical and dental providers can increase students\u2019 participation and that mobile dental units can improve access for students whose working parents are unable to take their children to dental offices ({Patel 2022a}). Services delivered via school partnerships with mobile dental clinics appear to reduce cavities among children living in under-resourced, rural areas ({Enciso 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ESchool dental programs may be supported by a variety of private and public entities. Boston University, for example, runs school-based oral health programs at 20 schools and 30 preschools in Boston, providing dental screenings, fluoride and sealant applications, and oral health education, along with programs in an additional eight cities in Massachusetts ({Boston School-based dental}). St. David\u2019s Foundation in Central Texas provides dental care at Title 1 elementary schools via one of the largest mobile dental fleets in the country ({St. David\u2019s Dental Program}). Multnomah County, Oregon and DuPage County, Illinois have programs tailored to serve children from families with low incomes ({Multnomah-School oral health}, {DuPage County-Dental health}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe University of Florida College of Dentistry sponsors three types of school dental programs: the Oral Health Surveillance Program provides annual dental screenings for third grade students across Alachua County\u2019s 21 elementary schools and Collier County\u2019s 36 elementary schools; the Alachua County School-Based Dental Sealant Program offers dental sealants to elementary and middle school students, in partnership with the United Way of North Central Florida; and the Head Start Fluoride Varnish Program provides fluoride varnish to attending preschool aged children from families with low incomes ({UF School-based programs}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeal America\u2019s School-Based Dental Sealant Program Training guides school administrators and dental professionals throughout the planning, implementation, and sustainability phases of a school dental sealant program ({Seal America}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ESchool dental programs may be supported by a variety of private and public entities. Boston University, for example, runs school-based oral health programs at 20 schools and 30 preschools in Boston, providing dental screenings, fluoride and sealant applications, and oral health education, along with programs in an additional eight cities in Massachusetts ({Boston School-based dental}). St. David\u2019s Foundation in Central Texas provides dental care at Title 1 elementary schools via one of the largest mobile dental fleets in the country ({St. David\u2019s Dental Program}). Multnomah County, Oregon and DuPage County, Illinois have programs tailored to serve children from families with low incomes ({Multnomah-School oral health}, {DuPage County-Dental health}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe University of Florida College of Dentistry sponsors three types of school dental programs: the Oral Health Surveillance Program provides annual dental screenings for third grade students across Alachua County\u2019s 21 elementary schools and Collier County\u2019s 36 elementary schools; the Alachua County School-Based Dental Sealant Program offers dental sealants to elementary and middle school students, in partnership with the United Way of North Central Florida; and the Head Start Fluoride Varnish Program provides fluoride varnish to attending preschool aged children from families with low incomes ({UF School-based programs}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeal America\u2019s School-Based Dental Sealant Program Training guides school administrators and dental professionals throughout the planning, implementation, and sustainability phases of a school dental sealant program ({Seal America}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":41,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced cavities","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced cavities\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased access to oral health care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to oral health care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CDC-School sealant","CDPH-Children\u2019s dental disease","Seal America","Big Smiles Dental"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CDC-School sealant\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215369\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CDC-School sealant\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Journal of the American Dental Association. 2009;140(11):1356\\u201365.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/jada.ada.org\\\/article\\\/S0002-8177(14)64584-0\\\/abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Simmer-Beck 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226068\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Simmer-Beck 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Simmer-Beck M, Walker M, Gadbury-Amyot C, et al. American Journal of Public Health. 2015;105(9):1763-1769.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/ajph.aphapublications.org\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.2105\\\/AJPH.2015.302714\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Carpino 2017\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227055\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Carpino 2017\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Carpino, R., Walker, M. Evaluation of school-based dental sealant programs: An updated Community Guide systematic economic review. \u003Cem\u003EAmerican Journal of Preventive Medicine, 52\u003C\\\/em\u003E(3), 407\u0026ndash;415.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1016\\\/j.amepre.2016.10.004\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-12-16\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Scherrer 2007\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222169\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Scherrer 2007\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Scherrer CR, Griffin PM, Swann JL. Medical Decision Making. 2007;27(6):762\\u201371.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/mdm.sagepub.com\\\/content\\\/27\\\/6\\\/762.abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Kohli 2022\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215184\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Kohli 2022\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Kohli, R., Clemens, J., Mann, L., Newton, M., Glassman, P., \u0026amp; Schwarz, E. (2022). Training dental hygienists to place interim therapeutic restorations in a school-based teledentistry program: Oregon\u0026rsquo;s virtual dental home. \u003Cem\u003EJournal of Public Health Dentistry\u003C\\\/em\u003E, \u003Cem\u003E82\u003C\\\/em\u003E(2), 229\u0026ndash;238.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1111\\\/jphd.12465\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-10-23\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Cochrane-Tubert 2011\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222168\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Cochrane-Tubert 2011\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Tubert-Jeannin S, Auclair C, Amsallem E, et al. Fluoride supplements (tablets, drops, lozenges or chewing gums) for preventing dental caries in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2011;(12):CD007592.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1002\\\/14651858.CD007592.pub2\\\/abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Cochrane-Marinho 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226059\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Cochrane-Marinho 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Marinho VCC, Worthington HV, Walsh T, Chong LY. Fluoride gels for preventing dental caries in children and adolescents. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2015;(6):CD002280.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1002\\\/14651858.CD002280.pub2\\\/full\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-09-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Cochrane-Kashbour 2020\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226064\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Cochrane-Kashbour 2020\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Kashbour, W., Gupta, P., Worthington, H. V., \u0026amp; Boyers, D. (2020). Pit and fissure sealants versus fluoride varnishes for preventing dental decay in the permanent teeth of children and adolescents. \u003Cem\u003ECochrane Database of Systematic Reviews\u003C\\\/em\u003E, (11), CD003067.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1002\\\/14651858.CD003067.pub5\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-12-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Pizzo 2007\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222170\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Pizzo 2007\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Pizzo G, Piscopo MR, Pizzo I, Giuliana G. Community water fluoridation and caries prevention: A critical review.
