bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"bcb0f898-d665-4233-97a3-1b6352d7436e","meta":{"target_revision_id":11312,"drupal_internal__target_id":6304}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"edcd2c4e-f3bd-4895-9036-f985885fa56b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":59}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"af38f3f7-9ef9-4871-a855-0323e6f545b3","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1710}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"358d2ea5-5e70-46f4-b0e3-671f28f41de9","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1679}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"14ca1cf1-eb53-4a88-9485-64680be04dbc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1641}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"172251c5-2560-4d8e-8da4-d7b1183d07df","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1581}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"944c05e4-433d-448e-97ba-1020af9b5408","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1351}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"c3c7f5ca-c671-4d4e-8360-07bd4a042113","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3853}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"f7e63583-f86d-4749-8ae5-7a0eab1cf564","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3956}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6def145-ce0a-496c-9c00-f8c641f79cae\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1355"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c?resourceVersion=id%3A1356"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1356,"drupal_internal__vid":1356,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Telemedicine","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:31+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Telemedicine | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Deliver consultative, diagnostic, and treatment services remotely, especially for patients who live in areas with limited access to care or who experience transportation or mobility barriers; sometimes called telehealth"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/telemedicine"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Deliver consultative, diagnostic, and treatment services remotely, especially for patients who live in areas with limited access to care or who experience transportation or mobility barriers; sometimes called telehealth"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/telemedicine","pid":1591,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-12-12","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow widely available and used is telemedicine in your community or state \u0026ndash; between providers, as well as providers and patients?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is choosing which types of telemedicine interventions to offer patients and how are those decisions being reached? Which health needs are the focus? Which patient groups?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are health care providers, as well as community members, engaged in efforts to expand telemedicine use? What local or state laws and regulations restrict its use?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat barriers might people experience at the local or state level in accessing telemedicine (e.g., health insurance coverage, internet access)? To using telemedicine meaningfully (e.g., digital literacy)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow widely available and used is telemedicine in your community or state \u2013 between providers, as well as providers and patients?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is choosing which types of telemedicine interventions to offer patients and how are those decisions being reached? Which health needs are the focus? Which patient groups?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow are health care providers, as well as community members, engaged in efforts to expand telemedicine use? What local or state laws and regulations restrict its use?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat barriers might people experience at the local or state level in accessing telemedicine (e.g., health insurance coverage, internet access)? To using telemedicine meaningfully (e.g., digital literacy)?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine is a suggested strategy to decrease geographic disparities in access to health care between rural and urban areas ({Shaver 2022}) by improving access for rural populations and in areas with medical provider shortages ({Shigekawa 2018}). Experts also suggest telemedicine could improve access to care for populations experiencing transportation barriers ({Shigekawa 2018}), such as among older adults with limited mobility outside the home ({Dorsey 2016}). Telemedicine-supported abortion care may increase access for women who live in states that prohibit or restrict abortion ({Skuster 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHowever, telemedicine use appears to differ significantly by patients\u2019 race, household income, insurance status, and whether the household has high-speed internet ({Shaver 2022}, {US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Adults without health insurance are least likely to use telemedicine ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}) and video-enabled visits in particular appear to be used more by younger, higher income, urban, white adults, and less by those with lower incomes, adults with less than a high school degree, individuals who identify as Black, Latino\/a, or Asian, and adults over age 65 ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}), even with significant increases in use in 2020 and 2021 when barriers were removed due to the COVID-19 pandemic ({Shaver 2022}, {US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). One study suggests that video visits appear to be used more often by individuals who identify as transgender, compared with other groups ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMore research is needed on telemedicine acceptability among diverse groups. Among individuals aged 50 and older, individuals of color appear more likely than white individuals to express concerns about telemedicine related to quality of care; health information security; privacy; and coverage or reimbursement issues ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). However, among patients who use telemedicine, those from households with lower incomes or households that do not identify as white appear to be as satisfied with their experiences as other groups ({Shaver 2022}). A Michigan-based study of rural patients\u2019 satisfaction with telemedicine visits in a rural health care system also suggests a high percentage of patients have positive perceptions of telemedicine visits, though satisfaction was highest among younger patients ({Klee 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEvaluating whether telemedicine improves health equitably among different demographic groups is also challenging, because prior to COVID-19, patients using telemedicine were mostly self-selecting though use is expanding ({Shaver 2022}). Barriers to using telemedicine may still include health insurance coverage, and, especially among older adults, access to the internet and equipment (e.g., desktop, laptop, or smartphone), technological literacy, and cognitive and physical ability ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Telemedicine may also not be available to those who desire to use it.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine is a suggested strategy to decrease geographic disparities in access to health care between rural and urban areas ({Shaver 2022}) by improving access for rural populations and in areas with medical provider shortages ({Shigekawa 2018}). Experts also suggest telemedicine could improve access to care for populations experiencing transportation barriers ({Shigekawa 2018}), such as among older adults with limited mobility outside the home ({Dorsey 2016}). Telemedicine-supported abortion care may increase access for women who live in states that prohibit or restrict abortion ({Skuster 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHowever, telemedicine use appears to differ significantly by patients\u2019 race, household income, insurance status, and whether the household has high-speed internet ({Shaver 2022}, {US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Adults without health insurance are least likely to use telemedicine ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}) and video-enabled visits in particular appear to be used more by younger, higher income, urban, white adults, and less by those with lower incomes, adults with less than a high school degree, individuals who identify as Black, Latino\/a, or Asian, and adults over age 65 ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}), even with significant increases in use in 2020 and 2021 when barriers were removed due to the COVID-19 pandemic ({Shaver 2022}, {US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). One study suggests that video visits appear to be used more often by individuals who identify as transgender, compared with other groups ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMore research is needed on telemedicine acceptability among diverse groups. Among individuals aged 50 and older, individuals of color appear more likely than white individuals to express concerns about telemedicine related to quality of care; health information security; privacy; and coverage or reimbursement issues ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). However, among patients who use telemedicine, those from households with lower incomes or households that do not identify as white appear to be as satisfied with their experiences as other groups ({Shaver 2022}). A Michigan-based study of rural patients\u2019 satisfaction with telemedicine visits in a rural health care system also suggests a high percentage of patients have positive perceptions of telemedicine visits, though satisfaction was highest among younger patients ({Klee 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEvaluating whether telemedicine improves health equitably among different demographic groups is also challenging, because prior to COVID-19, patients using telemedicine were mostly self-selecting though use is expanding ({Shaver 2022}). Barriers to using telemedicine may still include health insurance coverage, and, especially among older adults, access to the internet and equipment (e.g., desktop, laptop, or smartphone), technological literacy, and cognitive and physical ability ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Telemedicine may also not be available to those who desire to use it.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine was initially used for acute conditions, such as strokes or traumatic injuries, to connect specialist providers with clinicians treating patients in emergency departments. Telemedicine programs have also historically focused on rural populations, as well as those in the military and individuals who are incarcerated ({Dorsey 2016}). Before March 2020 and the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in the U.S., provider-patient telemedicine use was increasing but was a tiny proportion of overall care ({Shaver 2022}), especially video-enabled visits ({Dorsey 2016}). Most patients in the U.S. who used telemedicine did so through large academic medical centers, the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems, or purchased access if their healthcare provider offered direct-to-consumer services. Barriers to internet access and use prevented patients in rural areas, those with lower household incomes, disabilities ({Shaver 2022}), and older adults from accessing care via telemedicine ({Dorsey 2016}). Legal barriers and differing state rules, such as whether medication could be prescribed over the internet also restricted use ({Dorsey 2016}). For example, prior to the legal decision to reverse Roe v. Wade in 2022, 19 states had banned or restricted use of telehealth for medication abortion ({KFF-Anderson 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn March 2020, to support access to care and financial solvency for health care systems, Congress adjusted telemedicine restrictions for Medicare, including removing some restrictions for reimbursement, geography, and platform, as well as including telephone-only visits, and addressing interstate barriers to practice and privacy related to states\u2019 differing rules, with state and private health insurance payors following this example ({Shaver 2022}). A study of private and Medicare health care claims estimates that telehealth claims increased from 0.1% in 2019 to 5% of overall claims, as of 2021 ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine-supported abortion care has also been affected by recent changes in state and federal law and regulation. Medication abortion in early pregnancy has been available since 2000, when mifeprestone was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for this use. As of 2017, medication abortion comprised 39% of all abortions in the U.S., and by 2020, it comprised more than half ({Guttmacher-Medication abortion 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine was initially used for acute conditions, such as strokes or traumatic injuries, to connect specialist providers with clinicians treating patients in emergency departments. Telemedicine programs have also historically focused on rural populations, as well as those in the military and individuals who are incarcerated ({Dorsey 2016}). Before March 2020 and the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in the U.S., provider-patient telemedicine use was increasing but was a tiny proportion of overall care ({Shaver 2022}), especially video-enabled visits ({Dorsey 2016}). Most patients in the U.S. who used telemedicine did so through large academic medical centers, the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems, or purchased access if their healthcare provider offered direct-to-consumer services. Barriers to internet access and use prevented patients in rural areas, those with lower household incomes, disabilities ({Shaver 2022}), and older adults from accessing care via telemedicine ({Dorsey 2016}). Legal barriers and differing state rules, such as whether medication could be prescribed over the internet also restricted use ({Dorsey 2016}). For example, prior to the legal decision to reverse Roe v. Wade in 2022, 19 states had banned or restricted use of telehealth for medication abortion ({KFF-Anderson 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn March 2020, to support access to care and financial solvency for health care systems, Congress adjusted telemedicine restrictions for Medicare, including removing some restrictions for reimbursement, geography, and platform, as well as including telephone-only visits, and addressing interstate barriers to practice and privacy related to states\u2019 differing rules, with state and private health insurance payors following this example ({Shaver 2022}). A study of private and Medicare health care claims estimates that telehealth claims increased from 0.1% in 2019 to 5% of overall claims, as of 2021 ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine-supported abortion care has also been affected by recent changes in state and federal law and regulation. Medication abortion in early pregnancy has been available since 2000, when mifeprestone was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for this use. As of 2017, medication abortion comprised 39% of all abortions in the U.S., and by 2020, it comprised more than half ({Guttmacher-Medication abortion 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":2,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that telemedicine increases access to care ({Saragih 2021}, {Dorsey 2016}, {Molini-Avejonas 2015}, {Penate 2012}, {Kehle 2011}), particularly through increasing patients\u2019 direct access to providers, services, and medication for women\u2019s reproductive health care ({Aiken 2021}, {Endler 2019}, {DeNicola 2020}). Telemedicine may increase access to care among rural populations and other groups who experience challenges in access, such as mobility ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). Telemedicine appears, in some cases, to provide care equivalent to more traditional in person care ({Shaver 2022}, {Shigekawa 2018}, {Bashshur 2016}), but more rigorous research is needed evaluating whether telemedicine improves health outcomes among individuals when used to treat acute conditions or more complex or chronic diseases, compared to solely in-person care ({Bashshur 2016}, {Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}), especially as the focus of telemedicine services shifts to increasing patient convenience and reducing costs ({Shigekawa 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EReproductive health care.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine can provide early access to medical abortion services ({DeNicola 2020}, {Aiken 2021}). A British study suggests a telemedicine\/in-person hybrid model for providing remote medical abortions could lead to significantly shorter wait times from referral to treatment, increasing the number of abortions provided at 6 weeks or less gestation ({Aiken 2021}). There is demand for self-managed abortion care, where medication is received through the mail and patients are supported via telemedicine ({Skuster 2022}), and telemedicine-supported abortion care appears to be as safe and effective as in-person services, and acceptable to providers and patients ({Endler 2019}, {DeNicola 2020}). However, in the U.S. legal and policy challenges to telemedicine-supported abortion care are increasing ({Skuster 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine interventions for reproductive health can impact some pregnancy and birth-related health outcomes, including increasing perinatal smoking cessation and breastfeeding ({DeNicola 2020}), reducing postpartum depression ({Hanach 2021}), and are a comparable alternative to in-person office visits to monitor patients for high-risk obstetric conditions ({DeNicola 2020}). However, it may not significantly improve maternal and fetal outcomes related to pregestational and gestational diabetes compared to usual care, although that may be because pregnant individuals are often already closely monitored for some conditions, limiting telemedicine\u2019s effect ({Laursen 2022}). Additionally, telemedicine interventions designed for adolescent sexual health may improve self-efficacy and condom use and increase screening and testing for sexually transmitted infections ({Saragih 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EChronic disease.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine may improve chronic disease management in some cases, including reducing Hba1c in diabetic patients ({Timpel 2020}) and modestly improving disease control in patients with multiple morbidities when interventions focus on a specific risk factor ({Kraef 2020}). Pharmacist-delivered telemedicine care, especially interventions delivered at predetermined times, may improve disease management, self-management, and treatment adherence for chronic diseases, as much as or more than in-person visits ({Niznik 2018}). A variety of telemedicine interventions appear to modestly improve blood pressure in patients with cardiovascular disease and hypertension, particularly if the interventions last 6 months or longer; experts recommend telemedicine interventions include monitoring devices which report data automatically ({Gao 2022}). Asynchronous patient-physician messaging may decrease emergency department and hospital utilization among patients with multiple chronic conditions ({Reed 2019}). Conditions that have been shown to be sensitive to telemedicine include hypertension, diabetes ({Timpel 2020}, {Cochrane-Flodgren 2015}, {Huang 2015}, {Greenwood 2014}), anticoagulation, hyperlipidemia, asthma, heart failure, HIV, chronic kidney disease, stroke, and COPD, as well as depression and posttraumatic stress disorder ({Niznik 2018}, {Wootton 2012}). Experts caution, however, that the type and intensity of interventions vary widely, and that overall evidence quality is low. More rigorous research is needed on whether telemedicine improves clinical outcomes for chronic diseases and overall health status among patients with multiple morbidities ({Shaver 2022}, {Kraef 2020}, {Timpel 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAcute conditions.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine may be an appropriate alternative, or first step in triage, for low-risk acute conditions for which people commonly seek treatment at an in-person appointment, such as conjunctivitis, emergency contraception, urinary tract infection (UTI), upper respiratory tract infections (URI), and sore throat (pharyngitis) ({Reed 2021a}); such e-visits do not appear to increase emergency department use, and may be cost effective due to their short length (often only two or three minutes) ({Reed 2021a}). Evidence is mixed, with some studies suggesting telemedicine leads to similar or better care outcomes such as appropriate prescribing of antibiotics or ordering of medical imaging ({Bashshur 2016}) while other studies suggest patients may be more likely to receive inappropriate antibiotics or that clinicians may not order appropriate tests. Telemedicine may reduce physician-related medication errors among seriously ill or injured children in rural emergency departments ({Dharmar 2013}). Experts suggest telemedicine may be more likely to produce beneficial outcomes, such as appropriate prescribing and expected rates of follow-up care, when providers and patients have an established relationship, the patient\u2019s medical record is available, and on-site testing and follow-up care are accessible ({Shaver 2022}). More research is needed about difficult-to-assess conditions and among patients with communication barriers ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOther specialties.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telerehabilitation services may improve motor function following total knee replacement ({Agostini 2015}) and reduce short-term disability and symptoms for patients with multiple sclerosis ({Cochrane-Khan 2015}). Telerehabilitation also appears to produce similar outcomes to center-based cardiac rehabilitation for low to moderate risk coronary artery disease patients ({Huang 2015a}). Teleglaucoma screening detects more cases of glaucoma than in-person screening in remote and underserved communities ({Thomas 2014b}), and, overall, telemedicine appears to increase access to care for speech, language, and hearing services ({Molini-Avejonas 2015}). Telemedicine is also used globally for routine dermatologic care, but more research is needed which compares tele-dermatology with in-person consultation; experts suggest it may be well-suited for initial evaluations and follow-up visits ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EEnvironmental benefits.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine has the potential to reduce the carbon footprint of the health care industry, primarily by reducing vehicle miles traveled (VMT) and greenhouse gas emissions from patients driving to appointments. Telemedicine does generate some carbon emissions and those amounts vary, for example, with the length of the appointment, type of teleconferencing platform used, energy used to support the virtual connection, and different broadband capacities. In general, telemedicine appointments that replace a car trip of a few kilometers or more reduce carbon emissions ({Dacones 2021}, {Holmner 2014}). Experts also suggest that telemedicine can reduce traffic, wear on medical facilities, and reduce staff and patients\u2019 exposure to infectious disease ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EChallenges.\u003C\/strong\u003E Providers and patients may encounter challenges in using telemedicine, including inconsistent reimbursement policies, inadequate reimbursement amounts, restrictions on which technologies can be used, and from what settings, and privacy regulations that can increase costs to ensure exchanges are secure ({Shaver 2022}). Patients who are traveling may be excluded from care due to states\u2019 different medical licensing systems, and certain prescription, visit, and patient types may also be excluded ({Shaver 2022}). Telemedicine can also be challenging to evaluate because telemedicine visits can be simple or intensive and complex. Providers may prefer in-patient visits for high-risk patients or those with complex conditions when there is no disincentive for using in-person visits ({Shaver 2022}). More research is also needed on diagnostic accuracy and timing in telemedicine, as well as delayed diagnosis legal claims in telemedicine compared to standard care ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERecommendations.\u003C\/strong\u003E Overall, experts recommend telemedicine alongside standard care, not as a replacement ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). More research is needed on the effects of telemedicine on patient-provider trust and rapport; the ability to pick up on less easily observed symptoms and non-verbal communication remotely; the unavailability of therapeutic touch; and patients\u2019 treatment adherence ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). Experts suggest that video appointments may allow providers to check on a patient\u2019s home environment, perform a partial physical exam, observe some non-verbal communication, and may enhance the patient-provider relationship compared to audio only appointments ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Experts suggest asynchronous messaging may be well-suited for hospitals\u2019 busiest times, such as flu seasons or during disasters, but recommend measures to prevent physician fatigue or burnout; increased care burdens may fall on outpatient clinicians handling a high message volume and could contribute to fatigue or burnout over time if not addressed ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that telemedicine increases access to care ({Saragih 2021}, {Dorsey 2016}, {Molini-Avejonas 2015}, {Penate 2012}, {Kehle 2011}), particularly through increasing patients\u2019 direct access to providers, services, and medication for women\u2019s reproductive health care ({Aiken 2021}, {Endler 2019}, {DeNicola 2020}). Telemedicine may increase access to care among rural populations and other groups who experience challenges in access, such as mobility ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). Telemedicine appears, in some cases, to provide care equivalent to more traditional in person care ({Shaver 2022}, {Shigekawa 2018}, {Bashshur 2016}), but more rigorous research is needed evaluating whether telemedicine improves health outcomes among individuals when used to treat acute conditions or more complex or chronic diseases, compared to solely in-person care ({Bashshur 2016}, {Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}), especially as the focus of telemedicine services shifts to increasing patient convenience and reducing costs ({Shigekawa 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EReproductive health care.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine can provide early access to medical abortion services ({DeNicola 2020}, {Aiken 2021}). A British study suggests a telemedicine\/in-person hybrid model for providing remote medical abortions could lead to significantly shorter wait times from referral to treatment, increasing the number of abortions provided at 6 weeks or less gestation ({Aiken 2021}). There is demand for self-managed abortion care, where medication is received through the mail and patients are supported via telemedicine ({Skuster 2022}), and telemedicine-supported abortion care appears to be as safe and effective as in-person services, and acceptable to providers and patients ({Endler 2019}, {DeNicola 2020}). However, in the U.S. legal and policy challenges to telemedicine-supported abortion care are increasing ({Skuster 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETelemedicine interventions for reproductive health can impact some pregnancy and birth-related health outcomes, including increasing perinatal smoking cessation and breastfeeding ({DeNicola 2020}), reducing postpartum depression ({Hanach 2021}), and are a comparable alternative to in-person office visits to monitor patients for high-risk obstetric conditions ({DeNicola 2020}). However, it may not significantly improve maternal and fetal outcomes related to pregestational and gestational diabetes compared to usual care, although that may be because pregnant individuals are often already closely monitored for some conditions, limiting telemedicine\u2019s effect ({Laursen 2022}). Additionally, telemedicine interventions designed for adolescent sexual health may improve self-efficacy and condom use and increase screening and testing for sexually transmitted infections ({Saragih 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EChronic disease.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine may improve chronic disease management in some cases, including reducing Hba1c in diabetic patients ({Timpel 2020}) and modestly improving disease control in patients with multiple morbidities when interventions focus on a specific risk factor ({Kraef 2020}). Pharmacist-delivered telemedicine care, especially interventions delivered at predetermined times, may improve disease management, self-management, and treatment adherence for chronic diseases, as much as or more than in-person visits ({Niznik 2018}). A variety of telemedicine interventions appear to modestly improve blood pressure in patients with cardiovascular disease and hypertension, particularly if the interventions last 6 months or longer; experts recommend telemedicine interventions include monitoring devices which report data automatically ({Gao 2022}). Asynchronous patient-physician messaging may decrease emergency department and hospital utilization among patients with multiple chronic conditions ({Reed 2019}). Conditions that have been shown to be sensitive to telemedicine include hypertension, diabetes ({Timpel 2020}, {Cochrane-Flodgren 2015}, {Huang 2015}, {Greenwood 2014}), anticoagulation, hyperlipidemia, asthma, heart failure, HIV, chronic kidney disease, stroke, and COPD, as well as depression and posttraumatic stress disorder ({Niznik 2018}, {Wootton 2012}). Experts caution, however, that the type and intensity of interventions vary widely, and that overall evidence quality is low. More rigorous research is needed on whether telemedicine improves clinical outcomes for chronic diseases and overall health status among patients with multiple morbidities ({Shaver 2022}, {Kraef 2020}, {Timpel 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAcute conditions.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine may be an appropriate alternative, or first step in triage, for low-risk acute conditions for which people commonly seek treatment at an in-person appointment, such as conjunctivitis, emergency contraception, urinary tract infection (UTI), upper respiratory tract infections (URI), and sore throat (pharyngitis) ({Reed 2021a}); such e-visits do not appear to increase emergency department use, and may be cost effective due to their short length (often only two or three minutes) ({Reed 2021a}). Evidence is mixed, with some studies suggesting telemedicine leads to similar or better care outcomes such as appropriate prescribing of antibiotics or ordering of medical imaging ({Bashshur 2016}) while other studies suggest patients may be more likely to receive inappropriate antibiotics or that clinicians may not order appropriate tests. Telemedicine may reduce physician-related medication errors among seriously ill or injured children in rural emergency departments ({Dharmar 2013}). Experts suggest telemedicine may be more likely to produce beneficial outcomes, such as appropriate prescribing and expected rates of follow-up care, when providers and patients have an established relationship, the patient\u2019s medical record is available, and on-site testing and follow-up care are accessible ({Shaver 2022}). More research is needed about difficult-to-assess conditions and among patients with communication barriers ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOther specialties.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telerehabilitation services may improve motor function following total knee replacement ({Agostini 2015}) and reduce short-term disability and symptoms for patients with multiple sclerosis ({Cochrane-Khan 2015}). Telerehabilitation also appears to produce similar outcomes to center-based cardiac rehabilitation for low to moderate risk coronary artery disease patients ({Huang 2015a}). Teleglaucoma screening detects more cases of glaucoma than in-person screening in remote and underserved communities ({Thomas 2014b}), and, overall, telemedicine appears to increase access to care for speech, language, and hearing services ({Molini-Avejonas 2015}). Telemedicine is also used globally for routine dermatologic care, but more research is needed which compares tele-dermatology with in-person consultation; experts suggest it may be well-suited for initial evaluations and follow-up visits ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EEnvironmental benefits.\u003C\/strong\u003E Telemedicine has the potential to reduce the carbon footprint of the health care industry, primarily by reducing vehicle miles traveled (VMT) and greenhouse gas emissions from patients driving to appointments. Telemedicine does generate some carbon emissions and those amounts vary, for example, with the length of the appointment, type of teleconferencing platform used, energy used to support the virtual connection, and different broadband capacities. In general, telemedicine appointments that replace a car trip of a few kilometers or more reduce carbon emissions ({Dacones 2021}, {Holmner 2014}). Experts also suggest that telemedicine can reduce traffic, wear on medical facilities, and reduce staff and patients\u2019 exposure to infectious disease ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EChallenges.\u003C\/strong\u003E Providers and patients may encounter challenges in using telemedicine, including inconsistent reimbursement policies, inadequate reimbursement amounts, restrictions on which technologies can be used, and from what settings, and privacy regulations that can increase costs to ensure exchanges are secure ({Shaver 2022}). Patients who are traveling may be excluded from care due to states\u2019 different medical licensing systems, and certain prescription, visit, and patient types may also be excluded ({Shaver 2022}). Telemedicine can also be challenging to evaluate because telemedicine visits can be simple or intensive and complex. Providers may prefer in-patient visits for high-risk patients or those with complex conditions when there is no disincentive for using in-person visits ({Shaver 2022}). More research is also needed on diagnostic accuracy and timing in telemedicine, as well as delayed diagnosis legal claims in telemedicine compared to standard care ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERecommendations.\u003C\/strong\u003E Overall, experts recommend telemedicine alongside standard care, not as a replacement ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). More research is needed on the effects of telemedicine on patient-provider trust and rapport; the ability to pick up on less easily observed symptoms and non-verbal communication remotely; the unavailability of therapeutic touch; and patients\u2019 treatment adherence ({Shaver 2022}, {Dorsey 2016}). Experts suggest that video appointments may allow providers to check on a patient\u2019s home environment, perform a partial physical exam, observe some non-verbal communication, and may enhance the patient-provider relationship compared to audio only appointments ({US DHHS-Karimi 2022}). Experts suggest asynchronous messaging may be well-suited for hospitals\u2019 busiest times, such as flu seasons or during disasters, but recommend measures to prevent physician fatigue or burnout; increased care burdens may fall on outpatient clinicians handling a high message volume and could contribute to fatigue or burnout over time if not addressed ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2023, all 50 states and Washington, D.C. provide Medicaid reimbursement for live video telehealth services, 43 states and Washington, D.C. have telehealth private payer laws, and the same number also reimburse for audio-only telephone services, which is a significant increase since 2021 ({CCHP-Telehealth glance}). As of 2018, 76% of U.S. hospital systems use telemedicine in some form, most often for radiology, cardiology, and psychiatry ({Shaver 2022}). Telemedicine visits increased among all patient types, especially those with chronic illnesses, after the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020 ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA number of telemedicine and telehealth programs exist in the United States ({HRSA-Telehealth}). The Missouri Telehealth Network ({MTN}), for example, is aimed at enhancing access to care in rural and underserved areas of Missouri. The Children\u2019s National Medical Center in Washington, D.C. has a telemedicine program that serves community hospitals, suburban health centers, inner-city health clinics, national hospitals, and international partners ({CNHS-Telemedicine}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EU.S. regulations on abortion care are changing quickly, complicating telemedicine-supported care. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) removed restrictions on dispensing medication for abortions in 2023, making it possible for individuals to obtain medication abortion pills from retail pharmacies except in states with a near-total ban on abortion. Other states limit prescribing power to physicians, despite guidance from the World Health Organization (WHO) and others which says it is safe for advanced practice clinicians, such as physician assistants, to provide medication abortion ({Guttmacher-Medication abortion 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2023, all 50 states and Washington, D.C. provide Medicaid reimbursement for live video telehealth services, 43 states and Washington, D.C. have telehealth private payer laws, and the same number also reimburse for audio-only telephone services, which is a significant increase since 2021 ({CCHP-Telehealth glance}). As of 2018, 76% of U.S. hospital systems use telemedicine in some form, most often for radiology, cardiology, and psychiatry ({Shaver 2022}). Telemedicine visits increased among all patient types, especially those with chronic illnesses, after the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020 ({Shaver 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA number of telemedicine and telehealth programs exist in the United States ({HRSA-Telehealth}). The Missouri Telehealth Network ({MTN}), for example, is aimed at enhancing access to care in rural and underserved areas of Missouri. The Children\u2019s National Medical Center in Washington, D.C. has a telemedicine program that serves community hospitals, suburban health centers, inner-city health clinics, national hospitals, and international partners ({CNHS-Telemedicine}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EU.S. regulations on abortion care are changing quickly, complicating telemedicine-supported care. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) removed restrictions on dispensing medication for abortions in 2023, making it possible for individuals to obtain medication abortion pills from retail pharmacies except in states with a near-total ban on abortion. Other states limit prescribing power to physicians, despite guidance from the World Health Organization (WHO) and others which says it is safe for advanced practice clinicians, such as physician assistants, to provide medication abortion ({Guttmacher-Medication abortion 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":43,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved access to reproductive health care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved access to reproductive health care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved chronic disease management","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved chronic disease management\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced vehicle miles traveled","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced vehicle miles traveled\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced emissions","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced emissions\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased access to care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased access to care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["HRSA-HHS Telehealth","CCHP-Telehealth Fall 2023","RHIhub-Telehealth","LawAtlas-Telehealth","ATA","HRSA-Telehealth"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022HRSA-HHS Telehealth\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213562\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022HRSA-HHS Telehealth\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Health Resources \u0026 Services Administration (HRSA). Telehealth and primary care provider laws map.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/lawatlas.org\\\/query?dataset=telehealth\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-18\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022ATA\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222068\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022ATA\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022American Telemedicine Association (ATA).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.americantelemed.org\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-11-13\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022HRSA-Telehealth\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222070\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022HRSA-Telehealth\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), Office for the Advancement of Telehealth. Journal of Telemedicine and Telecare. 2021.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1177\\\/1357633X211047762\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Dorsey 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213550\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Dorsey 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Dorsey ER, Topol EJ. State of telehealth. Journal of Telemedicine and Telecare. 2015;21(7):367-376.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1177\\\/1357633X15583215\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-14\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Penate 2012\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222874\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Penate 2012\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Pe\\u00f1ate W. About the effectiveness of telehealth procedures in psychological treatments. International Journal of Clinical and Health Psychology. 2012;12(3):475-487.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.aepc.es\\\/ijchp\\\/articulos_pdf\\\/ijchp-423.pdf\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-18\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Kehle 2011\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222072\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Kehle 2011\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Kehle SM, Greer N, Rutks I, Wilt T. Interventions to improve veterans\\u2019 access to care: A systematic review of the literature. Journal of General Internal Medicine. 2011;26(Suppl 2):689-96.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/books\\\/NBK54224\\\/pdf\\\/TOC.pdf\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-14\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Aiken 2021\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213554\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Aiken 2021\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Aiken ARA, Lohr PA, Lord J, Ghosh N, Starling J. Effectiveness, safety and acceptability of no-test medical abortion (termination of pregnancy) provided via telemedicine: A national cohort study. BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology. 2021;128(9):1464-1474.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1111\\\/1471-0528.16668\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Endler 2019\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213653\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Endler 2019\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Endler M, Lavelanet A, Cleeve A, et al. Telemedicine for medical abortion: A systematic review. BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics \u0026 Gynaecology. 2019;126(9):1094-1102.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1111\\\/1471-0528.15684\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022DeNicola 2020\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213555\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022DeNicola 2020\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022DeNicola N, Grossman D, Marko K, et al. Telehealth interventions to improve obstetric and gynecologic health outcomes. Obstetrics \u0026 Gynecology. 2020;135(2):371-382.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1097\\\/AOG.0000000000003646\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Shaver 2022\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213543\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Shaver 2022\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Shaver J. The state of telehealth before and after the COVID-19 pandemic. Primary Care: Clinics in Office Practice. 2022;49(4):517-530.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1016\\\/j.pop.2022.04.002\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-25\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Shigekawa 2018\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213551\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Shigekawa 2018\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Shigekawa E, Fix M, Corbett G, Roby DH, Coffman J. The current state of telehealth evidence: A rapid review. Health Affairs. 2018;37(12):1975-1982.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1377\\\/hlthaff.2018.05132\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-25\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Bashshur 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213544\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Bashshur 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Bashshur RL, Howell JD, Krupinski EA, et al. The empirical foundations of telemedicine interventions in primary care. Telemedicine and e-Health. 2016;22(5):342-375.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1089\\\/tmj.2016.0045\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222023-12-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Skuster 2022\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213553\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Skuster 2022\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Skuster P, Moseson H. d4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"3b2dae1f-78ad-4d38-ab02-b33fed903264","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3848}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1356"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1356"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"4628455e-e56b-416e-9015-9c63782538bf","meta":{"target_revision_id":11313,"drupal_internal__target_id":6305}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1356"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/89eb59d1-9b99-4118-b703-fa04e2b4734c\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1356"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"21e26481-f013-4ce2-8a6b-f0f87a7b0242","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":38}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"cbd9a012-996b-4ba5-a3d6-02d78e250003","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3542}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"caa976a6-79ad-4c48-a887-5861092f88ef","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3551}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"aaabe8d7-b91d-428d-9cf7-be21a06a6822","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":64}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--progra career recruitment for minority students","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Health career recruitment for minority students | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Recruit and train underrepresented minority (URM) students for careers in health fields via information about health careers, classes, practicum experiences, advising about college or medical school admissions, etc."}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/health-career-recruitment-for-minority-students"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026
