tionships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1358"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/fb6b53a1-646d-4818-a234-3c61574ae36c\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1358"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/fb6b53a1-646d-4818-a234-3c61574ae36c\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1358"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1359,"drupal_internal__vid":1359,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Transitional and subsidized jobs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Transitional and subsidized jobs | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Establish time-limited, subsidized, paid jobs to help individuals with barriers to employment transition to unsubsidized employment"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/transitional-and-subsidized-jobs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Establish time-limited, subsidized, paid jobs to help individuals with barriers to employment transition to unsubsidized employment"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Workplace"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Employment \u0026 job training"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/transitional-and-subsidized-jobs","pid":1594,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2022-08-18","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat population(s) is the subsidized employment program recruiting from?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional supports or resources can subsidized employment program include to better support their target population and improve long-term outcomes?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can transitional jobs programs partner with local or regional employers to meet current and future workforce needs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can program implementation support a more equitable recovery during times of economic crises?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat underlying conditions contribute to training and skills gaps in your community? What other strategies can be implemented to address those underlying conditions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat population(s) is the subsidized employment program recruiting from?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat additional supports or resources can subsidized employment program include to better support their target population and improve long-term outcomes?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can transitional jobs programs partner with local or regional employers to meet current and future workforce needs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can program implementation support a more equitable recovery during times of economic crises?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat underlying conditions contribute to training and skills gaps in your community? What other strategies can be implemented to address those underlying conditions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact transitional and subsidized jobs programs have on disparities in employment and earnings between the general population and individuals who are hard-to-employ or historically disadvantaged workers such as Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) recipients, people with criminal records, older workers, other long-term unemployed individuals. While there is strong evidence that such programs increase employment and earnings for the duration of the subsidized position, these gains do not appear to consistently last beyond the duration of the transitional job ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}), except in some circumstances ({MDRC-Barden 2018}, {Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}). Subsidized employment is likely to be most beneficial for individuals with the biggest barriers to employment ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Transitional job programs also have the potential to decrease disparities in employment for individuals who have been incarcerated, particularly those who are more disadvantaged and those most likely to re-offend ({MDRC-Foley 2018}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESubsidized and transitional jobs programs are often used as a tool during economic crises, which further exacerbate racial inequities and poverty, harm workers of color, and worsen conditions for other historically disadvantaged workers; using these programs may contribute to more equitable economic recoveries ({CBPP-Meyer 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact transitional and subsidized jobs programs have on disparities in employment and earnings between the general population and individuals who are hard-to-employ or historically disadvantaged workers such as Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) recipients, people with criminal records, older workers, other long-term unemployed individuals. While there is strong evidence that such programs increase employment and earnings for the duration of the subsidized position, these gains do not appear to consistently last beyond the duration of the transitional job ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}), except in some circumstances ({MDRC-Barden 2018}, {Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}). Subsidized employment is likely to be most beneficial for individuals with the biggest barriers to employment ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Transitional job programs also have the potential to decrease disparities in employment for individuals who have been incarcerated, particularly those who are more disadvantaged and those most likely to re-offend ({MDRC-Foley 2018}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESubsidized and transitional jobs programs are often used as a tool during economic crises, which further exacerbate racial inequities and poverty, harm workers of color, and worsen conditions for other historically disadvantaged workers; using these programs may contribute to more equitable economic recoveries ({CBPP-Meyer 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ESubsidized employment programs were initially created as tools to support workers during economic crises. In response to the Great Depression, President Franklin D. Roosevelt\u2019s New Deal programs, including the Work Progress Administration (WPA), were established to stabilize the economy and provide jobs and relief to workers in the 1930s ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Over the decades, programs have expanded to support workers who experience high rates of joblessness, even when labor market conditions are good ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). For example, in the 1970s the National Supported Work Demonstration expanded subsidized work programs to women receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children and individuals who were formerly incarcerated, and the Youth Incentive Entitlement Pilot Project provided jobs to disconnected youth ({Georgetown-Dutta-Gupta 2016}). More recently, in 2010, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services launched the Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) and the U.S. Department of Labor launched the Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD), two complementary, large-scale research projects designed to build rigorous evidence on the effectiveness of the latest generation of subsidized employment models and to inform future program development, providing jobs to individuals who were formerly incarcerated or are non-custodial parents ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGiven the history of overincarceration of people of color (who make up more than two thirds of the prison population) and the discriminatory hiring practices individuals face following release from prison, effective transitional jobs for those who were previously incarcerated are needed. Half of individuals released from prison are reincarcerated within three years ({OPRE-Redcross 2012}). Even without the burden of a criminal record, Black and Hispanic workers are more likely to experience a higher rate of unemployment during an economic crisis and are more likely to experience a slower return to pre-crisis unemployment levels during economic recoveries. During the Great Recession, the unemployment rate for Black workers was 16% compared to 8% for white workers ({CBPP-Meyer 2021}), making transitional and subsidized jobs an important tool for just economic recoveries.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ESubsidized employment programs were initially created as tools to support workers during economic crises. In response to the Great Depression, President Franklin D. Roosevelt\u2019s New Deal programs, including the Work Progress Administration (WPA), were established to stabilize the economy and provide jobs and relief to workers in the 1930s ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Over the decades, programs have expanded to support workers who experience high rates of joblessness, even when labor market conditions are good ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). For example, in the 1970s the National Supported Work Demonstration expanded subsidized work programs to women receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children and individuals who were formerly incarcerated, and the Youth Incentive Entitlement Pilot Project provided jobs to disconnected youth ({Georgetown-Dutta-Gupta 2016}). More recently, in 2010, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services launched the Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) and the U.S. Department of Labor launched the Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD), two complementary, large-scale research projects designed to build rigorous evidence on the effectiveness of the latest generation of subsidized employment models and to inform future program development, providing jobs to individuals who were formerly incarcerated or are non-custodial parents ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGiven the history of overincarceration of people of color (who make up more than two thirds of the prison population) and the discriminatory hiring practices individuals face following release from prison, effective transitional jobs for those who were previously incarcerated are needed. Half of individuals released from prison are reincarcerated within three years ({OPRE-Redcross 2012}). Even without the burden of a criminal record, Black and Hispanic workers are more likely to experience a higher rate of unemployment during an economic crisis and are more likely to experience a slower return to pre-crisis unemployment levels during economic recoveries. During the Great Recession, the unemployment rate for Black workers was 16% compared to 8% for white workers ({CBPP-Meyer 2021}), making transitional and subsidized jobs an important tool for just economic recoveries.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that transitional and subsidized jobs programs increase employment and earnings for low income adults, youth, unemployed individuals, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) recipients, and recently released former prisoners for the duration of their subsidized position ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Barden 2018}, {Georgetown-Dutta-Gupta 2016}, {Mathematica-Maxwell 2015}, {EMC-Roder 2013}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}). However, these gains do not appear to consistently last beyond the duration of the transitional job ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome transitional jobs programs can increase competitive employment and earnings after subsidized employment ends ({CLASP-Baider 2006}, {MDRC-Bloom 2010a}, {EMC-Roder 2013}), particularly for those that have been out of the workforce longer and those without a high school diploma ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Participants from some programs of the U.S. Department of Labor\u2019s Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) project were more likely to be working in full-time, permanent jobs, earning over $10 per hour, and to have employer-sponsored health insurance 30 months later ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). Transitional job programs appear to have no effect on longer term employment among TANF recipients and individuals who have been incarcerated ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETransitional job programs may reduce recidivism among individuals who have been incarcerated, particularly those at highest risk of recidivism ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}, {MDRC-Bloom 2010a}). The Center for Employment Opportunities\u2019 program in New York City and the RecycleForce program in Indiana, for example, reduced recidivism among participants who entered the program within four months of release from prison, particularly those who were more disadvantaged and those most likely to re-offend ({MDRC-Foley 2018}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}). However, the Transitional Jobs Reentry Demonstration and two of the three programs from the Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) did not appear to affect recidivism rates ({MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENon-custodial parents may increase child support payments during program participation, though impacts fade after the programs end ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETransitional jobs without additional supports may not increase employment for individuals with severe mental illness ({Davis 2018b}, {Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}, {Abraham 2017}), with only small increases in long-term employment ({Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}). For example, transitional work rehabilitation programs through Veterans Affairs medical centers appear to have small or no effects on long-term employment for participating veterans with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) ({Davis 2018b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) suggests characteristics such as program strategy, ability to find job placements, and required employer commitments impact program success ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Employer characteristics are not consistent predictors of success: for example, in programs supported by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA), permanent employment was typically with for-profit employers ({EMC-Roder 2013}), but in ETJD programs it was with non-profit employers ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). A study of the transitional work program for veterans with PTSD found placement in community settings was more effective than placement in the Veterans Health Administration system ({Abraham 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EProgram costs vary based on program structure (e.g., maximum wage rates and hours worked, percentage of wages and payroll costs subsidized, and maximum time allowed for participation). For example, in the Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) costs ranged from $3,300 to $11,100 per participant ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}), while Wisconsin\u2019s implementation of ARRA-subsidized job funding had an average cost per subsidized placement of $7,913 ({EMC-Roder 2013}). Initial start-up costs for a subsidized employment program are significant, but some programs can increase earnings and employment for participants within the first year of program launch ({Geckeler 2019}). Cost benefit analysis of several programs suggest some transitional jobs programs can generate positive net benefits ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Foley 2018}), though they may not save money for the government ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). For example, a cost benefit analysis of RecycleForce, an ETJD program in Indiana, found a $2,200 net benefit per person due to the sustained impacts on recidivism and earnings ({MDRC-Foley 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA recent report projects that providing subsidized jobs to unemployed and underemployed individuals in families with children would reduce child poverty by 8.6%, or 0.8 million children. Provision of jobs at this scale would cost approximately $23.1 billion ({Urban-Minton 2019}). Income gains to participants in transitional and subsidized jobs programs may be offset by reduced government benefits and increased taxes, creating barriers to program success and transitioning participants out of poverty ({CDF 2015}, {Mathematica-Maxwell 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that transitional and subsidized jobs programs increase employment and earnings for low income adults, youth, unemployed individuals, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) recipients, and recently released former prisoners for the duration of their subsidized position ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Barden 2018}, {Georgetown-Dutta-Gupta 2016}, {Mathematica-Maxwell 2015}, {EMC-Roder 2013}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}). However, these gains do not appear to consistently last beyond the duration of the transitional job ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome transitional jobs programs can increase competitive employment and earnings after subsidized employment ends ({CLASP-Baider 2006}, {MDRC-Bloom 2010a}, {EMC-Roder 2013}), particularly for those that have been out of the workforce longer and those without a high school diploma ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Participants from some programs of the U.S. Department of Labor\u2019s Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) project were more likely to be working in full-time, permanent jobs, earning over $10 per hour, and to have employer-sponsored health insurance 30 months later ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). Transitional job programs appear to have no effect on longer term employment among TANF recipients and individuals who have been incarcerated ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {OPRE-Butler 2012}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETransitional job programs may reduce recidivism among individuals who have been incarcerated, particularly those at highest risk of recidivism ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}, {MDRC-Bloom 2010a}). The Center for Employment Opportunities\u2019 program in New York City and the RecycleForce program in Indiana, for example, reduced recidivism among participants who entered the program within four months of release from prison, particularly those who were more disadvantaged and those most likely to re-offend ({MDRC-Foley 2018}, {OPRE-Redcross 2012}). However, the Transitional Jobs Reentry Demonstration and two of the three programs from the Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) did not appear to affect recidivism rates ({MDRC-Jacobs 2012}, {MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENon-custodial parents may increase child support payments during program participation, though impacts fade after the programs end ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETransitional jobs without additional supports may not increase employment for individuals with severe mental illness ({Davis 2018b}, {Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}, {Abraham 2017}), with only small increases in long-term employment ({Cochrane-Suijkerbuijk 2017}). For example, transitional work rehabilitation programs through Veterans Affairs medical centers appear to have small or no effects on long-term employment for participating veterans with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) ({Davis 2018b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) suggests characteristics such as program strategy, ability to find job placements, and required employer commitments impact program success ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). Employer characteristics are not consistent predictors of success: for example, in programs supported by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA), permanent employment was typically with for-profit employers ({EMC-Roder 2013}), but in ETJD programs it was with non-profit employers ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). A study of the transitional work program for veterans with PTSD found placement in community settings was more effective than placement in the Veterans Health Administration system ({Abraham 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EProgram costs vary based on program structure (e.g., maximum wage rates and hours worked, percentage of wages and payroll costs subsidized, and maximum time allowed for participation). For example, in the Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) costs ranged from $3,300 to $11,100 per participant ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}), while Wisconsin\u2019s implementation of ARRA-subsidized job funding had an average cost per subsidized placement of $7,913 ({EMC-Roder 2013}). Initial start-up costs for a subsidized employment program are significant, but some programs can increase earnings and employment for participants within the first year of program launch ({Geckeler 2019}). Cost benefit analysis of several programs suggest some transitional jobs programs can generate positive net benefits ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}, {MDRC-Foley 2018}), though they may not save money for the government ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}). For example, a cost benefit analysis of RecycleForce, an ETJD program in Indiana, found a $2,200 net benefit per person due to the sustained impacts on recidivism and earnings ({MDRC-Foley 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA recent report projects that providing subsidized jobs to unemployed and underemployed individuals in families with children would reduce child poverty by 8.6%, or 0.8 million children. Provision of jobs at this scale would cost approximately $23.1 billion ({Urban-Minton 2019}). Income gains to participants in transitional and subsidized jobs programs may be offset by reduced government benefits and increased taxes, creating barriers to program success and transitioning participants out of poverty ({CDF 2015}, {Mathematica-Maxwell 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ETransitional jobs programs exist across the country ({Georgetown-Subsidized Employment Programs}) but are not universally available.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) was a multi-site project by the U.S. Department of Labor to test new subsidized employment models for hard-to-employ populations such as welfare recipients, former prisoners, and non-custodial parents with low incomes ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). Some results are now available from a second multi-site project with the same goals, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services\u2019 Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2020, Baltimore, Maryland launched the Baltimore Health Corps, which recruited, trained, and employed 300 residents who lost their jobs due to the COVID-19 pandemic, to support the city\u2019s response to the crisis ({Rockefeller-Baltimore Health Corps 2020}). Colorado has a transitional jobs program that prioritizes unemployed or underemployed non-custodial parents, veterans, or displaced workers that are fifty years of age or older ({NCSL-WD Legislation 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ETransitional jobs programs exist across the country ({Georgetown-Subsidized Employment Programs}) but are not universally available.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Enhanced Transitional Jobs Demonstration (ETJD) was a multi-site project by the U.S. Department of Labor to test new subsidized employment models for hard-to-employ populations such as welfare recipients, former prisoners, and non-custodial parents with low incomes ({MDRC-Barden 2018}). Some results are now available from a second multi-site project with the same goals, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services\u2019 Subsidized and Transitional Employment Demonstration (STED) ({MDRC-Cummings 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2020, Baltimore, Maryland launched the Baltimore Health Corps, which recruited, trained, and employed 300 residents who lost their jobs due to the COVID-19 pandemic, to support the city\u2019s response to the crisis ({Rockefeller-Baltimore Health Corps 2020}). Colorado has a transitional jobs program that prioritizes unemployed or underemployed non-custodial parents, veterans, or displaced workers that are fifty years of age or older ({NCSL-WD Legislation 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":51,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced recidivism","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced recidivism\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced poverty","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced poverty\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased employment","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased employment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased earnings","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased earnings\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Georgetown-Subsidized Employment Programs","CEO"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Employment \u0026 job training","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Workplace","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Georgetown-Subsidized Employment Programs\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002211181\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Georgetown-Subsidized Employment Programs\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Eckel M, Belledonne J, Bambrick B, et al. employment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"ce15b851-48a1-4c70-ab86-7cde0c7de259","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3621}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"a3143724-bcb1-43db-81c5-1dd05945eaab","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3613}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"6421c7b2-7014-440e-9db3-ddcef2347c45","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3635}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/w h_tags","id":"96922922-ed4f-40f0-aa7f-c46d52ae9333","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":66}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a8be2a4f-8ec9-4630-92a3-5851d31be1f5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1738}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"606e688d-3b96-4135-b4cc-5e0179861fbf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1730}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"ab1c537f-4b13-4d78-b4f4-68ddf455de87","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1724}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"22c0d50b-7dc6-4fba-af43-278f8681b454","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1723}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"aca9fc11-91fe-4ef6-b443-bef038a7eda7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1676}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7aba029f-def5-4c05-8fc0-058977dcaffe","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1444}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9419a38f-a726-40eb-b756-8a1db36258b0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1443}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"0fcd2d23-6284-49bd-9af5-b0a5db80d4fc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1442}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1388}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"9dcd03fe-f263-4c05-a626-7a3a158bf1c6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4004}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"5d78b823-cc84-49e7-9cb7-2cf92db63428","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3953}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1359"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1360,"drupal_internal__vid":1360,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Multi-component groundwater management programs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Multi-component groundwater management programs | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Protect underground water resources via regular groundwater monitoring, education about risks to groundwater, water quotas and taxes, and other efforts"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/multi-component-groundwater-management-programs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Protect underground water resources via regular groundwater monitoring, education about risks to groundwater, water quotas and taxes, and other efforts"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/multi-component-groundwater-management-programs","pid":1595,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2021-02-22","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that multi-component groundwater management programs increase use of water management best practices ({Holsman 2002}, {Keesstra 2012}), and improve water quality ({Sahrawat 2010}, {Kay 2009}, {Kay 2012}, {Esteban 2013}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects, especially at the catchment level ({Kay 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMulti-component groundwater management programs can increase closure of abandoned wells, use of safeguards in pesticide storage and handling, well water testing, nutrient best management, and integrated pest management practices ({Holsman 2002}, {Keesstra 2012}). Soil and water conservation practices can reduce soil loss, as well as water, pesticide, and excess nutrient runoff ({Sahrawat 2010}, {Keesstra 2012}), especially from individual plots and fields ({Kay 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAt catchment scale, current programs appear to be less effective, often due to their voluntary nature, insufficient financial rewards, unclear farm costs, or insufficient regulatory pressure and monitoring ({Kay 2012}). Experts suggest that increased monitoring and regulation of these programs at the catchment level could improve their effectiveness ({Sahrawat 2010}, {King County DNR 2005}, {Kay 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOne California-based study suggests regional source water protection plans offer an opportunity to address inequities in rural access to safe, affordable drinking water and water management planning. However, especially among small, rural communities of color with low incomes, limited power and resources can prevent participation in regional strategies. Efforts to support rural community participation are suggested to avoid further establishing historic inequities in water provision, access, and quality ({Dobbin 2020}). Farmer participation is also important to understand the feasibility and implications of regional water governance plans ({Mendez-Barrientos 2020}, {Wagner 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESuccessful efforts to promote sustainable groundwater management incorporate scientific knowledge about aquifers, climate, and habitat characteristics; understand the legal, economic, political, and historical context surrounding groundwater rights and use ({Blomquist 2020}); seek out and incorporate community feedback to solve problems continuously ({Simpson 2020}); and use landscape scale planning as a tool to consider land use changes over time ({Braga 2020}). Local design and implementation plans may be more successful for settling conflicts between groundwater users than top-down efforts ({Castilla-Rho 2019}). Groundwater management programs can use taxes on pumping groundwater to reduce aquifer use, though education efforts may also be needed to improve the political acceptability of such tax policies ({Duke 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInconvenience, ignorance, and cost can be barriers to implementing groundwater management practices for private well owners. Including educational materials and regulatory enforcement in multi-component programs may overcome such barriers ({Kreutzwiser 2011}). Surveys suggest many groundwater management programs face staffing limitations and budget decreases, and issues with declining groundwater quality and quantity often due to contamination and overuse ({Petersen-Perlman 2018}). Timing and frequency of management decisions, especially relative to irrigation season, can influence the effectiveness of groundwater management efforts ({White 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that multi-component groundwater management programs increase use of water management best practices ({Holsman 2002}, {Keesstra 2012}), and improve water quality ({Sahrawat 2010}, {Kay 2009}, {Kay 2012}, {Esteban 2013}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects, especially at the catchment level ({Kay 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMulti-component groundwater management programs can increase closure of abandoned wells, use of safeguards in pesticide storage and handling, well water testing, nutrient best management, and integrated pest management practices ({Holsman 2002}, {Keesstra 2012}). Soil and water conservation practices can reduce soil loss, as well as water, pesticide, and excess nutrient runoff ({Sahrawat 2010}, {Keesstra 2012}), especially from individual plots and fields ({Kay 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAt catchment scale, current programs appear to be less effective, often due to their voluntary nature, insufficient financial rewards, unclear farm costs, or insufficient regulatory pressure and monitoring ({Kay 2012}). Experts suggest that increased monitoring and regulation of these programs at the catchment level could improve their effectiveness ({Sahrawat 2010}, {King County DNR 2005}, {Kay 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOne California-based study suggests regional source water protection plans offer an opportunity to address inequities in rural access to safe, affordable drinking water and water management planning. However, especially among small, rural communities of color with low incomes, limited power and resources can prevent participation in regional strategies. Efforts to support rural community participation are suggested to avoid further establishing historic inequities in water provision, access, and quality ({Dobbin 2020}). Farmer participation is also important to understand the feasibility and implications of regional water governance plans ({Mendez-Barrientos 2020}, {Wagner 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESuccessful efforts to promote sustainable groundwater management incorporate scientific knowledge about aquifers, climate, and habitat characteristics; understand the legal, economic, political, and historical context surrounding groundwater rights and use ({Blomquist 2020}); seek out and incorporate community feedback to solve problems continuously ({Simpson 2020}); and use landscape scale planning as a tool to consider land use changes over time ({Braga 2020}). Local design and implementation plans may be more successful for settling conflicts between groundwater users than top-down efforts ({Castilla-Rho 2019}). Groundwater management programs can use taxes on pumping groundwater to reduce aquifer use, though education efforts may also be needed to improve the political acceptability of such tax policies ({Duke 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInconvenience, ignorance, and cost can be barriers to implementing groundwater management practices for private well owners. Including educational materials and regulatory enforcement in multi-component programs may overcome such barriers ({Kreutzwiser 2011}). Surveys suggest many groundwater management programs face staffing limitations and budget decreases, and issues with declining groundwater quality and quantity often due to contamination and overuse ({Petersen-Perlman 2018}). Timing and frequency of management decisions, especially relative to irrigation season, can influence the effectiveness of groundwater management efforts ({White 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many groundwater management programs in the U.S. Examples include state-level programs such as those established by the Sustainable Groundwater Management Act in California ({CA DWR-SGMA}), Florida\u2019s Ground Water Program ({FL DEP-Water resource management}), Minnesota\u2019s Department of Natural Resources Groundwater Management Program ({MN DNR-GMP}), and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality\u2019s groundwater protection programs ({TCEQ-Groundwater}). In Arizona, regional Active Management Areas (AMAs) coordinate state and local efforts to regulate groundwater use, with a goal of achieving safe yield, or withdrawing no more groundwater than is being replaced annually, by 2025. Some AMA initiatives include efforts to capture surface water and use it to replenish underground water supplies ({AZ DWR-AMA}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMany regional or municipal areas have programs such as the Sacramento Groundwater Authority\u2019s Groundwater Management Plan ({SGA-GMP}), the Las Vegas Valley Groundwater Management Program ({Las Vegas-GMP}), and the King County Groundwater Protection Program in Washington ({King County-GPP}). In Kansas, five regional Groundwater Management Districts address groundwater depletion and declining groundwater quality, often using intensive local conservation and enhanced management plans ({KS DOA-GMDs}). In Nebraska, 23 local Natural Resources Districts (NRDs) have been established based on river basin boundaries; NRDs have state support, local authority, and mandated responsibilities for groundwater protection and preservation and 11 other focus areas, including protection for surface water resources, from flooding, against soil erosion, and for rangeland and forestry management ({NE NRD-Water}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENon-governmental organizations can also partner to create groundwater management programs that offer education, technical assistance, monitoring services, and outline voluntary steps to reduce water contamination risks, for example the Michigan Water Stewardship Program ({MWSP}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many groundwater management programs in the U.S. Examples include state-level programs such as those established by the Sustainable Groundwater Management Act in California ({CA DWR-SGMA}), Florida\u2019s Ground Water Program ({FL DEP-Water resource management}), Minnesota\u2019s Department of Natural Resources Groundwater Management Program ({MN DNR-GMP}), and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality\u2019s groundwater protection programs ({TCEQ-Groundwater}). In Arizona, regional Active Management Areas (AMAs) coordinate state and local efforts to regulate groundwater use, with a goal of achieving safe yield, or withdrawing no more groundwater than is being replaced annually, by 2025. Some AMA initiatives include efforts to capture surface water and use it to replenish underground water supplies ({AZ DWR-AMA}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMany regional or municipal areas have programs such as the Sacramento Groundwater Authority\u2019s Groundwater Management Plan ({SGA-GMP}), the Las Vegas Valley Groundwater Management Program ({Las Vegas-GMP}), and the King County Groundwater Protection Program in Washington ({King County-GPP}). In Kansas, five regional Groundwater Management Districts address groundwater depletion and declining groundwater quality, often using intensive local conservation and enhanced management plans ({KS DOA-GMDs}). In Nebraska, 23 local Natural Resources Districts (NRDs) have been established based on river basin boundaries; NRDs have state support, local authority, and mandated responsibilities for groundwater protection and preservation and 11 other focus areas, including protection for surface water resources, from flooding, against soil erosion, and for rangeland and forestry management ({NE NRD-Water}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ENon-governmental organizations can also partner to create groundwater management programs that offer education, technical assistance, monitoring services, and outline voluntary steps to reduce water contamination risks, for example the Michigan Water Stewardship Program ({MWSP}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":52,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased water conservation","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased water conservation\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced soil erosion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced soil erosion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced run-off","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced run-off\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased use of water management practices","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased use of water management practices\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved water quality","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved water quality\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NGWA-Resources","CDC-Groundwater awareness","BC-Well protection"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NGWA-Resources\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00223648\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NGWA-Resources\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Groundwater Association (NGWA). -4a58-a4bd-c6e45417c0bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":17}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"9c091979-5739-4910-9ff2-1518c33bd741","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":24}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"6e4a4e84-7af4-4bd9-931e-c77a4bee7fd9","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3847}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"88440bd3-31ca-437c-b4c3-2a2e96ba95fe","meta":{"target_revision_id":11317,"drupal_internal__target_id":6309}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"db29cd12-ba50-4afe-9c7a-a8815b72cd46","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":34}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"10f0f0e1-cd87-4b20-9eca-6e176e2506cb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":35}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ac6842c1-64d6-4d67-b177-0c542e9604c0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":37}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ce826d90-f97f-4a05-8b29-93f405b1fb33","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":40}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ca8c87e8-ad24-461f-9429-a93bf91f6fe4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":45}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"af68bd1e-7b67-4620-8f44-64ef2a30a310","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":48}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"e076998a-491c-45ee-bc55-43ea4b0b8d03","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":55}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"65b3c8c1-a534-4eff-b863-bcc00c3f7ecb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":56}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"47bdd586-bb5c-4446-8ca1-2e4fa9f5b1b7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":57}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--progr l__target_id":1543}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"10dc5cd6-4401-4cdc-9eec-ca3c6ba48218","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1448}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"d18bba32-4ee0-4adb-b10f-c9f43602f0d9","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1447}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"009d5a6e-0a77-439e-b780-85560f472874","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3971}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"cffc2cd7-44a0-424b-a5c0-d04087163459","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3949}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/463e62e2-c504-494d-a57e-d3903f0f3f8d\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1360"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1362,"drupal_internal__vid":1362,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Patient shared decision making","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Patient shared decision making | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Support joint decision making between health care practitioners and patients through shared decision making (SDM); part of patient-centered care"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/patient-shared-decision-making"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Support joint decision making between health care practitioners and patients through shared decision making (SDM); part of patient-centered care"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/patient-shared-decision-making","pid":1597,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-02-19","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that patient shared decision making (SDM) using decision aids improves patients\u2019 knowledge of treatment options ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Volk 2016}, {Austin 2015}, {Durand 2014}, {Knops 2013}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}), increases their involvement in the decision making process ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Ivlev 2017}, {Blyer 2016}, {Nathan 2016}, {Austin 2015}, {Shay 2015}, {Durand 2014}, {Knops 2013}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}), and improves patient-provider communication ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {Nathan 2016}, {Mead 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDecision aids improve patient participation in their treatment decisions ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}), help patients make difficult decisions ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Shay 2015}, {Knops 2013}, {Woodhouse 2017}), and reduce anxiety related to treatment ({Mead 2013}, {Dugas 2012}, {Joosten 2008}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}) and screenings ({Nathan 2016}). Using probabilities in decision aids, especially expressed in numbers, improves the accuracy of the level of risk patients perceive ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}). Computerized aids appear as effective as aids delivered in person ({Sheehan 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESDM has been shown to be particularly effective for patients making long-term decisions, patients with chronic health problems ({Joosten 2008}), seriously ill patients in palliative care ({Austin 2015}), and patients with atrial fibrillation who are at risk of strokes ({O\u2019Neill 2017}). SDM can also increase knowledge regarding colorectal cancer screening ({Volk 2016}), reduce decision conflict and anxiety regarding decisions for cancer screening ({Nathan 2016}), and support women\u2019s decisions related to pregnancy and birth ({Dugas 2012}). Allowing time to build rapport and trust with providers using SDM may improve patients\u2019 mental health ({Cochrane-Legare 2014}, {Zisman-Ilani 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUse of decision aids has been shown to reduce the frequency of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening, major elective surgeries ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}) and other invasive procedures ({Knops 2013}), and to reduce antibiotic use for respiratory infections ({Cochrane-Tonkin-Crine 2017}, {Blyer 2016}). SDM may improve asthma management and increase satisfaction for asthmatic patients and their parents ({Cochrane-Kew 2017}). SDM also appears to improve quality of life for patients during cancer treatment ({Kashaf 2015}) and can increase patient satisfaction overall ({Shay 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESDM has been shown to improve patient-provider communication for racial and ethnic minorities ({Nathan 2016}, {Mead 2013}). Individuals with low incomes or low literacy levels appear to benefit more from SDM than peers with higher incomes or levels of education ({Durand 2014}). Educational meetings, feedback, learning materials, and decision aids ({Cochrane-Legare 2014}), along with policies to support use, may help health care providers adopt SDM ({Williams 2017}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe impact of patient shared decision making on health care costs is unclear. Some studies show lower costs or no additional costs ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {Walsh 2014}), while others suggest per person savings ranging from $8 to $3,068 ({Walsh 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that patient shared decision making (SDM) using decision aids improves patients\u2019 knowledge of treatment options ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Volk 2016}, {Austin 2015}, {Durand 2014}, {Knops 2013}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}), increases their involvement in the decision making process ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Ivlev 2017}, {Blyer 2016}, {Nathan 2016}, {Austin 2015}, {Shay 2015}, {Durand 2014}, {Knops 2013}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}), and improves patient-provider communication ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {Nathan 2016}, {Mead 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDecision aids improve patient participation in their treatment decisions ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}), help patients make difficult decisions ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}, {O\u2019Neill 2017}, {Shay 2015}, {Knops 2013}, {Woodhouse 2017}), and reduce anxiety related to treatment ({Mead 2013}, {Dugas 2012}, {Joosten 2008}, {O\u2019Brien 2009}) and screenings ({Nathan 2016}). Using probabilities in decision aids, especially expressed in numbers, improves the accuracy of the level of risk patients perceive ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}). Computerized aids appear as effective as aids delivered in person ({Sheehan 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESDM has been shown to be particularly effective for patients making long-term decisions, patients with chronic health problems ({Joosten 2008}), seriously ill patients in palliative care ({Austin 2015}), and patients with atrial fibrillation who are at risk of strokes ({O\u2019Neill 2017}). SDM can also increase knowledge regarding colorectal cancer screening ({Volk 2016}), reduce decision conflict and anxiety regarding decisions for cancer screening ({Nathan 2016}), and support women\u2019s decisions related to pregnancy and birth ({Dugas 2012}). Allowing time to build rapport and trust with providers using SDM may improve patients\u2019 mental health ({Cochrane-Legare 2014}, {Zisman-Ilani 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUse of decision aids has been shown to reduce the frequency of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening, major elective surgeries ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}) and other invasive procedures ({Knops 2013}), and to reduce antibiotic use for respiratory infections ({Cochrane-Tonkin-Crine 2017}, {Blyer 2016}). SDM may improve asthma management and increase satisfaction for asthmatic patients and their parents ({Cochrane-Kew 2017}). SDM also appears to improve quality of life for patients during cancer treatment ({Kashaf 2015}) and can increase patient satisfaction overall ({Shay 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESDM has been shown to improve patient-provider communication for racial and ethnic minorities ({Nathan 2016}, {Mead 2013}). Individuals with low incomes or low literacy levels appear to benefit more from SDM than peers with higher incomes or levels of education ({Durand 2014}). Educational meetings, feedback, learning materials, and decision aids ({Cochrane-Legare 2014}), along with policies to support use, may help health care providers adopt SDM ({Williams 2017}). \u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe impact of patient shared decision making on health care costs is unclear. Some studies show lower costs or no additional costs ({Cochrane-Stacey 2017}, {Walsh 2014}), while others suggest per person savings ranging from $8 to $3,068 ({Walsh 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality\u2019s (AHRQ\u2019s) SHARE Approach promotes patient shared decision making (SDM) and trains health care providers to engage their patients in the decision making process ({AHRQ-SHARE}). The Mayo Clinic\u2019s Shared Decision Making National Resource Center also supports implementation of SDM and includes decision aids for conditions such as osteoporosis, depression, rheumatoid arthritis, and diabetes ({Mayo Clinic-SDM}). Dartmouth-Hitchcock\u2019s Center for Shared Decision Making was the first center in the U.S. focused primarily on SDM; it includes Patient Support Corps volunteers to assist patients prior to and during appointments ({Dartmouth-Hitchcock-SDM}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality\u2019s (AHRQ\u2019s) SHARE Approach promotes patient shared decision making (SDM) and trains health care providers to engage their patients in the decision making process ({AHRQ-SHARE}). The Mayo Clinic\u2019s Shared Decision Making National Resource Center also supports implementation of SDM and includes decision aids for conditions such as osteoporosis, depression, rheumatoid arthritis, and diabetes ({Mayo Clinic-SDM}). Dartmouth-Hitchcock\u2019s Center for Shared Decision Making was the first center in the U.S. focused primarily on SDM; it includes Patient Support Corps volunteers to assist patients prior to and during appointments ({Dartmouth-Hitchcock-SDM}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":59,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced use of expensive procedures","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced use of expensive procedures\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved patient knowledge","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved patient knowledge\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved patient decision making","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved patient decision making\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved patient-provider communication","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved patient-provider communication\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Healthwise-SDM","Mayo Clinic-SDM"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Healthwise-SDM\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221998\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Healthwise-SDM\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Healthwise. Care transformation: Uncover the voice of patients with shared decision making (SDM).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.healthwise.org\\\/shareddecisionmaking.aspx\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222018-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Mayo Clinic-SDM\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228099\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Mayo Clinic-SDM\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Mayo Clinic.
