,"id":"9965185f-f51b-4cd1-b923-271966f6ce16","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1579}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1383}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"8826acaa-9ba9-411f-8778-87641ed8d0fb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1344}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"c3c7f5ca-c671-4d4e-8360-07bd4a042113","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3853}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"43c2f44f-e680-4360-9b07-746bd89f50af","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3857}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"fb93818a-de8b-4ff0-b8d2-a393381b0524","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3958}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/4d847174-ddd5-4a1f-abd3-5416a0a52285\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1362"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"00100c80-e50b-49f9-ad8c-4e01e061de13","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/00100c80-e50b-49f9-ad8c-4e01e061de13?resourceVersion=id%3A1363"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1363,"drupal_internal__vid":1363,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Financial rewards for employee healthy behavior","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:18:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Financial rewards for employee healthy behavior | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Offer payments, credits toward health insurance premiums, or other financial rewards to encourage employees to lose weight, eat more healthily, quit smoking, engage in physical activity, etc."}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-rewards-for-employee-healthy-behavior"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Offer payments, credits toward health insurance premiums, or other financial rewards to encourage employees to lose weight, eat more healthily, quit smoking, engage in physical activity, etc."}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Workplace"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/financial-rewards-for-employee-healthy-behavior","pid":1598,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2020-05-22","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that offering financial rewards for healthy behavior helps employees reach short-term health goals ({John 2011}, {Volpp 2008}, {Cawley 2013a}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm long-term effects ({O\u2019Donnell 2012}, {Paul-Ebhohimhen 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERewards increase program participation and can help employees reach short-term health goals in some circumstances ({O\u2019Donnell 2012}). Workplace interventions offering financial rewards for weight loss can result in modest weight loss after one year, although such programs often have high attrition rates ({Cawley 2013a}). Financial incentives can encourage more weight loss than program participation without incentives ({John 2011}, {Volpp 2008}). One workplace wellness program study suggests temporary reductions of health care premiums may not have a significant effect on participants\u2019 weight loss; experts recommend different incentive designs or larger incentive amounts ({Patel 2016}). In a study of smoking cessation, employees who received a financial reward were more likely to have maintained abstinence at six months compared to those who received only informational resources and free smoking cessation aids; although many participants resumed smoking after one year, suggesting a need for on-going incentives ({Halpern 2015}).\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEffects appear strongest for larger rewards and rewards delivered soon after participants adopt the target behaviors ({Marteau 2009}). Studies suggest modest financial incentives may increase employees\u2019 healthy food purchases and vigorous and strength training exercise at on-site facilities. However, tailoring is needed to ensure incentives appeal to individuals who may benefit the most from participation, those who typically purchase less healthy foods or report less exercise at the beginning of the program ({Thorndike 2016}, {Crespin 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPoorly constructed programs, however, may encourage gaming or unhealthy behavior ({NIHCR-Tu 2010}), and can increase disparities in health care coverage if they penalize disadvantaged persons less able to reach health goals ({Volk 2012}). Tying large incentives to health status can lead to unfair cost sharing for employees less able to participate, such as shift, part-time and off-site employees, who may also experience increased health risks ({RAND-Mattke 2013}). Financial incentives may also undermine motivation to continue healthy behaviors once rewards end ({Mantzari 2015}, {Marteau 2009}). Experts therefore suggest pairing rewards with health programs that encourage participation, progress towards health goals, and lifestyle change ({Volk 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOne study suggests group incentives may motivate greater weight loss, depending on design and reward amount, compared to individual incentives ({Kullgren 2013a}); however, a study of incentives for smoking cessation and physical activity finds no difference between individual and group incentives ({Halpern 2015}). Still another study of incentives to increase physical activity suggests that the opportunity to earn an individual incentive in addition to an incentive as part of a team leads to the greatest increase in physical activity, though there was no difference at follow up between approaches ({Patel 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWorkplace wellness initiatives that include financial rewards for healthy behavior can generate cost savings; savings result from reduced absenteeism, lower use of health care services, or reduced workers compensation and disability claims, and generally begin two or more years after implementation ({Volk 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that offering financial rewards for healthy behavior helps employees reach short-term health goals ({John 2011}, {Volpp 2008}, {Cawley 2013a}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm long-term effects ({O\u2019Donnell 2012}, {Paul-Ebhohimhen 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERewards increase program participation and can help employees reach short-term health goals in some circumstances ({O\u2019Donnell 2012}). Workplace interventions offering financial rewards for weight loss can result in modest weight loss after one year, although such programs often have high attrition rates ({Cawley 2013a}). Financial incentives can encourage more weight loss than program participation without incentives ({John 2011}, {Volpp 2008}). One workplace wellness program study suggests temporary reductions of health care premiums may not have a significant effect on participants\u2019 weight loss; experts recommend different incentive designs or larger incentive amounts ({Patel 2016}). In a study of smoking cessation, employees who received a financial reward were more likely to have maintained abstinence at six months compared to those who received only informational resources and free smoking cessation aids; although many participants resumed smoking after one year, suggesting a need for on-going incentives ({Halpern 2015}).\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EEffects appear strongest for larger rewards and rewards delivered soon after participants adopt the target behaviors ({Marteau 2009}). Studies suggest modest financial incentives may increase employees\u2019 healthy food purchases and vigorous and strength training exercise at on-site facilities. However, tailoring is needed to ensure incentives appeal to individuals who may benefit the most from participation, those who typically purchase less healthy foods or report less exercise at the beginning of the program ({Thorndike 2016}, {Crespin 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPoorly constructed programs, however, may encourage gaming or unhealthy behavior ({NIHCR-Tu 2010}), and can increase disparities in health care coverage if they penalize disadvantaged persons less able to reach health goals ({Volk 2012}). Tying large incentives to health status can lead to unfair cost sharing for employees less able to participate, such as shift, part-time and off-site employees, who may also experience increased health risks ({RAND-Mattke 2013}). Financial incentives may also undermine motivation to continue healthy behaviors once rewards end ({Mantzari 2015}, {Marteau 2009}). Experts therefore suggest pairing rewards with health programs that encourage participation, progress towards health goals, and lifestyle change ({Volk 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOne study suggests group incentives may motivate greater weight loss, depending on design and reward amount, compared to individual incentives ({Kullgren 2013a}); however, a study of incentives for smoking cessation and physical activity finds no difference between individual and group incentives ({Halpern 2015}). Still another study of incentives to increase physical activity suggests that the opportunity to earn an individual incentive in addition to an incentive as part of a team leads to the greatest increase in physical activity, though there was no difference at follow up between approaches ({Patel 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWorkplace wellness initiatives that include financial rewards for healthy behavior can generate cost savings; savings result from reduced absenteeism, lower use of health care services, or reduced workers compensation and disability claims, and generally begin two or more years after implementation ({Volk 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EA national CDC survey of employers suggests slightly more than half of worksites with health promotion programs include incentives for employees to earn through participation, achievement of a health standard, or both ({Linnan 2019}). The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) requires that employers offer reasonable alternatives for employees medically unable to reach those standards ({Volk 2012}), though different rules apply to participatory wellness programs, which do not base rewards or penalties on health status ({KFF-Pollitz 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECommon types of incentives include cash, gift cards, merchandise, paid time off, and health plan premium discounts; for example, wellness programs which use defined health targets may reimburse employees up to 30% of the total cost of health care coverage or up to 50% if tobacco-related components are included ({KFF-Pollitz 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EA national CDC survey of employers suggests slightly more than half of worksites with health promotion programs include incentives for employees to earn through participation, achievement of a health standard, or both ({Linnan 2019}). The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) requires that employers offer reasonable alternatives for employees medically unable to reach those standards ({Volk 2012}), though different rules apply to participatory wellness programs, which do not base rewards or penalties on health status ({KFF-Pollitz 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECommon types of incentives include cash, gift cards, merchandise, paid time off, and health plan premium discounts; for example, wellness programs which use defined health targets may reimburse employees up to 30% of the total cost of health care coverage or up to 50% if tobacco-related components are included ({KFF-Pollitz 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":60,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved weight status","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved weight status\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced employer health insurance costs","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced employer health insurance costs\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced absenteeism","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced absenteeism\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved attainment of short-term health goals","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved attainment of short-term health goals\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CDC-Workplace health","O\u2019Donnell 2012","TCHS-Workplace wellness 2015"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Workplace","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CDC-Workplace health\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221486\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CDC-Workplace health\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Financial incentives for extended weight loss: A randomized, controlled trial. Journal of General Internal Medicine. 2011;26(6):621\\u20136.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/link.springer.com\\\/article\\\/10.1007\\\/s11606-010-1628-y\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222020-05-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Volpp 2008\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222697\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Volpp 2008\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Volpp KG, John LK, Troxel AB, et al. Financial incentive-based approaches for weight loss: A randomized trial. Journal of the American Medical Association. 2008;300(22):2631\\u20137.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/jama.jamanetwork.com\\\/article.aspx?articleid=183047\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222020-05-06\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Cawley 2013a\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210032\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Cawley 2013a\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Cawley J, Price JA. A case study of a workplace wellness program that offers financial incentives for weight loss. Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-taxes","pid":1599,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-03-07","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs there an alcohol tax in your community? If not, does your state preempt you from having a local alcohol tax?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs the alcohol tax implemented in your community effective in reducing the purchase and consumption of alcohol? How does it need to be altered to be effective?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat other interventions, such as alcohol outlet density restrictions, could be paired with the alcohol tax to support positive change?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre you seeing substitution effects in your community? Is substitution higher amongst certain population groups (e.g., consumers with low incomes)? What steps can be taken, or interventions implemented, to reduce the potential for a substitution effect?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs there an alcohol tax in your community? If not, does your state preempt you from having a local alcohol tax?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EIs the alcohol tax implemented in your community effective in reducing the purchase and consumption of alcohol? How does it need to be altered to be effective?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat other interventions, such as alcohol outlet density restrictions, could be paired with the alcohol tax to support positive change?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre you seeing substitution effects in your community? Is substitution higher amongst certain population groups (e.g., consumers with low incomes)? What steps can be taken, or interventions implemented, to reduce the potential for a substitution effect?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that alcohol taxes have the potential to decrease disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms by income level ({NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Meier 2016}). However, it is unclear what impact alcohol taxes may have on racial and ethnic disparities.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPeople with low incomes may experience more health benefits from alcohol taxes since increased alcohol costs may lead to decreased alcohol consumption ({Meier 2016}). Additionally, alcohol consumers with lower incomes are more likely to experience alcohol-related harms than those with higher incomes ({Meier 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxes appear to change drinking behavior across racial and ethnic groups differently, with a greater impact on whites and the smallest impact among Hispanics ({An 2011}). The effects vary by the type of alcohol taxed. For example, higher beer taxes are associated with lower odds of any drinking among white women, and less beer consumed and lower odds of alcohol-related consequences among Black women. Higher spirits taxes are associated with less beer consumed by Hispanic men and women and less wine consumed by Hispanic women ({Subbaraman 2020}). Experts suggest further research is needed to understand how to address efficiency and equity in implementation of alcohol taxes to close disparities in alcohol-related harms ({An 2011}). An Illinois-based study suggests that alcohol tax increases may reduce sexually transmitted infections, particularly among non-Hispanic Blacks ({Staras 2014}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBlacks and Latinos experience disproportionate personal and social consequences of alcohol use, including alcohol use disorder symptoms and various social problems, compared with other racial and ethnic groups when consuming similar levels of alcohol ({Mulia 2017}). Alcohol consumers who are Black or Hispanic appear more likely to experience alcohol-related injuries, accidents, and health and social consequences than consumers who are white. These racial and ethnic disparities are seen across all levels of consumption and may be most pronounced at low levels of consumption, suggesting there are environmental and cultural factors at play ({Delker 2016}, {Witbrodt 2014}). Evidence suggests that the combined effects of drinking cultures, historically rooted patterns of racial discrimination and persistent socioeconomic disadvantage in racialized groups contribute to these disparities ({Vaeth 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that alcohol taxes have the potential to decrease disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms by income level ({NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Meier 2016}). However, it is unclear what impact alcohol taxes may have on racial and ethnic disparities.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPeople with low incomes may experience more health benefits from alcohol taxes since increased alcohol costs may lead to decreased alcohol consumption ({Meier 2016}). Additionally, alcohol consumers with lower incomes are more likely to experience alcohol-related harms than those with higher incomes ({Meier 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxes appear to change drinking behavior across racial and ethnic groups differently, with a greater impact on whites and the smallest impact among Hispanics ({An 2011}). The effects vary by the type of alcohol taxed. For example, higher beer taxes are associated with lower odds of any drinking among white women, and less beer consumed and lower odds of alcohol-related consequences among Black women. Higher spirits taxes are associated with less beer consumed by Hispanic men and women and less wine consumed by Hispanic women ({Subbaraman 2020}). Experts suggest further research is needed to understand how to address efficiency and equity in implementation of alcohol taxes to close disparities in alcohol-related harms ({An 2011}). An Illinois-based study suggests that alcohol tax increases may reduce sexually transmitted infections, particularly among non-Hispanic Blacks ({Staras 2014}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBlacks and Latinos experience disproportionate personal and social consequences of alcohol use, including alcohol use disorder symptoms and various social problems, compared with other racial and ethnic groups when consuming similar levels of alcohol ({Mulia 2017}). Alcohol consumers who are Black or Hispanic appear more likely to experience alcohol-related injuries, accidents, and health and social consequences than consumers who are white. These racial and ethnic disparities are seen across all levels of consumption and may be most pronounced at low levels of consumption, suggesting there are environmental and cultural factors at play ({Delker 2016}, {Witbrodt 2014}). Evidence suggests that the combined effects of drinking cultures, historically rooted patterns of racial discrimination and persistent socioeconomic disadvantage in racialized groups contribute to these disparities ({Vaeth 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxation in the U.S. began in 1791. Alcohol taxes were used at the end of Prohibition in 1933 to offset federal deficits during the Great Depression, and eventually helped fund spending associated with World War II and the Korean War. Additionally, alcohol taxes have been levied to benefit public health to reduce excessive drinking and help cover the costs of alcohol-related societal harms. Federal alcohol excise taxes were last increased in 1991, then reduced in 2020 ({CRS-Cilluffo 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe alcohol industry is viewed by public health and academia as legitimate partners in the development of national alcohol policy. Since the 1950s the alcohol industry has intervened and influenced research and policy to help normalize drinking, reproduce industry narratives regarding the causes of alcohol harms, and reduce regulation ({Maani 2023}). These attempts to influence public perceptions of alcohol have the potential to confuse public opinion about the health effects of alcohol, discredit independent scientists, damage the integrity of science, and discourage or delay implementation of effective alcohol policies ({Babor 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxation in the U.S. began in 1791. Alcohol taxes were used at the end of Prohibition in 1933 to offset federal deficits during the Great Depression, and eventually helped fund spending associated with World War II and the Korean War. Additionally, alcohol taxes have been levied to benefit public health to reduce excessive drinking and help cover the costs of alcohol-related societal harms. Federal alcohol excise taxes were last increased in 1991, then reduced in 2020 ({CRS-Cilluffo 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe alcohol industry is viewed by public health and academia as legitimate partners in the development of national alcohol policy. Since the 1950s the alcohol industry has intervened and influenced research and policy to help normalize drinking, reproduce industry narratives regarding the causes of alcohol harms, and reduce regulation ({Maani 2023}). These attempts to influence public perceptions of alcohol have the potential to confuse public opinion about the health effects of alcohol, discredit independent scientists, damage the integrity of science, and discourage or delay implementation of effective alcohol policies ({Babor 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that increasing alcohol taxes reduces excessive alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {NBER-Saffer 2022}) and alcohol-related harms ({CG-Alcohol}, {Lavoie 2017}, {Wagenaar 2010}). Alcohol consumption decreases when alcohol prices increase; effects have been shown for beer, wine, and spirits ({CG-Alcohol}, {NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {Giesbrecht 2016}, {Esser 2016}). Higher alcohol prices, often achieved through tax increases, are also associated with lower levels of drinking among high school and college-age youth ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigher alcohol prices reduce alcohol-related harms such as alcohol-related motor vehicle crashes. Injuries and fatalities ({CG-Alcohol}, {Lavoie 2017}, {Wagenaar 2010}, {Wagenaar 2015}), and mortality from liver cirrhosis ({CG-Alcohol}). Lower state beer taxes are associated with higher prevalence of alcoholic liver disease across all age groups, and in particular middle-aged individuals with low socioeconomic status ({Aslam 2021}). Alcohol tax increases may also reduce violence ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2010}) and reduce sexually transmitted infections (STIs) ({Wagenaar 2010}, {Staras 2014}, {Staras 2016}). In states with higher beer taxes, male adults are less likely to report being physically harmed by someone who had been drinking ({Trangenstein 2020}). Furthermore, a study of beer excise taxes in five U.S. states finds tax increases are associated with reductions in firearm homicide rates in most cases ({Tessler 2019}). A Maryland-based study suggests that state alcohol tax increases are less effective in preventing alcohol-related offenses among underage populations than for adults ({Smart 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxes are most effective at reducing the amount of alcohol consumed by people who are considered heavy drinkers ({NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Naimi 2016}). An analysis of potential alcohol tax increases suggests excessive drinkers would pay almost three quarters of the revenue generated by such increases, and those with higher incomes and who are white would pay higher per capita costs ({Naimi 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic health effects are expected to be proportional to the size of the tax increase ({CG-Alcohol}). Alcohol taxes have not substantially increased over the last several decades, resulting in an erosion in value due to inflation ({Blanchette 2020}, {Naimi 2018}). Experts suggest future legislation index alcohol taxes to inflation ({Blanchette 2020}, {Naimi 2018}) and prioritize beer taxes ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}). Furthermore, revenue generated from alcohol taxes typically help address the costs of alcohol overuse, however revenue currently only covers about a quarter of the costs ({Blanchette 2019}). Findings from an Illinois-based study suggest tax increases on spirits and wine led to an increase in beer sales. Policymakers may want to increase alcohol taxes on all alcohol types by the same percentage ({Gehrsitz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that increasing alcohol taxes reduces excessive alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {NBER-Saffer 2022}) and alcohol-related harms ({CG-Alcohol}, {Lavoie 2017}, {Wagenaar 2010}). Alcohol consumption decreases when alcohol prices increase; effects have been shown for beer, wine, and spirits ({CG-Alcohol}, {NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {Giesbrecht 2016}, {Esser 2016}). Higher alcohol prices, often achieved through tax increases, are also associated with lower levels of drinking among high school and college-age youth ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigher alcohol prices reduce alcohol-related harms such as alcohol-related motor vehicle crashes. Injuries and fatalities ({CG-Alcohol}, {Lavoie 2017}, {Wagenaar 2010}, {Wagenaar 2015}), and mortality from liver cirrhosis ({CG-Alcohol}). Lower state beer taxes are associated with higher prevalence of alcoholic liver disease across all age groups, and in particular middle-aged individuals with low socioeconomic status ({Aslam 2021}). Alcohol tax increases may also reduce violence ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2010}) and reduce sexually transmitted infections (STIs) ({Wagenaar 2010}, {Staras 2014}, {Staras 2016}). In states with higher beer taxes, male adults are less likely to report being physically harmed by someone who had been drinking ({Trangenstein 2020}). Furthermore, a study of beer excise taxes in five U.S. states finds tax increases are associated with reductions in firearm homicide rates in most cases ({Tessler 2019}). A Maryland-based study suggests that state alcohol tax increases are less effective in preventing alcohol-related offenses among underage populations than for adults ({Smart 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol taxes are most effective at reducing the amount of alcohol consumed by people who are considered heavy drinkers ({NBER-Saffer 2022}, {Naimi 2016}). An analysis of potential alcohol tax increases suggests excessive drinkers would pay almost three quarters of the revenue generated by such increases, and those with higher incomes and who are white would pay higher per capita costs ({Naimi 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic health effects are expected to be proportional to the size of the tax increase ({CG-Alcohol}). Alcohol taxes have not substantially increased over the last several decades, resulting in an erosion in value due to inflation ({Blanchette 2020}, {Naimi 2018}). Experts suggest future legislation index alcohol taxes to inflation ({Blanchette 2020}, {Naimi 2018}) and prioritize beer taxes ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}). Furthermore, revenue generated from alcohol taxes typically help address the costs of alcohol overuse, however revenue currently only covers about a quarter of the costs ({Blanchette 2019}). Findings from an Illinois-based study suggest tax increases on spirits and wine led to an increase in beer sales. Policymakers may want to increase alcohol taxes on all alcohol types by the same percentage ({Gehrsitz 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol tax rates vary by state and by type of alcohol. As of February 2023, state excise taxes range from $1.50 (MD, DC) to $14.27 (WA) per gallon of spirits, $0.20 (CA) to $2.50 (AK) per gallon of wine, and $0.02 (WY) to $1.29 (TN) per gallon of beer. Most states also levy sales taxes on spirits, wine, and beer ({TPC-Alcohol tax 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol tax rates vary by state and by type of alcohol. As of February 2023, state excise taxes range from $1.50 (MD, DC) to $14.27 (WA) per gallon of spirits, $0.20 (CA) to $2.50 (AK) per gallon of wine, and $0.02 (WY) to $1.29 (TN) per gallon of beer. Most states also levy sales taxes on spirits, wine, and beer ({TPC-Alcohol tax 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":72,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced incidence of STIs","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced incidence of STIs\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related harms","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related harms\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["APIS","TPC-Alcohol tax 2023"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022APIS\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u0022394\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APIS\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Alcohol Policy Information System (APIS). International Journal of Alcohol and Drug Research. 2016;5(3):89-99.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.ijadr.org\\\/index.php\\\/ijadr\\\/article\\\/view\\\/227\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Esser 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227393\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Esser 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Esser MB, Waters H, Smart M, Jernigan DH. Impact of Maryland\u0026rsquo;s 2011 alcohol sales tax increase on alcoholic beverage sales. The American Journal of Drug and Alcohol Abuse. 2016;42(4):404-411.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.tandfonline.com\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.3109\\\/00952990.2016.1150485\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Wagenaar 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227394\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Wagenaar 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Wagenaar AC, Livingston MD, Staras SS. Effects of a 2009 Illinois alcohol tax increase on fatal motor vehicle crashes. American Journal of Public Health. 2015;105(9):1880-1885.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/ajph.aphapublications.org\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.2105\\\/AJPH.2014.302428\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Aslam 2021\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214076\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Aslam 2021\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Aslam S, Buggs J, Melo S, et al. The association between alcoholic liver disease and alcohol tax. American Surgeon. 2021;87(1):92-96.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1177\\\/0003134820945223\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-04\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Staras 2014\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227395\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Staras 2014\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Staras SAS, Livingston MD, Christou AM, Jernigan DH, Wagenaar AC. Heterogeneous population effects of an alcohol excise tax increase on sexually transmitted infections morbidity. Addiction. 2014;109(6):904-912.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1111\\\/add.12493\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Staras 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227396\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Staras 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Staras SAS, Livingston MD, Wagenaar AC. Maryland alcohol sales tax and sexually transmitted infections: A natural experiment. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2016;50(3):e73-e80.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.sciencedirect.com\\\/science\\\/article\\\/pii\\\/S0749379715006273\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Trangenstein 2020\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214081\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Trangenstein 2020\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Trangenstein PJ, Subbaraman MS, Greenfield TK, et al. Association between state-level alcohol availability and taxation policies on the prevalence of alcohol-related harms to persons other than the drinker in the USA, 2000\\u20132015. Drug and Alcohol Review. 2020;39(3):255-266.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1111\\\/dar.13041\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-04\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Tessler 2019\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214082\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Tessler 2019\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Tessler RA, Mooney SJ, Quistberg DA, et al. State-level beer excise tax and firearm homicide in adolescents and young adults. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2019;56(5):708-715.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1016\\\/j.amepre.2019.01.009\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-04\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Smart 2018\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214078\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Smart 2018\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Smart MJ, Yearwood SS, Hwang S, Thorpe RJ, Furr-Holden CD. :{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1365}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"65233f27-7dd5-4458-a842-27b40b9ff0d3","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3960}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"858e48c6-01dd-4884-a299-bdd7a2b34bf5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3943}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/0e76f6af-aca1-498a-b41c-f9046d3b327f\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1364"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1365,"drupal_internal__vid":1365,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Drink special restrictions","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Drink special restrictions | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Limit or ban alcohol establishments from serving alcohol at a reduced price as part of promotions; also called happy hour restrictions"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/drink-special-restrictions"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Limit or ban alcohol establishments from serving alcohol at a reduced price as part of promotions; also called happy hour restrictions"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/drink-special-restrictions","pid":1600,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2019-05-14","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that restricting drink specials decreases excessive alcohol consumption ({Nelson 2015}, {Kingsland 2013}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Happy hour restrictions are a suggested strategy to reduce binge drinking, especially among college students ({RAND-Imm 2007}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDrink promotions that reduce the price of alcohol increase planned ({Kaplan 2018}, {Christie 2001}) and actual alcohol consumption ({Kingsland 2013}, {Nelson 2015}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Younger college students, women, and individuals living on campus report greater intent to increase alcohol consumption in response to happy hour specials than peers who are older, men, or live off campus ({Baldwin 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, alcohol consumption decreases when alcohol prices increase; effects have been shown for beer, wine, and spirits ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {Giesbrecht 2016}). As alcohol prices increase, alcohol-related motor vehicle accidents, traffic offenses, violence, and negative health effects also decrease ({Wagenaar 2010}, {Purshouse 2010}, {Chaloupka 2002}, {Adrian 2001}), especially among young adults ({Purshouse 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELower alcohol prices are associated with increased underage and binge drinking among college students ({Chaloupka 2002}, {Wechsler 2000}). Higher prices are associated with a lower risk of leaving an establishment intoxicated ({O\u2019Mara 2009}). The price of beer may not influence alcohol consumption among college males, but its cost appears to affect the likelihood of underage and binge drinking by college women ({Chaloupka 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that restricting drink specials decreases excessive alcohol consumption ({Nelson 2015}, {Kingsland 2013}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Happy hour restrictions are a suggested strategy to reduce binge drinking, especially among college students ({RAND-Imm 2007}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDrink promotions that reduce the price of alcohol increase planned ({Kaplan 2018}, {Christie 2001}) and actual alcohol consumption ({Kingsland 2013}, {Nelson 2015}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Younger college students, women, and individuals living on campus report greater intent to increase alcohol consumption in response to happy hour specials than peers who are older, men, or live off campus ({Baldwin 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOverall, alcohol consumption decreases when alcohol prices increase; effects have been shown for beer, wine, and spirits ({CG-Alcohol}, {Wagenaar 2009}, {Giesbrecht 2016}). As alcohol prices increase, alcohol-related motor vehicle accidents, traffic offenses, violence, and negative health effects also decrease ({Wagenaar 2010}, {Purshouse 2010}, {Chaloupka 2002}, {Adrian 2001}), especially among young adults ({Purshouse 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELower alcohol prices are associated with increased underage and binge drinking among college students ({Chaloupka 2002}, {Wechsler 2000}). Higher prices are associated with a lower risk of leaving an establishment intoxicated ({O\u2019Mara 2009}). The price of beer may not influence alcohol consumption among college males, but its cost appears to affect the likelihood of underage and binge drinking by college women ({Chaloupka 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2018, Alaska, Indiana, Massachusetts, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, Utah, and Vermont ban drink specials or happy hours ({APIS}). Some states allow drink specials or happy hours but ban unlimited drink specials. Others limit time of day or discount amount for happy hours ({APIS}, {Happy hour laws 2015}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2018, Alaska, Indiana, Massachusetts, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, Utah, and Vermont ban drink specials or happy hours ({APIS}). Some states allow drink specials or happy hours but ban unlimited drink specials. Others limit time of day or discount amount for happy hours ({APIS}, {Happy hour laws 2015}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":73,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":[],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Nelson 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228978\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Nelson 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Nelson JP. American Journal of Preventive Medicine. 2000;19(1):24\\u20139.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.sciencedirect.com\\\/science\\\/article\\\/pii\\\/S074937970000163X\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-05-21\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022O\\u2019Mara 2009\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00223477\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022O\\u2019Mara 2009\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022O\\u2019Mara RJ, Thombs DL, Wagenaar AC, et al. Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research. 2009;33(11):1973\\u201380.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1111\\\/j.1530-0277.2009.01036.x\\\/abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-05-21\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022APIS\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u0022394\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APIS\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Alcohol Policy Information System (APIS). Huffpost. 2015.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.huffpost.com\\\/entry\\\/happy-hour-restrictions-map_n_55bbc853e4b06363d5a22c7b\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-05-21\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022}}","field_retired_strategy":false,"field_strategy_acknowledgements":"Kate 07f263470\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"8b513290-1891-4635-a21f-425ed5ca28a4","meta":{"target_revision_id":11322,"drupal_internal__target_id":6314}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"10f0f0e1-cd87-4b20-9eca-6e176e2506cb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":35}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"01c2a90f-f836-44ed-a16a-613ab4674834","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3559}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ed4d2f95-44f3-4afd-b9ee-26e6f20f4b4f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":68}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"090b6d1b-ed08-4e60-a9da-69ad5fcd433c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":154 d707f263470\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/041d2a39-8c31-43cc-ad87-fd707f263470\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1365"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"3ecf4d7e-3c52-488e-a027-92c2082a85ce","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3ecf4d7e-3c52-488e-a027-92c2082a85ce?resourceVersion=id%3A1366"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1366,"drupal_internal__vid":1366,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Alcohol outlet density restrictions","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:37+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Alcohol outlet density restrictions | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Limit increases in the number and concentration of alcohol outlets by area or by population through licensing or zoning regulations"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-outlet-density-restrictions"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Limit increases in the number and concentration of alcohol outlets by area or by population through licensing or zoning regulations"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-outlet-density-restrictions","pid":1601,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2019-05-22","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alcohol outlet density restrictions reduce rates of alcohol consumption and violent crime ({CG-Alcohol}, {Sherk 2018}, {Gmel 2016}, {Jernigan 2013}, {Fitterer 2015}). Restrictions can also reduce individuals\u2019 alcohol consumption ({Gmel 2016}, {Sherk 2018}) and underage drinking ({CG-Alcohol}, {Siegfried 2019}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). Limiting the location of alcohol outlets near colleges, universities, and primary and secondary schools is a suggested strategy to reduce underage drinking ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERates of alcohol consumption and violent crimes such as assault and robbery increase as alcohol outlet density increases ({CG-Alcohol}, {Gmel 2016}, {Jernigan 2013}, {Fitterer 2015}). Youth living in areas with a high density of on-premise alcohol outlets are more likely to report alcohol use and heavy drinking than peers living in low density areas ({Siegfried 2019}, {Shih 2015}, {Paschall 2014a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGreater alcohol outlet density is associated with higher rates of intimate partner violence ({Siegfried 2019}, {Gmel 2016}, {Kearns 2015}, {Wilson 2014a}, {Snowden 2016}) and child abuse and neglect ({CG-Alcohol}, {Gmel 2016}, {Freisthler 2014}, {Morton 2014}). Effects appear to vary by alcohol outlet type ({Kearns 2015}, {Wilson 2014a}, {Snowden 2016}, {Freisthler 2014}, {Morton 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELower alcohol outlet density appears to be associated with lower rates of suicide and gun violence ({Gmel 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alcohol outlet density restrictions reduce rates of alcohol consumption and violent crime ({CG-Alcohol}, {Sherk 2018}, {Gmel 2016}, {Jernigan 2013}, {Fitterer 2015}). Restrictions can also reduce individuals\u2019 alcohol consumption ({Gmel 2016}, {Sherk 2018}) and underage drinking ({CG-Alcohol}, {Siegfried 2019}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). Limiting the location of alcohol outlets near colleges, universities, and primary and secondary schools is a suggested strategy to reduce underage drinking ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERates of alcohol consumption and violent crimes such as assault and robbery increase as alcohol outlet density increases ({CG-Alcohol}, {Gmel 2016}, {Jernigan 2013}, {Fitterer 2015}). Youth living in areas with a high density of on-premise alcohol outlets are more likely to report alcohol use and heavy drinking than peers living in low density areas ({Siegfried 2019}, {Shih 2015}, {Paschall 2014a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGreater alcohol outlet density is associated with higher rates of intimate partner violence ({Siegfried 2019}, {Gmel 2016}, {Kearns 2015}, {Wilson 2014a}, {Snowden 2016}) and child abuse and neglect ({CG-Alcohol}, {Gmel 2016}, {Freisthler 2014}, {Morton 2014}). Effects appear to vary by alcohol outlet type ({Kearns 2015}, {Wilson 2014a}, {Snowden 2016}, {Freisthler 2014}, {Morton 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELower alcohol outlet density appears to be associated with lower rates of suicide and gun violence ({Gmel 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2012, 18 states have exclusive local or joint state-local alcohol retail licensing to regulate alcohol outlet density; 24 states have exclusive state licensing but grant local governments zoning authority or have other mixed policies for density regulation ({CDC-Alcohol PSR 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2016, 12 states have some restrictions on alcohol outlet location near colleges and universities; 11 of these states apply restrictions to both on- and off-premise outlets. Thirty-one states restrict outlet locations near primary and secondary schools; 23 of these states apply such restrictions to both on- and off-premises outlets ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECalifornia and Nebraska are examples of states that have undertaken efforts to reduce alcohol outlet density ({CAMY-Alcohol outlet density}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2012, 18 states have exclusive local or joint state-local alcohol retail licensing to regulate alcohol outlet density; 24 states have exclusive state licensing but grant local governments zoning authority or have other mixed policies for density regulation ({CDC-Alcohol PSR 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2016, 12 states have some restrictions on alcohol outlet location near colleges and universities; 11 of these states apply restrictions to both on- and off-premise outlets. Thirty-one states restrict outlet locations near primary and secondary schools; 23 of these states apply such restrictions to both on- and off-premises outlets ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECalifornia and Nebraska are examples of states that have undertaken efforts to reduce alcohol outlet density ({CAMY-Alcohol outlet density}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":74,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced intimate partner violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced intimate partner violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced child maltreatment","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced child maltreatment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced suicide","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced suicide\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced gun violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced gun violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced crime","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced crime\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CAMY-Alcohol outlet density","US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018","Jernigan 2013"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CAMY-Alcohol outlet density\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221698\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CAMY-Alcohol outlet density\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Sparks M, Jernigan DH, Mosher JF. Alcohol consumption and the physical availability of take-away alcohol: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses of the days and hours of sale and outlet density. Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs. 2018;79(1):58-67.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.jsad.com\\\/doi\\\/full\\\/10.15288\\\/jsad.2018.79.58\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222020-10-21\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Gmel 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00229266\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Gmel 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Gmel G, Holmes J, Studer J. halls)"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/campus-alcohol-bans"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Restrict alcohol consumption anywhere on a college or university campus or only in specific areas (e.g., residence halls)"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/campus-alcohol-bans","pid":1602,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-10-26","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether banning alcohol on college campuses reduces underage and excessive drinking. Available evidence suggests campus-wide bans may reduce heavy drinking in some cases ({Wechsler 2001a}, {Fuertes 2016}, {Walter 2012}) and alcohol use overall ({Williams 2004}), but have no effect on mild or moderate drinking ({Fuertes 2016}). Banning both alcohol and cigarette use in substance-free student housing may decrease alcohol use ({Wechsler 2001b}), but alcohol-free student housing alone appears not to reduce alcohol use ({Williams 2004}, {Wechsler 2001b}). Alcohol and substance bans in student housing are associated with decreases in unwanted sexual advances, sexual assaults, and property damage ({Wechsler 2002}, {Wechsler 2001b}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({NIAAA-Environmental strategies}, {Lippy 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether banning alcohol on college campuses reduces underage and excessive drinking. Available evidence suggests campus-wide bans may reduce heavy drinking in some cases ({Wechsler 2001a}, {Fuertes 2016}, {Walter 2012}) and alcohol use overall ({Williams 2004}), but have no effect on mild or moderate drinking ({Fuertes 2016}). Banning both alcohol and cigarette use in substance-free student housing may decrease alcohol use ({Wechsler 2001b}), but alcohol-free student housing alone appears not to reduce alcohol use ({Williams 2004}, {Wechsler 2001b}). Alcohol and substance bans in student housing are associated with decreases in unwanted sexual advances, sexual assaults, and property damage ({Wechsler 2002}, {Wechsler 2001b}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({NIAAA-Environmental strategies}, {Lippy 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) provides a directory of alcohol policies from thousands of colleges and universities ({NIAAA-College alcohol policies}). Mississippi State University, Oklahoma State University, and University of Missouri are examples of public universities with campus-wide bans on alcohol ({MSU-Alcohol}, {OSU-Alcohol}, {MU-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) provides a directory of alcohol policies from thousands of colleges and universities ({NIAAA-College alcohol policies}). Mississippi State University, Oklahoma State University, and University of Missouri are examples of public universities with campus-wide bans on alcohol ({MSU-Alcohol}, {OSU-Alcohol}, {MU-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":75,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced sexual violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced sexual violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NIAAA-College alcohol policies","CollegeAIM"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NIAAA-College alcohol policies\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228909\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NIAAA-College alcohol policies\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA).
