beaches"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-access-restrictions-in-public-places","pid":1603,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-04-18","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there places in your community where alcohol access restrictions are already being implemented (i.e. public parks, event venues etc.)? If not, where can alcohol access restrictions be introduced and implemented?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho can you partner with to bring alcohol access restrictions to your community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho could benefit the most from alcohol access restrictions in their community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there places in your community where alcohol access restrictions are already being implemented (i.e. public parks, event venues etc.)? If not, where can alcohol access restrictions be introduced and implemented?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho can you partner with to bring alcohol access restrictions to your community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho could benefit the most from alcohol access restrictions in their community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact alcohol access restrictions in public places or sporting events may have on disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBlacks and Latinos experience disproportionate personal and social consequences of alcohol use, including alcohol use disorder symptoms and various social problems, compared with other racial and ethnic groups when consuming similar levels of alcohol ({Mulia 2017}). For example, in 2018 6.4% of non-Hispanic white adults engaged in heavy drinking compared to non-Hispanic Black (2.9%), Hispanic (2.6%), and non-Hispanic Asian (2.0%) adults ({CDC-Heavy Drinking 2018}). However, alcohol consumers who are Black or Hispanic appear more likely to experience alcohol-related injuries, accidents, and health and social consequences than consumers who are white. These racial and ethnic disparities are seen across all levels of consumption and may be most pronounced at low levels of consumption, suggesting there are environmental and cultural factors at play ({Delker 2016}, {Witbrodt 2014}). Evidence suggests that the combined effects of drinking cultures, historically rooted patterns of racial discrimination and persistent socioeconomic disadvantage in racialized groups contribute to these disparities ({Vaeth 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact alcohol access restrictions in public places or sporting events may have on disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBlacks and Latinos experience disproportionate personal and social consequences of alcohol use, including alcohol use disorder symptoms and various social problems, compared with other racial and ethnic groups when consuming similar levels of alcohol ({Mulia 2017}). For example, in 2018 6.4% of non-Hispanic white adults engaged in heavy drinking compared to non-Hispanic Black (2.9%), Hispanic (2.6%), and non-Hispanic Asian (2.0%) adults ({CDC-Heavy Drinking 2018}). However, alcohol consumers who are Black or Hispanic appear more likely to experience alcohol-related injuries, accidents, and health and social consequences than consumers who are white. These racial and ethnic disparities are seen across all levels of consumption and may be most pronounced at low levels of consumption, suggesting there are environmental and cultural factors at play ({Delker 2016}, {Witbrodt 2014}). Evidence suggests that the combined effects of drinking cultures, historically rooted patterns of racial discrimination and persistent socioeconomic disadvantage in racialized groups contribute to these disparities ({Vaeth 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe alcohol industry is viewed by public health and academia as legitimate partners in the development of national alcohol policy. Since the 1950s the alcohol industry has intervened and influenced research and policy to help normalize drinking, reproduce industry narratives regarding the causes of alcohol harms, and reduce regulation ({Maani 2023}). For example, the alcohol industry-funds research designed to establish the benefits of alcohol use. These attempts to influence public perceptions of alcohol have the potential to confuse public opinion about the health effects of alcohol, discredit independent scientists, damage the integrity of science, and discourage or delay implementation of effective alcohol policies ({Babor 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe alcohol industry is viewed by public health and academia as legitimate partners in the development of national alcohol policy. Since the 1950s the alcohol industry has intervened and influenced research and policy to help normalize drinking, reproduce industry narratives regarding the causes of alcohol harms, and reduce regulation ({Maani 2023}). For example, the alcohol industry-funds research designed to establish the benefits of alcohol use. These attempts to influence public perceptions of alcohol have the potential to confuse public opinion about the health effects of alcohol, discredit independent scientists, damage the integrity of science, and discourage or delay implementation of effective alcohol policies ({Babor 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ERestricting alcohol use and availability at public events and on public property is a suggested strategy to reduce excessive drinking and underage drinking ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}, {UMN-AEP}, {Toomey 2008}, {Toomey 2005}). An Australia-based study of alcohol sale regulations at community sports clubs indicates such regulations may reduce risky alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harm ({Kingsland 2015}). Available evidence suggests that banning or restricting alcohol sales at public events may reduce alcohol availability for youth and may also reduce alcohol-related problems such as traffic crashes, vandalism, fighting, and other public disturbances ({UMN-AEP}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). However, a study of U.S. universities suggests that allowing alcohol sales at college sporting events may have no significant impact on alcohol-related incidents and in-stadium offenses ({Popp 2020}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Nelson 2013}, {Toomey 2005}, {Toomey 2008}). \u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ERestricting alcohol use and availability at public events and on public property is a suggested strategy to reduce excessive drinking and underage drinking ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}, {UMN-AEP}, {Toomey 2008}, {Toomey 2005}). An Australia-based study of alcohol sale regulations at community sports clubs indicates such regulations may reduce risky alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harm ({Kingsland 2015}). Available evidence suggests that banning or restricting alcohol sales at public events may reduce alcohol availability for youth and may also reduce alcohol-related problems such as traffic crashes, vandalism, fighting, and other public disturbances ({UMN-AEP}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). However, a study of U.S. universities suggests that allowing alcohol sales at college sporting events may have no significant impact on alcohol-related incidents and in-stadium offenses ({Popp 2020}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Nelson 2013}, {Toomey 2005}, {Toomey 2008}). \u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMany local government ordinances regulate alcohol sales and use on public property and at public events. Santa Fe, New Mexico is an example of a city that prohibits alcohol sales on most city property ({Santa Fe-Regulations}) and the City of Gulf Shores in Alabama bans alcohol consumption or possession on public beaches ({Gulf Shores-Alcohol}). Event organizers in urban and rural areas around the country also implement restrictions and work to ensure that staff who serve alcohol beverage are trained to comply with these policies and sometimes use other strategies together, such as limiting crowd size ({UMN-AEP}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMany local government ordinances regulate alcohol sales and use on public property and at public events. Santa Fe, New Mexico is an example of a city that prohibits alcohol sales on most city property ({Santa Fe-Regulations}) and the City of Gulf Shores in Alabama bans alcohol consumption or possession on public beaches ({Gulf Shores-Alcohol}). Event organizers in urban and rural areas around the country also implement restrictions and work to ensure that staff who serve alcohol beverage are trained to comply with these policies and sometimes use other strategies together, such as limiting crowd size ({UMN-AEP}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":77,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related harms","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related harms\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["HSNI-Alcohol management"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022HSNI-Alcohol management\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222553\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022HSNI-Alcohol management\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Helping Services for Northeast Iowa (HSNI). About alcohol policy.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/alcoholpolicy.niaaa.nih.gov\\\/about\\\/about-alcohol-policy\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Zapolski 2014\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214243\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Zapolski 2014\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Zapolski TCB, Pedersen SL, McCarthy DM, Smith GT. Less drinking, yet more problems: Understanding African American drinking and related problems. Psychological Bulletin. 2014;140(1).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pmc\\\/articles\\\/PMC3758406\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Sudhinaraset 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214239\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Sudhinaraset 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Sudhinaraset M, Wigglesworth C, Takeuchi DT. Social and cultural contexts of alcohol use: Influences in a social\\u2013ecological framework. Alcohol Research: Current Reviews. 2016;38(1):35-45.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pmc\\\/articles\\\/PMC4872611\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Maani 2023\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214244\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Maani 2023\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Maani N, Ci Van Schalkwyk M, Petticrew M. Under the influence: System-level effects of alcohol industry-funded health information organizations. Health Promotion International. 2023;38(6):1-9.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pmc\\\/articles\\\/PMC10721437\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Babor 2013\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214245\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Babor 2013\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Babor TF, Robaina K. Public health, academic medicine, and the alcohol industry\\u2019s corporate social responsibility activities. fh_topics","id":"858e48c6-01dd-4884-a299-bdd7a2b34bf5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3943}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/fe6eea53-6539-47e8-957b-87eabb938e2f\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1368"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/fe6eea53-6539-47e8-957b-87eabb938e2f\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1368"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"688beef9-307c-403c-88e5-fff6561e2888","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/688beef9-307c-403c-88e5-fff6561e2888?resourceVersion=id%3A1369"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1369,"drupal_internal__vid":1369,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Social host laws","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Social host laws | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Adopt laws that hold private property owners who provide alcohol to minors or obviously intoxicated individuals on their property liable if someone is killed or injured as a result"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/social-host-laws"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Adopt laws that hold private property owners who provide alcohol to minors or obviously intoxicated individuals on their property liable if someone is killed or injured as a result"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/social-host-laws","pid":1604,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-07-13","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ESocial host liability laws are a suggested strategy to reduce drunk driving, heavy episodic drinking, and underage drinking ({Hingson 2014}, {US DHHS SG-Addiction 2016}, {Wagoner 2012}, {Dills 2010}, {Stout 2000}). Available evidence suggests that these policies may reduce heavy episodic drinking and drunk driving ({Stout 2000}, {Wagoner 2012}), particularly among adolescents who already drink ({Paschall 2014}). One study of 18-20 year olds indicates that such laws are more likely to affect drunk driving than heavy drinking ({Dills 2010}). States with social host civil liability laws appear to have fewer fatal crashes of underage drunk drivers than state without such laws; the number of fatal crashes among underage drunk drivers does not appear to differ significantly in states with social host criminal liability laws and states without such laws ({Fell 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUnderage drinking parties may be smaller in communities that have established social host policies than communities that have not ({Wagoner 2013}). A California-based analysis suggests that when implemented with other interventions, social host liability can reduce heavy drinking among college students at off-campus parties, bars, and restaurants ({Saltz 2010}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ESocial host liability laws are a suggested strategy to reduce drunk driving, heavy episodic drinking, and underage drinking ({Hingson 2014}, {US DHHS SG-Addiction 2016}, {Wagoner 2012}, {Dills 2010}, {Stout 2000}). Available evidence suggests that these policies may reduce heavy episodic drinking and drunk driving ({Stout 2000}, {Wagoner 2012}), particularly among adolescents who already drink ({Paschall 2014}). One study of 18-20 year olds indicates that such laws are more likely to affect drunk driving than heavy drinking ({Dills 2010}). States with social host civil liability laws appear to have fewer fatal crashes of underage drunk drivers than state without such laws; the number of fatal crashes among underage drunk drivers does not appear to differ significantly in states with social host criminal liability laws and states without such laws ({Fell 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUnderage drinking parties may be smaller in communities that have established social host policies than communities that have not ({Wagoner 2013}). A California-based analysis suggests that when implemented with other interventions, social host liability can reduce heavy drinking among college students at off-campus parties, bars, and restaurants ({Saltz 2010}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2016, 31 states have criminal penalties for adults who host underage drinking events ({APIS}). Ten states\u2019 laws focus specifically on underage parties, 21 states have policies with a broader scope ({APIS}). Thirty-three states have statutes that assign civil liability for injuries or damages caused by minors provided with alcohol ({Fell 2016}). Four states (Delaware, Kentucky, North Carolina, and West Virginia) and Washington, D.C. have no law that addresses social host liability ({APIS}, {NCSL-Social host}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2016, 31 states have criminal penalties for adults who host underage drinking events ({APIS}). Ten states\u2019 laws focus specifically on underage parties, 21 states have policies with a broader scope ({APIS}). Thirty-three states have statutes that assign civil liability for injuries or damages caused by minors provided with alcohol ({Fell 2016}). Four states (Delaware, Kentucky, North Carolina, and West Virginia) and Washington, D.C. have no law that addresses social host liability ({APIS}, {NCSL-Social host}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":79,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced impaired driving","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced impaired driving\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["GFPC-Lacy 2011","PIRE-Social host","WA-Social host guide"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022GFPC-Lacy 2011\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222362\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022GFPC-Lacy 2011\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Lacy D, Becket M. Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs. 2000;61(3):402-12.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.jsad.com\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.15288\\\/jsa.2000.61.402\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222017-07-19\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Paschall 2014\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00225130\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Paschall 2014\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Paschall MJ, Lipperman-Kreda S, Grube JW, Thomas S. Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs. 2014;75(6):901-907.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pubmed\\\/25343646\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222017-07-19\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Fell 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227521\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Fell 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Fell JC, Scherer M, Thomas S, Voas RB. shop liability laws","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Dram shop liability laws | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Hold alcohol retailers legally responsible for injuries or damage caused by providing alcohol to intoxicated or underage customers; also called commercial host liability laws"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/dram-shop-liability-laws"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County alcohol retailers legally responsible for injuries or damage caused by providing alcohol to intoxicated or underage customers; also called commercial host liability laws"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Court"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/dram-shop-liability-laws","pid":1605,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-12-19","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that dram shop liability laws reduce alcohol-related motor vehicle fatalities among adult and underage drinkers ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDram shop liability laws appear to decrease fatal crashes among underage drivers who drink relative to non-drinking peers ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}), but do not appear to reduce binge drinking or teen alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {Romano 2015}). States with strong dram shop liability laws are associated with lower per capita beer consumption than states with weaker laws ({Scherer 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that dram shop liability laws reduce alcohol-related motor vehicle fatalities among adult and underage drinkers ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDram shop liability laws appear to decrease fatal crashes among underage drivers who drink relative to non-drinking peers ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}), but do not appear to reduce binge drinking or teen alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {Romano 2015}). States with strong dram shop liability laws are associated with lower per capita beer consumption than states with weaker laws ({Scherer 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2015, 37 states impose dram shop liability for service to intoxicated adult customers via statute, common law, or both ({ChangeLab-CHL}). As of January 2017, nearly all states (except for Delaware, Kansas, Maryland, Nevada, South Dakota, and Virginia) impose liability for service to underage customers; 28 states and Washington, D.C. have civil liability without limitation ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2015, 37 states impose dram shop liability for service to intoxicated adult customers via statute, common law, or both ({ChangeLab-CHL}). As of January 2017, nearly all states (except for Delaware, Kansas, Maryland, Nevada, South Dakota, and Virginia) impose liability for service to underage customers; 28 states and Washington, D.C. have civil liability without limitation ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":80,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced fatal and non-fatal injuries","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced fatal and non-fatal injuries\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["ChangeLab-CHL","US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Court","field_program_sources":"{\u0022ChangeLab-CHL\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228985\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022ChangeLab-CHL\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022ChangeLab Solutions (ChangeLab). Assessing the impact of twenty underage drinking laws. Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs. 2016;77(2):249-260.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.jsad.com\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.15288\\\/jsad.2016.77.249\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-03\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Scherer 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227540\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Scherer 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Scherer M, Fell JC, Thomas S, Voas RB. Effects of dram shop, responsible beverage service training, and state alcohol control laws on underage drinking driver fatal crash ratios.Traffic Injury Prevention. 2015;16(0 2):S59-S65.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pmc\\\/articles\\\/PMC4602396\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222018-12-19\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Romano 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227522\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Romano 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Romano E, Scherer M, Fell J, Taylor E. A comprehensive examination of U.S. laws enacted to reduce alcohol-related crashes among underage drivers. Journal of Safety Research. 2015;55:213-221.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www.sciencedirect.com\\\/science\\\/article\\\/pii\\\/S0022437515000687\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-03\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022NCSL-Dram shop\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00223952\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NCSL-Dram shop\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Conference of State Legislators (NCSL). media campaigns against underage map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mass-media-campaigns-against-underage-drinking","pid":1606,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2021-05-14","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether mass media campaigns against underage drinking reduce underage drinking ({Young 2018a}). Available evidence suggests that mass media campaigns may increase adolescents\u2019 knowledge or alter perceived social norms about alcohol use in some circumstances, but have little or no effect on alcohol consumption among youth ({Young 2018a}). An evaluation of a national media campaign reported mixed effects on alcohol use; for youth ages 15-18, increased campaign awareness was associated with reductions in binge drinking, though such awareness was associated with accelerated alcohol use among youth ages 12-14 ({Scheier 2010}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Young 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that mass media campaigns that increase adult awareness of underage drinking may reduce underage drinking ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects of increased parental knowledge on their monitoring and supervision regarding youth alcohol use ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether mass media campaigns against underage drinking reduce underage drinking ({Young 2018a}). Available evidence suggests that mass media campaigns may increase adolescents\u2019 knowledge or alter perceived social norms about alcohol use in some circumstances, but have little or no effect on alcohol consumption among youth ({Young 2018a}). An evaluation of a national media campaign reported mixed effects on alcohol use; for youth ages 15-18, increased campaign awareness was associated with reductions in binge drinking, though such awareness was associated with accelerated alcohol use among youth ages 12-14 ({Scheier 2010}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Young 2018a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that mass media campaigns that increase adult awareness of underage drinking may reduce underage drinking ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects of increased parental knowledge on their monitoring and supervision regarding youth alcohol use ({IOM-Underage drinking 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are a variety of mass media interventions implemented throughout the country. Some examples include, Talk. They Hear You. ({SAMHSA-Talk}), Parents Who Host, Lose the Most ({PAA-Parents who host}), and Alcohol: True Stories ({ATS}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are a variety of mass media interventions implemented throughout the country. Some examples include, Talk. They Hear You. ({SAMHSA-Talk}), Parents Who Host, Lose the Most ({PAA-Parents who host}), and Alcohol: True Stories ({ATS}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":81,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased adult awareness of underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased adult awareness of underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["SAMHSA-Talk","SAMHSA-Communities Talk"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022SAMHSA-Talk\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00224038\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022SAMHSA-Talk\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA). \u0026 server minimum age","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Seller \u0026 server minimum age | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Require a minimum age for sellers in off-premise locations that sell alcohol and servers and bartenders in on-premise locations"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/seller-server-minimum-age"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County a minimum age for sellers in off-premise locations that sell alcohol and servers and bartenders in on-premise locations"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/seller-server-minimum-age","pid":1607,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2017-06-22","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether age of seller and server policies reduce underage drinking. Available evidence suggests that underage sellers are more likely to sell alcohol to customers under the age of 21 ({Forster 1994}, {Forster 1995}) and to intoxicated patrons ({Freisthler 2003}). States with legislation that requires a minimum age of 21 for bartenders appear to have fewer alcohol-related fatal crashes among underage drivers than states with a younger minimum age or no required age ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}); however, regulations that establish a minimum age for sellers and servers do not appear to affect alcohol-related fatal crashes ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}, {Romano 2015}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether age of seller and server policies reduce underage drinking. Available evidence suggests that underage sellers are more likely to sell alcohol to customers under the age of 21 ({Forster 1994}, {Forster 1995}) and to intoxicated patrons ({Freisthler 2003}). States with legislation that requires a minimum age of 21 for bartenders appear to have fewer alcohol-related fatal crashes among underage drivers than states with a younger minimum age or no required age ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}); however, regulations that establish a minimum age for sellers and servers do not appear to affect alcohol-related fatal crashes ({Fell 2016}, {Scherer 2015}, {Romano 2015}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe minimum age required for sellers in off-premise locations and servers and bartenders in on-premise locations varies by state. As of January 2016, the minimum age to serve alcohoic beverages ranges from 17 in Maine to 21 in Alaska, Nevada, and Utah; most states set a minimum age of 18. Ten states require a manager to be present when underage servers are working ({APIS}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe minimum age required for sellers in off-premise locations and servers and bartenders in on-premise locations varies by state. As of January 2016, the minimum age to serve alcohoic beverages ranges from 17 in Maine to 21 in Alaska, Nevada, and Utah; most states set a minimum age of 18. Ten states require a manager to be present when underage servers are working ({APIS}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":82,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":[],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Forster 1994\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221874\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Forster 1994\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Forster JL, McGovern PG, Wagenaar AC, et al. servers and bartenders in on-premise locations","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003ERequire a minimum age for sellers in off-premise locations that sell alcohol and servers and bartenders in on-premise locations\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/3bcf96e0-6e84-4db8-810a-cf1dcf6f972c\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1372"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0f beverage server training (RBS\/RBST)","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Responsible beverage server training (RBS\/RBST) | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Educate owners, managers, servers, and sellers at alcohol establishments about strategies to avoid illegally selling alcohol to underage youth or intoxicated patrons"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/responsible-beverage-server-training-rbsrbst"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Educate owners, managers, servers, and sellers at alcohol establishments about strategies to avoid illegally selling alcohol to underage youth or intoxicated patrons"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/responsible-beverage-server-training-rbsrbst","pid":1608,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2021-06-17","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that responsible beverage server training (RBST) reduces harmful alcohol consumption ({Jones 2011a}, {CG-Alcohol}), especially when implemented as part of a multi-component intervention ({Brennan 2011}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({CG-Alcohol}, {Brennan 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERBST can improve server policies and practices and reduce the portion of patrons leaving drinking establishments intoxicated ({CG-Alcohol}, {Jones 2011a}, {Fell 2017a}), overservice to intoxicated patrons ({Woodall 2018}, {Elgan 2021}), and, in some circumstances with targeted enforcement, may reduce blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels ({Fell 2017a}). Multi-component RBST that combines server training, community coalition efforts, and enhanced enforcement reduces excessive consumption more than server training alone ({Brennan 2011}). A RBST for managers that includes both online and in-person components may increase managers\u2019 practice of written alcohol policies and their communication with staff about cutting off intoxicated patrons, but may not reduce likelihood of selling alcohol to obviously intoxicated patrons ({Lenk 2018}, {Toomey 2017}). Online RBST programs with user involvement and interactive activities can have greater impact in reducing overservice rates than in-person trainings ({Woodall 2018}). Sweden-based multi-component alcohol prevention efforts including brief online RBST appear to reduce overservice at sporting events but are not likely to reduce excessive alcohol consumption among spectators ({Elgan 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERBST may reduce alcohol sales to minors ({Chinman 2014}) and alcohol-related violence ({Brennan 2011}, {Trolldal 2012}). States with RBS laws are associated with lower fatal crash ratios but not with beer consumption compared to states without such laws ({Fell 2016}). The strength of RBS laws is not associated with self-reported binge drinking or alcohol-impaired driving ({Linde 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EClear role definition, evaluation, and feedback can also help facilitate effective RBST implementation ({Haggard 2014}, {Trolldal 2013}). Stable and high-quality instruction and implementation that includes active discussions among participants may contribute to successful RBST programs ({Woodall 2018}, {Ecklund 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that responsible beverage server training (RBST) reduces harmful alcohol consumption ({Jones 2011a}, {CG-Alcohol}), especially when implemented as part of a multi-component intervention ({Brennan 2011}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({CG-Alcohol}, {Brennan 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERBST can improve server policies and practices and reduce the portion of patrons leaving drinking establishments intoxicated ({CG-Alcohol}, {Jones 2011a}, {Fell 2017a}), overservice to intoxicated patrons ({Woodall 2018}, {Elgan 2021}), and, in some circumstances with targeted enforcement, may reduce blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels ({Fell 2017a}). Multi-component RBST that combines server training, community coalition efforts, and enhanced enforcement reduces excessive consumption more than server training alone ({Brennan 2011}). A RBST for managers that includes both online and in-person components may increase managers\u2019 practice of written alcohol policies and their communication with staff about cutting off intoxicated patrons, but may not reduce likelihood of selling alcohol to obviously intoxicated patrons ({Lenk 2018}, {Toomey 2017}). Online RBST programs with user involvement and interactive activities can have greater impact in reducing overservice rates than in-person trainings ({Woodall 2018}). Sweden-based multi-component alcohol prevention efforts including brief online RBST appear to reduce overservice at sporting events but are not likely to reduce excessive alcohol consumption among spectators ({Elgan 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ERBST may reduce alcohol sales to minors ({Chinman 2014}) and alcohol-related violence ({Brennan 2011}, {Trolldal 2012}). States with RBS laws are associated with lower fatal crash ratios but not with beer consumption compared to states without such laws ({Fell 2016}). The strength of RBS laws is not associated with self-reported binge drinking or alcohol-impaired driving ({Linde 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EClear role definition, evaluation, and feedback can also help facilitate effective RBST implementation ({Haggard 2014}, {Trolldal 2013}). Stable and high-quality instruction and implementation that includes active discussions among participants may contribute to successful RBST programs ({Woodall 2018}, {Ecklund 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ERBST is in place in many states. As of January 2020, RBST is mandatory in 24 states and Washington, D.C. and voluntary in 15 states ({APIS}). Eleven states do not have beverage server training laws ({APIS}).\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ERBST is in place in many states. As of January 2020, RBST is mandatory in 24 states and Washington, D.C. and voluntary in 15 states ({APIS}). Eleven states do not have beverage server training laws ({APIS}).\u0026nbsp;\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":83,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced violence","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced violence\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved alcohol server practices","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved alcohol server practices\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["PIRE-RBST","APIS","ChangeLab-RBST","UW WAPP-RBST"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022PIRE-RBST\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221642\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022PIRE-RBST\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Pacific Institute for Research and Evaluation (PIRE). registration laws","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Keg registration laws | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Require wholesalers or retailers to record an identification number for beer kegs and a purchaser\u2019s information (e.g., name and address, date of birth, etc.) at the time of purchase"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/keg-registration-laws"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Require wholesalers or retailers to record an identification number for beer kegs and a purchaser\u2019s information (e.g., name and address, date of birth, etc.) at the time of purchase"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/keg-registration-laws","pid":1609,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2019-07-31","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether keg registration laws decrease underage drinking and alcohol-impaired driving by minors ({Child Trends-Sacks 2014}, {Ringwalt 2011}). Available evidence suggests keg registration laws are associated with reduced underage drinking ({Fell 2016}, {Child Trends-Sacks 2014}) and alcohol-related motor vehicle fatalities ({RAND-Imm 2007}), but not associated with reduced adolescent binge drinking ({Fairman 2019}, {Ringwalt 2011}). Some experts suggest keg registration laws may reduce underage drinking and alcohol-impaired driving ({Harding 2016}, {GHSA-Policies}), while others suggest such laws may have unintended consequences and may be ineffective, especially if implemented without more comprehensive efforts to reduce alcohol availability ({Jernigan 2019}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Available evidence suggests states with more stringent alcohol control and underage drinking policies, including keg registration laws and regulations, may have less per capita beer consumption ({Fell 2015}) and fewer alcohol-impaired motor vehicle fatalities among youth than states with less stringent laws ({Fell 2015}, {Fell 2008}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). However, in some cases, keg registration laws alone appear not to decrease alcohol-impaired driving and motor vehicle fatalities among youth ({Ringwalt 2011}, {Fell 2009}) and may be associated with increased alcohol-related crashes among underage drivers ({Fell 2016}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is insufficient evidence to determine whether keg registration laws decrease underage drinking and alcohol-impaired driving by minors ({Child Trends-Sacks 2014}, {Ringwalt 2011}). Available evidence suggests keg registration laws are associated with reduced underage drinking ({Fell 2016}, {Child Trends-Sacks 2014}) and alcohol-related motor vehicle fatalities ({RAND-Imm 2007}), but not associated with reduced adolescent binge drinking ({Fairman 2019}, {Ringwalt 2011}). Some experts suggest keg registration laws may reduce underage drinking and alcohol-impaired driving ({Harding 2016}, {GHSA-Policies}), while others suggest such laws may have unintended consequences and may be ineffective, especially if implemented without more comprehensive efforts to reduce alcohol availability ({Jernigan 2019}, {NIAAA-Environmental strategies}). Available evidence suggests states with more stringent alcohol control and underage drinking policies, including keg registration laws and regulations, may have less per capita beer consumption ({Fell 2015}) and fewer alcohol-impaired motor vehicle fatalities among youth than states with less stringent laws ({Fell 2015}, {Fell 2008}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). However, in some cases, keg registration laws alone appear not to decrease alcohol-impaired driving and motor vehicle fatalities among youth ({Ringwalt 2011}, {Fell 2009}) and may be associated with increased alcohol-related crashes among underage drivers ({Fell 2016}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2018, thirty states and Washington, D.C. have keg registration laws and require retailers to collect one or more pieces of identifying information from a purchaser such as name, government-issued identification number, phone number, and address where the keg will be consumed; sixteen of those states prohibit possessing an unregistered or unlabeled keg. Utah bans keg sales ({APIS}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2018, thirty states and Washington, D.C. have keg registration laws and require retailers to collect one or more pieces of identifying information from a purchaser such as name, government-issued identification number, phone number, and address where the keg will be consumed; sixteen of those states prohibit possessing an unregistered or unlabeled keg. Utah bans keg sales ({APIS}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":84,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced fatal and non-fatal injuries","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced fatal and non-fatal injuries\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced impaired driving","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced impaired driving\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["APRC-Keg","APIS","UMN-AEP","Iowa-Keg registration","RAND-Imm 2007"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022APRC-Keg\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00229406\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APRC-Keg\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Prevention First, Alcohol Policy Resource Center (APRC). enforcement of laws prohibiting alcohol sales to minors","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Enhanced enforcement of laws prohibiting alcohol sales to minors | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Initiate or increase retailer compliance checks, shoulder tap operations, parking lot observation outside alcohol establishments for laws that prohibit alcohol sales to minors"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/enhanced-enforcement-of-laws-prohibiting-alcohol-sales-to-minors"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Initiate or increase retailer compliance checks, shoulder tap operations, parking lot observation outside alcohol establishments for laws that prohibit alcohol sales to minors"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/enhanced-enforcement-of-laws-prohibiting-alcohol-sales-to-minors","pid":1610,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2021-08-10","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that enhanced enforcement of laws that prohibit alcohol sales to minors, especially conducting underage compliance checks, reduces retail sales to minors ({CG-Alcohol}, {Erickson 2013}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). Such enforcement also appears to reduce underage alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {IOM-Underage drinking 2004}, {Wolfson 2017}) and alcohol-related crashes among drivers under age 21 ({George 2021}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUnderage compliance checks have been shown to reduce alcohol sales to minors of various racial and ethnic groups in both bars and liquor stores in rural and urban communities ({CG-Alcohol}). Compliance checks may also reduce alcohol sales to underage youth, in the short-term, at establishments in neighboring communities that do not conduct such enforcement ({Erickson 2013}). Adopting rigorous enforcement strategies such as compliance checks, shoulder tap operations, and enforcement of laws against providing alcohol to minors is associated with reduced underage drinking ({Wolfson 2017}). An increase in the number of compliance checks is associated with decreases in alcohol-related crashes for drivers under age 21, but not with crashes for drivers aged 21 or older ({George 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol enforcement agencies in urban areas are more likely to conduct underage compliance checks than suburban, small town, and rural agencies. Agencies in urban areas are also more likely to enforce penalties around alcohol provision to minors and consumption by minors than agencies in suburban areas ({Calvert 2020}). Enforcement agencies are more likely to enforce laws that target adults providing alcohol to underage youth, including underage alcohol compliance checks, if they have a full-time officer specific to alcohol enforcement, a division specific to alcohol enforcement, perceive underage drinking as very common, and\/or are in larger communities ({Jones-Webb 2015}, {Erickson 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that compliance checks are most effective when checks are frequent, well-publicized, well-designed, solicit community support, and involve penalties to the licensed establishment, instead of just the server ({RAND-Imm 2007}). Compliance checks are labor-intensive and expensive to implement frequently and should be paired with other efforts to reduce underage drinking ({OJJDP-Krevor 2017}). Publicizing monitoring and enforcement activities and building public awareness are components for effective alcohol control policy implementation ({Jones-Webb 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that enhanced enforcement of laws that prohibit alcohol sales to minors, especially conducting underage compliance checks, reduces retail sales to minors ({CG-Alcohol}, {Erickson 2013}, {RAND-Imm 2007}). Such enforcement also appears to reduce underage alcohol consumption ({CG-Alcohol}, {IOM-Underage drinking 2004}, {Wolfson 2017}) and alcohol-related crashes among drivers under age 21 ({George 2021}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EUnderage compliance checks have been shown to reduce alcohol sales to minors of various racial and ethnic groups in both bars and liquor stores in rural and urban communities ({CG-Alcohol}). Compliance checks may also reduce alcohol sales to underage youth, in the short-term, at establishments in neighboring communities that do not conduct such enforcement ({Erickson 2013}). Adopting rigorous enforcement strategies such as compliance checks, shoulder tap operations, and enforcement of laws against providing alcohol to minors is associated with reduced underage drinking ({Wolfson 2017}). An increase in the number of compliance checks is associated with decreases in alcohol-related crashes for drivers under age 21, but not with crashes for drivers aged 21 or older ({George 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol enforcement agencies in urban areas are more likely to conduct underage compliance checks than suburban, small town, and rural agencies. Agencies in urban areas are also more likely to enforce penalties around alcohol provision to minors and consumption by minors than agencies in suburban areas ({Calvert 2020}). Enforcement agencies are more likely to enforce laws that target adults providing alcohol to underage youth, including underage alcohol compliance checks, if they have a full-time officer specific to alcohol enforcement, a division specific to alcohol enforcement, perceive underage drinking as very common, and\/or are in larger communities ({Jones-Webb 2015}, {Erickson 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that compliance checks are most effective when checks are frequent, well-publicized, well-designed, solicit community support, and involve penalties to the licensed establishment, instead of just the server ({RAND-Imm 2007}). Compliance checks are labor-intensive and expensive to implement frequently and should be paired with other efforts to reduce underage drinking ({OJJDP-Krevor 2017}). Publicizing monitoring and enforcement activities and building public awareness are components for effective alcohol control policy implementation ({Jones-Webb 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2017, 36 states have formal compliance check protocols or guidelines: the maximum age of the decoy ranges from 19 to 21, and decoy training is mandatory in 15 states. Most states permit law enforcement agencies to conduct compliance checks on a random basis ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}). Many states and local governments use community-based strategies to prevent underage drinking that include enhanced enforcement of laws prohibiting sales to minors. For example, South Carolina\u2019s Alcohol Enforcement Teams and their enforcement and education partners implement various efforts to reduce youth access to alcohol, including compliance checks, public education, and media advocacy ({SC-AETs}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of 2017, 36 states have formal compliance check protocols or guidelines: the maximum age of the decoy ranges from 19 to 21, and decoy training is mandatory in 15 states. Most states permit law enforcement agencies to conduct compliance checks on a random basis ({US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018}). Many states and local governments use community-based strategies to prevent underage drinking that include enhanced enforcement of laws prohibiting sales to minors. For example, South Carolina\u2019s Alcohol Enforcement Teams and their enforcement and education partners implement various efforts to reduce youth access to alcohol, including compliance checks, public education, and media advocacy ({SC-AETs}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":86,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related crashes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related crashes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced underage alcohol purchases","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage alcohol purchases\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["PSEDC-Compliance checks","Prevention First-Enforcement","US DHHS-Underage drinking 2018"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022PSEDC-Compliance checks\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210663\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022PSEDC-Compliance checks\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Prevention Solutions@EDC. American Journal of Health Promotion. 2014;28(5):328-335.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/journals.sagepub.com\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.4278\\\/ajhp.121001-QUAL-478\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222021-08-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022SC-AETs\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210665\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022SC-AETs\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022South Carolina Department of Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse Services. ent_block","id":"ac6054e5-2db6-4cd5-bff9-b3091ffb1393","meta":{"target_revision_id":11332,"drupal_internal__target_id":6324}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/7ee65c3f-026a-428a-8b6d-da4476462eb1\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1375"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/7ee65c3f-026a-428a-8b6d-da4476462eb1\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1375"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"db29cd12-ba50-4afe-9c7a-a8815b72cd46","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":34}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"aa5e98e2-e2aa-49dc-aee6-059300d3dc82","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":39}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/7ee65c3f-026a-428a-8b6d-da4476462eb1\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1375"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/7ee65c3f-026a-428a-8b6d-da4476462eb1\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1375"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"fc9115c5-f918-43f9-9073-7396cdf91337","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1722}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e99ff09c-2899-496b-a9f0-e3d1a33f3b8c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1653}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c31d1633-e896-4d6d-9fbc-aa189e18cc91","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1591}},{"type":"node--wwfh_progra
