advertising restrictions","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:39+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Alcohol advertising restrictions | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Restrict the content and placement of alcohol advertisements on broadcasts, outdoor displays, internet marketing, etc. via state laws, local ordinances, industry self-regulation, or a combination of efforts"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-advertising-restrictions"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Restrict the content and placement of alcohol advertisements on broadcasts, outdoor displays, internet marketing, etc. via state laws, local ordinances, industry self-regulation, or a combination of efforts"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Substance Abuse"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alcohol-advertising-restrictions","pid":1611,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2019-09-23","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that restricting the content and placement of alcohol advertisements reduces alcohol consumption and excessive drinking among adults and youth ({Burton 2017}, {Weitzman 2004}, {Saffer 1991}). Complete marketing bans can reduce excessive drinking more than partial bans ({Burton 2017}, {Bosque-Prous 2014}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Panchal 2018}, {Cochrane-Siegfried 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigher levels of youth exposure to alcohol advertising are associated with increases in alcohol consumption, earlier initiation of alcohol use, and binge drinking ({Jernigan 2017}). Among college students, viewing alcohol advertisements can increase immediate alcohol consumption compared to viewing other advertisements ({Stautz 2016}). A survey of European adolescents reports that a higher level of exposure to online alcohol marketing is associated with increases in initiation of alcohol use and binge drinking ({de Bruijn 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EModel-based evidence suggests that restricting alcohol advertising is associated with reductions in alcohol consumption ({Burton 2017}), disability, and premature deaths ({IAS-Anderson 2006}). A California-based study reports that cities with greater bar density are more likely to restrict alcohol advertisements in windows ({Thomas 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EComplete marketing bans are cost-effective and have low implementation costs ({Burton 2017}); such bans are more cost-effective in areas with a low prevalence of hazardous drinking ({Panchal 2018}). Alcohol marketing restrictions can be cost-effective in both developed and developing countries ({Chisholm 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that restricting the content and placement of alcohol advertisements reduces alcohol consumption and excessive drinking among adults and youth ({Burton 2017}, {Weitzman 2004}, {Saffer 1991}). Complete marketing bans can reduce excessive drinking more than partial bans ({Burton 2017}, {Bosque-Prous 2014}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Panchal 2018}, {Cochrane-Siegfried 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigher levels of youth exposure to alcohol advertising are associated with increases in alcohol consumption, earlier initiation of alcohol use, and binge drinking ({Jernigan 2017}). Among college students, viewing alcohol advertisements can increase immediate alcohol consumption compared to viewing other advertisements ({Stautz 2016}). A survey of European adolescents reports that a higher level of exposure to online alcohol marketing is associated with increases in initiation of alcohol use and binge drinking ({de Bruijn 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EModel-based evidence suggests that restricting alcohol advertising is associated with reductions in alcohol consumption ({Burton 2017}), disability, and premature deaths ({IAS-Anderson 2006}). A California-based study reports that cities with greater bar density are more likely to restrict alcohol advertisements in windows ({Thomas 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EComplete marketing bans are cost-effective and have low implementation costs ({Burton 2017}); such bans are more cost-effective in areas with a low prevalence of hazardous drinking ({Panchal 2018}). Alcohol marketing restrictions can be cost-effective in both developed and developing countries ({Chisholm 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EVirginia\u2019s youth presence law prohibits all types of alcohol advertising within 500 feet of schools, public playgrounds, and churches. Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, Pennsylvania, and Washington also implement some variation of this youth presence law to restrict alcohol advertising near youth-oriented locations ({CAMY-State laws 2012}).\u0026nbsp;Oakland, CA also has an ordinance restricting alcohol advertisements. Adopted in 1998, the ordinance prohibits alcohol ads on billboards in residential areas and near schools. It also bans alcohol advertising within three blocks of recreation centers, churches, and licensed day care facilities ({UMN-AEP}). Baltimore, MD enforces alcohol and tobacco billboard ordinances and ensures regulation compliance through threat of fines and a community surveillance system ({Meisel 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EVirginia\u2019s youth presence law prohibits all types of alcohol advertising within 500 feet of schools, public playgrounds, and churches. Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, Pennsylvania, and Washington also implement some variation of this youth presence law to restrict alcohol advertising near youth-oriented locations ({CAMY-State laws 2012}).\u0026nbsp;Oakland, CA also has an ordinance restricting alcohol advertisements. Adopted in 1998, the ordinance prohibits alcohol ads on billboards in residential areas and near schools. It also bans alcohol advertising within three blocks of recreation centers, churches, and licensed day care facilities ({UMN-AEP}). Baltimore, MD enforces alcohol and tobacco billboard ordinances and ensures regulation compliance through threat of fines and a community surveillance system ({Meisel 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":89,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced alcohol use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["APRC-Advertising","CAMY-State laws 2012","PIRE-Alcohol advertising 2004","UMN-AEP"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Community","field_program_sources":"{\u0022APRC-Advertising\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00229581\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APRC-Advertising\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Prevention First, Alcohol Policy Resource Center (APRC). are the disparities in alcohol use disorders in your community? What groups are most affected?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the barriers to high quality linguistically and culturally appropriate alcohol screening and intervention? How are interventions tailored to reflect the cultures of people in your community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can alcohol screening and intervention be more equitably delivered in community, hospital, and primary care settings? What resources and partnership opportunities exist in your community to increase access to these services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat barriers, like stigma, are preventing people from accessing information about alcohol and available treatment services? What additional strategies can be implemented to overcome those barriers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the disparities in alcohol use disorders in your community? What groups are most affected?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the barriers to high quality linguistically and culturally appropriate alcohol screening and intervention? How are interventions tailored to reflect the cultures of people in your community?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can alcohol screening and intervention be more equitably delivered in community, hospital, and primary care settings? What resources and partnership opportunities exist in your community to increase access to these services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat barriers, like stigma, are preventing people from accessing information about alcohol and available treatment services? What additional strategies can be implemented to overcome those barriers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact alcohol brief interventions can have on disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBrief interventions that utilize motivational interviewing techniques may be effective regardless of gender, race, or ethnicity ({Contreras-Perez 2024}). Brief alcohol interventions delivered by community health workers may have the potential to reduce alcohol use and alcohol-related problems in Hispanic communities, who experience higher rates of unhealthy alcohol use and morbidity, and lower access to addiction treatment ({Carson 2023}). People living with HIV are particularly at risk of having an alcohol use disorder, which negatively affects their HIV treatment and increases their morbidity and mortality. It appears that individual-level brief interventions delivered in clinical and community settings are effective at improving alcohol outcomes and reducing mortality risk in people living with HIV ({Ghosh 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA California-based study suggests women, particularly women of color, are less likely to receive brief interventions in primary care settings than men ({Parthasarathy 2023}). A study of patients in the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems suggests that Black women and men, and Asian\/Pacific Islander women are less likely to receive brief interventions ({Chen 2020b}). Evidence indicates that race and ethnicity do not moderate treatment effects of brief interventions, suggesting that if disparities in receipt of brief interventions are closed, effects should be equal ({Contreras-Perez 2024}). There seem to be slight differences in receiving brief screening and interventions across sexual minority and heterosexual adults: lesbian women appear to be asked about heavy drinking more often in health care settings and gay men appear to receive brief interventions less often than heterosexual men who consume similar amounts of alcohol ({Lehavot 2017}). Experts suggest that reducing disparities in receiving alcohol-related care may require targeted interventions ({Chen 2020b}, {Carson 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe available evidence of the effectiveness of brief interventions in young adults appears to be representative of white college-age students, highlighting the need for additional research evaluating the effectiveness among other young adult subpopulations, such as those with minoritized identities ({Cronce 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact alcohol brief interventions can have on disparities in alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harms.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBrief interventions that utilize motivational interviewing techniques may be effective regardless of gender, race, or ethnicity ({Contreras-Perez 2024}). Brief alcohol interventions delivered by community health workers may have the potential to reduce alcohol use and alcohol-related problems in Hispanic communities, who experience higher rates of unhealthy alcohol use and morbidity, and lower access to addiction treatment ({Carson 2023}). People living with HIV are particularly at risk of having an alcohol use disorder, which negatively affects their HIV treatment and increases their morbidity and mortality. It appears that individual-level brief interventions delivered in clinical and community settings are effective at improving alcohol outcomes and reducing mortality risk in people living with HIV ({Ghosh 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA California-based study suggests women, particularly women of color, are less likely to receive brief interventions in primary care settings than men ({Parthasarathy 2023}). A study of patients in the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems suggests that Black women and men, and Asian\/Pacific Islander women are less likely to receive brief interventions ({Chen 2020b}). Evidence indicates that race and ethnicity do not moderate treatment effects of brief interventions, suggesting that if disparities in receipt of brief interventions are closed, effects should be equal ({Contreras-Perez 2024}). There seem to be slight differences in receiving brief screening and interventions across sexual minority and heterosexual adults: lesbian women appear to be asked about heavy drinking more often in health care settings and gay men appear to receive brief interventions less often than heterosexual men who consume similar amounts of alcohol ({Lehavot 2017}). Experts suggest that reducing disparities in receiving alcohol-related care may require targeted interventions ({Chen 2020b}, {Carson 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe available evidence of the effectiveness of brief interventions in young adults appears to be representative of white college-age students, highlighting the need for additional research evaluating the effectiveness among other young adult subpopulations, such as those with minoritized identities ({Cronce 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}). In 1957, alcohol brief interventions were first used to allow a psychiatrist and social worker to refer patients in the emergency department to outpatient alcohol treatment. Towards the end of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century, alcohol brief interventions became a more established practice in a variety of environments ({McCambridge 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAlcohol is deeply rooted in American life and history. Prior to the American Revolution, alcohol was perceived as an invigorating and restorative beverage that did not spoil easily and was safer than water. Its taxation provided a major source of revenue for colonial governments ({Olson 1985}). After the American Revolution, the temperance and women\u2019s rights movements shifted societal perspectives of alcohol and led efforts for its banishment. These efforts led to the adoption of the 18th Amendment in 1920, which banned the manufacture, sale, and transport of alcohol across the U.S., also known as Prohibition ({Aaron 1981}). Prohibition ended in 1933 in large part because of the need to generate tax revenue and stimulate job growth during the Great Depression and gave states authority to regulate alcohol, and each have approached regulation differently ({Olson 1985}). Today, the federal government has limited authority to impose national-level rules and regulations and there continues to be a patchwork of alcohol regulations that vary by state. Some state legislatures have preempted local government from implementing certain regulations and laws ({APIS-State Preemption}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThroughout history, alcohol misuse was seen as a personal failing. This evolved over the 19th century as the addictive properties of alcohol were understood ({Olson 1985}). Alcohol use disorder is now seen as a chronic disease that is influenced by genetics, neighborhood disadvantage, stress, access to alcohol, drinking cultures and contexts, and alcohol-industry influences ({Zapolski 2014}, {Sudhinaraset 2016}). In 1957, alcohol brief interventions were first used to allow a psychiatrist and social worker to refer patients in the emergency department to outpatient alcohol treatment. Towards the end of the 20\u003Csup\u003Eth\u003C\/sup\u003E century, alcohol brief interventions became a more established practice in a variety of environments ({McCambridge 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alcohol brief interventions reduce alcohol consumption and excessive drinking among adults when administered in primary care ({O\u2019Connor 2018}, {Cochrane-Kaner 2018}, {Alvarez-Bueno 2015}, {NICE-Jackson 2010}, {WHO-SBI}) and general hospital settings ({Schweer-Collins 2023}, {Scharer 2022}, {Cochrane-McQueen 2011}), and reduce alcohol consumption among adolescents and young adults when administered in school and college settings ({Hennessy 2019}, {Cochrane-Carney 2016}, {Tanner-Smith 2016}, {Seigers 2010}). Such interventions have also been shown to modestly reduce alcohol-related injuries ({NICE-Jackson 2010}, {Cochrane-Dinh-Zarr 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBrief interventions in emergency departments appear to modestly decrease alcohol consumption and heavy drinking among patients who are injured or intoxicated ({Barata 2017}, {Schmidt 2016}). Brief interventions in primary care settings may be similarly effective between men and women ({Cochrane-Kaner 2018}), though women may be less likely to drink and more likely to pursue treatment when brief interventions are delivered in general hospital settings ({Schweer-Collins 2023}). Brief interventions for pregnant women appear to modestly increase rates of abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy and prevent preterm births ({Popova 2023}). People living with HIV, a third of whom have an alcohol use disorder, appear likely to reduce the number of drinks per day and excessive drinking episodes when they receive brief interventions, which lowers their mortality risk ({Ghosh 2023}). Brief interventions may reduce excessive drinking in older adults, however more research is needed to understand effects ({Purser 2022}, {Kelly 2018}). The effect of brief interventions on people with mental health conditions is unclear ({Boniface 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based alcohol brief interventions can reduce alcohol consumption among adolescents ({Cochrane-Carney 2016}), especially when individually delivered ({Hennessy 2015}). Effects on adolescents in hospital settings are mixed and vary by type of intervention ({O\u2019Connor 2018}, {Samson 2019}); brief interventions with motivational interviewing techniques can reduce heavy alcohol use and substance-related problems for adolescents with substance use disorders ({Steele 2020}). Brief interventions can reduce driving after drinking among college students, especially when delivered using motivational interviewing techniques with personalized feedback ({Mun 2022}). Several brief interventions programs can be effective for college students: for example, BASICS may be the most effective and better suited for students at higher risk while THRIVE and e-CHUG may work best for universal prevention efforts ({Hennessy 2019}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EElectronic screening and brief interventions (e-SBI) reduce alcohol consumption ({Sohi 2023}), especially among youth and college students; effects are strongest in the short-term ({Sohi 2023}, {Campbell-Smedslund 2017}, {Donoghue 2014}). E-SBI conducted in college, health care, and community settings can also reduce excessive drinking and alcohol-related harms ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETraining physicians and nonphysician practitioners to deliver brief interventions appears to support effective implementation ({Loughran 2021}). Alcohol brief interventions appear to be cost effective approaches to reduce harmful alcohol consumption and health care utilization ({Barbosa 2020}, {IAS-Anderson 2006}, {WHO-SBI}, {NICE-Jackson 2010}). The cost-effectiveness ratio of brief interventions is calculated to be a $0.40 to $303 per drinks reduced per week, with a benefit-cost ratio of $39 per dollar invested ({Le 2023a}). Delivering brief interventions to pregnant women is likely a cost-effective approach for reducing cases of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). Preventing one case of FASD costs just 3% of the total costs required to provide services to an individual with FASD over their lifetime ({Popova 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alcohol brief interventions reduce alcohol consumption and excessive drinking among adults when administered in primary care ({O\u2019Connor 2018}, {Cochrane-Kaner 2018}, {Alvarez-Bueno 2015}, {NICE-Jackson 2010}, {WHO-SBI}) and general hospital settings ({Schweer-Collins 2023}, {Scharer 2022}, {Cochrane-McQueen 2011}), and reduce alcohol consumption among adolescents and young adults when administered in school and college settings ({Hennessy 2019}, {Cochrane-Carney 2016}, {Tanner-Smith 2016}, {Seigers 2010}). Such interventions have also been shown to modestly reduce alcohol-related injuries ({NICE-Jackson 2010}, {Cochrane-Dinh-Zarr 2004}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBrief interventions in emergency departments appear to modestly decrease alcohol consumption and heavy drinking among patients who are injured or intoxicated ({Barata 2017}, {Schmidt 2016}). Brief interventions in primary care settings may be similarly effective between men and women ({Cochrane-Kaner 2018}), though women may be less likely to drink and more likely to pursue treatment when brief interventions are delivered in general hospital settings ({Schweer-Collins 2023}). Brief interventions for pregnant women appear to modestly increase rates of abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy and prevent preterm births ({Popova 2023}). People living with HIV, a third of whom have an alcohol use disorder, appear likely to reduce the number of drinks per day and excessive drinking episodes when they receive brief interventions, which lowers their mortality risk ({Ghosh 2023}). Brief interventions may reduce excessive drinking in older adults, however more research is needed to understand effects ({Purser 2022}, {Kelly 2018}). The effect of brief interventions on people with mental health conditions is unclear ({Boniface 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESchool-based alcohol brief interventions can reduce alcohol consumption among adolescents ({Cochrane-Carney 2016}), especially when individually delivered ({Hennessy 2015}). Effects on adolescents in hospital settings are mixed and vary by type of intervention ({O\u2019Connor 2018}, {Samson 2019}); brief interventions with motivational interviewing techniques can reduce heavy alcohol use and substance-related problems for adolescents with substance use disorders ({Steele 2020}). Brief interventions can reduce driving after drinking among college students, especially when delivered using motivational interviewing techniques with personalized feedback ({Mun 2022}). Several brief interventions programs can be effective for college students: for example, BASICS may be the most effective and better suited for students at higher risk while THRIVE and e-CHUG may work best for universal prevention efforts ({Hennessy 2019}). \u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EElectronic screening and brief interventions (e-SBI) reduce alcohol consumption ({Sohi 2023}), especially among youth and college students; effects are strongest in the short-term ({Sohi 2023}, {Campbell-Smedslund 2017}, {Donoghue 2014}). E-SBI conducted in college, health care, and community settings can also reduce excessive drinking and alcohol-related harms ({CG-Alcohol}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETraining physicians and nonphysician practitioners to deliver brief interventions appears to support effective implementation ({Loughran 2021}). Alcohol brief interventions appear to be cost effective approaches to reduce harmful alcohol consumption and health care utilization ({Barbosa 2020}, {IAS-Anderson 2006}, {WHO-SBI}, {NICE-Jackson 2010}). The cost-effectiveness ratio of brief interventions is calculated to be a $0.40 to $303 per drinks reduced per week, with a benefit-cost ratio of $39 per dollar invested ({Le 2023a}). Delivering brief interventions to pregnant women is likely a cost-effective approach for reducing cases of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). Preventing one case of FASD costs just 3% of the total costs required to provide services to an individual with FASD over their lifetime ({Popova 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)\u2019s Screening, Brief Intervention, Referral and Treatment (SBIRT) program conducts demonstration projects across the country that assess and disseminate information on new SBIRT methods ({SAMHSA-SBIRT}). In the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems, the largest integrated health care system in the U.S., alcohol screening and brief intervention is universal ({Chen 2020b}). Example intervention programs for college students include Brief Alcohol Screening and Intervention for College Students (BASICS), which takes a harm prevention approach ({Blueprints-BASICS}), and Alcohol eCHECKUP TO GO (eCHUG), a resource-intensive program that uses normative feedback ({eCHUG}, {Hennessy 2019}). Additionally, there are brief interventions that focus on supporting pregnant women, such as CHOICES, that can be effectively tailored for minoritized communities, such as indigenous communities ({Deutsch 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)\u2019s Screening, Brief Intervention, Referral and Treatment (SBIRT) program conducts demonstration projects across the country that assess and disseminate information on new SBIRT methods ({SAMHSA-SBIRT}). In the Veterans Administration (VA) health systems, the largest integrated health care system in the U.S., alcohol screening and brief intervention is universal ({Chen 2020b}). Example intervention programs for college students include Brief Alcohol Screening and Intervention for College Students (BASICS), which takes a harm prevention approach ({Blueprints-BASICS}), and Alcohol eCHECKUP TO GO (eCHUG), a resource-intensive program that uses normative feedback ({eCHUG}, {Hennessy 2019}). Additionally, there are brief interventions that focus on supporting pregnant women, such as CHOICES, that can be effectively tailored for minoritized communities, such as indigenous communities ({Deutsch 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":90,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Reduced alcohol use","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol use\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced excessive drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced excessive drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced underage drinking","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced underage drinking\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced alcohol-related harms","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced alcohol-related harms\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["SAMHSA-SBIRT","IRETA-SBIRT toolkit","CDC-SBI 2014","CDC-SBI Tribal 2018","NIAAA-SBI youth","NHMA-SBIRT 2006","CDC-Higgins-Biddle 2009","APHA-SBI Manual 2008"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Substance Abuse","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022SAMHSA-SBIRT\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221901\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022SAMHSA-SBIRT\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA). JAMA. 2018;320(18):1910-1928.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1001\\\/jama.2018.12086\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-04\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Cochrane-Kaner 2018\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214102\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Cochrane-Kaner 2018\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Kaner EFS, Beyer FR, Muirhead C, et al. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2018;(2):CD004148.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.1002\\\/14651858.CD004148.pub4\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-03-04\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Alvarez-Bueno 2015\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00227679\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Alvarez-Bueno 2015\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022\\u00c1lvarez-Bueno C, Rodr\\u00edguez-Mart\\u00edn B, Garc\\u00eda-Ortiz L, G\\u00f3mez-Marcos M\\u00c1, Mart\\u00ednez-Vizca\\u00edno V. Effectiveness of brief interventions in primary health care settings to decrease alcohol consumption by adult non-dependent drinkers: A systematic review of systematic reviews. Preventive Medicine. 2015;76(Suppl):S33-S38.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/pubmed\\\/25514547?dopt=Abstract\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-02\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022NICE-Jackson 2010\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221896\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NICE-Jackson 2010\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Jackson R, Johnson M, Campbell F, et al. Screening and brief interventions for prevention and early identification of alcohol use disorders in adults and young people. Sheffield: School of Health and Related Research (ScHARR) Public Health Collaborating Centre, University of Sheffield; 2010.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ias.org.uk\\\/uploads\\\/pdf\\\/UK%20alcohol%20reports\\\/univ-sheffield-sbi.pdf\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-02-02\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022WHO-SBI\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u0022774\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022WHO-SBI\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022World Health Organization (WHO). Washington, D.C.: The National Academies Press; 1981.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/nap.nationalacademies.org\\\/catalog\\\/114\\\/alcohol-and-public-policy-beyond-the-shadow-of-prohibition\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-04-12\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022APIS-State Preemption\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002214242\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022APIS-State Preemption\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Alcohol Policy Information System (APIS). House homes","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:01+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Green House homes | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Support self-contained, homelike dwellings for 10-12 elderly adults who require nursing care; universal caregivers, usually CNAs, provide care and other supports while clinical teams visit for specialized care"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/green-house-homes"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Support care"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Residential facility"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/green-house-homes","pid":1613,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2016-07-19","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that Green House homes (GH homes) improve residents\u2019 quality of life ({Afendulis 2016}, {Kane 2007}) and increase the amount of direct care time caregivers spend with residents ({Brown 2016}, {Sharkey 2011}) compared to traditional nursing homes. Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGH homes may decrease rates of hospital readmission ({Bowers 2016}, {Afendulis 2016}) and preventable hospitalization ({Bowers 2016}), perhaps due to the amount of time Shahbazim spend with residents and early identification of potential health concerns ({Brown 2016}, {Sharkey 2011}). GH homes appear to provide quality of care equal to and, in some cases better than, traditional nursing homes ({Afendulis 2016}, {Kane 2007}). GH homes also appear to have greater staff retention than traditional nursing homes ({Brown 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost to operate GH homes appears to be comparable to traditional nursing homes and may be less in some circumstances ({Jenkens 2011}). Some practices core to Green House homes, such as universal caregiving staff and self-managed work teams, can be implemented in traditional nursing homes with little capital investment ({Elliot 2014}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that Green House homes (GH homes) improve residents\u2019 quality of life ({Afendulis 2016}, {Kane 2007}) and increase the amount of direct care time caregivers spend with residents ({Brown 2016}, {Sharkey 2011}) compared to traditional nursing homes. Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EGH homes may decrease rates of hospital readmission ({Bowers 2016}, {Afendulis 2016}) and preventable hospitalization ({Bowers 2016}), perhaps due to the amount of time Shahbazim spend with residents and early identification of potential health concerns ({Brown 2016}, {Sharkey 2011}). GH homes appear to provide quality of care equal to and, in some cases better than, traditional nursing homes ({Afendulis 2016}, {Kane 2007}). GH homes also appear to have greater staff retention than traditional nursing homes ({Brown 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost to operate GH homes appears to be comparable to traditional nursing homes and may be less in some circumstances ({Jenkens 2011}). Some practices core to Green House homes, such as universal caregiving staff and self-managed work teams, can be implemented in traditional nursing homes with little capital investment ({Elliot 2014}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of Summer 2016, there are 205 Green House homes across 33 states ({GH Project}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAs of Summer 2016, there are 205 Green House homes across 33 states ({GH Project}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":94,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced hospital readmissions","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced hospital readmissions\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced preventable hospitalizations","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced preventable hospitalizations\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of life","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of life\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased direct care time","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased direct care time\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["GH Project"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Residential facility","field_program_sources":"{\u0022GH Project\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226353\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022GH Project\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022The Green House (GH) Project. Journal of the American Geriatrics Society. 2011;59(1):126\\u2013131.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1111\\\/j.1532-5415.2010.03209.x\\\/full\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-10-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Bowers 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226348\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Bowers 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Bowers B, Roberts T, Nolet K, Ryther B. Inside the Green House \\u201cblack box\\u201d: Opportunities for high-quality clinical decision making. Health Services Research. 2016;51(S1):378\\u2013397.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\\/doi\\\/10.1111\\\/1475-6773.12427\\\/abstract;jsessionid=7A023745005A15A766B4D624C1DB6BE9.f03t04\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-10-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Jenkens 2011\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226350\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Jenkens 2011\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Jenkens R, Sult T, Lessell N, Hammer D, Ortigara A. 1):S17\\u2013S24.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/gerontologist.oxfordjournals.org\\\/content\\\/54\\\/Suppl_1\\\/S17.short\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222019-10-17\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022}}","field_retired_strategy":true,"field_strategy_acknowledgements":null,"field_strategy_author":"Jessica a8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--conten fh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"dae243d3-da2e-4764-bd58-731fe544a5dd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3963}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/e6b03c65-e18f-4f1f-ae37-e48dee00015c\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1378"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1379,"drupal_internal__vid":1379,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Health literacy interventions","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:40+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Health literacy interventions | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Increase patients\u2019 health-related knowledge via efforts to simplify health education materials, improve patient-provider communication, and increase overall literacy"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/health-literacy-interventions"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Increase patients\u2019 health-related knowledge via efforts to simplify health education materials, improve patient-provider communication, and increase overall literacy"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/health-literacy-interventions","pid":1614,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2019-05-23","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that interventions designed to address limited health literacy increase health-related knowledge ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Brainard 2016},\u0026nbsp;{Brijnath 2016},\u0026nbsp;{Jacobs 2014a},\u0026nbsp;{Manafo 2012},\u0026nbsp;{DeWalt 2009},\u0026nbsp;{Pignone 2005}) and comprehension ({Sheridan 2011}), and improve adherence to treatment ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Miller 2016}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which interventions are most effective.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that use written and print-based materials designed to be easy to read and understand have been shown to increase health-related knowledge among children and adults more than traditional materials ({DeWalt 2009}, {Pignone 2005}). Primary care-based group education programs designed to be sensitive to health literacy limitations also appear to increase knowledge among adults ({Brega 2013}). Health literacy programs for older adults offered in community settings can build capacity to access and apply relevant health information ({Manafo 2012}). Similarly, broader health intervention programs tailored for older adults and designed to be sensitive to health literacy limitations can increase participants\u2019 knowledge and capacity to find relevant health information ({Brainard 2016}). More intense interventions appear to increase the likelihood of improvement ({Dennis 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that combine multiple approaches (e.g., written and visual materials that are easy to read and understand, video tutorials, health literacy training for physicians, and in-person patient assessments) appear to increase patients\u2019 comprehension and appropriate use of health care ({Sheridan 2011}). Interventions that use multi-media approaches, focus on interpersonal interactions ({Wilson 2012a}), or face-to-face communication appear to promote improved communication between patients and providers ({Miller 2016}). Health literacy interventions that use technology or the internet (i.e., eHealth interventions) can increase knowledge of HIV ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Jacobs 2014a}), colorectal cancer ({Jacobs 2014a}), and mental health conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) ({Brijnath 2016}). Web-based interventions can reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety ({Brijnath 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions can improve adherence to medical treatment, particularly for patients following non-medication regimens or with cardiovascular disease ({Miller 2016}). Benefits appear greater for minorities and individuals with low incomes than for non-Hispanic whites and those with higher incomes ({Miller 2016}, {Mantwill 2015}). Interventions that include in-person counseling with interactive or technology-assisted education can also increase treatment adherence for those taking HIV medications ({Perazzo 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that include skills-building in communication and self-management techniques can increase patient satisfaction and improve chronic disease management for older adults ({Brainard 2016}). Health literacy-sensitive diabetes self-management interventions may reduce HbA1C levels, particularly for patients with low health literacy levels ({Kim 2016b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETailoring interventions to minorities, those with low levels of education, or limited experience with computers can promote patient engagement ({Jacobs 2014a}). Classes that teach participants how to access health information on the internet may increase self-efficacy in health information seeking and health information comprehension, improving the ability to find, evaluate, and use online health information ({Cochrane-Car 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that health care providers may have difficulty accurately identifying patients\u2019 health literacy limitations ({Kelly 2007}, {Rogers 2006}) and recommend that medical educators train medical students and residents to assess health literacy for all patients ({Rogers 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that interventions designed to address limited health literacy increase health-related knowledge ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Brainard 2016},\u0026nbsp;{Brijnath 2016},\u0026nbsp;{Jacobs 2014a},\u0026nbsp;{Manafo 2012},\u0026nbsp;{DeWalt 2009},\u0026nbsp;{Pignone 2005}) and comprehension ({Sheridan 2011}), and improve adherence to treatment ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Miller 2016}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects and determine which interventions are most effective.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that use written and print-based materials designed to be easy to read and understand have been shown to increase health-related knowledge among children and adults more than traditional materials ({DeWalt 2009}, {Pignone 2005}). Primary care-based group education programs designed to be sensitive to health literacy limitations also appear to increase knowledge among adults ({Brega 2013}). Health literacy programs for older adults offered in community settings can build capacity to access and apply relevant health information ({Manafo 2012}). Similarly, broader health intervention programs tailored for older adults and designed to be sensitive to health literacy limitations can increase participants\u2019 knowledge and capacity to find relevant health information ({Brainard 2016}). More intense interventions appear to increase the likelihood of improvement ({Dennis 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that combine multiple approaches (e.g., written and visual materials that are easy to read and understand, video tutorials, health literacy training for physicians, and in-person patient assessments) appear to increase patients\u2019 comprehension and appropriate use of health care ({Sheridan 2011}). Interventions that use multi-media approaches, focus on interpersonal interactions ({Wilson 2012a}), or face-to-face communication appear to promote improved communication between patients and providers ({Miller 2016}). Health literacy interventions that use technology or the internet (i.e., eHealth interventions) can increase knowledge of HIV ({Perazzo 2017},\u0026nbsp;{Jacobs 2014a}), colorectal cancer ({Jacobs 2014a}), and mental health conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) ({Brijnath 2016}). Web-based interventions can reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety ({Brijnath 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions can improve adherence to medical treatment, particularly for patients following non-medication regimens or with cardiovascular disease ({Miller 2016}). Benefits appear greater for minorities and individuals with low incomes than for non-Hispanic whites and those with higher incomes ({Miller 2016}, {Mantwill 2015}). Interventions that include in-person counseling with interactive or technology-assisted education can also increase treatment adherence for those taking HIV medications ({Perazzo 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth literacy interventions that include skills-building in communication and self-management techniques can increase patient satisfaction and improve chronic disease management for older adults ({Brainard 2016}). Health literacy-sensitive diabetes self-management interventions may reduce HbA1C levels, particularly for patients with low health literacy levels ({Kim 2016b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETailoring interventions to minorities, those with low levels of education, or limited experience with computers can promote patient engagement ({Jacobs 2014a}). Classes that teach participants how to access health information on the internet may increase self-efficacy in health information seeking and health information comprehension, improving the ability to find, evaluate, and use online health information ({Cochrane-Car 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest that health care providers may have difficulty accurately identifying patients\u2019 health literacy limitations ({Kelly 2007}, {Rogers 2006}) and recommend that medical educators train medical students and residents to assess health literacy for all patients ({Rogers 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, the National Academies of Medicine, the American Medical Association, and the National Institutes of Health promote health literacy as a research priority ({CDC-NCHS 2012}). Federal initiatives including the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the National Action Plan to Improve Health Literacy, and the Plain Writing Act also emphasize health literacy ({Koh 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThere are a number of statewide programs that aim to improve health literacy; at least 20 states maintain health literacy coalitions or working groups, including Arizona, Kentucky, Ohio, and Texas ({CDC-Health literacy}). Specific examples include the North Carolina Program on Health Literacy ({NCPHL}), the Colorado Health Literacy Coalition ({Colorado-HL}), and Engage for Health, a Pennsylvania-based program that uses the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality\u2019s (AHRQ\u2019s) \u0026ldquo;Questions are the Answer\u0026rdquo; patient engagement tools and resources ({AHRQ-Tools}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch organizations such as the University of Michigan Taubman Health Sciences Library, Duke University Medical Center, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health provide information and training materials for patients, providers, and educators on strategies to improve health literacy ({UM-HL resources}, {Duke-HL}, {Harvard-Health literacy}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, the National Academies of Medicine, the American Medical Association, and the National Institutes of Health promote health literacy as a research priority ({CDC-NCHS 2012}). Federal initiatives including the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the National Action Plan to Improve Health Literacy, and the Plain Writing Act also emphasize health literacy ({Koh 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThere are a number of statewide programs that aim to improve health literacy; at least 20 states maintain health literacy coalitions or working groups, including Arizona, Kentucky, Ohio, and Texas ({CDC-Health literacy}). Specific examples include the North Carolina Program on Health Literacy ({NCPHL}), the Colorado Health Literacy Coalition ({Colorado-HL}), and Engage for Health, a Pennsylvania-based program that uses the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality\u2019s (AHRQ\u2019s) \u201cQuestions are the Answer\u201d patient engagement tools and resources ({AHRQ-Tools}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch organizations such as the University of Michigan Taubman Health Sciences Library, Duke University Medical Center, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health provide information and training materials for patients, providers, and educators on strategies to improve health literacy ({UM-HL resources}, {Duke-HL}, {Harvard-Health literacy}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":95,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved patient-provider communication","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved patient-provider communication\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Increased patient satisfaction","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased patient satisfaction\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved health-related knowledge","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health-related knowledge\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved adherence to treatment","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved adherence to treatment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CDC-Health literacy","NNLM-Health literacy","HRSA-Health literacy","AHRQ-Health literacy toolkit","CDC-Cross-cultural tools","AHRQ-Teach-Back","Harvard-Health literacy","AHRQ-Shoemaker 2014","PLAIN","Georgetown-Patient education"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CDC-Health literacy\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222224\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CDC-Health literacy\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Rockville: Agency of Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ); 2004.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\\\/books\\\/NBK11942\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-04-29\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Eichler 2009\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00222227\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Eichler 2009\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Eichler K, Wieser S, Brugger U. The costs of limited health literacy: A systematic review. International Journal of Public Health. 2009;54(5):313-24.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/link.springer.com\\\/article\\\/10.1007%2Fs00038-009-0058-2\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-04-29\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022NCES-Kutner 2006\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00229248\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NCES-Kutner 2006\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Kutner M, Greenberg E, Jin Y, Paulsen C, White S. The health literacy of America\\u2019s adults: Results from the 2003 National Assessment of Adult Literacy (NCES 2006\\u2013483). Washington, D.C.: U.S. Department of Education (U.S. ED), National Center for Education Statistics (NCES); 2006.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/nces.ed.gov\\\/pubsearch\\\/pubsinfo.asp?pubid=2006483\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-04-29\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022}}","field_retired_strategy":false,"field_strategy_acknowledgements":"Alison Bergum","field_strategy_author":"Jessica Solcz","field_strategy_contributors":"Jessica Rubenstein","field_strategy_footnotes":["Ratzan 2000","AHRQ-Berkman 2011","AHRQ-Berkman 2004","Eichler 2012a","Mantwill 2015","Kim 2016b","Cochrane-Car 2011","Kelly 2007","Rogers 2006","CDC-NCHS 2012","Koh 2012","CDC-Health literacy","NCPHL","Colorado-HL","AHRQ-Tools","UM-HL communication, and increase overall literacy","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncrease patients\u2019 health-related knowledge via efforts to simplify health education materials, improve patient-provider communication, and increase overall literacy\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"bdbfb0c8-7f51-4487-bf38-46fe4e35bd2e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":16}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"185d395a-df3d-4aa8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"a638af05-06d6-46ce-b490-25e18d55c91f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":21}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"9c091979-5739-4910-9ff2-1518c33bd741","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":24}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"arity":0,"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_compon
