e":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"96922922-ed4f-40f0-aa7f-c46d52ae9333","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":66}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"01593356-ed9b-4b16-889b-c2189e79d1da","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1672}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"91f17206-9ede-4ef3-b152-34c9badd12ce","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1668}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"37e1c14d-48ae-4a5a-be2a-8896a741f746","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1664}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4581979e-6568-4f9f-8301-9654716ad98b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1661}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"74d0efca-07cd-4815-8004-e41b930ce852","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1625}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1381}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"fb6b53a1-646d-4818-a234-3c61574ae36c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1358}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"5faad96b-7b57-47d7-baa8-528a144bc5c5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1345}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"c3c7f5ca-c671-4d4e-8360-07bd4a042113","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3853}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"57e5aeed-186d-45bd-9365-db42bf45c06e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4011}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"30133e69-3e72-4e56-8509-f31c761ded8f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4000}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1379"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1381,"drupal_internal__vid":1381,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Public reporting of health care quality performance","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:40+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Public reporting of health care quality performance | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Make clinician, hospital, clinic, long-term care facility, and insurance plan performance on health care quality measures publicly available via report cards, reporting websites, or similar tools"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/public-reporting-of-health-care-quality-performance"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Make clinician, hospital, clinic, long-term care facility, and insurance plan performance on health care quality measures publicly available via report cards, reporting websites, or similar tools"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/public-reporting-of-health-care-quality-performance","pid":1616,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2020-09-03","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that public reporting of health care quality data improves quality of care ({Campanella 2016}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Hibbard 2005}). Effects appear strongest in competitive markets, especially for nursing home facilities ({Gabrowski 2011}) and health insurance plans ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Cochrane-Metcalfe 2018}, {Campanella 2016}, {Fung 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic reporting may lead health care insurers or long-term care (LTC) providers to improve performance on measures reported, especially when initial scores are poor ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Hibbard 2005}). Public reporting may also lead to better patient outcomes, such as reduced mortality among hospital patients, reduced pain and fewer pressure ulcers among LTC patients, and increased vaccination among individuals with health insurance plans that provide data publicly ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}). Public reporting may increase health care equity across racial and ethnic groups and reduce disparities in health outcomes between hospitals ({Trivedi 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome studies suggest public reporting may be linked to physicians choosing not to perform certain procedures for higher risk patients ({Narins 2005}, {Burack 1999}). One study suggests that LTC providers may readmit residents to the hospital before facility assessments to improve the LTC facility\u2019s performance measures ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}), and another suggests lower quality health plans may choose to discontinue reporting quality information ({Fung 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic reporting does not usually affect consumers\u2019 choice of providers or insurance plans ({Reid 2013}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Faber 2009}). Publicly reported quality ratings may support informed patient decision making about hospital selection for non-urgent care, such as elective surgery ({Blake 2017a}). In some circumstances, performance data can lead more educated consumers to select health plans ({Reid 2013}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Faber 2009}) and hospitals ({Faber 2009}, {James 2012}) with higher quality ratings than they would have otherwise selected.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome experts suggest that health care reporting systems should develop performance measurement standards based on measures that are transparent and systematically reviewed. In addition, to ensure reliability of the reports and accurate comparisons of the included organizations, insurance plans, or providers, each should provide comprehensive data for all measures collected, which may then be used by consumers for decision making purposes ({Winters 2016}, {Bilimoria 2016}, {Shahian 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost existing reporting systems are not sensitive to patients\u2019 health literacy levels ({Bilimoria 2016}). Experts suggest that less complex websites increase consumers\u2019 understanding and lead to more informed choices ({Kurtzman 2016}). Presenting the site\u2019s purpose in simple terms on the home page and using action words such as \u0026ldquo;learn,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;compare,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;choose\u0026rdquo; can guide users through the site ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}). Displaying data clearly and uniformly ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}), with summary scores and performance results shown in positive directions (i.e., higher is better) along with brief explanations or context (i.e., extra use of care is not always better), may aid understanding ({Kurtzman 2016}). As consumers may assume that higher costs indicate higher quality care, experts suggest pairing information about health care costs with easy-to-interpret data about quality ({Hibbard 2012a}) and the results of patient experience surveys ({Findlay 2016}), and then highlighting the high value options ({Hibbard 2012a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETo increase patients\u2019 use of publicly reported health care quality data, experts suggest social media public education campaigns about quality and the value of evidence-based care ({Findlay 2016}). Websites that clearly identify responsible entities ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}) and are produced by independent or local stakeholder coalitions could increase consumer trust of report cards ({Sinaiko 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that public reporting of health care quality data improves quality of care ({Campanella 2016}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Hibbard 2005}). Effects appear strongest in competitive markets, especially for nursing home facilities ({Gabrowski 2011}) and health insurance plans ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Cochrane-Metcalfe 2018}, {Campanella 2016}, {Fung 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic reporting may lead health care insurers or long-term care (LTC) providers to improve performance on measures reported, especially when initial scores are poor ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Hibbard 2005}). Public reporting may also lead to better patient outcomes, such as reduced mortality among hospital patients, reduced pain and fewer pressure ulcers among LTC patients, and increased vaccination among individuals with health insurance plans that provide data publicly ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}). Public reporting may increase health care equity across racial and ethnic groups and reduce disparities in health outcomes between hospitals ({Trivedi 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome studies suggest public reporting may be linked to physicians choosing not to perform certain procedures for higher risk patients ({Narins 2005}, {Burack 1999}). One study suggests that LTC providers may readmit residents to the hospital before facility assessments to improve the LTC facility\u2019s performance measures ({AHRQ-Totten 2012}), and another suggests lower quality health plans may choose to discontinue reporting quality information ({Fung 2008}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPublic reporting does not usually affect consumers\u2019 choice of providers or insurance plans ({Reid 2013}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Faber 2009}). Publicly reported quality ratings may support informed patient decision making about hospital selection for non-urgent care, such as elective surgery ({Blake 2017a}). In some circumstances, performance data can lead more educated consumers to select health plans ({Reid 2013}, {AHRQ-Totten 2012}, {Faber 2009}) and hospitals ({Faber 2009}, {James 2012}) with higher quality ratings than they would have otherwise selected.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome experts suggest that health care reporting systems should develop performance measurement standards based on measures that are transparent and systematically reviewed. In addition, to ensure reliability of the reports and accurate comparisons of the included organizations, insurance plans, or providers, each should provide comprehensive data for all measures collected, which may then be used by consumers for decision making purposes ({Winters 2016}, {Bilimoria 2016}, {Shahian 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMost existing reporting systems are not sensitive to patients\u2019 health literacy levels ({Bilimoria 2016}). Experts suggest that less complex websites increase consumers\u2019 understanding and lead to more informed choices ({Kurtzman 2016}). Presenting the site\u2019s purpose in simple terms on the home page and using action words such as \u201clearn,\u201d \u201ccompare,\u201d and \u201cchoose\u201d can guide users through the site ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}). Displaying data clearly and uniformly ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}), with summary scores and performance results shown in positive directions (i.e., higher is better) along with brief explanations or context (i.e., extra use of care is not always better), may aid understanding ({Kurtzman 2016}). As consumers may assume that higher costs indicate higher quality care, experts suggest pairing information about health care costs with easy-to-interpret data about quality ({Hibbard 2012a}) and the results of patient experience surveys ({Findlay 2016}), and then highlighting the high value options ({Hibbard 2012a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETo increase patients\u2019 use of publicly reported health care quality data, experts suggest social media public education campaigns about quality and the value of evidence-based care ({Findlay 2016}). Websites that clearly identify responsible entities ({AF4Q-Public reporting 2012}) and are produced by independent or local stakeholder coalitions could increase consumer trust of report cards ({Sinaiko 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are a variety of government agencies and private organizations which report on health care quality performance. The Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) promotes public reporting and publishes reports allowing consumers to compare providers, hospitals, long-term care (LTC) facilities, and Medicare coverage options through Care Compare, a tool combining CMS\u2019s existing eight compare sites ({CMS-Care Compare}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) reports national and state quality data, helps stakeholders develop quality measures, and disseminates research on public reporting best practices ({AHRQ-Talking quality}, {James 2012}). AHRQ also provides State Snapshots for every state, which feature state-specific health care quality information outlining strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement; State Snapshots contain over 250 quality measures and example users include state health officials, hospital associations, health plans, and community organizations ({AHRQ-State Snapshots}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) uses measurement, transparency, and accountability in reporting on health care across the country ({NCQA}). NCQA offers report cards on clinicians, health care organizations, and health insurance plans nationwide, with the option for consumers to filter within each category by name, state, accreditations, or care specialty ({NCQA-Report cards}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth insurance plans offered through state exchanges must report quality and cost information ({CMS-Exchanges}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are a variety of government agencies and private organizations which report on health care quality performance. The Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) promotes public reporting and publishes reports allowing consumers to compare providers, hospitals, long-term care (LTC) facilities, and Medicare coverage options through Care Compare, a tool combining CMS\u2019s existing eight compare sites ({CMS-Care Compare}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) reports national and state quality data, helps stakeholders develop quality measures, and disseminates research on public reporting best practices ({AHRQ-Talking quality}, {James 2012}). AHRQ also provides State Snapshots for every state, which feature state-specific health care quality information outlining strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement; State Snapshots contain over 250 quality measures and example users include state health officials, hospital associations, health plans, and community organizations ({AHRQ-State Snapshots}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) uses measurement, transparency, and accountability in reporting on health care across the country ({NCQA}). NCQA offers report cards on clinicians, health care organizations, and health insurance plans nationwide, with the option for consumers to filter within each category by name, state, accreditations, or care specialty ({NCQA-Report cards}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth insurance plans offered through state exchanges must report quality and cost information ({CMS-Exchanges}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":101,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved patient decision making","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved patient decision making\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["AHRQ-Hibbard 2018","AHRQ-State Snapshots","NQF","NCQA","NPWF-Quality","IPRO-WNTB","AHRQ HCIE-Snowden"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022AHRQ-Hibbard 2018\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210283\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022AHRQ-Hibbard 2018\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Hibbard J, Sofaer S. report cards, reporting websites, or similar tools","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMake clinician, hospital, clinic, long-term care facility, and insurance plan performance on health care quality measures publicly available via report cards, reporting websites, or similar tools\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"185d395a-df3d-4aa8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"9c091979-5739-4910-9ff2-1518c33bd741","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":24}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3 am_search_tags","id":"47bdd586-bb5c-4446-8ca1-2e4fa9f5b1b7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":57}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"edcd2c4e-f3bd-4895-9036-f985885fa56b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":59}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"96922922-ed4f-40f0-aa7f-c46d52ae9333","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":66}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ed4d2f95-44f3-4afd-b9ee-26e6f20f4b4f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":68}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"033505bd-9b89-43db-b9e1-05da78971925","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":69}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"e922742d-f022-4978-8dbf-60f9dea6e555","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1707}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"37878594-5ad9-46b1-9e05-b5422b00079a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1671}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"4beae2f3-a41b-4100-bce4-cc38e70835c6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1669}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"91f17206-9ede-4ef3-b152-34c9badd12ce","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1668}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c8a3fcb9-c3dd-47e0-8429-f0d904d3fb4a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1590}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"eb8f1c76-8a16-4c9f-85bc-0ce96bbf5820","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1527}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"dc475e28-c903-454e-acb2-59603b676692","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1379}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9280ab6e-9f27-4b08-9963-24992cb61aab","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1350}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"c3c7f5ca-c671-4d4e-8360-07bd4a042113","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3853}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"963079f8-2eae-4328-914d-b128aefb7d0b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3854}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"f19a7d55-bf01-4879-9013-2d8c8607c29a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4002}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/512746cd-1bef-476e-964c-da433fd9aa24\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1381"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"be674d22-d2ac-427f-9edf-841cfd0a15e8","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/be674d22-d2ac-427f-9edf-841cfd0a15e8?resourceVersion=id%3A1382"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1382,"drupal_internal__vid":1382,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Chronic disease management programs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:01+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Chronic disease management programs | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Implement multi-component efforts that include coordination of health services by multidisciplinary teams of health care professionals, patient self-management, and patient education"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/chronic-disease-management-programs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Implement multi-component efforts that include coordination of health services by multidisciplinary teams of health care professionals, patient self-management, and patient education"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Mental health,Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/chronic-disease-management-programs","pid":1617,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2024-01-25","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the disparities in chronic disease prevalence in your community? What groups are most affected?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat resources are available for chronic disease management? Are certain groups less able to access the care and services available?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the barriers to high quality linguistically and culturally appropriate chronic disease management services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can chronic disease management services be more equitably delivered? What partnership opportunities exist in your community to increase access to these services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the disparities in chronic disease prevalence in your community? What groups are most affected?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat resources are available for chronic disease management? Are certain groups less able to access the care and services available?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat are the barriers to high quality linguistically and culturally appropriate chronic disease management services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can chronic disease management services be more equitably delivered? What partnership opportunities exist in your community to increase access to these services?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact chronic disease management (CDM) programs may have on disparities in chronic diseases.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPeople with one or more chronic diseases are at greater risk for disability, death, poor functional status, unnecessary hospitalizations, and many other challenges ({Bleich 2015}). Individuals from minoritized racial backgrounds ({Price 2013}), from rural areas ({RHIhub-Chronic Disease}), and those with low incomes are disproportionately more likely to have one or more chronic disease ({Eyler 2019}). Patients who are racial and ethnic minorities are almost twice as likely to be affected by major chronic diseases such asthma, diabetes, hypertension, obesity, and mental illness compared to patients who are white ({Price 2013}). Similar disparities exist between patients with different incomes: for example, diabetes rates are twice as high among adults with lower incomes than those with higher incomes ({Eyler 2019}). Rural residents, particularly those from minoritized backgrounds, are more likely to experience chronic diseases and have higher mortality rates than those in urban areas ({Durfey 2019}). People living in disadvantaged areas (i.e., with lower levels of safety, walkability, access to health care, nutritious foods, recreation, and higher levels of stress) are at higher risk for negative health outcomes, including hypertension and diabetes, and these communities are disproportionately Black. Hypertension and diabetes are less likely to be adequately managed in Black patients, regardless of income level ({Durfey 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIt is unclear what impact chronic disease management (CDM) programs may have on disparities in chronic diseases.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPeople with one or more chronic diseases are at greater risk for disability, death, poor functional status, unnecessary hospitalizations, and many other challenges ({Bleich 2015}). Individuals from minoritized racial backgrounds ({Price 2013}), from rural areas ({RHIhub-Chronic Disease}), and those with low incomes are disproportionately more likely to have one or more chronic disease ({Eyler 2019}). Patients who are racial and ethnic minorities are almost twice as likely to be affected by major chronic diseases such asthma, diabetes, hypertension, obesity, and mental illness compared to patients who are white ({Price 2013}). Similar disparities exist between patients with different incomes: for example, diabetes rates are twice as high among adults with lower incomes than those with higher incomes ({Eyler 2019}). Rural residents, particularly those from minoritized backgrounds, are more likely to experience chronic diseases and have higher mortality rates than those in urban areas ({Durfey 2019}). People living in disadvantaged areas (i.e., with lower levels of safety, walkability, access to health care, nutritious foods, recreation, and higher levels of stress) are at higher risk for negative health outcomes, including hypertension and diabetes, and these communities are disproportionately Black. Hypertension and diabetes are less likely to be adequately managed in Black patients, regardless of income level ({Durfey 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal Housing Administration\u2019s redlining practices entrenched racial residential segregation in the U.S. and resulted in fewer health care facilities, resources, and funding in urban areas with largely Black populations ({Lee 2023}, {Lee 2022c}). Past residential redlining and present-day disparities in access to health care are associated with delays in disease diagnosis and treatment of health conditions, fewer preventive health visits, shortages of behavioral health clinicians, and larger Medicaid or uninsured populations in neighborhoods that are primarily Black and low income ({Lee 2023}). Formerly redlined neighborhoods are more likely to be near man-made environmental hazards producing pollution or toxins and have older homes in poor condition containing health hazards such as lead paint and mold ({Braveman 2022}), and residents continue to experience worse health outcomes, including chronic diseases like diabetes ({Lee 2022c}). Rural areas lack adequate access to physicians; approximately 20% of the U.S. population resides in rural areas, but only 10% of physicians provide care there ({Arredondo 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EChronic diseases have increased in prevalence over the last century as public health and modern medicine became increasingly effective in preventing and treating communicable diseases and are now the leading causes of death. Unlike diseases caused by single pathogens, chronic diseases are often the result of multiple factors accumulating over time, with aspects of the neighborhoods and communities individuals live in harming them by restricting their opportunities for healthy living ({Hong 2019b}). The chronic disease management (CDM) model emerged in the 1990s because of the increasing prevalence and complexity of treating patients with chronic illnesses ({Wagner 1998}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal Housing Administration\u2019s redlining practices entrenched racial residential segregation in the U.S. and resulted in fewer health care facilities, resources, and funding in urban areas with largely Black populations ({Lee 2023}, {Lee 2022c}). Past residential redlining and present-day disparities in access to health care are associated with delays in disease diagnosis and treatment of health conditions, fewer preventive health visits, shortages of behavioral health clinicians, and larger Medicaid or uninsured populations in neighborhoods that are primarily Black and low income ({Lee 2023}). Formerly redlined neighborhoods are more likely to be near man-made environmental hazards producing pollution or toxins and have older homes in poor condition containing health hazards such as lead paint and mold ({Braveman 2022}), and residents continue to experience worse health outcomes, including chronic diseases like diabetes ({Lee 2022c}). Rural areas lack adequate access to physicians; approximately 20% of the U.S. population resides in rural areas, but only 10% of physicians provide care there ({Arredondo 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EChronic diseases have increased in prevalence over the last century as public health and modern medicine became increasingly effective in preventing and treating communicable diseases and are now the leading causes of death. Unlike diseases caused by single pathogens, chronic diseases are often the result of multiple factors accumulating over time, with aspects of the neighborhoods and communities individuals live in harming them by restricting their opportunities for healthy living ({Hong 2019b}). The chronic disease management (CDM) model emerged in the 1990s because of the increasing prevalence and complexity of treating patients with chronic illnesses ({Wagner 1998}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":3,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that chronic disease management (CDM) programs improve quality of life ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {John 2020}, {Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}, {Miller 2013b}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Drewes 2012}) and health outcomes for a variety of chronic conditions ({John 2020}, {Baptista 2016}, {Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}, {CG-CVD 2015}, {Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Stellefson 2013b}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}, {Drewes 2012}, {Pimouguet 2011}, {Si 2008}, {CG-Diabetes}), including mental illness ({John 2020}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}). CDM programs have also been shown to reduce hospital admissions or readmissions ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {John 2020}, {Drewes 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDM programs, and the Chronic Care Model specifically, have been shown to improve health outcomes in patients with diabetes ({Stellefson 2013b}, {Pimouguet 2011}, {Si 2008}, {CG-Diabetes}), hypertension ({John 2020}, {Pascucci 2021}, {CG-CVD 2015}), anxiety and depression ({John 2020}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}), COPD ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Peytremann-Bridevaux 2008}), and heart failure, including reducing mortality ({Drewes 2012}). In some cases, such interventions also improve outcomes for patients with asthma ({Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}), osteoarthrosis ({Brand 2014}), and HIV ({Pasricha 2013}). Studies of CDM for patients with diabetes, asthma, and COPD indicate that using multiple components of the Chronic Care Model may increase program effectiveness ({Baptista 2016}, {Lemmens 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDM improves quality of life for patients ({John 2020}), including patients with asthma ({Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}), COPD ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Peytremann-Bridevaux 2008}), heart failure ({Drewes 2012}), and anxiety and depression ({Woltmann 2012}). CDM may be more effective for patients with more severe mental illness than for those with less severe symptoms ({Miller 2013b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInterprofessional collaboration opportunities for health care providers implementing CDM programs can improve health outcomes for patients with chronic diseases and may increase preventive behaviors, such as smoking cessation ({Pascucci 2021}). Disease management interventions for patients with multiple chronic diseases may improve some health outcomes but additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Cochrane-Smith 2016}, {Bleich 2015}). Utilizing community health workers (CHWs) in CDM programs may improve primary care access and cancer screening ({Mistry 2021}, {Kim 2016}), and can be cost effective, especially for vulnerable populations ({Kim 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatient-centered medical homes (PCMH) appear more effective than standard primary care models in chronic disease management ({John 2020}). Some evidence suggests programs that combine physician decision-support interventions with patient self-management support interventions may lead to the largest improvement in patient outcomes ({Reynolds 2018a}). However, further research is needed to evaluate which program components of disease management interventions and intervention duration is most effective for management of chronic diseases ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that chronic disease management (CDM) programs improve quality of life ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {John 2020}, {Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}, {Miller 2013b}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Drewes 2012}) and health outcomes for a variety of chronic conditions ({John 2020}, {Baptista 2016}, {Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}, {CG-CVD 2015}, {Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Stellefson 2013b}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}, {Drewes 2012}, {Pimouguet 2011}, {Si 2008}, {CG-Diabetes}), including mental illness ({John 2020}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}). CDM programs have also been shown to reduce hospital admissions or readmissions ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {John 2020}, {Drewes 2012}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDM programs, and the Chronic Care Model specifically, have been shown to improve health outcomes in patients with diabetes ({Stellefson 2013b}, {Pimouguet 2011}, {Si 2008}, {CG-Diabetes}), hypertension ({John 2020}, {Pascucci 2021}, {CG-CVD 2015}), anxiety and depression ({John 2020}, {Cochrane-Archer 2012}, {Woltmann 2012}), COPD ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Peytremann-Bridevaux 2008}), and heart failure, including reducing mortality ({Drewes 2012}). In some cases, such interventions also improve outcomes for patients with asthma ({Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}), osteoarthrosis ({Brand 2014}), and HIV ({Pasricha 2013}). Studies of CDM for patients with diabetes, asthma, and COPD indicate that using multiple components of the Chronic Care Model may increase program effectiveness ({Baptista 2016}, {Lemmens 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECDM improves quality of life for patients ({John 2020}), including patients with asthma ({Cochrane-Peytremann-Bridevaux 2015}), COPD ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}, {Peytremann-Bridevaux 2008}), heart failure ({Drewes 2012}), and anxiety and depression ({Woltmann 2012}). CDM may be more effective for patients with more severe mental illness than for those with less severe symptoms ({Miller 2013b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInterprofessional collaboration opportunities for health care providers implementing CDM programs can improve health outcomes for patients with chronic diseases and may increase preventive behaviors, such as smoking cessation ({Pascucci 2021}). Disease management interventions for patients with multiple chronic diseases may improve some health outcomes but additional evidence is needed to confirm effects ({Cochrane-Smith 2016}, {Bleich 2015}). Utilizing community health workers (CHWs) in CDM programs may improve primary care access and cancer screening ({Mistry 2021}, {Kim 2016}), and can be cost effective, especially for vulnerable populations ({Kim 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EPatient-centered medical homes (PCMH) appear more effective than standard primary care models in chronic disease management ({John 2020}). Some evidence suggests programs that combine physician decision-support interventions with patient self-management support interventions may lead to the largest improvement in patient outcomes ({Reynolds 2018a}). However, further research is needed to evaluate which program components of disease management interventions and intervention duration is most effective for management of chronic diseases ({Cochrane-Poot 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many types of CDM programs. The Upper Great Lakes Family Health Center in Michigan is an example of a health center collaborating with local agencies to coordinate behavioral healthcare in a primary care setting to address and treat substance use disorder and depression ({RHIhub-Cross Walk}). Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Connecticut\u2019s program is an example of a hospital-based outpatient effort that serves the sickest patients with asthma, heart failure, obesity, and diabetes ({Middlesex Health-CCM}). The Sutter Care Coordination Program in the Sacramento Sierra region, which combines chronic care and disease management to address the medical and psychosocial needs of patients with multiple chronic conditions, is another example ({Sutter Care Coordination Program}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2015, Medicare covers non-face-to-face chronic care management for patients with multiple chronic conditions who are at significant risk of death, acute exacerbation\/decomposition, or functional decline ({CMS-CCMS}). The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Connected Care Toolkit can assist in the implementation of chronic care management programs ({US DHHS-Connected Care Toolkit}), and the National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion within the Centers for Disease Control offers resources to advance equity in chronic disease prevention and management ({CDC-Health Equity CCM}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere are many types of CDM programs. The Upper Great Lakes Family Health Center in Michigan is an example of a health center collaborating with local agencies to coordinate behavioral healthcare in a primary care setting to address and treat substance use disorder and depression ({RHIhub-Cross Walk}). Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Connecticut\u2019s program is an example of a hospital-based outpatient effort that serves the sickest patients with asthma, heart failure, obesity, and diabetes ({Middlesex Health-CCM}). The Sutter Care Coordination Program in the Sacramento Sierra region, which combines chronic care and disease management to address the medical and psychosocial needs of patients with multiple chronic conditions, is another example ({Sutter Care Coordination Program}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAs of January 2015, Medicare covers non-face-to-face chronic care management for patients with multiple chronic conditions who are at significant risk of death, acute exacerbation\/decomposition, or functional decline ({CMS-CCMS}). The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Connected Care Toolkit can assist in the implementation of chronic care management programs ({US DHHS-Connected Care Toolkit}), and the National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion within the Centers for Disease Control offers resources to advance equity in chronic disease prevention and management ({CDC-Health Equity CCM}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":105,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of life","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of life\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved health outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved health outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Improved mental health","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved mental health\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced hospital utilization","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced hospital utilization\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["CDC-Health Equity CCM","US DHHS-Connected Care Toolkit","Nordian-CCM","RHIhub-CCM","Fromer 2011"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Mental health,Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022CDC-Health Equity CCM\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002213823\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CDC-Health Equity CCM\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). purchasing (VBP)","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:40+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Value-based purchasing (VBP) | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Use the purchasing power of employers and groups of insured individuals to create incentives and disincentives for health care providers to deliver high quality, high value care"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/value-based-purchasing-vbp"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Use the purchasing power of employers and groups of insured individuals to create incentives and disincentives for health care providers to deliver high quality, high value care"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Public health"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/value-based-purchasing-vbp","pid":1618,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2015-11-18","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that value-based purchasing (VBP) programs that include pay for performance (P4P) modestly improve health care quality for chronic disease management, when implemented as part of a broader initiative to improve quality of care ({Huang 2013},\u0026nbsp;{de Bruin 2011}); effects have been demonstrated for diabetes and asthma management, but not for heart disease management ({Eijkenaar 2013}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects of VBP, especially long-term effects on patient outcomes and system costs ({Eijkenaar 2013}, {Eldridge 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFinancial incentives such as VBP and P4P may improve health care practice and process outcomes ({Cochrane-Flodgren 2011}). In a New York City-based study, small clinical practices that implemented a P4P program have modest improvements in cardiovascular processes and outcomes ({Bardach 2013}). In UK-based studies, P4P programs that included larger bonuses than most U.S. programs and significant investment by hospitals in quality improvement activities are associated with a clinically significant reduction in mortality ({Sutton 2012}), however, the effect may not be maintained over the long-term ({Kristensen 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that effective programs engage providers with program design, measures, and performance targets, and set objective achievement and improvement targets so all providers who reach that target receive an incentive. Effective VBP programs also track cost and quality data, strive for measure alignment across programs, and include provider supports (e.g., best practice sharing mechanisms, health information technology and data registries, and infrastructure building). Larger incentives have been associated with greater effects on performance when these incentives do not reduce resources for low quality provider improvement ({RAND-Damberg 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Eijkenaar 2013},\u0026nbsp;{AHRQ-VBP lessons}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn some circumstances, providers participating in VBP programs have neglected care that is not incentivized by the program\u2019s design. U.S. and UK-based studies suggest that VBP and P4P could also lead providers to select healthy or compliant patients over severely ill or non-compliant patients or encourage gaming or manipulating data to maximize income. Careful design and implementation of VBP programs, including aligning financial incentives with professional values, can help avoid such unintended consequences ({Eijkenaar 2013}, {Roland 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EValue-based purchasing could narrow, widen, or maintain existing disparities in access to and receipt of quality health care ({Eijkenaar 2013}). Programs that explicitly consider disparities, collect race and ethnicity data, focus on conditions that are of higher prevalence among minorities, reward improvements, and support efforts to establish national disparity measures and guidelines are more likely to reduce disparities than programs that do not ({Chien 2007}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EVBP and P4P have the potential to be cost-effective when programs are well designed and implemented ({Eijkenaar 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that value-based purchasing (VBP) programs that include pay for performance (P4P) modestly improve health care quality for chronic disease management, when implemented as part of a broader initiative to improve quality of care ({Huang 2013},\u0026nbsp;{de Bruin 2011}); effects have been demonstrated for diabetes and asthma management, but not for heart disease management ({Eijkenaar 2013}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects of VBP, especially long-term effects on patient outcomes and system costs ({Eijkenaar 2013}, {Eldridge 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EFinancial incentives such as VBP and P4P may improve health care practice and process outcomes ({Cochrane-Flodgren 2011}). In a New York City-based study, small clinical practices that implemented a P4P program have modest improvements in cardiovascular processes and outcomes ({Bardach 2013}). In UK-based studies, P4P programs that included larger bonuses than most U.S. programs and significant investment by hospitals in quality improvement activities are associated with a clinically significant reduction in mortality ({Sutton 2012}), however, the effect may not be maintained over the long-term ({Kristensen 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that effective programs engage providers with program design, measures, and performance targets, and set objective achievement and improvement targets so all providers who reach that target receive an incentive. Effective VBP programs also track cost and quality data, strive for measure alignment across programs, and include provider supports (e.g., best practice sharing mechanisms, health information technology and data registries, and infrastructure building). Larger incentives have been associated with greater effects on performance when these incentives do not reduce resources for low quality provider improvement ({RAND-Damberg 2014},\u0026nbsp;{Eijkenaar 2013},\u0026nbsp;{AHRQ-VBP lessons}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn some circumstances, providers participating in VBP programs have neglected care that is not incentivized by the program\u2019s design. U.S. and UK-based studies suggest that VBP and P4P could also lead providers to select healthy or compliant patients over severely ill or non-compliant patients or encourage gaming or manipulating data to maximize income. Careful design and implementation of VBP programs, including aligning financial incentives with professional values, can help avoid such unintended consequences ({Eijkenaar 2013}, {Roland 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EValue-based purchasing could narrow, widen, or maintain existing disparities in access to and receipt of quality health care ({Eijkenaar 2013}). Programs that explicitly consider disparities, collect race and ethnicity data, focus on conditions that are of higher prevalence among minorities, reward improvements, and support efforts to establish national disparity measures and guidelines are more likely to reduce disparities than programs that do not ({Chien 2007}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EVBP and P4P have the potential to be cost-effective when programs are well designed and implemented ({Eijkenaar 2013}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) has linked Medicare\u2019s payment system to a value-based purchasing system for inpatient stays in over 3,500 hospitals in the U.S. ({CMS-Hospital VBP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA few states have enacted policy reforms that include value-based purchasing, as in Massachusetts, Minnesota, and Vermont ({CWF-McCarthy 2009}). State agencies and public\/private coalitions have also led initiatives to increase value in health care services using value-based purchasing, for example the Massachusetts Group Insurance Commission ({MA-GIC}), the Minnesota Smart Buy Alliance ({MHAG-SMART}), the Washington Health Alliance ({WHA-CC}), and the Wisconsin Department of Employee Trust Funds ({CWF-Alteras 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) has linked Medicare\u2019s payment system to a value-based purchasing system for inpatient stays in over 3,500 hospitals in the U.S. ({CMS-Hospital VBP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA few states have enacted policy reforms that include value-based purchasing, as in Massachusetts, Minnesota, and Vermont ({CWF-McCarthy 2009}). State agencies and public\/private coalitions have also led initiatives to increase value in health care services using value-based purchasing, for example the Massachusetts Group Insurance Commission ({MA-GIC}), the Minnesota Smart Buy Alliance ({MHAG-SMART}), the Washington Health Alliance ({WHA-CC}), and the Wisconsin Department of Employee Trust Funds ({CWF-Alteras 2007}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":108,"field_program_impact":2,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Reduced health care costs","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced health care costs\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Improved quality of care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved quality of care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["AHRQ-VBP guide","CHQPR-Resources","NQF-Ryan 2014"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Public health","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Hospital\/treatment center","field_program_sources":"{\u0022AHRQ-VBP guide\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00224725\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022AHRQ-VBP guide\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ). health care providers to deliver high quality, high value care","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EUse the purchasing power of employers and groups of insured individuals to create incentives and disincentives for health care providers to deliver high quality, high value care\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"78dd1730-191c-4a58-a4bd-c6e45417c0bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":17}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"185d395a-df3d-4aa8-a131-5ea40fb2ef8a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":18}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"bc0ccd4a-ab06-47fb-9124-82ba89ec5148","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3845}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"e035cd59-29b8-4ce0-a046-ea02c155a171","meta":{"target_revision_id":11340,"drupal_internal__target_id":6332}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"db29cd12-ba50-4afe-9c7a-a8815b72cd46","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":34}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"10f0f0e1-cd87-4b20-9eca-6e176e2506cb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":35}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ac6842c1-64d6-4d67-b177-0c542e9604c0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":37}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"ca8c87e8-ad24-461f-9429-a93bf91f6fe4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":45}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"af68bd1e-7b67-4620-8f44-64ef2a30a310","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":48}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"e076998a-491c-45ee-bc55-43ea4b0b8d03","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":55}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"65b3c8c1-a534-4eff-b863-bcc00c3f7ecb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":56}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"47bdd586-bb5c-4446-8ca1-2e4fa9f5b1b7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":57}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"edcd2c4e-f3bd-4895-9036-f985885fa56b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":59}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_
