e7-028a20f55b93","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3855}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"fb93818a-de8b-4ff0-b8d2-a393381b0524","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3958}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"dca80161-7e4a-433b-b47e-e03797e0e5f4","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3947}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/c62ba0b2-47fb-41e9-9604-70d98bc4b0fe\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1383"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"2b077dbf-b2a8-4c10-8dda-0f83a854cb00","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/2b077dbf-b2a8-4c10-8dda-0f83a854cb00?resourceVersion=id%3A1384"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1384,"drupal_internal__vid":1384,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Comprehensive school reform","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-06-16T20:19:40+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Comprehensive school reform | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Implement a coordinated effort to overhaul school operation, integrating curriculum, instruction, professional development, parent involvement, classroom and school management; also called school-wide or whole school reform"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/comprehensive-school-reform"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Implement a coordinated effort to overhaul school operation, integrating curriculum, instruction, professional development, parent involvement, classroom and school management; also called school-wide or whole school reform"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/comprehensive-school-reform","pid":1619,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2018-06-21","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that comprehensive school reform (CSR) improves academic outcomes ({Borman 2003}, {Walpole 2017}, {NBER-Bonilla 2017}, {Blueprints-SFA}). Additional evidence is needed to determine which programs and implementation methods are most effective.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECSR programs can modestly improve student achievement in most circumstances ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}, {AIR-CSRQ middle and high}). Effects appear strongest after CSR has been implemented for several years ({Borman 2003}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome programs have demonstrated stronger effects than others, particularly in elementary schools ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}). Success for All (SFA), a CSR program to detect and prevent reading problems, improves children\u2019s reading skills ({SPTW}, {IES WWC}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}, {Borman 2003}). Positive reading effects may depend on early exposure to SFA; students initially exposed to SFA later, in grades 3 to 5, do not improve reading achievement ({Hanselman 2013}). The Direct Instruction program may also improve academic outcomes ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}). Oregon\u2019s CSR program, Reading First, is associated with improved student reading in general; however, students in special education and those at risk for reading failure who need more intensive instruction and assessment demonstrate less improvement ({Sanford 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that schools can best implement CSR by fitting it to their circumstances ({Borman 2003}), selectively pursuing cohesive reforms, and building time and resources for CSR into regular operation ({Waldron 2010}). The professional development component of CSR appears most effective when teachers and administrators share leadership and focus on evidence-based practices ({Waldron 2010}). Teacher beliefs, self-efficacy, professional development, and buy-in can support positive attitudes toward school reform ({Donnell 2015}). Principals\u2019 use of data-informed practices to support CSR can increase teacher buy-in ({Yoon 2016}), and over time increased teacher buy-in is associated with improved student achievement ({Lee 2017b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigh costs and maintaining political will and buy-in from school districts, principals, and teachers are challenges to implementing and sustaining CSR programs over the long time horizon needed for change\u0026nbsp;({Brookings-Levesque 2016}). Research indicates that most schools pursuing CSR do not fully implement it. Teachers in CSR schools are not usually offered the full amount of professional development recommended, and may not be given adequate implementation time or leadership roles in the change process ({RAND-Vernez 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECSR costs vary by program. Success for All typically costs elementary schools $100,000 in the first year, $37,000 in the second, and $26,000 in the third year ({SPTW}). Direct Instruction costs $284,000 for a school of 500 students in the first year ({PPN}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that comprehensive school reform (CSR) improves academic outcomes ({Borman 2003}, {Walpole 2017}, {NBER-Bonilla 2017}, {Blueprints-SFA}). Additional evidence is needed to determine which programs and implementation methods are most effective.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECSR programs can modestly improve student achievement in most circumstances ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}, {AIR-CSRQ middle and high}). Effects appear strongest after CSR has been implemented for several years ({Borman 2003}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome programs have demonstrated stronger effects than others, particularly in elementary schools ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}). Success for All (SFA), a CSR program to detect and prevent reading problems, improves children\u2019s reading skills ({SPTW}, {IES WWC}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}, {Borman 2003}). Positive reading effects may depend on early exposure to SFA; students initially exposed to SFA later, in grades 3 to 5, do not improve reading achievement ({Hanselman 2013}). The Direct Instruction program may also improve academic outcomes ({Borman 2003}, {AIR-CSRQ elementary}). Oregon\u2019s CSR program, Reading First, is associated with improved student reading in general; however, students in special education and those at risk for reading failure who need more intensive instruction and assessment demonstrate less improvement ({Sanford 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearch suggests that schools can best implement CSR by fitting it to their circumstances ({Borman 2003}), selectively pursuing cohesive reforms, and building time and resources for CSR into regular operation ({Waldron 2010}). The professional development component of CSR appears most effective when teachers and administrators share leadership and focus on evidence-based practices ({Waldron 2010}). Teacher beliefs, self-efficacy, professional development, and buy-in can support positive attitudes toward school reform ({Donnell 2015}). Principals\u2019 use of data-informed practices to support CSR can increase teacher buy-in ({Yoon 2016}), and over time increased teacher buy-in is associated with improved student achievement ({Lee 2017b}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHigh costs and maintaining political will and buy-in from school districts, principals, and teachers are challenges to implementing and sustaining CSR programs over the long time horizon needed for change\u0026nbsp;({Brookings-Levesque 2016}). Research indicates that most schools pursuing CSR do not fully implement it. Teachers in CSR schools are not usually offered the full amount of professional development recommended, and may not be given adequate implementation time or leadership roles in the change process ({RAND-Vernez 2006}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECSR costs vary by program. Success for All typically costs elementary schools $100,000 in the first year, $37,000 in the second, and $26,000 in the third year ({SPTW}). Direct Instruction costs $284,000 for a school of 500 students in the first year ({PPN}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003ESeveral CSR programs have been widely implemented. For example, Success for All has been implemented in schools in 48 states and 4 other countries ({SFAF}) and Direct Instruction has been implemented in schools in 22 states, Guam, and Australia ({NIFDI}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Whole School, Whole Community, Whole Child (WSCC) model uses a CSR or whole school approach with support from the community to build on the relationship between education and health and improve each child\u2019s cognitive, physical, social, and emotional development; the WSCC model is being implemented at the national, state, and school district level ({ASCD-WSCC implementation 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003ESeveral CSR programs have been widely implemented. For example, Success for All has been implemented in schools in 48 states and 4 other countries ({SFAF}) and Direct Instruction has been implemented in schools in 22 states, Guam, and Australia ({NIFDI}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Whole School, Whole Community, Whole Child (WSCC) model uses a CSR or whole school approach with support from the community to build on the relationship between education and health and improve each child\u2019s cognitive, physical, social, and emotional development; the WSCC model is being implemented at the national, state, and school district level ({ASCD-WSCC implementation 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":109,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased academic achievement","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased academic achievement\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NIFDI","CSRI","SFAF","AIR-SSL SCI Resources","AIR-School improvement"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NIFDI\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u0022721\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NIFDI\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Institute for Direct Instruction (NIFDI). Safe supportive learning (SSL): School climate improvement (SCI) resource package.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/safesupportivelearning.ed.gov\\\/scirp\\\/about\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222024-12-02\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022AIR-School improvement\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228536\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022AIR-School improvement\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022American Institutes for Research (AIR). School climate improvement.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/safesupportivelearning.ed.gov\\\/scirp\\\/about\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-02-03\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Borman 2003\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u0022718\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Borman 2003\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Borman GD, Hewes GM, Overman LT, Brown S. Comprehensive school reform and achievement: A meta-analysis. Review of Educational Research. 2003;73(2):125-230.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/doi.org\\\/10.3102\\\/00346543073002125\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222025-05-01\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Walpole 2017\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00228528\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Walpole 2017\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Walpole S, McKenna MC, Amendum S, Pasquarella A, Strong JZ. classrooms"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/small-elementary-classes"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Reduce the number of students in elementary school classrooms"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/small-elementary-classes","pid":1620,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2016-03-30","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":null,"field_equity_description":null,"field_equity_historical_context":null,"field_equity_rating":-1,"field_equity_rationale":-1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that smaller classes modestly improve academic outcomes ({Konstantopoulos 2011}, {Nye 2004}, {Finn 2005}, {Cho 2012}), especially when implemented in kindergarten or first grade ({Ding 2010}, {Brookings-Chingos 2011}, {Watson 2013}). However, class size reduction efforts typically have small effect sizes, perhaps due to continued use of teaching methods applied in larger classes ({Hattie 2005}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA small first grade class can modestly improve outcomes for students who were in larger kindergarten classes ({Ding 2010}). Overall, reductions in class size appear to benefit students who struggle in school more than high-achieving students, and smaller classes appear to have smaller achievement gaps than classes with more children ({Bosworth 2014}). Studies of Tennessee\u2019s Student\u0026ndash;Teacher Achievement Ratio (TN STAR) experiment indicate that small classes have the greatest benefits for children from households with low incomes and minority students ({Reynolds 2010a}), and improvements in reading skills among minority students persist for at least five years ({Nye 2004}). Small classes from kindergarten to second grade may improve high school completion rates for children from low income backgrounds, especially those who are placed in a small third grade class ({Finn 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESmaller classes appear to have modest positive effects on academic outcomes when teachers adopt teaching practices that take advantage of smaller class environments ({Watson 2013}), increasing individual attention and student-teacher interactions ({Blatchford 2011}). Class size reduction efforts also appear more likely to affect academic outcomes when implemented with professional development efforts that support teacher and staff use of teaching techniques, classroom management, and student interaction strategies suited to small class environments ({Harker 2004}). Class size reductions may also improve student and teacher work environments ({Hattie 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EClass size reduction efforts frequently require additional classroom space, though principals willing to fundamentally restructure school space can overcome space challenges. Principals\u0026nbsp;can also deploy funding streams creatively to reduce class size ({Burch 2010}).\u0026nbsp;Researchers suggest that many interventions can more cost effectively improve academic achievement than class size reduction efforts; tutoring and professional development are two examples ({Brookings-Chingos 2011}, {Hattie 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that smaller classes modestly improve academic outcomes ({Konstantopoulos 2011}, {Nye 2004}, {Finn 2005}, {Cho 2012}), especially when implemented in kindergarten or first grade ({Ding 2010}, {Brookings-Chingos 2011}, {Watson 2013}). However, class size reduction efforts typically have small effect sizes, perhaps due to continued use of teaching methods applied in larger classes ({Hattie 2005}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EA small first grade class can modestly improve outcomes for students who were in larger kindergarten classes ({Ding 2010}). Overall, reductions in class size appear to benefit students who struggle in school more than high-achieving students, and smaller classes appear to have smaller achievement gaps than classes with more children ({Bosworth 2014}). Studies of Tennessee\u2019s Student\u2013Teacher Achievement Ratio (TN STAR) experiment indicate that small classes have the greatest benefits for children from households with low incomes and minority students ({Reynolds 2010a}), and improvements in reading skills among minority students persist for at least five years ({Nye 2004}). Small classes from kindergarten to second grade may improve high school completion rates for children from low income backgrounds, especially those who are placed in a small third grade class ({Finn 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESmaller classes appear to have modest positive effects on academic outcomes when teachers adopt teaching practices that take advantage of smaller class environments ({Watson 2013}), increasing individual attention and student-teacher interactions ({Blatchford 2011}). Class size reduction efforts also appear more likely to affect academic outcomes when implemented with professional development efforts that support teacher and staff use of teaching techniques, classroom management, and student interaction strategies suited to small class environments ({Harker 2004}). Class size reductions may also improve student and teacher work environments ({Hattie 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EClass size reduction efforts frequently require additional classroom space, though principals willing to fundamentally restructure school space can overcome space challenges. Principals\u0026nbsp;can also deploy funding streams creatively to reduce class size ({Burch 2010}).\u0026nbsp;Researchers suggest that many interventions can more cost effectively improve academic achievement than class size reduction efforts; tutoring and professional development are two examples ({Brookings-Chingos 2011}, {Hattie 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 2009, 23 states had enacted policies to reduce class size to a level below 20 students per classroom; 15 of those states focus on students in grades K-3 ({ECS-Zinth 2009}). By 2010, 35 states had laws restricting the number of students allowed in a general education classroom. Following the economic downturn, however, 19 states relaxed or eliminated these laws ({Ed Week-Class size 2011}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2016, Arizona introduced a bill for a class size reduction and teacher retention program in grades K-3 ({NCSL-Early ed tracking 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIn 2009, 23 states had enacted policies to reduce class size to a level below 20 students per classroom; 15 of those states focus on students in grades K-3 ({ECS-Zinth 2009}). By 2010, 35 states had laws restricting the number of students allowed in a general education classroom. Following the economic downturn, however, 19 states relaxed or eliminated these laws ({Ed Week-Class size 2011}).\u0026nbsp;\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn 2016, Arizona introduced a bill for a class size reduction and teacher retention program in grades K-3 ({NCSL-Early ed tracking 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":111,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased high school completion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased high school completion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased academic achievement","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased academic achievement\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["WI DPI-SAGE","Burch 2010"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022WI DPI-SAGE\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221635\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022WI DPI-SAGE\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (WI DPI). classrooms\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"32ab8f8f-0143-494d-b090-aa9b1a4c230a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":19}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":null,"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"7560095a-5e2b-49f1-947b-30aa282c41cd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":26}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"658e7f64-2f55-4e77-8d18-24a34bc1f926","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3850}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"542c39e0-5c89-41a9-8c6c-6edd1bbbf6ed","meta":{"target_revision_id":11342,"drupal_internal__target_id":6334}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"cbd9a012-996b-4ba5-a3d6-02d78e250003","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3542}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"edcd2c4e-f3bd-4895-9036-f985885fa56b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":59}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"c58587b0-f756-4cd7-8999-72052eaeb774","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":2645}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"3ed8af21-bd99-4573-85d4-b757a3a8e3be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":2574}},{"type":"n 3987}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"405f084e-8f43-4cb8-8e13-59fd96af074f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3952}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/f7ecf812-5308-434b-a79a-1e3c4843c307\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1385"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1386,"drupal_internal__vid":1386,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"Mentoring programs for high school graduation","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:08+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Mentoring programs for high school graduation | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Establish programs that connect students at risk of dropping out with trained adult mentors who provide ongoing guidance for academic and personal challenges"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-programs-for-high-school-graduation"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Establish programs that connect students at risk of dropping out with trained adult mentors who provide ongoing guidance for academic and personal challenges"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/mentoring-programs-for-high-school-graduation","pid":1621,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2023-03-10","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhich schools in your community have many students at risk of dropping out? What resources are available to support mentoring programs for these students? Which community or non-profit organizations could partner with schools to enhance mentoring program resources and opportunities?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow could your community increase access to mentoring relationships and programs for students at risk of dropping out? How could your community support engaging students in a mentoring relationship earlier in their school careers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is making decisions about allocating resources for mentoring and school support for students at risk of dropping out in your community? How could you support efforts to involve parents, youth, and other stakeholders in those decisions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhich schools in your community have many students at risk of dropping out? What resources are available to support mentoring programs for these students? Which community or non-profit organizations could partner with schools to enhance mentoring program resources and opportunities?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow could your community increase access to mentoring relationships and programs for students at risk of dropping out? How could your community support engaging students in a mentoring relationship earlier in their school careers?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is making decisions about allocating resources for mentoring and school support for students at risk of dropping out in your community? How could you support efforts to involve parents, youth, and other stakeholders in those decisions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs for students at high risk of school drop-out have the potential to decrease disparities in academic and health outcomes by increasing high school completion rates ({CG-HS Completion}). In the U.S., almost 1 out of 5 students do not complete high school on time, and high school drop-out rates are especially high among students of color, students from low income backgrounds, and students with disabilities ({Heppen 2018}). High school dropouts have worse health outcomes, lower wages, higher unemployment rates, and are more likely to engage in criminal activity than peers who complete high school ({Chan 2020a}, {Campbell-Wilson 2011}). These outcomes also reduce tax revenues and increase costs for society to offer social support, criminal justice, and public health services ({Chan 2020a}, {Heppen 2018}). Mentoring programs that support students at risk of dropping out during their transition to high school improve academic outcomes ({Chan 2020a}) and high school completion rates ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs can improve academic outcomes among young men of color ({Urban-Hanson 2016}) and students with disabilities ({Lindsay 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege application and admissions information availability varies dramatically for students depending on their family\u2019s income and racial or ethnic status. Mentoring programs can help students from low income backgrounds and first-generation college students through the college application and admission process, which has the potential to decrease disparities in college enrollment and completion rates between these students and peers from backgrounds with higher income and education levels ({Glass 2023}). As of 2018, only 56% of first generation college students completed their bachelor\u2019s degree within six years, compared to 74% of students whose parents have at least a bachelor\u2019s degree ({Glass 2023}). Significant racial disparities in college degree attainment persist; as of 2022, among young adults age 25 to 29 years old, 68% of Asian, 45% of white, 28% of Black, and 25% of Hispanic young adults have a bachelor\u2019s degree ({Brookings-Reber 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMentoring programs for students at high risk of school drop-out have the potential to decrease disparities in academic and health outcomes by increasing high school completion rates ({CG-HS Completion}). In the U.S., almost 1 out of 5 students do not complete high school on time, and high school drop-out rates are especially high among students of color, students from low income backgrounds, and students with disabilities ({Heppen 2018}). High school dropouts have worse health outcomes, lower wages, higher unemployment rates, and are more likely to engage in criminal activity than peers who complete high school ({Chan 2020a}, {Campbell-Wilson 2011}). These outcomes also reduce tax revenues and increase costs for society to offer social support, criminal justice, and public health services ({Chan 2020a}, {Heppen 2018}). Mentoring programs that support students at risk of dropping out during their transition to high school improve academic outcomes ({Chan 2020a}) and high school completion rates ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs can improve academic outcomes among young men of color ({Urban-Hanson 2016}) and students with disabilities ({Lindsay 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege application and admissions information availability varies dramatically for students depending on their family\u2019s income and racial or ethnic status. Mentoring programs can help students from low income backgrounds and first-generation college students through the college application and admission process, which has the potential to decrease disparities in college enrollment and completion rates between these students and peers from backgrounds with higher income and education levels ({Glass 2023}). As of 2018, only 56% of first generation college students completed their bachelor\u2019s degree within six years, compared to 74% of students whose parents have at least a bachelor\u2019s degree ({Glass 2023}). Significant racial disparities in college degree attainment persist; as of 2022, among young adults age 25 to 29 years old, 68% of Asian, 45% of white, 28% of Black, and 25% of Hispanic young adults have a bachelor\u2019s degree ({Brookings-Reber 2023}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in educational opportunities in the U.S. are shaped by many factors, including a long history of racial segregation in schools and differences in family income levels. The public school system in the U.S. continues to be highly segregated and schools in different neighborhoods have vastly different resources available, since school financing largely depends on local property taxes. Discriminatory housing, lending, and exclusionary zoning policies have entrenched racial residential segregation, reduced local property values, and concentrated poverty ({Braveman 2022}, {EPI-Rothstein 2014}). Students of color, especially Black, Hispanic, and Native students, are much more likely to attend school districts with high poverty rates than white students ({Knight 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudent absenteeism is one of the primary factors that drives high school drop-out rates. Students are absent from school for many reasons. Students cannot attend when they are sick, and in some cases, they may also have to miss school to care for a sick sibling when parents do not have sick days, flexible work arrangements, or affordable alternative childcare arrangements. Housing instability, evictions, and homelessness can also force students to miss school. In some cases, students refuse to attend school to avoid bullying and violence. Other students are absent when they do not feel that school is a worthwhile place for them ({NBER-Guryan 2020}). Students of color, students living in poverty, students from single-parent families, students with limited English language skills, and students with disabilities are more likely to be chronically absent ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe complexity of the issues that lead to student absenteeism and school drop-out suggests that mentors may need to also function as advocates and provide individualized referrals to additional interventions and supports to help students at risk of dropping out reengage with and successfully complete high school ({Heppen 2018}). Experts suggest that efforts to prevent school drop-out should include increasing access to many services both in school and in the community, including mentoring as well as additional academic assistance, behavioral interventions, basic needs programs, family support services, college preparation counseling, and more ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in educational opportunities in the U.S. are shaped by many factors, including a long history of racial segregation in schools and differences in family income levels. The public school system in the U.S. continues to be highly segregated and schools in different neighborhoods have vastly different resources available, since school financing largely depends on local property taxes. Discriminatory housing, lending, and exclusionary zoning policies have entrenched racial residential segregation, reduced local property values, and concentrated poverty ({Braveman 2022}, {EPI-Rothstein 2014}). Students of color, especially Black, Hispanic, and Native students, are much more likely to attend school districts with high poverty rates than white students ({Knight 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudent absenteeism is one of the primary factors that drives high school drop-out rates. Students are absent from school for many reasons. Students cannot attend when they are sick, and in some cases, they may also have to miss school to care for a sick sibling when parents do not have sick days, flexible work arrangements, or affordable alternative childcare arrangements. Housing instability, evictions, and homelessness can also force students to miss school. In some cases, students refuse to attend school to avoid bullying and violence. Other students are absent when they do not feel that school is a worthwhile place for them ({NBER-Guryan 2020}). Students of color, students living in poverty, students from single-parent families, students with limited English language skills, and students with disabilities are more likely to be chronically absent ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe complexity of the issues that lead to student absenteeism and school drop-out suggests that mentors may need to also function as advocates and provide individualized referrals to additional interventions and supports to help students at risk of dropping out reengage with and successfully complete high school ({Heppen 2018}). Experts suggest that efforts to prevent school drop-out should include increasing access to many services both in school and in the community, including mentoring as well as additional academic assistance, behavioral interventions, basic needs programs, family support services, college preparation counseling, and more ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":1,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mentoring programs for students at risk of dropping out improve high school completion rates ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs can also help youth with disabilities graduate and transition to postsecondary education or employment ({Lindsay 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOn average, mentoring programs increase high school completion rates among students at risk of dropping out by 9% ({CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs with longer durations (e.g., lasting more than one year) have stronger effects than shorter programs on academic, social-emotional, and employment outcomes ({Lindsay 2016}, {Child Trends-Lawner 2013}). Students who have close relationships with their mentors appear to have stronger academic outcomes than mentored students without close mentor relationships ({MDRC-Bayer 2013}). One study found mentoring program participation can reduce school absences during middle school (e.g., grades 5-7), though this effect did not appear during elementary school (e.g., grades 1-4) ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudents participating in group mentoring programs have more instructional time and earned credits in 9th and 10th grade than non-participating peers, which increases the likelihood that participants can complete high school on-time ({Chan 2020a}). Small group-based mentoring programs also can increase resilience among academically vulnerable students in the short term by helping increase their sense of school belonging, participation in school, school support, positive peer relationships, home participation, and social problem-solving skills ({Kuperminc 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELow program attendance or completion rates, staffing, mentor recruitment, and other administrative challenges can reduce the effectiveness of mentoring programs ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}). Mentoring programs that start in 10th grade may be too late in a student\u2019s academic career to have positive effects on on-time high school completion, since students may already be substantially behind on credit completion ({Heppen 2018}). In one study of a two-year community-based mentoring program, students reported positive experiences with mentoring, however, their attendance, behavior, and academic outcomes varied by program site, which may be due to short program duration, lack of integration with schools, or several implementation variables ({Mac Iver 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers suggest that programs choose willing adult mentors committed to their task, purposefully match students to mentors, provide training and support for adult mentors, and establish mentor\/student meetings at least weekly ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}). Mentoring programs with weekly meetings and opportunities for mentor-mentee interaction outside of large-group settings are more likely to foster close mentor-mentee relationships ({MDRC-Bayer 2013}). Experts suggest school districts implement mentoring programs over multiple years, begin mentoring programs before high school, monitor mentor caseloads to allow enough time for mentors to work with all of their students, and consider offering additional academic support activities in conjunction with mentoring ({Heppen 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost of mentoring programs ranges from $600 to $4500 per student ({CG-HS Completion}). Check \u0026amp; Connect, a mentoring program that has been shown to prevent dropout in urban areas with high poverty rates, costs about $1800 per student per year ({SPTW}, {NBER-Guryan 2020}). Mentoring programs have an estimated benefit to cost ratio of 2 to 1 ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that mentoring programs for students at risk of dropping out improve high school completion rates ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs can also help youth with disabilities graduate and transition to postsecondary education or employment ({Lindsay 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EOn average, mentoring programs increase high school completion rates among students at risk of dropping out by 9% ({CG-HS Completion}). Mentoring programs with longer durations (e.g., lasting more than one year) have stronger effects than shorter programs on academic, social-emotional, and employment outcomes ({Lindsay 2016}, {Child Trends-Lawner 2013}). Students who have close relationships with their mentors appear to have stronger academic outcomes than mentored students without close mentor relationships ({MDRC-Bayer 2013}). One study found mentoring program participation can reduce school absences during middle school (e.g., grades 5-7), though this effect did not appear during elementary school (e.g., grades 1-4) ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudents participating in group mentoring programs have more instructional time and earned credits in 9th and 10th grade than non-participating peers, which increases the likelihood that participants can complete high school on-time ({Chan 2020a}). Small group-based mentoring programs also can increase resilience among academically vulnerable students in the short term by helping increase their sense of school belonging, participation in school, school support, positive peer relationships, home participation, and social problem-solving skills ({Kuperminc 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ELow program attendance or completion rates, staffing, mentor recruitment, and other administrative challenges can reduce the effectiveness of mentoring programs ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}). Mentoring programs that start in 10th grade may be too late in a student\u2019s academic career to have positive effects on on-time high school completion, since students may already be substantially behind on credit completion ({Heppen 2018}). In one study of a two-year community-based mentoring program, students reported positive experiences with mentoring, however, their attendance, behavior, and academic outcomes varied by program site, which may be due to short program duration, lack of integration with schools, or several implementation variables ({Mac Iver 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers suggest that programs choose willing adult mentors committed to their task, purposefully match students to mentors, provide training and support for adult mentors, and establish mentor\/student meetings at least weekly ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}). Mentoring programs with weekly meetings and opportunities for mentor-mentee interaction outside of large-group settings are more likely to foster close mentor-mentee relationships ({MDRC-Bayer 2013}). Experts suggest school districts implement mentoring programs over multiple years, begin mentoring programs before high school, monitor mentor caseloads to allow enough time for mentors to work with all of their students, and consider offering additional academic support activities in conjunction with mentoring ({Heppen 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost of mentoring programs ranges from $600 to $4500 per student ({CG-HS Completion}). Check \u0026amp; Connect, a mentoring program that has been shown to prevent dropout in urban areas with high poverty rates, costs about $1800 per student per year ({SPTW}, {NBER-Guryan 2020}). Mentoring programs have an estimated benefit to cost ratio of 2 to 1 ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EMany mentoring programs are established in several locations across the country. For example, Check \u0026amp; Connect has been implemented in 48 states, including 9 state-wide programs, and internationally ({Check and Connect}). YouthBuild USA also has established over 100 local YouthBuild Mentoring programs that pair students and mentors for academic and career support. Students and mentors stay connected while students are participating in YouthBuild and after they graduate ({YB-Mentoring}). MENTOR is another non-profit organization that works with many partners around the country to support over 5,000 mentoring programs ({MENTOR}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMENTOR and its network of affiliates also support National Mentoring Month, to increase awareness about the impacts mentors can have on youth and encourage civic leaders and stakeholders to prioritize and invest in mentoring programs and opportunities ({MENTOR-Mentoring month}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EMany mentoring programs are established in several locations across the country. For example, Check \u0026amp; Connect has been implemented in 48 states, including 9 state-wide programs, and internationally ({Check and Connect}). YouthBuild USA also has established over 100 local YouthBuild Mentoring programs that pair students and mentors for academic and career support. Students and mentors stay connected while students are participating in YouthBuild and after they graduate ({YB-Mentoring}). MENTOR is another non-profit organization that works with many partners around the country to support over 5,000 mentoring programs ({MENTOR}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMENTOR and its network of affiliates also support National Mentoring Month, to increase awareness about the impacts mentors can have on youth and encourage civic leaders and stakeholders to prioritize and invest in mentoring programs and opportunities ({MENTOR-Mentoring month}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":113,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Improved academic outcomes","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EImproved academic outcomes\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased high school completion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased high school completion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NMRC-Mentoring","YG-Mentoring resources","Check and Connect","MENTOR","MENTOR-Mentoring connector database"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NMRC-Mentoring\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226340\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NMRC-Mentoring\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Mentoring Resource Center (NMRC). challenges","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EEstablish programs that connect students at risk of dropping out with trained adult mentors who provide ongoing guidance for academic and personal challenges\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"6421c7b2-7014-440e-9db3-ddcef2347c45","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3635}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"bdbfb0c8-7f51-4487-bf38-46fe4e35bd2e","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":16}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"32ab8f8f-0143-494d-b090-aa9b1a4c230a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":19}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--disparity_ratings","id":"37e6c336-4955-4db7-8a11-5f9dfe2f44ba","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3651}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"9db6427d-c54c-4a80-918d-4a5dd6012582","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":25}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1386"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"658e7f64-2f55-4e77-8d18-24a34bc1f926","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3850}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.gi high schools for students at risk of dropping out","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:08+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"Alternative high schools for students at risk of dropping out | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Provide educational and social services in an map of the United Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/alternative-high-schools-for-students-at-risk-of-dropping-out","pid":1622,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2025-04-23","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is at risk of dropping out of school in your community? What factors, such as external influences, like the need to work a job, or internal influences, like hostile or discriminatory learning environments, are increasing their risk?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community better understand who leaves school and why? Are there community or non-profit organizations you could partner with to help understand risk factors and enhance high school completion program resources and opportunities, including alternative high schools?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is making decisions about allocating school support resources for students at risk of dropping out in your community? Including implementing alternative high schools? How could you involve parents, students, and other stakeholders and strategic partners in those decisions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is at risk of dropping out of school in your community? What factors, such as external influences, like the need to work a job, or internal influences, like hostile or discriminatory learning environments, are increasing their risk?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community better understand who leaves school and why? Are there community or non-profit organizations you could partner with to help understand risk factors and enhance high school completion program resources and opportunities, including alternative high schools?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWho is making decisions about allocating school support resources for students at risk of dropping out in your community? Including implementing alternative high schools? How could you involve parents, students, and other stakeholders and strategic partners in those decisions?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alternative high schools for students at risk of dropping out have the potential to reduce disparities in academic achievement by increasing high school completion rates or high school equivalency achievement among students of color and students from low income backgrounds ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Available data shows alternative schools disproportionately serve students who are Black and Hispanic, who are English language learners, who have disabilities, who are male, and who live in urban areas ({Urban-Kho 2022}). Overall, students who are Hispanic, Black, or Native American graduate from high school at lower rates than students who are white or Asian ({NCES-Young adult education}). A wide range of factors may be related to dropout rates, including adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), making students repeat grades, and discrimination ({Hughes 2017}, {McWhirter 2018}, {Ianchini 2016}).\u003Cbr \/\u003E\u003Cbr \/\u003EExperts suggest that efforts to prevent school drop-out should include increasing access to many services both in school and in the community, including mentoring, additional academic assistance, behavioral interventions, basic needs programs, family support services, college preparation counseling, and more ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alternative high schools for students at risk of dropping out have the potential to reduce disparities in academic achievement by increasing high school completion rates or high school equivalency achievement among students of color and students from low income backgrounds ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}, {CG-HS Completion}). Available data shows alternative schools disproportionately serve students who are Black and Hispanic, who are English language learners, who have disabilities, who are male, and who live in urban areas ({Urban-Kho 2022}). Overall, students who are Hispanic, Black, or Native American graduate from high school at lower rates than students who are white or Asian ({NCES-Young adult education}). A wide range of factors may be related to dropout rates, including adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), making students repeat grades, and discrimination ({Hughes 2017}, {McWhirter 2018}, {Ianchini 2016}).\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EExperts suggest that efforts to prevent school drop-out should include increasing access to many services both in school and in the community, including mentoring, additional academic assistance, behavioral interventions, basic needs programs, family support services, college preparation counseling, and more ({IES WWC-Rumberger 2017}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in educational opportunities in the U.S. are shaped by many factors, including a long history of racial segregation in schools. The public school system in the U.S. continues to be highly segregated and schools in different neighborhoods have vastly different resources available since school financing largely depends on local property taxes. Discriminatory housing, lending, and exclusionary zoning policies have entrenched racial residential segregation, reduced local property values, and concentrated poverty ({Braveman 2022}, {EPI-Rothstein 2014}). Students of color, especially Black, Hispanic, and Native students, are much more likely to attend school districts with high poverty rates and fewer resources than white students ({Knight 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudent absenteeism is one of the primary factors that drives high school drop-out rates. Students are absent from school for many reasons. For example, students cannot attend when they are sick, and in some cases, they may also have to miss school to care for a sick sibling when parents do not have sick days, flexible work arrangements, or affordable alternative childcare arrangements. Housing instability, evictions, and homelessness can also force students to miss school. In some cases, students refuse to attend school to avoid bullying and violence. Other students are absent when they do not feel that school is a worthwhile place for them ({NBER-Guryan 2020}). Students of color, students living in poverty, students from single-parent families, students with limited English language skills, and students with disabilities are more likely to be chronically absent ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlternative schools were developed as an innovative part of the American public school system in the 1960s and became more common in the 1970s ({Lehr 2003}). During the 1980s and 1990s, many alternative schools as well as state and local policies for alternative schools began to focus more on behavioral management and remedial education specifically for students struggling in traditional settings with low achievement and with chronically disruptive or violent behavior ({Lehr 2003}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EDisparities in educational opportunities in the U.S. are shaped by many factors, including a long history of racial segregation in schools. The public school system in the U.S. continues to be highly segregated and schools in different neighborhoods have vastly different resources available since school financing largely depends on local property taxes. Discriminatory housing, lending, and exclusionary zoning policies have entrenched racial residential segregation, reduced local property values, and concentrated poverty ({Braveman 2022}, {EPI-Rothstein 2014}). Students of color, especially Black, Hispanic, and Native students, are much more likely to attend school districts with high poverty rates and fewer resources than white students ({Knight 2022}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EStudent absenteeism is one of the primary factors that drives high school drop-out rates. Students are absent from school for many reasons. For example, students cannot attend when they are sick, and in some cases, they may also have to miss school to care for a sick sibling when parents do not have sick days, flexible work arrangements, or affordable alternative childcare arrangements. Housing instability, evictions, and homelessness can also force students to miss school. In some cases, students refuse to attend school to avoid bullying and violence. Other students are absent when they do not feel that school is a worthwhile place for them ({NBER-Guryan 2020}). Students of color, students living in poverty, students from single-parent families, students with limited English language skills, and students with disabilities are more likely to be chronically absent ({NBER-Guryan 2020}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlternative schools were developed as an innovative part of the American public school system in the 1960s and became more common in the 1970s ({Lehr 2003}). During the 1980s and 1990s, many alternative schools as well as state and local policies for alternative schools began to focus more on behavioral management and remedial education specifically for students struggling in traditional settings with low achievement and with chronically disruptive or violent behavior ({Lehr 2003}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":0,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alternative high schools for students at risk of dropping out improve high school completion rates ({CG-HS Completion}, {Campbell-Wilson 2011}). On average, alternative schools increase completion rates among students at risk of dropping out by 15.5% ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInterviews with students at risk of dropping out suggest that students are more likely to stay in alternative high schools that provide safe spaces physically, emotionally, and psychologically; foster a sense of community; affirm students\u2019 racial\/ethnic identities; and use flexible disciplinary systems based on discussion and conflict resolution ({O\u2019Gorman 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EImplementation challenges such as staffing or funding difficulties, problems with the physical space, and low program attendance or completion rates can reduce the effectiveness of alternative high schools ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost of alternative schools varies significantly, ranging from $1,700 to $12,900 per student. The estimated benefit to cost ratio for alternative schools ranges from 0.6 to 1 to 1.6 to 1 ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that alternative high schools for students at risk of dropping out improve high school completion rates ({CG-HS Completion}, {Campbell-Wilson 2011}). On average, alternative schools increase completion rates among students at risk of dropping out by 15.5% ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EInterviews with students at risk of dropping out suggest that students are more likely to stay in alternative high schools that provide safe spaces physically, emotionally, and psychologically; foster a sense of community; affirm students\u2019 racial\/ethnic identities; and use flexible disciplinary systems based on discussion and conflict resolution ({O\u2019Gorman 2016}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EImplementation challenges such as staffing or funding difficulties, problems with the physical space, and low program attendance or completion rates can reduce the effectiveness of alternative high schools ({Campbell-Wilson 2011}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe cost of alternative schools varies significantly, ranging from $1,700 to $12,900 per student. The estimated benefit to cost ratio for alternative schools ranges from 0.6 to 1 to 1.6 to 1 ({CG-HS Completion}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EAlternative education programs have been formally defined in 43 states; definitions vary, but usually include guidelines about services, for example, regular academic instruction (21 states), counseling (14 states), social and life skills training (13 states), vocational and workplace preparation (12 states), or behavioral services (e.g., anger management or conflict resolution) (11 states) ({IES-Porowski 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 2007-2008 school year, there were about 10,300 alternative schools or alternative education programs for students at risk of dropping out administered by school districts across the country; approximately 63% of these schools or programs were offered in facilities outside of traditional public schools ({NCES-Rouse Carver 2010}). University High School in Boston, MA and Middle College High School in Seattle, WA are examples of alternative high schools that offer enhanced social services, flexible enrollment policies, small classes, counseling and mentoring support, and vocational training and work experiences ({ABCD-UHS}, {SPS-MCHS}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeveral national non-profit organizations have developed alternative education programs into pathways to earn high school diplomas or GEDs. For example, The Corps Network supports students earning high school diplomas or GEDs with more personal attention in the classroom; comprehensive academic, career, and personal counseling; and job skills training ({TCN-Impacts}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EAlternative education programs have been formally defined in 43 states; definitions vary, but usually include guidelines about services, for example, regular academic instruction (21 states), counseling (14 states), social and life skills training (13 states), vocational and workplace preparation (12 states), or behavioral services (e.g., anger management or conflict resolution) (11 states) ({IES-Porowski 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn the 2007-2008 school year, there were about 10,300 alternative schools or alternative education programs for students at risk of dropping out administered by school districts across the country; approximately 63% of these schools or programs were offered in facilities outside of traditional public schools ({NCES-Rouse Carver 2010}). University High School in Boston, MA and Middle College High School in Seattle, WA are examples of alternative high schools that offer enhanced social services, flexible enrollment policies, small classes, counseling and mentoring support, and vocational training and work experiences ({ABCD-UHS}, {SPS-MCHS}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeveral national non-profit organizations have developed alternative education programs into pathways to earn high school diplomas or GEDs. For example, The Corps Network supports students earning high school diplomas or GEDs with more personal attention in the classroom; comprehensive academic, career, and personal counseling; and job skills training ({TCN-Impacts}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":114,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased high school completion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased high school completion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["NDPC-Alternative schools","NDPC-Addis 2020","PSR-State search","Urban-Aron 2006"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022NDPC-Alternative schools\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002215730\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022NDPC-Alternative schools\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022National Dropout Prevention Center (NDPC).
