schools\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_decision_makers":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"32ab8f8f-0143-494d-b090-aa9b1a4c230a","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":19}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"c13941aa-0fe0-4a32-9190-dd8507b8018b","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":20}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--decision_makers","id":"9c091979-5739-4910-9ff2-1518c33bd741","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":24}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_decision_makers?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_disparity_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--disparity_ratings","id":"37e6c336-4955-4db7-8a11-5f9dfe2f44ba","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3651}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_disparity_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_evidence_rating":{"data":{"type":"taxonomy_term--evidence_ratings","id":"9db6427d-c54c-4a80-918d-4a5dd6012582","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":25}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_evidence_rating?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_health_factors":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"658e7f64-2f55-4e77-8d18-24a34bc1f926","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3850}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.git ,"id":"2f922cdc-edea-4e75-9a26-8d5ab10334ad","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1566}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"eaa5ace9-767f-45c2-be83-3db7a03e4634","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1499}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"52d271a2-f29d-43a5-a20a-cb3753771a9c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1390}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1388}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1386}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"7779a6bc-2841-472e-8eda-3d7cf8f11997","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3988}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"405f084e-8f43-4cb8-8e13-59fd96af074f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3952}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1387"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1388,"drupal_internal__vid":1388,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"High school equivalency credentials","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:08+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"High school equivalency credentials | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Offer programs to help individuals without a high school diploma or its equivalent achieve a high school equivalency credential"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/high-school-equivalency-credentials"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Offer programs to help individuals without a high school diploma or its equivalent achieve a high school equivalency credential"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,Correctional facility,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education,Employment \u0026 job training"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/high-school-equivalency-credentials","pid":1623,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":"bundle_default","rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":301,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":"bundle_default","sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2022-05-18","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can HSE credential programs be tailored to be more culturally competent?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhy do youth decide not to finish their traditional high school credentials? What factors contribute to the incompletion?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supports and\/or resources could help youth in your community complete high school?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there additional resources that can be provided to individuals participating in HSE credential programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supports can increase access to HSE credential programs for individuals in rural areas? For those with limited access to broadband? For individuals with disabilities? For those with English language learner status?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can HSE credential programs be tailored to be more culturally competent?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhy do youth decide not to finish their traditional high school credentials? What factors contribute to the incompletion?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supports and\/or resources could help youth in your community complete high school?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre there additional resources that can be provided to individuals participating in HSE credential programs?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat supports can increase access to HSE credential programs for individuals in rural areas? For those with limited access to broadband? For individuals with disabilities? For those with English language learner status?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EHigh school equivalency (HSE) credentials are a suggested strategy to decrease disparities in earnings and labor market outcomes between people without a high school degree and those who have completed high school. HSE credentials may be especially beneficial for those from low-income backgrounds who did not complete a traditional high school program and for those who use their HSE credential to pursue further education ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). On average, GED recipients earn more than peers who did not complete high school, but still less than high school graduates ({Tyler 2005}). It often takes time for recipients\u2019 incomes to increase, and gains are typically modest ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}). GED recipients who do advance to postsecondary education substantially increase their earnings ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm the effects of HSE credentials.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth outcomes for GED recipients are generally similar to individuals who do not complete high school and are significantly worse than outcomes for high school graduates ({Zajacova 2014}). These outcomes may be compounded for some students, since most individuals who are pursuing HSE credentials are from low income and disadvantaged backgrounds and identify as persons of color ({Zukowski 2021}). A Canada-based survey shows that 10 percent of Native populations who live off of reservations leave high school prior to completion and return to complete their credentials in adulthood. The survey indicates that HSE credentials provide a second chance to those who were unable to complete traditional high school ({O\u2019Donnell 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EHigh school equivalency (HSE) credentials are a suggested strategy to decrease disparities in earnings and labor market outcomes between people without a high school degree and those who have completed high school. HSE credentials may be especially beneficial for those from low-income backgrounds who did not complete a traditional high school program and for those who use their HSE credential to pursue further education ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). On average, GED recipients earn more than peers who did not complete high school, but still less than high school graduates ({Tyler 2005}). It often takes time for recipients\u2019 incomes to increase, and gains are typically modest ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}). GED recipients who do advance to postsecondary education substantially increase their earnings ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm the effects of HSE credentials.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth outcomes for GED recipients are generally similar to individuals who do not complete high school and are significantly worse than outcomes for high school graduates ({Zajacova 2014}). These outcomes may be compounded for some students, since most individuals who are pursuing HSE credentials are from low income and disadvantaged backgrounds and identify as persons of color ({Zukowski 2021}). A Canada-based survey shows that 10 percent of Native populations who live off of reservations leave high school prior to completion and return to complete their credentials in adulthood. The survey indicates that HSE credentials provide a second chance to those who were unable to complete traditional high school ({O\u2019Donnell 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe GED test in the U.S. was introduced in 1942 to help certify World War II veterans without a high school diploma. In turn, this allowed veterans a path to postsecondary education for those who are interested ({Davidson 2017}). The GED test was broadened in 1947, from a wartime emergency measure to include anyone who did not complete high school. Over the years, civilians who were leaving school early to join the industrial workforce also began pursuing GED credentials. By 1959 the majority of GED test takers were civilians ({General Education Development}). Increases in the number of GED test takers in the 1960s and 1970s were attributed to increased federal funding for adult education programs and financial assistance (e.g., Pell Grant) for individuals with GED credentials who want to go to college ({Tyler 2005}). In 2014, two additional tests were introduced: Test Assessing Secondary Completion (TASC) and High School Equivalency Test (HiSET) ({NCES-High school equivalency tests 2015}). Though TASC was discontinued as of December 31, 2021 ({DRC-TASC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe 2014 Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) adapted and reauthorized funding for the nation\u2019s employment, training, adult education, and vocational rehabilitation programs. WIOA acknowledged many of the barriers to adult education, high school completion, and workforce development that face adults and youth seeking job opportunities and economic success. One of the key provisions in WIOA expands the focus of education opportunities for adult secondary education or HSE credentials to include postsecondary training and career education opportunities ({CLASP-Bird 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe GED test in the U.S. was introduced in 1942 to help certify World War II veterans without a high school diploma. In turn, this allowed veterans a path to postsecondary education for those who are interested ({Davidson 2017}). The GED test was broadened in 1947, from a wartime emergency measure to include anyone who did not complete high school. Over the years, civilians who were leaving school early to join the industrial workforce also began pursuing GED credentials. By 1959 the majority of GED test takers were civilians ({General Education Development}). Increases in the number of GED test takers in the 1960s and 1970s were attributed to increased federal funding for adult education programs and financial assistance (e.g., Pell Grant) for individuals with GED credentials who want to go to college ({Tyler 2005}). In 2014, two additional tests were introduced: Test Assessing Secondary Completion (TASC) and High School Equivalency Test (HiSET) ({NCES-High school equivalency tests 2015}). Though TASC was discontinued as of December 31, 2021 ({DRC-TASC}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe 2014 Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) adapted and reauthorized funding for the nation\u2019s employment, training, adult education, and vocational rehabilitation programs. WIOA acknowledged many of the barriers to adult education, high school completion, and workforce development that face adults and youth seeking job opportunities and economic success. One of the key provisions in WIOA expands the focus of education opportunities for adult secondary education or HSE credentials to include postsecondary training and career education opportunities ({CLASP-Bird 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":2,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that high school equivalency credentials increase earnings for recipients ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}), especially among individuals with low cognitive skills and adults who use their credential to obtain postsecondary education ({NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). GED receipt through correctional education programs reduces recidivism and may increase employment for individuals who have been incarcerated ({RAND-Davis 2013}). Other recipients, such as youth transitioning out of foster care ({Okpych 2014}), are less likely to realize earnings or employment benefits ({NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects, especially among adults who have earned HSE credentials ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIt often takes several years of work experience after earning a HSE credential for recipients\u2019 incomes to increase, and gains are typically modest ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}). Few GED recipients advance to postsecondary education, but those who do substantially increase their earnings ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}). On average, GED recipients earn more than peers who do not complete high school and less than high school graduates ({Tyler 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth outcomes for GED recipients are generally similar to individuals who do not complete high school, and significantly worse than outcomes for high school graduates ({Zajacova 2014}). These outcomes may be compounded for some students, since most individuals pursuing HSE credentials come from low income, disadvantaged backgrounds and identify as persons of color ({Zukowski 2021}). One study suggests that HSE programs that include health literacy instruction can improve health literacy among Spanish-speaking, adult students ({Mas 2017}). The COVID-19 pandemic has also highlighted concerns about the viability of long-term virtual programs, including HSE programs, which require access to broadband. The growing digital divide may exacerbate educational, economic, and social inequities, especially for students trying to pursue HSE credentials without adequate broadband access ({Zukowski 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMulti-component bridge programs that include education and basic skill instruction, HSE test preparation, and career training and supports can increase HSE credential receipt as well as college enrollment more than standalone HSE programs ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}, {MDRC-Martin 2013}). GED programs that use more rigorous college and career readiness curricula may also be more likely to encourage GED recipients to continue with postsecondary education and training ({MDRC-Rutschow 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers recommend that HSE programs help students manage adult responsibilities that can make program completion difficult, link to postsecondary programs, stress the necessity of further education, and help students navigate the postsecondary admissions and financial aid processes ({Tyler 2005}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}, {MDRC-Rutschow 2014}). Research also suggests GED classes can increase receipt of GEDs regardless of participants\u2019 initial level of motivation ({MDRC-Bos 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn some cases, GED access can induce potential high school graduates to drop out. Factors that decrease GED desirability such as high minimum dropout ages, more rigorous GED standards, or parental consent requirements are associated with higher rates of school completion. High school exit exams, conversely, may increase attempts to earn GEDs ({NBER-Heckman 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is some evidence that high school equivalency credentials increase earnings for recipients ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}), especially among individuals with low cognitive skills and adults who use their credential to obtain postsecondary education ({NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). GED receipt through correctional education programs reduces recidivism and may increase employment for individuals who have been incarcerated ({RAND-Davis 2013}). Other recipients, such as youth transitioning out of foster care ({Okpych 2014}), are less likely to realize earnings or employment benefits ({NBER-Heckman 2010}, {Tyler 2005}). Additional evidence is needed to confirm effects, especially among adults who have earned HSE credentials ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIt often takes several years of work experience after earning a HSE credential for recipients\u2019 incomes to increase, and gains are typically modest ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}). Few GED recipients advance to postsecondary education, but those who do substantially increase their earnings ({Tyler 2005}, {NBER-Heckman 2010}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}). On average, GED recipients earn more than peers who do not complete high school and less than high school graduates ({Tyler 2005}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EHealth outcomes for GED recipients are generally similar to individuals who do not complete high school, and significantly worse than outcomes for high school graduates ({Zajacova 2014}). These outcomes may be compounded for some students, since most individuals pursuing HSE credentials come from low income, disadvantaged backgrounds and identify as persons of color ({Zukowski 2021}). One study suggests that HSE programs that include health literacy instruction can improve health literacy among Spanish-speaking, adult students ({Mas 2017}). The COVID-19 pandemic has also highlighted concerns about the viability of long-term virtual programs, including HSE programs, which require access to broadband. The growing digital divide may exacerbate educational, economic, and social inequities, especially for students trying to pursue HSE credentials without adequate broadband access ({Zukowski 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMulti-component bridge programs that include education and basic skill instruction, HSE test preparation, and career training and supports can increase HSE credential receipt as well as college enrollment more than standalone HSE programs ({Mathematica-Borradaile 2021}, {MDRC-Martin 2013}). GED programs that use more rigorous college and career readiness curricula may also be more likely to encourage GED recipients to continue with postsecondary education and training ({MDRC-Rutschow 2014}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EResearchers recommend that HSE programs help students manage adult responsibilities that can make program completion difficult, link to postsecondary programs, stress the necessity of further education, and help students navigate the postsecondary admissions and financial aid processes ({Tyler 2005}, {MDRC-Bos 2002}, {MDRC-Rutschow 2014}). Research also suggests GED classes can increase receipt of GEDs regardless of participants\u2019 initial level of motivation ({MDRC-Bos 2002}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn some cases, GED access can induce potential high school graduates to drop out. Factors that decrease GED desirability such as high minimum dropout ages, more rigorous GED standards, or parental consent requirements are associated with higher rates of school completion. High school exit exams, conversely, may increase attempts to earn GEDs ({NBER-Heckman 2010}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EHSE credential programs are available in all states, as well as online, and the U.S. Department of Education website provides the contacts for state adult education agencies that implement high school equivalency credential programs for each state ({US ED-State contacts}, {Learning Path}). As of 2018, over 1.1 million adult students were pursuing adult basic education, English as a second language, or adult secondary education. Approximately 108,000 students were taking classes to prepare for a high school equivalency credential ({NCES-Adult education 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBridge programs that support pathways for HSE recipients to continue with postsecondary education and training are also becoming more available like at Northeast Wisconsin Technical College ({NWTC-Career Pathways Bridge Program}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESciMentors is a science outreach program for adult learners from underserved backgrounds. SciMentors aims to create a sustainable and long-term mentorship program and to provide science focused education in partnership with HSE and adult literacy programs ({Gagnon 2017}, {UMN-SciMentors}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe High School Equivalency Program (HEP) helps migratory and seasonal farmworkers (and their family members) who are age 16 or older to obtain a high school equivalency certification. The program also supports those who obtain HSE certifications to gain employment or begin postsecondary education or training ({US ED-Migrant Education-HEP 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYouthBuild programs combine academic preparation for the GED or other HSE tests with hands-on job training to prepare students for postsecondary education or employment. As of 2020, there are more than 275 urban and rural YouthBuild programs available across the U.S. ({YouthBuild}). Project Rise, which links GED preparation classes with case management and part-time, paid internships, operates in New York City; Newark, New Jersey; and Kansas City, Missouri. ({MDRC-Project Rise}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EHSE credential programs are available in all states, as well as online, and the U.S. Department of Education website provides the contacts for state adult education agencies that implement high school equivalency credential programs for each state ({US ED-State contacts}, {Learning Path}). As of 2018, over 1.1 million adult students were pursuing adult basic education, English as a second language, or adult secondary education. Approximately 108,000 students were taking classes to prepare for a high school equivalency credential ({NCES-Adult education 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EBridge programs that support pathways for HSE recipients to continue with postsecondary education and training are also becoming more available like at Northeast Wisconsin Technical College ({NWTC-Career Pathways Bridge Program}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESciMentors is a science outreach program for adult learners from underserved backgrounds. SciMentors aims to create a sustainable and long-term mentorship program and to provide science focused education in partnership with HSE and adult literacy programs ({Gagnon 2017}, {UMN-SciMentors}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe High School Equivalency Program (HEP) helps migratory and seasonal farmworkers (and their family members) who are age 16 or older to obtain a high school equivalency certification. The program also supports those who obtain HSE certifications to gain employment or begin postsecondary education or training ({US ED-Migrant Education-HEP 2018}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EYouthBuild programs combine academic preparation for the GED or other HSE tests with hands-on job training to prepare students for postsecondary education or employment. As of 2020, there are more than 275 urban and rural YouthBuild programs available across the U.S. ({YouthBuild}). Project Rise, which links GED preparation classes with case management and part-time, paid internships, operates in New York City; Newark, New Jersey; and Kansas City, Missouri. ({MDRC-Project Rise}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":115,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased HSE credential completion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased HSE credential completion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased earnings","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased earnings\u003C\/p\u003E\n"},{"value":"Reduced recidivism","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EReduced recidivism\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["Learning Path","WI DPI-GED requirements","MDRC-Rutschow 2014","US ED-State contacts"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education,Employment \u0026 job training","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,Correctional facility,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022Learning Path\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221616\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Learning Path\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022LearningPath.org. Number and percentage of people taking, completing, and passing high school equivalency tests, by test taken and state or jurisdiction: 2013 and 2015.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/nces.ed.gov\\\/programs\\\/digest\\\/d17\\\/tables\\\/dt17_219.60.asp\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-18\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022DRC-TASC\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002211489\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022DRC-TASC\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Data Recognition Corporation (DRC). 2014"],"field_summary":{"value":"Offer programs to help individuals without a high school diploma or its equivalent achieve a high school equivalency credential","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EOffer programs to help individuals without a high school diploma or its equivalent achieve a high school equivalency credential\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}},"relationships":{"node_type":{"data":{"type":"node_type--node_type","id":"5e87f8ab-727f-4eee-a560-9385e4f74399","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":"wwfh_program"}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/node_type?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"revision_uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/revision_uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"uid":{"data":{"type":"user--user","id":"a8ef7b0f-6b04-4d8b-b3a9-07c04c5af436","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1}},"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/uid?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_curated_list":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--curated_list","id":"ce15b851-48a1-4c70-ab86-7cde0c7de259","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3621}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_curated_list?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_curated_ f64-2f55-4e77-8d18-24a34bc1f926","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3850}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--rankings_component","id":"2055a041-2143-4e6c-b33f-fc5a73707562","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3851}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_health_factors?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_page_content":{"data":[{"type":"paragraph--content_block","id":"0c918e2c-f24a-4450-9a23-cb4bdc77b7ef","meta":{"target_revision_id":11345,"drupal_internal__target_id":6337}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_page_content?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_program_search_tags":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"10f0f0e1-cd87-4b20-9eca-6e176e2506cb","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":35}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"87fd9065-4855-41ef-89f2-b42ac6da555f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":58}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"5aabbee9-ba90-425d-8f20-66650c8f06bf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3547}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"48c809b6-d931-4bcb-9f3e-490a51d6f7be","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3548}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--program_search_tags","id":"01c2a90f-f836-44ed-a16a-613ab4674834","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3559}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_program_search_tags?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_related_wwfh_programs":{"data":[{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a8be2a4f-8ec9-4630-92a3-5851d31be1f5","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1738}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"606e688d-3b96-4135-b4cc-5e0179861fbf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1730}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"ab1c537f-4b13-4d78-b4f4-68ddf455de87","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1724}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"22c0d50b-7dc6-4fba-af43-278f8681b454","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1723}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"b7ad0415-dfc6-4f66-8bb0-aee2c85fdcdd","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1705}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"aca9fc11-91fe-4ef6-b443-bef038a7eda7","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1676}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"2f922cdc-edea-4e75-9a26-8d5ab10334ad","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1566}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"eaa5ace9-767f-45c2-be83-3db7a03e4634","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1499}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"7aba029f-def5-4c05-8fc0-058977dcaffe","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1444}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"9419a38f-a726-40eb-b756-8a1db36258b0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1443}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"0fcd2d23-6284-49bd-9af5-b0a5db80d4fc","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1442}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"52d271a2-f29d-43a5-a20a-cb3753771a9c","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1390}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"d39a2192-46a1-47d2-82b0-a81d8246a598","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1387}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"a9c741d0-e48a-4676-bd94-58350ac134cf","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1386}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"5a67aee7-627c-49de-a617-532a0348cbd0","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":1359}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_related_wwfh_programs?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_societal_rules":{"data":[],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_societal_rules?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_wwfh_program_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"9dcd03fe-f263-4c05-a626-7a3a158bf1c6","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":4004}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--approaches","id":"7779a6bc-2841-472e-8eda-3d7cf8f11997","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3988}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_wwfh_program_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}},"field_wwfh_topics":{"data":[{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"405f084e-8f43-4cb8-8e13-59fd96af074f","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3952}},{"type":"taxonomy_term--wwfh_topics","id":"5d78b823-cc84-49e7-9cb7-2cf92db63428","meta":{"drupal_internal__target_id":3953}}],"links":{"related":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"},"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/909d6f06-6903-45e0-b690-9a04f36fed10\/relationships\/field_wwfh_topics?resourceVersion=id%3A1388"}}}}},{"type":"node--wwfh_program","id":"b48e79a1-9879-44fa-bbb7-e72a3842d4e7","links":{"self":{"href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program\/b48e79a1-9879-44fa-bbb7-e72a3842d4e7?resourceVersion=id%3A1389"}},"attributes":{"drupal_internal__nid":1389,"drupal_internal__vid":1389,"langcode":"en","revision_timestamp":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","status":true,"title":"College access programs","created":"2019-12-28T00:58:33+00:00","changed":"2025-05-15T19:19:14+00:00","promote":false,"sticky":false,"default_langcode":true,"revision_translation_affected":true,"metatag":[{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"title","content":"College access programs | County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"description","content":"Help high school students prepare for college, complete applications, and enroll, especially first-generation applicants and students from families with low incomes"}},{"tag":"link","attributes":{"rel":"canonical","href":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/college-access-programs"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:site_name","content":"County Health Rankings \u0026 Roadmaps"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:type","content":"website"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/jsonapi\/node\/wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:description","content":"Help high school students prepare for college, complete applications, and enroll, especially first-generation applicants and students from families with low incomes"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:secure_url","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"og:image:alt","content":"A map of the United States"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:card","content":"summary_large_image"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:site","content":"@CHRankings"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image","content":"https:\/\/klatovak.github.io\/pages-test\/\/sites\/default\/files\/media\/image\/og_logo_map.png"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"name":"twitter:image:alt","content":"CHR Map"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"chrr:content-type","content":"wwfh_program"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-settings","content":"Community,School"}},{"tag":"meta","attributes":{"property":"rf-categories","content":"Education"}}],"path":{"alias":"\/strategies-and-solutions\/what-works-for-health\/strategies\/college-access-programs","pid":1624,"langcode":"en"},"rh_action":null,"rh_redirect":null,"rh_redirect_response":null,"rh_redirect_fallback_action":null,"sae_exclude":false,"field_date":"2022-06-16","field_disclaimer":null,"field_equity_considerations":{"value":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhich schools in your community have the greatest need for college access programs? How can you support developing and improving college access programs in schools that need them?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community reduce financial barriers for students applying to and enrolling in college? Are there opportunities to increase funding for college access programs to increase resources and information sharing with students? To cover college application fees? To pay for college visits? To provide college scholarships?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat can your community do to reduce disparities in access to college application information and financial aid resources between students from low income backgrounds and high income backgrounds? Between students identifying as a minority and white students? For students with English language learner status? For students with disabilities? For students who are the first generation in their family to attend college?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhich schools in your community have the greatest need for college access programs? How can you support developing and improving college access programs in schools that need them?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHow can your community reduce financial barriers for students applying to and enrolling in college? Are there opportunities to increase funding for college access programs to increase resources and information sharing with students? To cover college application fees? To pay for college visits? To provide college scholarships?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWhat can your community do to reduce disparities in access to college application information and financial aid resources between students from low income backgrounds and high income backgrounds? Between students identifying as a minority and white students? For students with English language learner status? For students with disabilities? For students who are the first generation in their family to attend college?\u003C\/li\u003E\u003C\/ul\u003E"},"field_equity_description":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that college access programs for underrepresented students improve college readiness and increase college applications and enrollment ({Bowman 2018}, {Le 2016}, {Glennie 2015}). These programs can reduce gaps in college enrollment between students from low income backgrounds and those from high income backgrounds ({Bowman 2018}). College access programs can increase college enrollment for participating students irrespective of gender, socio-economic status, race or ethnicity, or special education status ({Bowman 2018}). One survey of students in 15 rural counties suggests participation in the program, College Readiness for Rural Youth, increases students\u2019 knowledge and understanding of the college admissions and financial aid application process ({Hedrick 2013}). Available research suggests more college access programs are needed that focus on assisting students with learning disabilities, especially those with diverse racial or ethnic backgrounds ({King 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege application and admissions information availability varies dramatically for students depending on their racial or ethnic status and family\u2019s income. College access programs can reduce disparities in college application and admissions information availability and in support and resources for the college application process ({Bowman 2018}, {Hurtado 2020}). College access programs can also help students with financial aid applications and increase financial aid receipt for students from disadvantaged backgrounds ({Glennie 2015}). College access programs that successfully increase scholarship and financial aid packages for students from disadvantaged backgrounds can reduce racial disparities in student debt burdens ({TCF-Mishory 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that college access programs for underrepresented students improve college readiness and increase college applications and enrollment ({Bowman 2018}, {Le 2016}, {Glennie 2015}). These programs can reduce gaps in college enrollment between students from low income backgrounds and those from high income backgrounds ({Bowman 2018}). College access programs can increase college enrollment for participating students irrespective of gender, socio-economic status, race or ethnicity, or special education status ({Bowman 2018}). One survey of students in 15 rural counties suggests participation in the program, College Readiness for Rural Youth, increases students\u2019 knowledge and understanding of the college admissions and financial aid application process ({Hedrick 2013}). Available research suggests more college access programs are needed that focus on assisting students with learning disabilities, especially those with diverse racial or ethnic backgrounds ({King 2009}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege application and admissions information availability varies dramatically for students depending on their racial or ethnic status and family\u2019s income. College access programs can reduce disparities in college application and admissions information availability and in support and resources for the college application process ({Bowman 2018}, {Hurtado 2020}). College access programs can also help students with financial aid applications and increase financial aid receipt for students from disadvantaged backgrounds ({Glennie 2015}). College access programs that successfully increase scholarship and financial aid packages for students from disadvantaged backgrounds can reduce racial disparities in student debt burdens ({TCF-Mishory 2019}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_historical_context":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EBefore the 1900s, higher education in the U.S. was provided by private colleges and was almost exclusively for white males typically from wealthier backgrounds, with some exceptions for female students studying to be teachers. In 1890, the federal government helped establish colleges in 17 southern states for Black students; however, this investment in education for Black students was also a government endorsement of racial segregation and did not provide equal support, access to, or resources for college to all groups. The Servicemen\u2019s Readjustment Act of 1944, known as the G.I. Bill, increased access to college for veterans, however, this support was also primarily offered to white veterans. In the 1960s and 1970s, efforts were developed to increase access to college, especially to high quality college and educational opportunities, for students identifying as minorities, from low income backgrounds, and for females. College access programs were designed and intended to address the long history of structural barriers that prevented underrepresented students from enrolling in higher education ({Thelin 2022}, {US ED-Harvill 2012}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}). The first college access programs at the federal level were the TRIO programs that were established through the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, as part of President Lyndon Johnson\u2019s War on Poverty ({US ED-TRIO history}). Available evidence suggests that substantial racial disparities in college attendance persist. The proportion of Black and Hispanic students going to college fell after the 1970s and it took until the 1990s to return to similar enrollment levels. At the same time, college attendance rates increased substantially for white students. Experts suggest more college access programs are needed to help reduce these disparities ({NCES-Gandara 2001}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EBefore the 1900s, higher education in the U.S. was provided by private colleges and was almost exclusively for white males typically from wealthier backgrounds, with some exceptions for female students studying to be teachers. In 1890, the federal government helped establish colleges in 17 southern states for Black students; however, this investment in education for Black students was also a government endorsement of racial segregation and did not provide equal support, access to, or resources for college to all groups. The Servicemen\u2019s Readjustment Act of 1944, known as the G.I. Bill, increased access to college for veterans, however, this support was also primarily offered to white veterans. In the 1960s and 1970s, efforts were developed to increase access to college, especially to high quality college and educational opportunities, for students identifying as minorities, from low income backgrounds, and for females. College access programs were designed and intended to address the long history of structural barriers that prevented underrepresented students from enrolling in higher education ({Thelin 2022}, {US ED-Harvill 2012}, {NCES-Gandara 2001}). The first college access programs at the federal level were the TRIO programs that were established through the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, as part of President Lyndon Johnson\u2019s War on Poverty ({US ED-TRIO history}). Available evidence suggests that substantial racial disparities in college attendance persist. The proportion of Black and Hispanic students going to college fell after the 1970s and it took until the 1990s to return to similar enrollment levels. At the same time, college attendance rates increased substantially for white students. Experts suggest more college access programs are needed to help reduce these disparities ({NCES-Gandara 2001}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_equity_rating":0,"field_equity_rationale":0,"field_meta_tags":null,"field_program_effectiveness":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that college access programs increase college enrollment ({US ED-Harvill 2012}, {Bowman 2018}, {Le 2016}, {Glennie 2015}). Research suggests that effective programs begin in ninth grade with college awareness and college readiness components ({Le 2016}), and guide eleventh and twelfth grade students through the college application and financial aid processes ({IES WWC-Tierney 2009}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm characteristics of the most effective programs.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EProviding college application guidance, financial information, and application fee waivers can increase college applications and enrollments at selective universities ({IES WWC-College opportunities 2014}). Several program components can increase college enrollment, including financial aid counseling, college visits, academic one-on-one tutoring, standardized test preparation, and planning tools for high school completion and college applications ({Kim 2021a}). College access programs can increase college enrollment for participating students irrespective of gender, socio-economic status, race or ethnicity, or special education status ({Bowman 2018}). College access programs that include opportunities to shadow college students during a campus visit can increase persistence in higher education ({Kim 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest in addition to tuition coverage, funding is needed to reduce the cost of books, rent, and other living expenses to increase college completion rates. Comprehensive efforts that address financial, informational, behavioral, and academic barriers and continue to support students through the transition to college and with financing and workloads in college may be needed to increase college persistence and completion rates ({NBER-Page 2015}, {Glennie 2015}). One example of a comprehensive college access program that partners with colleges and provides students with academic support and college life skills, the Early College High School program, has been shown to increase college enrollment and college completion ({Blueprints}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe availability of college application and admissions information varies dramatically for students from different income backgrounds and by racial or ethnic status. White students from families with high incomes have the most information and resources to support college applications. Many students of color from low income backgrounds, especially first-generation college students, depend on high schools to provide information and support; however, schools often have limited resources to fill that information and financial gap. College access programs can reduce these disparities in information and support for the college application process and college enrollment ({Bowman 2018}, {Hurtado 2020}), and can increase financial aid receipt for students from disadvantaged backgrounds ({Glennie 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege access programs that help students apply for and receive scholarships and financial aid can reduce student debt burdens. Students and families of color disproportionately rely on large loans to attend college because these families have been systematically denied opportunities to build the wealth that could pay for higher education. Experts suggest structural change and public investment in higher education is needed to manage student debt levels, increase access to higher education, address unequal outcomes for degree completion, job opportunities, and wages, and reduce the racial wealth divide. Efforts to prevent, reduce, and forgive student loan debts can contribute to reducing the racial wealth divide ({TCF-Mishory 2019}, {Brookings-Perry 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest college access programs disseminate college and financial information beginning in ninth grade, offer individual assistance, and advise teachers of upcoming milestones. Successful programs often partner with local colleges and high school alumni attending them, arrange or assist with campus visits, and offer separate financial workshops for parents and students ({Kim 2021a}, {IES WWC-Tierney 2009}). Research also suggests a need for more college access programs that assist students with learning disabilities, especially those with diverse racial or ethnic backgrounds ({King 2009}). Experts suggest more college access programs serving Latino\/a students are needed, especially in rural and underserved areas; programs should provide quality academic support, simplify the financial aid process, reduce the cost of applications, and develop support networks that promote a culture of high achievement with college attendance expectations ({Hurtado 2020}). Overall, the effectiveness of college access programs can vary based on the quality and quantity of support available ({Kim 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThere is strong evidence that college access programs increase college enrollment ({US ED-Harvill 2012}, {Bowman 2018}, {Le 2016}, {Glennie 2015}). Research suggests that effective programs begin in ninth grade with college awareness and college readiness components ({Le 2016}), and guide eleventh and twelfth grade students through the college application and financial aid processes ({IES WWC-Tierney 2009}). However, additional evidence is needed to confirm characteristics of the most effective programs.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EProviding college application guidance, financial information, and application fee waivers can increase college applications and enrollments at selective universities ({IES WWC-College opportunities 2014}). Several program components can increase college enrollment, including financial aid counseling, college visits, academic one-on-one tutoring, standardized test preparation, and planning tools for high school completion and college applications ({Kim 2021a}). College access programs can increase college enrollment for participating students irrespective of gender, socio-economic status, race or ethnicity, or special education status ({Bowman 2018}). College access programs that include opportunities to shadow college students during a campus visit can increase persistence in higher education ({Kim 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest in addition to tuition coverage, funding is needed to reduce the cost of books, rent, and other living expenses to increase college completion rates. Comprehensive efforts that address financial, informational, behavioral, and academic barriers and continue to support students through the transition to college and with financing and workloads in college may be needed to increase college persistence and completion rates ({NBER-Page 2015}, {Glennie 2015}). One example of a comprehensive college access program that partners with colleges and provides students with academic support and college life skills, the Early College High School program, has been shown to increase college enrollment and college completion ({Blueprints}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe availability of college application and admissions information varies dramatically for students from different income backgrounds and by racial or ethnic status. White students from families with high incomes have the most information and resources to support college applications. Many students of color from low income backgrounds, especially first-generation college students, depend on high schools to provide information and support; however, schools often have limited resources to fill that information and financial gap. College access programs can reduce these disparities in information and support for the college application process and college enrollment ({Bowman 2018}, {Hurtado 2020}), and can increase financial aid receipt for students from disadvantaged backgrounds ({Glennie 2015}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECollege access programs that help students apply for and receive scholarships and financial aid can reduce student debt burdens. Students and families of color disproportionately rely on large loans to attend college because these families have been systematically denied opportunities to build the wealth that could pay for higher education. Experts suggest structural change and public investment in higher education is needed to manage student debt levels, increase access to higher education, address unequal outcomes for degree completion, job opportunities, and wages, and reduce the racial wealth divide. Efforts to prevent, reduce, and forgive student loan debts can contribute to reducing the racial wealth divide ({TCF-Mishory 2019}, {Brookings-Perry 2021}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EExperts suggest college access programs disseminate college and financial information beginning in ninth grade, offer individual assistance, and advise teachers of upcoming milestones. Successful programs often partner with local colleges and high school alumni attending them, arrange or assist with campus visits, and offer separate financial workshops for parents and students ({Kim 2021a}, {IES WWC-Tierney 2009}). Research also suggests a need for more college access programs that assist students with learning disabilities, especially those with diverse racial or ethnic backgrounds ({King 2009}). Experts suggest more college access programs serving Latino\/a students are needed, especially in rural and underserved areas; programs should provide quality academic support, simplify the financial aid process, reduce the cost of applications, and develop support networks that promote a culture of high achievement with college attendance expectations ({Hurtado 2020}). Overall, the effectiveness of college access programs can vary based on the quality and quantity of support available ({Kim 2021a}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_examples":{"value":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal TRIO Programs assist students from disadvantaged backgrounds beginning in middle school to postsecondary education. There are 8 federally supported TRIO programs, including Talent Search, that improve college access and provide student services and outreach for individuals from low income backgrounds, with disabilities, or first-generation college students ({US ED-TRIO}). Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) is another federal program to increase college readiness, attendance, and success among students from families with low incomes. GEAR UP provides 6- or 7-year grants to states and partner organizations to provide college access services at middle and high schools in neighborhoods with high poverty rates ({US ED-GEAR UP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeveral states fund college access programs, as in California ({CAL-SOAP}) and Florida ({FCAN}). Universities can also operate college access programs; for example, the University of California\u2019s Early Academic Outreach Program ({UC Berkeley-EAOP}) and the University of Colorado\u2019s Pre-Collegiate Development Program ({CU Boulder-PCDP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMany non-profits also administer college access programs; for example, Advancement Via Individual Determination ({AVID}), the \u0026ldquo;I Have a Dream\u0026rdquo; program ({I Have A Dream}), Engaging Latino Communities for Education ({ENLACE}), College Possible ({College Possible}), Bottom Line ({Bottom Line}), and Sponsor-a-Scholar ({Sponsor-a-Scholar}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Collegiate Leaders in Increasing MoBility (CLIMB) initiative is a non-profit partnership between researchers and colleges across the country working to increase access to postsecondary education, promote economic opportunity, and support income upward mobility for students from low income backgrounds. CLIMB has several policy initiatives that include efforts to increase college access generally and specifically to increase the number of students from low income backgrounds that attend selective colleges and universities ({Opportunity Insights-CLIMB}).\u003C\/p\u003E","format":"full_html","processed":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Federal TRIO Programs assist students from disadvantaged backgrounds beginning in middle school to postsecondary education. There are 8 federally supported TRIO programs, including Talent Search, that improve college access and provide student services and outreach for individuals from low income backgrounds, with disabilities, or first-generation college students ({US ED-TRIO}). Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) is another federal program to increase college readiness, attendance, and success among students from families with low incomes. GEAR UP provides 6- or 7-year grants to states and partner organizations to provide college access services at middle and high schools in neighborhoods with high poverty rates ({US ED-GEAR UP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESeveral states fund college access programs, as in California ({CAL-SOAP}) and Florida ({FCAN}). Universities can also operate college access programs; for example, the University of California\u2019s Early Academic Outreach Program ({UC Berkeley-EAOP}) and the University of Colorado\u2019s Pre-Collegiate Development Program ({CU Boulder-PCDP}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EMany non-profits also administer college access programs; for example, Advancement Via Individual Determination ({AVID}), the \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d program ({I Have A Dream}), Engaging Latino Communities for Education ({ENLACE}), College Possible ({College Possible}), Bottom Line ({Bottom Line}), and Sponsor-a-Scholar ({Sponsor-a-Scholar}).\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe Collegiate Leaders in Increasing MoBility (CLIMB) initiative is a non-profit partnership between researchers and colleges across the country working to increase access to postsecondary education, promote economic opportunity, and support income upward mobility for students from low income backgrounds. CLIMB has several policy initiatives that include efforts to increase college access generally and specifically to increase the number of students from low income backgrounds that attend selective colleges and universities ({Opportunity Insights-CLIMB}).\u003C\/p\u003E"},"field_program_id":119,"field_program_impact":1,"field_program_outcomes_other":[{"value":"Increased college completion","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased college completion\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_outcomes_rated":[{"value":"Increased college enrollment","format":null,"processed":"\u003Cp\u003EIncreased college enrollment\u003C\/p\u003E\n"}],"field_program_res_citations":["IES WWC-Tierney 2009","US ED-TRIO","NACAC-Directory","Sponsor-a-Scholar","College Possible","SIR-College access 2010","Bottom Line","US ED-Financial aid","AVID","MCAN-College access guide"],"field_program_rf_categories":"Education","field_program_rf_settings":"Community,School","field_program_sources":"{\u0022IES WWC-Tierney 2009\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00221605\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022IES WWC-Tierney 2009\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Tierney WG, Bailey T, Constantine J, Finkelstein N, Hurd NF. Educational Evaluation and Policy Analysis. 2018;40(3):399-419.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/journals.sagepub.com\\\/doi\\\/abs\\\/10.3102\\\/0162373718778133\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00221\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-24\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Le 2016\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u00226193\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Le 2016\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Le VN, Mariano LT, Faxon-Mills S. Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022http:\\\/\\\/www2.ed.gov\\\/programs\\\/gearup\\\/index.html\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-24\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022CAL-SOAP\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210842\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CAL-SOAP\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022California Student Aid Commission. Early Academic Outreach Program (EAOP).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/eaop.berkeley.edu\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-07-05\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022CU Boulder-PCDP\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210846\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022CU Boulder-PCDP\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022University of Colorado-Boulder. Precollegiate Development Program (PCDP).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.colorado.edu\\\/precollege\\\/precollegiate-development-program\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-24\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022I Have A Dream\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210847\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022I Have A Dream\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022I Have A Dream Foundation. Educate, empower, achieve: We provide individualized social, emotional, and academic support to young people (\u0027Dreamers\u0027) from under-resourced communities from kindergarten all the way through college, along with guaranteed tuition support.\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.ihaveadreamfoundation.org\\\/\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-24\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022ENLACE\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210848\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022ENLACE\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Excelencia in Education. ENgaging LAtino Communities for Education (ENLACE).\u0022,\u0022webLink\u0022:\u0022https:\\\/\\\/www.edexcelencia.org\\\/programs-initiatives\\\/growing-what-works-database\\\/engaging-latino-communities-education-enlace\u0022,\u0022loginRequired\u0022:\u00220\u0022,\u0022lastAccessed\u0022:\u00222022-05-24\u0022,\u0022equityLens\u0022:\u00220\u0022},\u0022Opportunity Insights-CLIMB\u0022:{\u0022sourceId\u0022:\u002210837\u0022,\u0022shortName\u0022:\u0022Opportunity Insights-CLIMB\u0022,\u0022fullCitation\u0022:\u0022Opportunity Insights. College Readiness for Rural Youth Initiative: Creating a climate for success.
